Title: Mice in Bion-M 1 space mission: training and selection
Keywords: Bion-M 1, biosatellite, space biomedical research, microgravity, mice, C57BL/6N, physiological adaptation, in vivo studies, in vitro studies, training program, ground control, post-flight, nervous system, cardiovascular system, muscle, bone, telemetry, specific pathogens, molecular analysis, cellular analysis, behavior
Resumen: Russia resumed its biomedical space research program in 2013 with the successful 30-day mission of the Bion-M 1 biosatellite, following a 16-year hiatus. The objective was to investigate the cellular and molecular mechanisms of physiological systems' adaptation to prolonged microgravity and their post-flight readaptation using male C57BL/6N mice. The project combined in vivo measurements (behavior, blood pressure) during and after flight with extensive in vitro studies of various tissues. A rigorous mouse training and selection program was implemented, including adaptation to group housing and specific diets. The mice returned in good condition and showed signs of maladaptation to Earth's gravity, demonstrating the effectiveness of the training program and the feasibility of using male mice in future space-based biomedical research.

Title: Microgravity induces pelvic bone loss through osteoclastic activity, osteocytic osteolysis, and osteoblastic cell cycle inhibition by CDKN1a/p21
Keywords: Microgravity, bone loss, spaceflight, osteocytes, osteoclasts, osteoblasts, osteocytic osteolysis, bone remodeling, cell cycle arrest, CDKN1a/p21, MMPs, p53, mice, pelvis, ischium, µCT, nanoCT, lacuna enlargement, bone volume fraction, bone thickness, mechanical unloading, osteogenesis
Resumen: This study in mice exposed to microgravity for 15 days reveals rapid and significant bone loss in the pelvis, including a 6.29% reduction in bone volume fraction and 11.91% reduction in thickness, in addition to a 170% increase in the bone surface area covered by osteoclasts. Beyond the known osteoclastic activity, the findings demonstrate microgravity-induced osteocytic osteolysis, evidenced by an increase in the area (+17%) and perimeter (+14%) of bone lacunae and the overexpression of MMP10 in osteocytes. In parallel, elevated CDKN1a/p21 expression in osteoblasts suggests cell cycle arrest during osteogenesis, which compromises bone regenerative capacity. These newly identified pathways (osteocytic osteolysis and osteogenic cell cycle arrest) dramatically expand our understanding of bone degeneration in space, indicating that the problem is more complex than osteoclastic resorption alone and is crucial for the development of effective countermeasures for long-duration space missions.

Title: Stem Cell Health and Tissue Regeneration in Microgravity
Keywords: Microgravity, human health, immune system, cancer biology, cardiomyocytes, tissue regeneration, stem cells, space medicine, astronaut health, biological processes, apoptosis, multicellular spheroids, cellular metabolism, organ homeostasis
Resumen: Microgravity profoundly impacts biological systems, bearing dual significance for space missions and terrestrial health. It profoundly compromises the immune system by disrupting T cell activation and macrophage function, leading to increased astronaut susceptibility to infections and underscoring the need for protective measures in prolonged spaceflight. Concurrently, microgravity surprisingly enhances tissue regeneration, particularly improving stem cell differentiation into cardiac cells with advanced maturation and functional improvements, which offers promising therapeutic avenues for heart conditions like myocardial infarctions. In oncology, microgravity promotes multicellular spheroid formation in cancer cells, creating valuable models for research, and uniquely alters cancer stem cell properties, potentially increasing their susceptibility to treatment. These discoveries highlight microgravity's potential to advance regenerative medicine, oncology, and immunological interventions, crucial for both astronaut well-being and transformative biomedical applications on Earth.

Title: Microgravity Reduces the Differentiation and Regenerative Potential of Embryonic Stem Cells
Keywords: adipose-derived stem cell, microgravity culture, polystyrene microsphere, collagen microsphere, multilineage-differentiating stress-enduring cell, stemness, cell proliferation, cell differentiation, SSEA-3
Resumen: novel dynamic microgravity culture method using microspheres significantly expands highly functional adipose-derived mesenchymal stem cells (hASCs) by quadrupling the proportion of SSEA-3(+) cells, which exhibit marked pluripotency, increased expression of stemness markers, and enhanced multilineage proliferation and differentiation capabilities. This represents a critical advancement for space missions by enabling the generation of more robust and effective regenerative cell therapies, facilitating autonomous repair of radiation injury or damage in challenging environments, and overcoming current limitations in stem cell viability and potency for long-duration mission medical support.

Title: Microgravity validation of a novel system for RNA isolation and multiplex quantitative real time PCR analysis of gene expression on the International Space Station
Keywords: WetLab-2, microgravity, ISS, molecular biology, gene expression analysis, on-orbit, RT-qPCR, RNA purification, biological samples, Escherichia coli, mouse liver tissue, thermal cycler, lyophilized reagents, Sample Preparation Module, real-time analysis, end-to-end experimentation, gas bubbles, Ct values, PCR efficiencies, disease diagnostics, environmental monitoring
Resumen: WetLab-2 successfully validated a novel, end-to-end molecular biology system on the ISS, demonstrating real-time RNA isolation and quantitative gene expression analysis (RT-qPCR) from *E. coli* and mouse tissue with results comparable to Earth controls and rapid data transmission. A key finding included the successful on-orbit mitigation of gas bubble formation during thermal cycling, highlighting system adaptability. This breakthrough establishes critical autonomous molecular biology capabilities for future deep space missions, enabling immediate disease diagnostics, environmental monitoring, and research applications such as optimizing plant growth or assessing astronaut health, thereby eliminating the delays and sample degradation associated with Earth-return analysis and significantly advancing scientific discovery and operational independence in space.

Title: Spaceflight Modulates the Expression of Key Oxidative Stress and Cell Cycle Related Genes in Heart
Keywords: spaceflight, microgravity, heart, gene expression, oxidative stress, Nfe2l2, NADPH oxidase, Ptgs2, Cdkn1a, Myc, cardiovascular changes, cardiac deconditioning, Trp53, cell cycle, apoptosis, redox balance, cardiac dysfunction, inflammatory response, mice
Resumen: Spaceflight induces substantial changes in cardiac gene expression, revealing molecular pathways contributing to cardiovascular deconditioning. Key findings include a persistent increase in oxidative stress, evidenced by downregulated Nfe2l2 (a critical oxidative defense regulator) and upregulated Nox1, alongside altered cell cycle regulation with increased Cdkn1a and Myc, and reduced inflammatory responses. Computational analysis further linked these specific molecular alterations to potential cardiovascular pathologies like hypertension, atherosclerosis, and myocardial infarction. These results underscore that long-duration space missions pose a significant risk of cardiac dysfunction driven by these molecular-level stress responses, necessitating targeted countermeasures and advanced monitoring strategies to ensure astronaut cardiovascular health and mission success.

Title: Dose- and Ion-Dependent Effects in the Oxidative Stress Response to Space-Like Radiation Exposure in the Skeletal System
Keywords: Ionizing radiation, space radiation, 56Fe ions, protons, osteoblastogenesis, bone loss, skeletal health, oxidative stress, redox-related genes, cancellous bone, osteoblasts, mice, astronauts, spaceflight, galactic cosmic-rays, reactive oxygen species, superoxide dismutase, gene expression, mineralized nodules, dose
Resumen: High doses (200 cGy) of space radiation, especially high-LET heavy ions such as 56Fe, cause persistent cancellous bone loss and inhibit osteoblastogenesis by more than 90% in mouse models, effects that persist up to one year after exposure and are more severe than those produced by low-LET protons. Doses below 50 cGy showed no detectable effects on bone structure, but the limited ability of exogenous antioxidants to mitigate heavy ion damage suggests that specific countermeasures and risk models that consider radiation quality are needed to protect the skeletal health of astronauts on long-duration missions.

Title: From the bench to exploration medicine: NASA life sciences translational research for human exploration and habitation missions.
Keywords: Translational research, NASA, Human spaceflight, Astronaut health, Countermeasures, Space Biology, Human Research Program, International Space Station, Exploration Class missions, Spaceflight risks, Basic research, Applied research, Medical operations, Decadal Survey, NIH, Microgravity, Space radiation
Resumen: NASA is actively implementing a coordinated translational research framework, linking fundamental discoveries in space biology with the applied development of countermeasures and their operational deployment, which represents a key element of the agency's strategy. This two-way approach is crucial to addressing the significant health challenges of long-duration human missions beyond low-Earth orbit, including the effects of microgravity, radiation, and visual impairment. Practical implications include an acceleration in the development and application of solutions that improve crew safety and resilience, optimize planning for future exploration missions, leverage the International Space Station as a research platform, and foster synergies between NASA's scientific and operational programs, supported by the creation of a Translational Research Institute.

Title: High-precision method for cyclic loading of small-animal vertebrae to assess bone quality.
Keywords: Fatigue, Bone mechanics, Mouse, Vertebrae, Bone quality, Cyclic loading, Biomechanical testing, Precision, Finite element analysis, Micro-CT, Stiffness, Strain, Fatigue life, Specimen preparation, Loading plates, Machine compliance, Ex vivo, Small animals, Osteoporosis, Fracture risk, Statistical power
Resumen: This paper describes the development of a new and accurate method for ex vivo cyclic compressive loading of isolated mouse vertebral bodies, aiming to improve bone quality assessment in small animals. Existing methods are challenged by small bone size and machine compliance, which introduces variability in results. The new technique features the use of 3D-printed support templates to machine plane-parallel surfaces, pivoting loading platens to ensure uniform contact, and specimen-specific micro-CT-based finite element analysis, allowing stiffness measurements and prescribing force levels that produce the same level of deformation. When comparing the new method with two common techniques in the literature on mouse L5 vertebrae, a significant reduction in dispersion in mechanical behavior was demonstrated, with a fatigue life standard deviation up to five times lower. This increased precision facilitates a better understanding of bone quality and optimizes statistical power in animal experiments.

Title: Effects of ex vivo ionizing radiation on collagen structure and whole-bone mechanical properties of mouse vertebrae.
Keywords: ionizing radiation, bone, collagen, bone strength, fatigue, collagen fragmentation, non-enzymatic collagen crosslinking, radiation doses, sterilization, radiotherapy, bone allografts, ex vivo, mouse vertebrae, fracture, AGEs, micro-CT, electrophoresis
Resumen: An ex vivo study in mouse vertebrae examined the mechanism behind ionizing radiation-induced bone weakening, focusing on whether it is caused by collagen fragmentation or non-enzymatic cross-linking. Bone samples were exposed to various doses of X-rays (from 0 to 35,000 Gy), and the compressive mechanical properties and biochemical changes of collagen were measured. The findings indicated that the reduction in bone strength and fatigue life was only significant at high doses (17,000 and 35,000 Gy), which coincided with the onset of collagen fragmentation. Although nonenzymatic collagen crosslinking increased at all radiation doses, changes in mechanical properties were most consistently correlated with collagen fragmentation. It is concluded that the deterioration in bone strength and fatigue life due to ionizing radiation is more likely a consequence of collagen backbone fragmentation than of increased nonenzymatic crosslinking.

Title: Absence of gamma-sarcoglycan alters the response of p70S6 kinase to mechanical perturbation in murine skeletal muscle
Keywords: Sarcoglycan, Sarcoglycanopathies, Limb girdle muscular dystrophy, Mechanotransduction, Mechano-sensing, Load-sensing, p70S6K, S6K, p70S6 kinase, ERK1/2, Dystrophin Glycoprotein Complex, Calcium, mTOR, S6RP, gamma-sarcoglycan
Resumen: This study investigated the contribution of the sarcoglycan complex, specifically ?-sarcoglycan, to mechanotransduction and its role in muscular dystrophies. Signaling pathways activated by passive stretch were examined in myotubes and muscles isolated from C57 and ?-sarcoglycan-depleted mice. The results showed that basal p70S6K activation was elevated in ?-sarcoglycan-depleted muscles, independent of calcium. Although stretch increased p70S6K activation in both muscle types, the response was sustained in Î³-sarcoglycan-deficient muscles, unlike the transient response observed in wild-type muscles. Furthermore, the loss of Î³-sarcoglycan impaired rapamycin's ability to completely reduce downstream S6RP phosphorylation. These findings suggest that p70S6K is key in Î³-sarcoglycan-dependent mechanotransduction and that Î³-sarcoglycan is essential for the inactivation of this pathway, implying that impaired cargo-sensing mechanisms contribute to the pathology of sarcoglycan-deficient muscular dystrophies.

Title: AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c have overlapping functions in pollen development and pollen tube growth.
Keywords: Rab GTPases, AtRabD2b, AtRabD2c, Arabidopsis thaliana, pollen, pollen development, pollen tube growth, endomembrane trafficking, vesicle transport, functional redundancy, shorter siliques, deformed pollen, seed fertilization, Golgi, mutants
Resumen: This paper investigates the Rab GTPases AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c in *Arabidopsis thaliana*, which are important regulators of endomembrane trafficking. Single mutants of AtrabD2b and AtrabD2c were found to exhibit no notable morphological changes, but the AtrabD2b/2c double mutant exhibits shorter siliques and produces deformed pollen with swollen and branched pollen tube tips, resulting in unfertilized ovules and lower seed set. Both genes have overlapping expression patterns and are localized to Golgi bodies, suggesting a partially redundant role in vesicle trafficking during pollen development, germination, and pollen tube elongation that cannot be supplied by other members of the AtRabD family.

Title: TNO1 is involved in salt tolerance and vacuolar trafficking in Arabidopsis.
Keywords: TNO1, Arabidopsis, trans-Golgi network, vacuolar trafficking, vesicle fusion, salt tolerance, osmotic stress, SYP41, SYP61, AtVPS45, SNAREs, Brefeldin A, coimmunoprecipitation, mass spectrometry
Resumen: A novel protein, TNO1 (SYP41-interacting protein localized to the TGN), was identified in *Arabidopsis thaliana* that localizes to the trans-Golgi network (TGN) and is crucial for efficient vacuolar trafficking and salt stress tolerance. TNO1 mutants display increased sensitivity to salt and osmotic stress, as well as altered SYP41 localization and decreased membrane fusion efficiency. These findings suggest that TNO1 is involved in vesicle fusion and in maintaining TGN structure or identity, possibly in conjunction with the SNARE complex SYP41.

Title: Functional redundancy between trans-Golgi network SNARE family members in Arabidopsis thaliana.
Keywords: AtGTLP, Arabidopsis thaliana, glycosyltransferases, fucosyltransferases, O-fucosyltransferase, membrane trafficking, SNARE proteins, SYP43, Golgi apparatus, trans-Golgi network, glycosylation, subcellular localization, mutant phenotype, colocalization
Resumen: The present study investigates AtGTLP (Arabidopsis thaliana Glycosyltransferase-Like Protein), a novel membrane-anchored protein that interacts with the Qa-SNARE SYP43 in the trans-Golgi network. Named for its sequence similarity to metazoan fucosyltransferases, AtGTLP is predicted to be a novel member of an as yet uncharacterized family of Arabidopsis fucosyltransferases. Colocalization data indicate that AtGTLP localizes mainly to the Golgi apparatus, especially the trans-Golgi network. *atgtlp?/? single mutants showed no obvious phenotypic differences, suggesting that AtGTLP and related proteins with high sequence similarity may have redundant functions.

Title: Root growth movements: Waving and skewing.
Keywords: TNO1, Root skewing, Trans-Golgi network, Microtubules, Cell file rotation, Arabidopsis thaliana, Tethering factor
Resumen: This study reveals that the trans-Golgi network protein TNO1 modulates root movement in *Arabidopsis thaliana*. *tno1* knockout mutants exhibit increased root skewing and epidermal cell row rotation. Microtubule stabilization increases skewing in these mutant roots, while its destabilization causes severe defects in cell morphology, although microtubule orientation is not affected. It is concluded that TNO1 regulates skewing in a microtubule-dependent manner, but without altering microtubule orientation, and is essential for maintaining cell morphology in mature root regions.

Title: Gravitropism and lateral root emergence are dependent on the trans-Golgi network protein TNO1
Keywords: auxin, trans-Golgi network, lateral root, gravitropism, tethering factor, TNO1, protein trafficking, auxin transport, root development
Resumen: TNO1 is a protein located in the trans-Golgi network (TGN) that interacts with SYP41 and is essential for efficient protein trafficking to the vacuole. This study demonstrates that the *tno1* mutant exhibits defects related to auxin transport, including delayed lateral root emergence, reduced gravitropic curvature in plant organs, and increased auxin sensitivity. A reduction in auxin asymmetry was observed in lateral root tips and delayed auxin transport during gravistimulation, whereas endocytosis to the TGN was unaffected. These results suggest that TNO1 mediates responses to auxin during root development and gravity stimulation, possibly through trafficking of auxin-binding proteins.

Title: TNO1, a TGN-localized SNARE-interacting protein, modulates root skewing in Arabidopsis thaliana.
Keywords: TNO1, Root skewing, Trans-Golgi network, Cell file rotation, Microtubules, Tethering factor, Arabidopsis thaliana
Resumen: This study investigates the role of the trans-Golgi network protein TNO1 in root movement of *Arabidopsis thaliana*, specifically in the phenomena of skewing and waving. *tno1* null mutants were found to exhibit increased root skewing and epidermal cell rotation compared to wild-type plants. The results suggest that TNO1 modulates root skewing in a microtubule-dependent manner, but not in a microtubule-dependent manner. Furthermore, TNO1 is essential for maintaining cell morphology in mature regions of roots and hypocotyls, implying that the SNARE machinery of the trans-Golgi network is important for proper epidermal cell turnover and cell expansion during root growth.

Title: The Drosophila SUN protein Spag4 cooperates with the coiled-coil protein Yuri Gagarin to maintain association of the basal body and spermatid nucleus.
Keywords: Spag4, Spermatogenesis, Centriole attachment, SUN protein, KASH protein, LINC complex, Yuri Gagarin, Dynein-dynactin, Drosophila, Nuclear envelope, Centriole, Sperm basal body, Centrosome, Coiled-coil proteins
Resumen: This study characterizes the *Drosophila* Spag4 protein, a putative SUN ortholog, and its crucial role in spermatogenesis. It demonstrates that Spag4 is essential for centriole-nucleus tethering, dynamically localizing to testis germline nuclei and concentrating at the centriole anchoring site. Unlike typical LINC complexes, Spag4 function does not require KASH proteins, but rather the coiled-coil protein Yuri Gagarin, which localizes identically and whose activities, together with those of dynein-dynactin, act downstream of Spag4. The absence of Spag4 causes dissociation of nuclei and centrioles/basal bodies after meiosis, resulting in male infertility.

Title: Toll mediated infection response is altered by gravity and spaceflight in Drosophila
Keywords: Spaceflight, Immune response, Drosophila, Hypergravity, Microgravity, Toll pathway, Imd pathway, Fungal infections, Bacterial infections, Transcription profiling, Antimicrobial proteins, Immune dysfunction, Countermeasures, Heat shock system, yuri gagarin
Resumen: This study investigates the effects of prolonged space travel on immune function using the Drosophila model of innate immunity. Researchers analyzed immune responses under hypergravity and microgravity conditions (spaceflight), focusing on the Toll (for fungal infections) and IMD (for bacterial infections) signaling pathways. They found that hypergravity enhances resistance to Toll-mediated fungal infections, a host-dependent effect, as a gravitactic mutant did not show this enhancement. In contrast, development in microgravity during spaceflight altered gene transcription, activating the heat shock stress system. Specifically, flies exposed to space failed to activate the Toll pathway after being infected with fungi, although the Imd pathway responded normally to bacterial infections. The key findings are that hypergravity and spaceflight have opposing effects, with spaceflight producing stress-related transcriptional responses and a specific inability to mount a Toll-mediated immune response.

Title: Multi-omics analysis of multiple missions to space reveal a theme of lipid dysregulation in mouse liver
Keywords: multi omics, multiple, missions, space, reveal, theme
Resumen: Abstract generated: This article focuses on multi-omics analysis of multiple missions to space reveal a theme of lipid dysregulation in mouse liver. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6985101/)

Title: GeneLab database analyzes suggest long-term impact of space radiation on the cardiovascular system by the activation of FYN through reactive oxygen species.
Keywords: genelab, database, analyses, suggest, long term, impact
Resumen: Abstract generated: This article focuses on genelab database analyzes suggest long-term impact of space radiation on the cardiovascular system by the activation of fyn through reactive oxygen species.. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6387434/)

Title: FAIRness and usability for open-access omics data systems.
Keywords: fairness, and, usability, for, open access, omics
Resumen: The study evaluated the "FAIRness" (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable) of NASA's GeneLab Data Systems (GLDS) and four similar omics data systems using 14 metrics. The systems achieved an average score of 10.1 out of 14, excelling in searchability and accessibility, but showing significant weaknesses in data interoperability and metadata reusability. The text also proposes two new principles for maximizing data accessibility in Big Data systems.

Title: NASA GeneLab platform used for biological response to space radiation in animal models
Keywords: nasa, genelab, platform, used, for, biological
Resumen: This article describes a study using NASA's GeneLab omics database to investigate astronaut health risks due to ionizing radiation from galactic cosmic rays (GCR). Researchers analyzed transcriptomic datasets from animal models exposed to radiation, both in ground-based and spaceflight studies, with different ion types and doses. The results identified distinct biosignatures and specific cellular responses, such as changes in mitochondrial function, ribosomal assembly, and immune pathways, that correlate with radiation exposure and dose. The study concludes that GeneLab's rich database can be used to generate new hypotheses and improve understanding of the human health risks associated with GCR exposures in space.

Title: Circulating miRNA spaceflight signature reveals targets for countermeasure development
Keywords: circulating, mirna, spaceflight, signature, reveals, targets
Resumen: This study identifies and experimentally validates a spaceflight-associated microRNA (miRNA) signature common in rodents and humans in response to simulated and realistic space exposure. This signature includes miRNAs that regulate vascular damage induced by simulated space radiation, and inhibition of certain key miRNAs was successful in mitigating this damage. The research suggests that these miRNAs could be both biomarkers for health risks in space and targets for the development of countermeasures, by influencing cellular processes and being linked to diseases such as cancer, cardiovascular and neurological disorders, and muscle degeneration.

Title: Machine learning algorithm to characterize antimicrobial resistance associated with the International Space Station surface microbiome
Keywords: machine learning algorithm characterize antimicrobial resistance
Resumen: This study investigates antimicrobial resistance (AMR) in the International Space Station (ISS) microbiome, a crucial factor for astronaut health during extended spaceflight. Using metagenomic data from the Microbial Tracking-1 project and a deep learning model, the study overcame traditional sequence similarity thresholds to identify AMR genes in 226 culturable strains, metagenomic samples, and assembled genomes. The results revealed a prevalence of AMR on postflight, particularly in bacteria such as *Kalamiella piersonii* (associated with human urinary tract infections), *Enterobacter bugandensis*, and *Bacillus cereus*, which showed high resistance to antibiotics such as beta-lactams. This demonstrates the utility of machine learning in uncovering hidden AMR determinants, improving our understanding of ISS microbiomes and their pathogenic potential.

Title: Extraterrestrial Gynecology: Could Spaceflight Increase the Risk of Developing Cancer in Female Astronauts? An Updated Review
Keywords: extraterrestrial gynecology could spaceflight increase risk
Resumen: Outer space is a hostile environment, with microgravity and ionizing radiation posing significant health risks to astronauts. This text focuses on its effects on the female reproductive system and the risk of gynecological cancer, an area where women have a higher incidence of radiation-induced cancers on Earth. The objective is to summarize current research and identify future needs to ensure safety during long-duration exploration missions and the post-flight care of astronauts. Space radiation, distinct from terrestrial radiation in its type and energy (including high-energy particles that penetrate shields and tissues), causes complex DNA damage and increases the risk of cancer. Although microgravity also generates significant physiological changes, research on its specific effects on the female reproductive system and gender differences is limited, underscoring the need for further studies in light of the high cumulative radiation doses expected during long-term missions.

Title: Muscle atrophy phenotype gene expression during spaceflight is linked to a metabolic crosstalk in both the liver and the muscle in mice.
Keywords: muscle atrophy phenotype gene expression during
Resumen: study examined the transcriptomic response of the liver and quadriceps muscles of mice after 37 days of spaceflight, revealing that lipid metabolism is the most affected biological process in both organs. A strong correlation was found between a specific pattern of gene expression in the liver, linked to glucose conservation and energy saving, and the gene expression of energy-intensive muscle processes such as DNA repair, autophagy, and translation. The results indicate that altered liver lipid metabolism and muscle atrophy are associated events during spaceflight, and that dietary changes represent a potential countermeasure.

Title: Chromosomal positioning and epigenetic architecture influence DNA methylation patterns triggered by galactic cosmic radiation
Keywords: Chromosomal positioning and epigenetic architecture influence
Resumen: This study addresses the poorly understood impact of galactic cosmic radiation (GCR) on human health, focusing on DNA methylation patterns and the influence of chromatin architecture. Researchers assessed the spatial patterns of DNA methylation induced by high (56Fe, 28Si) and low (X-ray) linear energy transfer radiation, as well as the role of chromosomal positioning and epigenetic architecture in distinct radial layers of the cell nucleus. They found that 56Fe causes a persistent increase in DNA methylation, whereas 28Si and X-rays induce a non-persistent decrease. The study highlights the importance of nuclear chromatin architecture in the cellular response to external radiation, offering new insights into the epigenetic and transcriptomic response to GCR damage, vital information for minimizing adverse effects during space travel.

Title: comprehensive SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19 review, Part 2: Host extracellular to systemic effects of SARS-CoV-2 infection
Keywords: comprehensive, sars cov 2, and, covid 19, review, part
Resumen: This text is the second part of a review series on SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19, exploring the biological effects of the virus on post-acute disease, adaptations, and tissue and organ damage. It details how the infection affects whole-body metabolism, including mitochondrial function, the TCA cycle, and lipid levels, relating these changes to disease severity. It also describes the influence of SARS-CoV-2 on humoral factors such as the renin-angiotensin system and the endocrine system, resulting in organ imbalances and dysfunction. The series seeks to provide a comprehensive understanding of the virus from basic biology to clinical outcomes, highlighting future areas of research.

Title: Aging and putative frailty biomarkers are altered by spaceflight
Keywords: Aging and putative frailty biomarkers are
Resumen: Crewed space exploration exposes astronauts to health risks that induce molecular changes similar to the aging process on Earth, including genomic instability, mitochondrial dysfunction, and inflammation. This study addressed the limited understanding of the connection between these changes and the development of diseases, such as frailty syndrome, in space. Using rodent data from NASA's GeneLab and astronaut data from JAXA and Inspiration4 missions, biological markers and pathways related to frailty, aging, and sarcopenia were analyzed. The findings revealed significant changes in gene expression patterns and enrichment of pathways related to aging and inflammation in rodent and human muscles, suggesting the development of a frailty-like condition during spaceflight. Specifically, an increase in the inflammatory immune response and downregulation of the IGF-1 pathway were observed in the soleus muscle. These results indicate that the similarities between spaceflight and aging extend to frailty, warranting future research into the use of a frailty index to monitor astronaut health and develop countermeasures.

Title: Space radiation damage rescued by inhibition of key spaceflight associated miRNAs
Keywords: space, radiation, damage, rescued, inhibition, key
Resumen: This study developed a strategy to mitigate space radiation damage in astronauts based on the identification of a key microRNA signature. Using 3D cultures of human microvessels exposed to simulated radiation and treated with specific antagomirs (miR-16-5p, miR-125b-5p, let-7a-5p), a significant reduction in inflammation and double-stranded DNA damage was achieved, along with recovery of mitochondrial functions. The antagomirs also preserved microvessel morphology and restored angiogenesis. Validated with astronaut data and mouse models, the study confirms that the genes and pathways involved are altered in humans and that microRNAs play a crucial role in DNA repair pathways. These findings suggest a promising countermeasure to protect astronaut health during space missions.

Title: Ethical considerations for the age of non-governmental space exploration
Keywords: ethical considerations for age non governmental space
Resumen: The rise of commercial and private spaceflight has ushered in a new era of human exploration, attracting a growing diversity of occupants who are not professional astronauts. This shift has exposed significant shortcomings in existing regulations, ethical guidelines, and medical frameworks, which were primarily designed for government astronauts. Because space travel carries severe health risks, there is an urgent need to develop new policies and practices that address the selection, training, and human research of these non-professional travelers, whose oversight is currently limited. The opportunity to collect health data on these diverse crews also demands strict regulation.

Title: Innate immune responses of Drosophila melanogaster are altered by spaceflight.
Keywords: innate, immune, responses, drosophila, melanogaster, are
Resumen: This study investigates how the space environment affects pathogenic bacteria, using *Serratia marcescens* and *Drosophila melanogaster* as models. *Serratia marcescens* grown on the International Space Station was found to be significantly more lethal to flies than ground-based control samples. A similar increase in virulence was observed in bacteria grown under simulated microgravity conditions on Earth. However, this increased virulence was temporary and was lost upon re-growing the bacteria under terrestrial conditions, suggesting reversible physiological rather than genetic changes. Bacteria exposed to spaceflight also showed increased growth rates in vitro and in the host at later stages. The findings indicate that the space environment, especially microgravity, induces complex physiological changes in pathogenic bacteria that increase their virulence, underscoring the need to understand these mechanisms.

Title: Prolonged Exposure to Microgravity Reduces Cardiac Contractility and Initiates Remodeling in Drosophila
Keywords: prolonged exposure, microgravity, reduces, cardiac, contractility
Resumen: The paper describes research on the effects of microgravity on cardiac health using the fruit fly (Drosophila) model. The results show that exposure to microgravity aboard the International Space Station causes cardiac dysfunction, including reduced cardiac contraction, myofibrillar remodeling, and decreased cardiac output. Genetic and molecular analysis revealed reduced expression of sarcomere and extracellular matrix-related genes and significantly increased expression of proteasomal genes, along with the formation of proteasome aggregates, amyloid, and polyQ deposits, suggesting abnormal proteostatic stress. These effects, which include cardiac remodeling and proteostatic stress, were observed in both wild-type and sei/hERG mutant flies, indicating a fundamental response of cardiac muscle to microgravity and underscoring the importance of understanding these mechanisms for long-term space exploration.

Title: Regulation of plant gravity sensing and signaling by the actin cytoskeleton.
Keywords: regulation, plant, gravity, sensing, and signaling
Resumen: Primary root growth is essential for the plant, allowing it to anchor and seek nutrients. The actin cytoskeleton is critical in this process, integrating environmental and hormonal stimuli and regulating cell division and elongation. This article reviews how actin, its binding proteins, hormones (especially auxin), and certain drugs affect growth and actin organization in the root. Actin is crucial for cell elongation, characterized by longitudinal bundles and dynamism, and is involved in protein trafficking and vacuolar remodeling. Furthermore, actin mediates the root's response to gravity (statolith perception and auxin transport) and is influenced by light. Drug studies demonstrate that actin depolymerization inhibits root growth by impairing cell elongation. In summary, actin is essential for root cell elongation, contributing to cell wall remodeling and turgor pressure regulation.

Title: HLB1 Is a Tetratricopeptide Repeat Domain-Containing Protein That Operates at the Intersection of the Exocytic and Endocytic Pathways at the TGN/EE in Arabidopsis
Keywords: hlb1, tetratricopeptide, repeat, domain containing, protein, that
Resumen: This article identifies and characterizes the HLB1 (HYPERSENSITIVE TO LATRUNCULIN B1) protein in *Arabidopsis thaliana* through a genetic screen that searched for mutants hypersensitive to the actin-disrupting drug latrunculin B. HLB1 is a plant-only protein that associates with the trans-Golgi network (TGN)/early endosome (EE) and traffics along filamentous actin, suggesting that it links post-Golgi trafficking to the actin cytoskeleton. HLB1 was found to interact with MIN7/BEN1, and it is proposed that both proteins form a complex with actin to modulate TGN/EE function at the intersection of exocytic and endocytic trafficking pathways in plants.

Title: ERULUS is a plasma membrane-localized receptor-like kinase that specifies root hair growth by maintaining tip-focused cytoplasmic calcium oscillations.
Keywords: erulus, plasma, membrane localized, receptor like, kinase, that
Resumen: This study refutes a previous model by Bai et al. (2014) that the CAP1/ERULUS (ERU) protein localizes to the tonoplast and regulates root hair growth via ammonium (NH4+) homeostasis, with mutants presumably lacking cytoplasmic calcium (cyt) gradients at the tip. In contrast, this investigation demonstrates that ERU localizes to the plasma membrane and post-Golgi/endocytic vesicles at the root hair tip, becoming intensified during rapid growth. Furthermore, `eru` mutants do exhibit cyt gradients at the tip, albeit with compromised oscillations (lower frequency and higher amplitude) compared to the wild type. The authors suggest that previous findings on Cyt localization and the absence of gradients were based on inadequate expression methods and the analysis of non-growing root hairs. In conclusion, ERU is a CrRLK1L-like receptor kinase located at the plasma membrane, essential for maintaining normal Cyt oscillations at the tip, a process crucial for sustained root hair growth.

Title: Brassinosteroids inhibit autotropic root straightening by modifying filamentous-actin organization and dynamics.
Keywords: brassinosteroids, inhibit, autotropic, root, straightening, modifying
Resumen: This study investigated how epi-brassinolide (eBL) enhances radicular gravitropism, the downward growth of roots, proposing that it acts similarly to the actin inhibitor latrunculin B (LatB) by influencing filamentous actin (F-actin) and autotropism. Experiments in maize and Medicago truncatula roots revealed that both eBL and LatB not only enhance downward root growth but, crucially, inhibit autotropic righting (the ability of the root to correct its trajectory following a gravitational stimulus) in a clinostat, resulting in persistent curvature. Furthermore, eBL was observed to modify F-actin organization and dynamics, although its impact was less pronounced than that of LatB. These findings suggest that eBL's effect on enhancing gravitropism is due to the inhibition of autotropic straightening, mediated in part by alterations in F-actin organization and dynamics.

Title: Cell type-specific imaging of calcium signaling in Arabidopsis thaliana seedling roots using GCaMP3.
Keywords: cell, type specific, imaging, calcium, signaling, arabidopsis
Resumen: This study introduces new *Arabidopsis thaliana* lines that express the calcium sensor GCaMP3 in a targeted manner in five specific root cell types (columella, endodermis, cortex, epidermis, and trichoblasts), overcoming the limitations of constitutive promoters. The researchers verified accurate expression and examined the cytoplasmic calcium (cyt) responses of these cells to environmental stimuli such as ATP and glutamate. Both similarities and differences in cyt signatures were found between the different cell types, taking into account the responses induced by the control solution. These *Arabidopsis* lines represent a valuable resource for further understanding how environmental stimuli connect with specific root development pathways through calcium signaling.

Title: Spatial and temporal localization of SPIRRIG and WAVE/SCAR reveal roles for these proteins in actin-mediated root hair development.
Keywords: spatial and temporal localization spirrig wave
Resumen: This study explores the development of root hairs in Arabidopsis, which are crucial for nutrient and water acquisition through apical growth. The protein SPIRRIG (SPI), involved in membrane trafficking, was found to accumulate at the root hair apex and positively regulate apical growth by maintaining vesicle secretion and the integrity of filamentous actin. Furthermore, the BRK1 and SCAR2 subunits of the WAVE/SCAR (W/SC) complex mark the root hair initiation domain, specifying their emergence position. SPI-deficient mutants showed reduced apical growth, and root hair emergence was impaired in W/SC mutants. These findings suggest that SPI facilitates actin-dependent root hair development in Arabidopsis, through pathways that could interact with the W/SC complex.

Title: Microgravity Stress: Bone and Connective Tissue
Keywords: microgravity, stress, bone, and, connective, tissue
Resumen: This study investigated the impact of different gravitational forces (microgravity, 1/6 g and 1 g) on mice on the International Space Station for 25–35 days, focusing on behavior, bone, thymus, and spleen. Microgravity was found to significantly reduce bone density, which was mostly restored by 1 g but only partially by 1/6 g, and caused thymic atrophy, which was half restored by both gravities. Both 1 g and 1/6 g suppressed some microgravity-induced changes in bone marker gene expression, and lunar gravity (1/6 g) also partially, but not completely, reversed changes in thymic gene expression. In the spleen, gene expression alterations were noted without histological changes. The study highlighted organ-specific variations in the response to gravity, serving as an animal test to establish a molecular-level gravity threshold essential for health in future spaceflight.

Title: S. aureus MscL is a pentamer in vivo but of variable stoichiometries in vitro: implications for detergent-solubilized membrane proteins
Keywords: aureus, mscl, pentamer, living, but variable
Resumen: This paper addresses the oligomeric state of the bacterial mechanosensitive channel MscL from *S. aureus* (SaMscL), whose stoichiometry has been inconsistent in previous studies, with crystal structures revealing tetrameric or pentameric forms. Using an in vivo disulfide-trapping approach, SaMscL was shown to be predominantly pentameric in the cell, establishing this as its physiologically relevant form. In vitro experiments with detergents such as Triton X-100 and C8E5 corroborated the pentameric stoichiometry, while the use of LDAO, the detergent from the previous crystallography, reversibly induced a tetrameric configuration. This suggests that detergents can alter the stoichiometry of membrane proteins, highlighting the need for in vivo assays to determine their true functional oligomeric state.

Title: Manipulating the permeation of charged compounds through the MscL nanovalve.
Keywords: manipulating, permeation, charged, compounds, through, mscl
Resumen: The large-conductance mechanosensitive channel (MscL) is an essential bacterial sensor for osmoregulation and cell protection. Due to its properties, it is considered ideal for drug-delivery nanodevices, where the introduction of charges into its pore allows it to be activated without membrane tension, functioning as a nanoswitch. However, this study investigated whether the presence of charges in the pore not only activates the channel but also affects the permeation of large charged molecules, which is crucial for the efficiency of such devices. Using in vivo and electrophysiological approaches, wild-type MscL was shown to have a slight anion preference. The alteration of charged residues and the introduction of post-translational charges significantly modulated this ionic preference and anion passage. Furthermore, the release of K+, glutamate, and trehalose was observed in modified E. coli bacteria, even without membrane tension. The results conclude that the introduction of charges into the lumen of the MscL pore effectively influences the permeation of charged molecules, with more dramatic effects for larger compounds and related to channel orientation, which has important implications for the design of drug delivery devices.

Title: The oligomeric state of the truncated mechanosensitive channel of large conductance shows no variance in vivo.
Keywords: oligomeric state truncated mechanosensitive channel large
Resumen: The E. coli mechanosensitive large-conductance channel (MscL) is essential for cell survival in the face of osmotic shock. Although the crystal structures of the MscL orthologs from M. tuberculosis (pentamer) and truncated S. aureus (tetramer) showed discrepancies in their oligomeric state, previous research has shown that full-length SaMscL is a pentamer in its native environment and that detergent solubilization can induce tetramerization. This study used an in vivo disulfide-trapping technique to assess the role of the C-terminal region of SaMscL in its oligomerization in native membranes. The results indicated that SaMscL constructs, including those with C-terminal truncations (such as the one crystallized as a tetramer), maintain pentameric stoichiometry in vivo. This suggests that the C-terminal domain of SaMscL only plays a critical role in its oligomeric state when the protein is solubilized in detergent, not in native membranes, highlighting the importance of in vivo assessments given the ability of detergents to alter the structure of membrane proteins.

Title: Three routes to modulate the pore size of the MscL channel/nanovalve
Keywords: three, routes, modulate, pore, size, mscl
Resumen: The MscL channel, a bacterial mechanosensor that protects cells from osmotic lysis, is a model for stimulus transduction and has potential as a nanovalve in microelectronic and drug-delivery devices. This study investigated the function of its cytoplasmic bundle (CB), a key structural component. The results show that CB dissociation is not required for normal channel opening and conductance. Furthermore, shortening the linker between the transmembrane domain and the CB, or restricting it by cross-linking or coordinating it with heavy metals, was able to reduce the channel's conductance and modulate its mechanosensitivity. These findings demonstrate the stability of the CB during activation and offer reversible avenues for designing MscL sensors with tunable conductance, making them more versatile for nanotechnology applications.

Title: The dynamics of protein-protein interactions between domains of MscL at the cytoplasmic-lipid interface
Keywords: dynamics, protein protein, interactions, between, domains, mscl
Resumen: The bacterial mechanosensitive large-conductance (MscL) channel functions as an emergency valve to prevent cell lysis during hypo-osmotic shock. This study investigates the interactions between the N-terminal helix (S1) and the region of TM2 close to the cytoplasmic interface (TM2ci), both essential for channel activation. The researchers used double-cysteine mutants of E. coli MscL and an in vivo disulfide trapping assay to map the protein interactions between S1 and TM2ci. Complementarily, using patch clamp experiments, they analyzed how these interactions change under different redox conditions during channel opening. The results indicate that oxidation of disulfide bonds in specific mutants can lock the channel in either a closed or sub-conducting state, suggesting a model for the coordinated dynamics of the S1 and TM2ci domains during the MscL activation process.

Title: The MscS and MscL families of mechanosensitive channels act as microbial emergency release valves
Keywords: mscs, and, mscl, families, mechanosensitive, channels
Resumen: Unicellular organisms, especially bacteria, require mechanisms to survive extreme changes in the osmolarity of their environment, which can cause excessive accumulation or loss of internal pressure. To prevent cell lysis due to a sudden decrease in external osmolarity, many bacteria possess mechanosensitive (MS) channels of the MscS and MscL families. These channels act as emergency valves that release cytoplasmic solutes, relieving internal pressure. Although bacteria are known to adapt to high osmolarity by accumulating solutes such as potassium glutamate, these adaptations make them vulnerable to hypoosmolarity. In the event of hypoosmotic shock, the cell experiences a massive influx of water that, if left unchecked, leads to lysis. The MscS and MscL channels, discovered 25 years ago, are crucial for maintaining the physical integrity of the cell, sensing membrane tension and opening to allow solute egress. MscL is a highly conserved channel that acts as a last-resort mechanism, while the MscS family is more diverse, and its homologs can be found in different organisms and organelles, with multiple members in a single genome, suggesting more varied or specific functions for different environmental signals.

Title: Chimeras reveal a single lipid-interface residue that controls MscL channel kinetics as well as mechanosensitivity
Keywords: chimeras, reveal, single, lipid interface, residue, that
Resumen: The mechanosensitive bacterial channel MscL, which functions as an osmotic emergency valve, displays functional differences between its *E. coli* and *S. aureus* counterparts, such as channel open time and gating threshold. This study, through the creation of chimeras, found that the periplasmic region of the protein, particularly residue I49 in *E. coli* and its equivalent F47 in *S. aureus* at the lipid-aqueous interface of the first transmembrane domain, dramatically influences these characteristics. Mutations that swap these key residues between species significantly alter open time, with *E. coli* I49 correlating with longer openings and *S. aureus* F47 correlating with longer openings. aureus* with shorter openings. It is proposed that this site acts as a "spring" that adjusts resistance to stabilize open or closed channel structures.

Title: Evidence for extensive horizontal gene transfer from the draft genome of a tardigrade
Keywords: evidence for extensive horizontal gene transfer
Resumen: A correction to the article "Evidence for extensive horizontal gene transfer from the draft genome of a tardigrade" by Boothby et al. states that the link to the genome assembly provided in the manuscript was outdated. The correct version of the assembly used in the study is now available on GitHub.

Title: Reply to Bemm et al. and Arakawa: Identifying foreign genes in independent Hypsibius dujardini genome assemblies
Keywords: reply, bemm, and, arakawa, identifying, foreign
Resumen: This article is a response to questions from other groups about horizontal gene transfer (HGT) in the genome of the tardigrade *Hypsibius dujardini*. The authors admit to having mistakenly uploaded an outdated, larger version of their genome assembly, which contained microbial contamination and may have contributed to the discrepancies. Despite this, they reanalyzed the data using three different approaches on independent assemblies and conclude that *H. dujardini* still shows a significantly elevated level of genes of external origin compared to other animals. They argue that these genes are not mere contaminants, as they are found in scaffolds alongside tardigrade genes and show robust coverage across multiple datasets. Furthermore, they point out that the lack of expression of some of these genes in the RNA-Seq data does not rule out HGT, as many transferred genes are expressed at low levels or not at all. They acknowledge that the inferred HGT level is higher than in most animals, although not as high as their original conclusion, and they value the contributions of other groups to advance our understanding of the genome.

Title: Tardigrades Use Intrinsically Disordered Proteins to Survive Desiccation.
Keywords: tardigrades, use, intrinsically, disordered, proteins, survive
Resumen: The text describes research on SAHS (secretory-abundant heat soluble) proteins from tardigrades, microscopic animals known for their extreme resistance to desiccation. The study demonstrates that recombinant SAHS proteins prevent the fusion of desiccated liposomes and increase the dehydration tolerance of bacteria such as *E. coli* and *Rhizobium tropici* when applied externally. Unlike other tardigrade proteins, which are intrinsically disordered, SAHS possess defined structures in the hydrated state and are suggested to undergo a structural transition upon dehydration. These findings highlight the potential of SAHS proteins as stabilizing molecules for cell preservation.

Title: Desiccation of Hypsibius exemplaris
Keywords: desiccation, hypsibius, exemplaris
Resumen: This text is a correction posted on an official U.S. government website for an open-access article distributed under a Creative Commons license. The correction refers to the article "The Evolution of Temperature and Desiccation-Related Protein Families in Tardigrada Reveals a Complex Acquisition of Extremotolerance," published in Genome Biology and Evolution in January 2024. The notice details errors in the legend for Figure 7 of the original version, specifying the correct color assignments for the CAHS, MAHS, SAHS, EtAHS alpha, EtAHS beta, and MRE11 proteins. The original version of record has not been modified, and these errors are detailed only in this correction notice. The articles are courtesy of Oxford University Press through the National Library of Medicine.

Title: The biology of tardigrade disordered proteins in extreme stress tolerance.
Keywords: biology, tardigrade, disordered, proteins, extreme, stress
Resumen: This study investigates anhydrobiosis, a survival mechanism for extreme dehydration, focusing on tardigrades and CAHS (cytoplasmic abundant heat soluble) proteins. Although CAHS proteins are known to confer dehydration tolerance in tardigrades and other organisms, it was unclear whether they could protect mammalian cells from hyperosmotic stress. Using live-cell imaging in mammalian cells, the researchers demonstrated that expression of CAHS1, CAHS3, and CAHS8 enhances cellular resilience to hyperosmotic conditions. These findings deepen our understanding of anhydrobiosis and suggest the potential of CAHS proteins as cryoprotectants.

Title: Production of reactive oxygen species and involvement of bioprotectants during anhydrobiosis in the tardigrade Paramacrobiotus spatialis
Keywords: production, reactive, oxygen, species, and involvement
Resumen: This study investigated anhydrobiosis, the ability to survive dehydration, in the tardigrade *Paramacrobiotus spatialis*. It was shown that the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), indicative of oxidative stress, increases significantly over time in anhydrobiosis. Using RNA interference, glutathione peroxidase was identified as vital for survival during dehydration and rehydration, and glutathione reductase, catalase, and aquaporins 3 and 10 were important during the rehydration phase. The study concludes that dehydration tolerance in these animals is the result of the synergistic action of multiple protective molecules.

Title: Partial weight suspension: A novel murine model for investigating adaptation to reduced musculoskeletal loading.
Keywords: partial, weight, suspension, novel, murine, model
Resumen: novel hypodynamic loading (PWS) model was developed to simulate Mars-like reduced gravity conditions in mice, allowing partial loading on all four limbs and quadrupedal locomotion under low animal stress. A 21-day study of mice exposed to a Mars-analogous load (38% of body weight) revealed significant reductions in muscle mass (gastrocnemius), trabecular and cortical bone morphology (femur), and femoral biomechanical properties, with decreased bone formation rates and largely unaltered bone resorption. These results validate the PWS model as an effective tool for exploring musculoskeletal adaptations to reduced load environments.

Title: Partial reductions in mechanical loading yield proportional changes in bone density, bone architecture, and muscle mass
Keywords: partial, reductions, mechanical, loading, yield, proportional
Resumen: This study investigated bone and muscle adaptation to different levels of reduced loading using the partial weight-bearing suspension (PWS) system in mice. For 21 days, female mice were exposed to loads of 20%, 40%, 70%, or 100% of their body weight, including total hindlimb unloading (HLU) and control groups. The results showed that changes in bone and muscle were generally proportional to the degree of unloading, with a linear relationship observed in bone mineral density, calf muscle mass, and femoral microarchitecture. Even a load reduction to 70% resulted in significant bone deterioration and muscle atrophy. The PWS model was shown to be effective in applying controlled, reduced loads over the long term, producing predictable adaptive changes in hindlimb muscles and bones.

Title: Spaceflight and hind limb unloading induces similar changes in electrical impedance characteristics of mouse gastrocnemius muscle
Keywords: spaceflight and hind limb unloading induces
Resumen: A study evaluated the potential of electrical impedance myography (EIM) as a marker of disuse-induced muscle atrophy and bone deterioration using mice exposed to spaceflight or hindlimb unloading (HLU). The results showed that the EIM phase slope parameter was significantly decreased in the spaceflight and HLU groups compared to their controls. This parameter also correlated with muscle fiber size and bone mineral density. This suggests that EIM is a useful, noninvasive tool for assessing muscle disuse caused by immobilization or microgravity.

Title: Spaceflight Activates Lipotoxic Pathways in Mouse Liver
Keywords: spaceflight, activates, lipotoxic, pathways, mouse, liver
Resumen: Spaceflight causes detrimental physiological effects, also observed in rodents, and this study sought to determine whether hepatic alterations in lipid metabolism are a result of space stress alone. Analyzing data from International Space Station (ISS) mice sacrificed in orbit, unlike previous studies involving the stress of returning to Earth, abnormal lipid accumulation was found in the livers of all space mice, regardless of strain or duration of exposure (weeks to months). Transcriptomic and proteomic analysis revealed the activation of lipotoxic pathways, such as increased lipid and fatty acid metabolism. These data conclude that the activation of lipotoxic pathways is a direct consequence of spatial stressors, and this activation occurs in diverse genetic backgrounds. If similar responses occur in humans, this could lead to the development of liver disease, warranting further investigation.

Title: Treatment with a soluble bone morphogenetic protein type 1A receptor (BMPR1A) fusion protein increases bone mass and bone formation in mice subjected to hindlimb unloading.
Keywords: treatment with soluble bone morphogenetic protein
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of the soluble mBMPR1A-mFc fusion protein on disuse-induced bone loss using a female hindlimb unloading mouse model. The results showed that treatment with mBMPR1A-mFc prevented the decline in bone mineral density (BMD) in disuse mice and increased it in normal-weight-bearing controls. Furthermore, it significantly improved bone microarchitecture and strength in both groups by increasing the rate of bone formation and reducing the osteoclastic surface area. These findings suggest that mBMPR1A-mFc may be useful in maintaining skeletal integrity under conditions of disuse-induced bone loss.

Title: RNAseq and RNA molecular barcoding reveal differential gene expression in cortical bone following hindlimb unloading in female mice
Keywords: rnaseq and rna molecular barcoding reveal
Resumen: This study investigated changes in the complete transcriptomic profile of cortical bone in a mouse model of hindlimb unloading (HLU) to identify mechanosensitive genes associated with disuse bone loss. Using RNA sequencing (RNAseq) and NanoString in female mice, alterations in the expression of genes previously linked to Wnt signaling and metabolism were observed. An increase in the abundance of transcripts such as Pfkfb3 and Mss51 was identified, suggesting their role in the response of cortical bone to altered mechanical loading, potentially through mechanisms related to cellular energy balance and mitochondria. The findings demonstrate that an unbiased transcriptomic approach can reveal previously unidentified mechanosensitive genes, potentially leading to new targets for preventing disuse-induced osteoporosis.

Title: Proteomic and phosphoproteomic characterization of cardiovascular tissues after long term exposure to simulated space radiation
Keywords: proteomic, and, phosphoproteomic, characterization, cardiovascular, tissues
Resumen: study analyzed the proteome and phosphoproteome of cardiac tissue and plasma from mice exposed to a single dose of galactic cosmic ray radiation (GCR5-ion) to understand the biological basis of long-term cardiovascular dysfunction. Significant changes in proteins and biological pathways were identified, with those related to inflammation being the most affected. The presence of increased neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) in irradiated hearts suggests sustained inflammation. These results indicate that exposure to GCR5-ion induces long-lasting proteomic alterations that could cause acute and chronic health problems in astronauts, such as cardiac dysfunction.

Title: Adaptive Changes in the Vestibular System of Land Snail to a 30-Day Spaceflight and Readaptation on Return to Earth
Keywords: adaptive, changes, vestibular, system, land, snail
Resumen: The text describes a study on the adaptation of the vestibular system of land snails Helix lucorum to microgravity. The snails were exposed to 30 days of simulated weightlessness aboard the Bion-M1 satellite, and their geotactic behavior, gene expression in the statocyst, and the electrophysiological responses of their mechanoreceptors were analyzed. The findings revealed plastic changes in the snails' vestibular system in response to spaceflight and the absence of light during the mission. Readaptation to normal tilt responses was observed approximately 20 hours after their return to Earth, concluding that, despite the permanence of gravity in their evolution, snails respond compensatorily to its loss and readapt when it is restored.

Title: Morphology of the Utricular Otolith Organ in the Toadfish, Opsanus tau
Keywords: morphology, utricular, otolith, organ, toadfish, opsanus
Resumen: This study describes the anatomy of the utricle in the adult oyster toadfish (*Opsanus tau*), a structure of the inner ear crucial for balance and perception of movement and head orientation. Using optical, scanning, and transmission microscopy, researchers visualized the sensory epithelium, neural innervation, and synaptic organization. Key observations included a well-defined strola, zonal organization of hair cell bundles, hair cell density according to their macular location, bundle polarization, and specific synaptic specializations. The toadfish is considered a suitable vertebrate model due to its resilience and neural response to altered gravity, which may be analogous to that of humans. This research is essential for establishing a morphological basis for future functional studies under various gravitational conditions.

Title: Influence of Magnitude and Duration of Altered Gravity and Readaptation to 1g on the Structure and Function of the Utricle in Toadfish, Opsanus tau.
Keywords: influence, magnitude, and duration, altered, gravity
Resumen: This study investigates the effects of hypergravity (HG) on toadfish utricular afferents, using centrifugation for exposures ranging from 1 to 32 days and observing recovery at 1 g. Afferent sensitivity was found to robustly increase after 3-4 days of HG, followed by a significant decrease between 16 and 32 days. Recovery at 1 g from these changes took several days. Despite the physiological alterations, synaptic body counts in hair cells did not change significantly, and no clear role for the vestibular efferent pathway in regulating afferent behavior under HG was found. The study concludes that 1g HG transitions profoundly affect gravitational sensitivity and that readaptation to 1g resembles, in part, adaptation to 1g microgravity.

Title: Organization of the ER-Golgi interface for membrane traffic control.
Keywords: organization, er golgi, interface, for, membrane, traffic
Resumen: Bidirectional membrane trafficking between the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and the Golgi apparatus is essential in eukaryotic cells for the biogenesis and intracellular distribution of proteins, carbohydrates, and lipids. Coat protein complex II (COPII) mediates anterograde transport from the ER to the Golgi, exporting newly synthesized cargo, while coat protein complex I (COPI) facilitates retrograde transport from the Golgi to the ER, retrieving ER-resident proteins, lipids, and essential trafficking machinery. Both processes are interdependent, and their regulation is crucial for maintaining organelle homeostasis and the efficiency of the secretory pathway. The organization of the ER-Golgi interface and the regulation of COPII vary across species and cell types, displaying great plasticity to adapt to different cargo demands. A deeper understanding of how these interfaces are regulated provides key insights into the mechanisms that control efficient trafficking in the secretory pathway.

Title: IRE1: ER stress sensor and cell fate executor.
Keywords: ire1 stress sensor and cell fate
Resumen: The unfolded protein response (UPR) is a crucial cellular mechanism that, activated by transmembrane sensors in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) such as the enzyme IRE1, monitors protein folding capacity and maintains homeostasis. IRE1 acts as a vital sensor in eukaryotes, triggering an adaptive response through the unconventional splicing of transcription factors (such as Xbp-1 in mammals) to increase protein folding capacity and promote cell survival. However, under conditions of irremediable ER stress, IRE1 reveals itself as a master regulator of cell fate, repressing adaptive responses and initiating apoptosis through regulated RNA degradation (RIDD), which includes the elimination of anti-apoptotic microRNAs, leading to the activation of Caspase-2. Unlike other UPR sensors such as PERK (unique to animals) and ATF6 (with homologs in plants), recent studies redefine IRE1 as a persistent and active executor in determining cell fate, capable of directing both adaptation and cell death under prolonged ER stress.

Title: Inter-regulation of the unfolded protein response and auxin signaling.
Keywords: inter regulation, unfolded, protein, response, and auxin
Resumen: This study establishes a regulatory link between the unfolded protein response (UPR), activated by endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress, and the hormone auxin in *Arabidopsis thaliana*. ER stress was shown to induce downregulation of auxin sensors (TIR1/AFBs) and transporters (PIN family), resulting in an increase in AUX/IAA proteins. A mutant of the ER stress sensor IRE1 exhibits defects in auxin response and levels, suggesting that IRE1 is essential for auxin homeostasis. Furthermore, UPR activation is reduced in mutants of ER-localized auxin transporters, such as PIN5. These findings imply that the UPR in plants has evolved a hormone-dependent strategy to coordinate ER function with physiological processes.

Title: Endoplasmic reticulum-shape and function in stress translation
Keywords: endoplasmic, reticulum shape, and, function, stress, translation
Resumen: This article summarizes the current knowledge on the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) in plants, highlighting its versatility and central role as a gateway to the secretory pathway and in adaptation to abiotic and biotic stresses. The dynamics and architecture of the ER, its interaction with other organelles, and its function in stress translation and adaptation are explored, including protein quality control (ERQC), ER-associated degradation (ERAD), the unfolded protein response (UPR), and programmed cell death (PCD). The text also addresses mechanisms such as the regulation of their movement by myosins, stress detection by bZIP transcription factors, and their involvement in plant immunity and viral pathogenesis, highlighting the importance of the ER for sustainable agricultural production.

Title: Galactose-depleted xycoglucan is dysfunctional and leads to dwarfism in Arabidopsis
Keywords: galactose depleted, xycoglucan, dysfunctional, and leads to dwarfism
Resumen: Galactose depletion in xyloglucan (XyG), a plant cell wall polysaccharide, due to mutations in the MURUS3 (MUR3) gene in Arabidopsis results in the formation of dysfunctional XyG. This altered XyG, which lacks F side chains and is less galactosylated, causes a dwarfing phenotype with curled leaves and intracellular accumulation of cell wall polysaccharides. Surprisingly, complete deletion of XyG in these mutants restores near-normal growth, suggesting that the presence of dysfunctional XyG is more detrimental than its total absence. Growth was also restored by modifying the structure of the dysfunctional XyG by duplicating the galactosylated side chains. This study underscores the importance of galactosylation for the normal function of XyG and demonstrates that alterations in the structure of its side chains disrupt various cellular and physiological processes.

Title: Unfolded protein response in plants: one master, many questions.
Keywords: unfolded protein response plants one master
Resumen: The Misfolded Protein Response (UPR) in plants is a cytoprotective mechanism to counteract endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress, a potentially lethal condition. This response involves sensors in the ER that activate distinctive signaling pathways. Among the key components, the sensor IRE1 is conserved in eukaryotes, mediating the mRNA splicing of bZIP transcription factors (such as AtbZIP60 in plants), albeit with differences in the final product. Plants also possess membrane-anchored bZIP transcription factors (AtbZIP28 and AtbZIP17), whose proteolytic activation is similar to that of metazoan ATF6, displaying both overlapping and specialized functions. Although PERK-like activity has been detected, a specific PERK protein has not yet been identified in plants. Furthermore, NAC transcription factors, unique to plants, participate in the UPR, relocating from the ER or plasma membrane to the nucleus. Despite these similarities with other eukaryotes, plants have evolved unique strategies for the UPR. Open questions remain regarding the exact mechanisms of IRE1 activation, the functional diversification of its isoforms, the physiological relevance of IRE1-mediated mRNA degradation (RIDD), and the control of microRNAs in plants.

Title: Vesicles versus Tubes: Is Endoplasmic Reticulum-Golgi Transport in Plants Fundamentally Different from Other Eukaryotes?
Keywords: vesicles versus tubes endoplasmic reticulum golgi transport
Resumen: This text addresses the controversy surrounding the mechanism of transport between the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and the Golgi apparatus in higher plants, questioning whether it occurs via vesicles or direct tubular connections. Unlike animal cells, plants have mobile Golgi stacks that move along the ER and a narrow interface, making it difficult to identify transport vectors. Although the role of COPII and COPI proteins in anterograde and retrograde transport is generally accepted in eukaryotes, the existence of COPII vesicles in plants is the subject of considerable debate, and their visualization is rare. The article brings together the divergent opinions of four leading cell biologists: Federica Brandizzi introduces the molecular context, Chris Hawes presents evidence in favor of tubules, David Robinson argues for vesicular transport, and Akihiko Nakano explores alternatives. The distinctive mobility of the Golgi in plants and the dynamics of ER exit sites (ERES) contribute to the complexity of this issue, preventing experts from reaching a consensus on how this essential transport occurs.

Title: Pectin methylesterification impacts the relationship between photosynthesis and plant growth.
Keywords: pectin, methylesterification, impacts, relationship, between, photosynthesis
Resumen: This study investigates how pectin methylesterification, regulated by the CGR2 and CGR3 genes, affects leaf architecture, carbon partitioning, and plant growth in Arabidopsis. It was shown that high levels of methylesterification (via CGR2 overexpression) result in expanded leaves, increased intercellular air space, and increased plant dry weight, while reduced methylesterification (in the cgr2/3 mutant) causes a dense, thin leaf mesophyll, limiting CO2 diffusion and decreasing growth. Growth differences are attributed to altered carbon partitioning toward leaf surface area and leaf mass per unit area, rather than to variations in the photosynthetic rate per unit area. RGC-mediated pectin methylesterification acts as a primary factor by modulating cell expansion and positioning in leaves, which in turn directs carbon partitioning.

Title: Reduced Chloroplast Coverage genes from Arabidopsis thaliana help to establish the size of the chloroplast compartment
Keywords: Reduced chloroplast coverage genes from Arabidopsis
Resumen: The text describes research on a small gene family called REC (REDUCED CHLOROPLAST COVERAGE) in the plant *Arabidopsis thaliana*. These genes are critical for determining the proportion of cell volume devoted to chloroplasts. It is shown that this mechanism is extraplastidial, as the REC1 protein, the major contributor, is localized in the cytoplasm and nucleus, and its movement between them could regulate this process. Deleting these genes significantly reduces chloroplast volume. It is suggested that a deeper understanding of this mechanism could allow manipulation of chloroplast size to improve photosynthetic efficiency and crop yield.

Title: Maintaining the factory: The roles of the unfolded protein response in cellular homeostasis in plants.
Keywords: maintaining factory roles unfolded protein response
Resumen: The Unfolded Protein Response (UPR) is a set of signaling mechanisms essential for plants, allowing them to adapt and survive environmental stress. The endoplasmic reticulum (ER), a key cellular "factory" for protein folding, can accumulate misfolded proteins under stress, causing damage. The UPR detects these proteins and activates signaling cascades (involving IRE1, bZIP28, and bZIP60 in plants) to increase the ER's folding capacity and restore homeostasis. This process is critical for growth, development, and the response to various stresses (heat, pathogens, heavy metals, etc.). The research seeks to understand how the UPR integrates into plant physiology to improve crop productivity under adverse conditions.

Title: NADPH oxidase activity is required for ER stress survival in plants.
Keywords: nadph oxidase activity required for stress
Resumen: In eukaryotes, the unfolded protein response (UPR) mitigates endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress caused by the accumulation of misfolded proteins. While in mammals and yeast, reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated during ER stress attenuate the UPR, this relationship has been unclear in plants. This study demonstrates that in *Arabidopsis thaliana*, respiratory burst oxidase homologs (RBOHD and RBOHF) contribute to ROS production during ER stress and are required for a proper adaptive UPR, helping the plant overcome temporary and chronic ER stress conditions. These results assign a cytoprotective role to ROS generated by RBOH in the defense against proteotoxic stress, suggesting a specific plant characteristic in the management of UPR. The research used nitrotetrazolium blue (NBT) staining for superoxide and developed a fluorimetric method with Amplex Ultra Red for the quantification of H2O2, validating the involvement of RBOHD and RBOHF in ROS production.

Title: Relevance of the Unfolded Protein Response to Spaceflight-Induced Transcriptional Reprogramming in Arabidopsis
Keywords: relevance, unfolded, protein, response, spaceflight induced, transcriptional
Resumen: This study investigated the Unfolded Protein Response (UPR) in the model plant *Arabidopsis thaliana* grown on the International Space Station to understand its response to spaceflight stress. Gene expression was compared in wild-type plants and UPR-defective mutants in orbit and in ground-based controls. Results showed that in-orbit cultivation substantially altered the expression of hundreds of stress-related genes. However, unlike ground-based conditions where expression varied between mutants, in space it was largely similar across all genotypes. This suggests that spaceflight induces the activation of signaling pathways that compensate for the absence of UPR regulators, offering new insights into plant adaptation to extraterrestrial environments.

Title: Reanalysis of the Mars500 experiment reveals common gut microbiome alterations in astronauts induced by long-duration confinement
Keywords: reanalysis, mars500, experiment, reveals, common, gut
Resumen: study reanalyzed data from the Mars500 experiment, which simulated a 520-day Mars mission with confinement, to investigate changes in astronauts' gut microbiomes, crucial to their health during long-duration spaceflight. Using improved bioinformatics, the study identified 408 exact sequence variants (ESVs), finding that 32 of them significantly altered their abundance over time. This included depletion of beneficial species associated with anti-inflammation and insulin sensitivity, such as *Faecalibacterium prausnitzii* and *Ruminococcus bromii*, and enrichment of other bacteria. Furthermore, 49 microbial species were observed to be shared between the astronauts and their habitat. These findings reveal microbiome alterations that correlate with the symptoms of gut inflammation and glucose dysregulation observed in astronauts, improving our understanding of how prolonged confinement affects human health and is vital for future space missions.
