Title: High atomic weight, high-energy radiation (HZE) induces transcriptional responses shared with conventional stresses in addition to a core "DSB" response specific to clastogenic treatments
Keywords: high, atomic, weight, high energy, radiation, hze
Resumen: The text describes an open-access scholarly article published in *Frontiers in Plant Science*, edited and reviewed by Alma Balestrazzi and Anne B. Britt, which addresses topics such as DNA repair, stress, and radiation. A correction is included for an oversight in the original publication, specifying that the microarray data are deposited in Gene Expression Omnibus under its accession number. The authors declare no conflicts of interest, and the article is provided by Frontiers Media SA through an official and secure website of the United States government, specifically the National Library of Medicine.

Title: Genomic stability in response to high versus low linear energy transfer radiation in Arabidopsis thaliana
Keywords: genomic stability response high versus low
Resumen: This study investigates the differential effects of high linear energy transfer (LET) radiation, such as HZE particles, and low LET radiation, such as gamma rays, on *Arabidopsis thaliana* mutants deficient in DNA repair and checkpoints. HZE radiation was found to cause more densely packed DNA damage and to have a relative biological effectiveness (RBE) approximately 3:1 for root growth inhibition and 2:1 for loss of somatic heterozygosity compared to gamma rays. Defects in checkpoint and repair mechanisms increased sensitivity to both radiations, with the replication fork checkpoint (governed by ATR) playing a slightly larger role in resistance to HZE-induced mutagenesis.

Title: Acceleration profiles and processing methods for parabolic flight.
Keywords: acceleration, profiles, and, processing, methods, for
Resumen: This text presents an open-source solution for collecting, analyzing, and classifying altered-gravity environments experienced during parabolic flights, a cost-effective alternative for simulating microgravity or reduced-gravity conditions. Faced with limited availability of acceleration data and accessible processing methods, the authors validated their approach on a flight with 20 parabolas, using a commercial accelerometer and an orientation-independent analysis methodology. The solution enables automatic classification of all flight phases and consistent quantification of acceleration levels, making all data and analysis code publicly available. This aims to improve the planning, execution, and analysis of experiments in parabolic flights, thus facilitating future space activities.

Title: Cytoskeleton structure and total methylation of mouse cardiac and lung tissue during space flight.
Keywords: Cytoskeleton structure and total methylation mouse
Resumen: This study evaluated cytoskeletal protein and mRNA expression levels in cardiac and lung tissues from mice euthanized aboard the International Space Station (ISS) 37 days after a mission, in order to avoid the readaptation effects observed in previous research. The results indicated that while there were no changes in cytoskeletal protein content, significant modifications were observed in the mRNA expression levels of associated genes, which could be due to an increase in genome-wide methylation and a decrease in mRNA expression of the cytosine demethylase Tet2. This approach provides crucial data for developing methods to protect humans during long-duration spaceflight and during readaptation to Earth's gravity.

Title: Toward countering muscle and bone loss with spaceflight: GSK3 as a potential target
Keywords: toward countering muscle and bone loss
Resumen: Exposure to spaceflight causes significant musculoskeletal impairment in mice, characterized by muscle atrophy and bone loss. This study investigated glycogen synthase kinase 3 (GSK3), a negative regulator of muscle and bone mass, as a potential therapeutic target. After approximately 30 days in space, murine soleus muscles showed a reduction in GSK3Î² content, linked to a shift from slow to fast twitch muscle fibers. In contrast, GSK3 activation in bone increased after spaceflight. In simulated microgravity models (hindlimb unloading), muscle-specific deletion of Gsk3 (GSK3mKD) in mice resulted in increased muscle mass, preservation of muscle strength, promotion of a type of oxidative fiber, and, notably, an increase in bone mineral density. These findings suggest that GSK3 inhibition is a promising strategy to counteract the loss of musculoskeletal health during spaceflight.

Title: Spaceflight increases sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ leak and this cannot be counteracted with BuOE treatment
Keywords: spaceflight, increases, sarcoplasmic, reticulum, ca2, leak
Resumen: A study investigated whether the antioxidant BuOE could attenuate muscle atrophy and SERCA pump dysfunction in the soleus muscles of mice exposed to 35 days in microgravity. The results showed that spaceflight induced significant soleus muscle atrophy, increased Ca2+ leakage from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, and elevated levels of an oxidative stress marker (4-HNE). Although BuOE increased SERCA's affinity for Ca2+, it failed to mitigate the muscle atrophy, Ca2+ leakage, and increased 4-HNE caused by microgravity. Therefore, it is concluded that BuOE is not effective in counteracting these effects, and alternative therapies are suggested.

Title: Cardiovascular progenitor cells cultured aboard the International Space Station exhibit altered developmental and functional properties
Keywords: cardiovascular progenitor cells cultured aboard international
Resumen: study investigated the effects of spaceflight on human cardiovascular progenitor cells (CPCs), both neonatal and adult, cultured on the International Space Station. Significant alterations in the expression of microRNAs and genes related to mechanotransduction, cytoskeletal organization, Wnt signaling, DNA repair, and paracrine signaling were observed in both populations. Neonatal CPCs, in particular, displayed increased proliferative and regenerative potential, with elevated expression of early developmental markers and associated specific genes. These findings suggest that understanding these changes could inform new strategies for cardiac repair on Earth and for preserving astronaut health.

Title: Inter-agency perspective: Translating advances in biomarker discovery and medical countermeasures development between terrestrial and space radiation environments
Keywords: inter agency, perspective, translating, advances, biomarker, discovery
Resumen: The U.S. government, through the National Cancer Institute (NCI), the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID), and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), has significantly advanced radiation research for more than 20 years to protect humans from its biological effects. While the NCI focuses on minimizing tissue damage in radiation oncology therapy, and the NIAID focuses on countermeasures for civilian populations following radiation incidents, NASA seeks to protect astronauts from chronic exposure in space. Despite their different approaches, these agencies collaborate closely to identify biomarkers and develop medical countermeasures (radioprotectors, mitigators, and treatments) that safeguard human health against both acute and long-term radiation injury, maximizing resources and accelerating collaborative development.

Title: Genomic and functional characterization of Enterococcus faecalis isolates recovered from the International Space Station and their potential for pathogenicity
Keywords: Genomic and functional characterization of Enterococcus faecalis
Resumen: study evaluated isolates of *Enterococcus faecalis*, a multidrug-resistant opportunistic pathogen, recovered from the International Space Station (ISS) to determine their potential impact on astronaut health. Pan-genome and functional analyses, desiccation resistance tests, and pathogenicity assays were performed on *Caenorhabditis elegans*. The findings revealed no distinctive signatures that differentiated pathogenic from commensal strains based solely on current resources, underscoring the need to complement information from databases with experimental evaluation of the genotypic and phenotypic characteristics of clinically relevant microorganisms.

Title: Evaluation of in vitro macrophage differentiation during space flight.
Keywords: evaluation, vitro, macrophage, differentiation, during, space
Resumen: This study investigated the impact of spaceflight on the in vitro differentiation of macrophages from mouse bone marrow cells during the STS-126 mission at optimal physiological temperatures. During 14 days of flight, cells were differentiated in the presence of macrophage colony-stimulating factor and analyzed by flow cytometry and gene microarrays, comparing them with ground-based controls. The results showed significant differences in the number of macrophages developed in space and changes in the distribution of several cell surface molecules (such as CD11b, CD31, F4/80, Mac2, Ly6C, and c-Fos). However, there were no changes in the expression of the c-Fms receptor, nor a consistent pattern of accelerated or delayed differentiation. The findings suggested relatively normal differentiation but increased proliferation of bone marrow macrophages, along with an unexpected influence of spaceflight on coagulation pathway genes. These data confirm that spaceflight affects the development of macrophages from mouse bone marrow cells in vitro.

Title: Identification of critical host mitochondrion-associated genes during Ehrlichia chaffeensis infections
Keywords: identification critical host mitochondrion associated genes during
Resumen: This study identified host components crucial for the replication of *Ehrlichia chaffeensis*, the causative agent of human monocytic ehrlichiosis. Through microarray analysis in *Drosophila melanogaster* S2 cells and screening of mutant flies, 10 genes were discovered whose mutation increased resistance to *Ehrlichia* infection, seven of which are associated with mitochondrial functions. Disruption of the human UCK2 gene was confirmed to affect bacterial replication in human macrophages, and experiments with inhibitors suggest that the nucleotide salvage pathway is essential for *E. replication. chaffeensis*, providing nucleotides such as CTP, uridine and cytidine.

Title: Ehrlichia chaffeensis replication sites in adult Drosophila melanogaster.
Keywords: ehrlichia chaffeensis replication sites adult drosophila
Resumen: This study investigated the replication of *Ehrlichia chaffeensis*, the bacterium that causes human monocytic ehrlichiosis, in the arthropod model *Drosophila melanogaster*. Using the UAS-GAL4 RNAi system, the researchers silenced the genes *Uridine cytidine kinase 2* (*Uck2*) and *separation anxiety* (*san*) in specific fly tissues. They found that when *Uck2* or *san* were suppressed in hemocytes (equivalent to mammalian macrophages) or the fat body (a homolog of the liver), *E. chaffeensis* replication was significantly decreased and infections were less severe. However, silencing these genes in other tissues such as the eyes, wings, or salivary glands did not affect fly susceptibility or bacterial replication. The data suggest that, as in vertebrate hosts, *E. chaffeensis* replicates in the hemocytes and fat body of *Drosophila*, identifying key locations for host-pathogen interactions in arthropods.

Title: Development and characterization of two porcine monocyte-derived macrophage cell lines.
Keywords: Development and characterization of two porcine monocyte derived
Resumen: This study sought to identify natural compounds with antiviral and anti-inflammatory properties against African swine fever virus (ASFV), a serious threat to pig production with no effective vaccine, which induces a pathogenic "cytokine storm." After screening 297 compounds, five were identified that inhibited the cytopathic effect of ASFV in Vero cells. Of these, tetrandrine and berbamine displayed high anti-ASFV activity, inhibiting the early stages of infection and mitigating infection in porcine macrophages. Both compounds, especially tetrandrine, significantly reduced the production of proinflammatory cytokines during ASFV infection in these cells. The findings suggest that these dual-action natural compounds have potential as preventive and therapeutic agents by inhibiting viral replication and reducing virus-induced inflammation.

Title: Understanding macrophage differentiation during space flight: The importance of ground-based experiments before space flight
Keywords: understanding, macrophage, differentiation, during, space, flight
Resumen: This study investigated macrophage differentiation from primary mouse bone marrow cells using two in vitro culture systems, the Techshot Cell Cult bioreactor and the BioServe Fluid Processing Apparatus (FPA), in preparation for spaceflight. Results showed that both the orientation (horizontal or vertical) and movement of the culture devices significantly impacted macrophage growth, recovery, and differentiation. Significantly higher cell recovery was observed in horizontal orientations and in rotated bioreactors ("carousels"), compared to static or vertically rotating devices ("wheels"), which is linked to a larger surface area for cell propagation. Furthermore, the phenotype of the resulting macrophages, including their size, granularity, and expression of differentiation markers, varied markedly across devices and configurations. This underscores that culture results are highly dependent on the device and its orientation, which is critical for accurately interpreting data from spaceflight experiments, given the previous inconsistency observed in microgravity research.

Title: Bone marrow leptin signaling mediates obesity-associated adipose tissue inflammation in male mice.
Keywords: bone, marrow, leptin, signaling, mediates, obesity associated
Resumen: This study investigated the role of leptin signaling in the induction of obesity-associated inflammation. Using chimeric mice reconstituted with leptin receptor-deficient (db/db) or wild-type (WT) bone marrow and fed a high-fat diet, the researchers found that mice with db/db bone marrow (WT/db) had significantly lower body weight and adiposity. Furthermore, these mice exhibited reduced inflammatory gene expression in adipose tissue, fewer crown-like structures, and an anti-inflammatory phenotype in their adipose tissue macrophages, along with increased insulin sensitivity. The findings suggest that disruption of leptin signaling in bone marrow-derived cells attenuates the proinflammatory conditions and metabolic complications of obesity, establishing a novel mechanism in the regulation of obesity-associated systemic inflammation and supporting the hypothesis that leptin is a proinflammatory cytokine.

Title: Establishment and characterization of DB-1: a leptin receptor-deficient murine macrophage cell line
Keywords: establishment and characterization db 1 leptin receptor deficient
Resumen: The text describes the creation and characterization of DB-1, a novel leptin receptor-deficient macrophage cell line designed as a tool to investigate the link between leptin and innate immunity. Leptin, an adipokine, is a key sensor of nutritional status and regulator of the immune system, and its receptor influences various immune cells. The DB-1 line was developed from bone marrow cells from leptin receptor-deficient mice, differentiated and spontaneously immortalized. These cells are diploid, grow at a linear rate, are positive for macrophage markers (MAC-2 and F4/80), and possess phagocytic activity similar to that of primary macrophages. They respond to stimulation with interferon-? but not to leptin or to chemotaxis of adipocyte-conditioned media, confirming the absence of a functional leptin receptor. It is concluded that DB-1 is a reliable tool for studying the role of leptin or its receptor in obesity-associated inflammation and immune dysregulation.

Title: Validation of methods to assess the immunoglobulin gene repertoire in tissues obtained from mice on the International Space Station.
Keywords: validation, methods, assess, immunoglobulin, gene, repertoire
Resumen: This paper describes the development and validation of a bioinformatics and Next-Generation Sequencing (NGS) workflow to study the impact of spaceflight on the antibody repertoire of murine B cells, specifically the use of immunoglobulin genes. Given the known impact on immune cells during spaceflight and the limitations on sample collection and storage on the International Space Station, the study compared various sample preparation methods and sequencing techniques (Illumina MiSeq and HiSeq). The researchers created a bioinformatics workflow designed to reduce bias and capture maximum information from the Ig sequences, validating it with data from normal mice to ensure its reliability in future spaceflight experiments.

Title: Characterization of the naive murine antibody repertoire using unamplified high-throughput sequencing
Keywords: characterization, naive, murine, antibody, repertoire, unamplified
Resumen: study characterized the antibody repertoire of non-immunized adult female C57BL/6J mice using high-throughput sequencing (HTS) of pooled spleen tissue without amplification to avoid bias. More than 90,000 heavy chain sequences and more than 135,000 light chain sequences were recovered. The results showed uniform usage of V, D, and J gene segments among mouse groups, especially for the most abundant segments, but high diversity in the CDR3 amino acid sequences of B cells, confirming combinatorial diversity. A bias was also observed in the detected V gene segments based on their chromosomal location. This work provides an unbiased view of the antibody repertoire of these mice, useful as a reference for future research.

Title: Effects of spaceflight on the immunoglobulin repertoire of unimmunized C57BL/6 mice
Keywords: spaceflight, immunoglobulin, repertoire, unimmunized, c57bl, mice
Resumen: This study examined whether spaceflight alters the B cell repertoire. Using high-throughput sequencing, the immunoglobulin repertoire of unimmunized C57BL/6 mice on the International Space Station was compared with ground-based control mice. The results indicated that the usage of individual gene segments was similar between the two groups of animals. Although the combinations of gene segments and their splicing varied among animals, there were no significant differences between treatment groups. No increase in spontaneous somatic mutations was found. In conclusion, the data suggest that short-term space travel did not affect the B cell repertoire of the mice studied.

Title: comparison of unamplified and massively multiplexed PCR amplification for murine antibody repertoire sequencing.
Keywords: comparison, unamplified, and, massively, multiplexed, pcr
Resumen: This study compared unamplified antibody repertoire sequencing with two commercial amplified methods on the mouse splenic heavy chain repertoire and evaluated the impact of sample preparation, such as the use of mRNA versus total RNA, reverse transcriptase, and primers. Although mRNA for cDNA synthesis resulted in a higher number of reads, and the amplified data sets generally had more antibody reads, the unamplified method detected more unique V gene segments. Despite lower detection of unique CDR3s in the unamplified data, RNASeq sequencing identified 98% of the high-frequency CDR3s. The results demonstrate that unamplified antibody repertoire profiling is possible, reveals more V gene segments, and detects high-frequency clones.

Title: Effects of skeletal unloading on the antibody repertoire of tetanus toxoid and/or CpG treated C57BL/6J mice.
Keywords: skeletal, unloading, antibody, repertoire, tetanus, toxoid
Resumen: The text describes the preclinical development of TAK-754, an AAV8-based gene therapy vector designed to treat hemophilia A by delivering a liver-optimized, low-CpG factor VIII (FVIII) transgene. Studies in FVIII-deficient mice demonstrated a dose-dependent increase in plasma FVIII activity and a corresponding reduction in blood loss, as well as stable and long-lasting FVIII expression. Safety and biodistribution assessments revealed predominantly hepatic distribution, minimal vector integration, and an absence of adverse clinical signs at the highest doses. These preclinical findings support a favorable safety and efficacy profile for TAK-754 as a potential treatment for hemophilia A.

Title: Effects of skeletal unloading on the bone marrow antibody repertoire of tetanus toxoid and/or CpG treated C57BL/6J mice.
Keywords: skeletal, unloading, bone, marrow, antibody, repertoire
Resumen: TAK-754 is an AAV8-based gene therapy vector designed to treat hemophilia A, delivering an optimized, CpG-free F8 transgene under a hepatic promoter. Preclinical studies in mice demonstrated a dose-dependent increase in plasma factor VIII activity and a reduction in blood loss, along with stable, long-term expression of factor VIII. Safety and biodistribution assessments confirmed predominant detection in the liver, minimal vector integration, and an absence of adverse clinical signs related to TAK-754, suggesting a good safety and efficacy profile for this therapy.

Title: An Analysis of the Effects of Spaceflight and Vaccination on Antibody Repertoire Diversity
Keywords: spaceflight, and, vaccination, antibody, repertoire, diversity
Resumen: This study investigates antibody (Ab) repertoire diversity, specifically in the CDR3 region, in C57BL/6 mice to analyze the effects of spaceflight and a physiological microgravity model following vaccination. Using rank-abundance curves and Shannon indices in five data sets from four experiments, the researchers observed a trend toward decreased Ab repertoire diversity as a result of spaceflight. However, they did not find the same decrease in their physiological microgravity model in the spleen or bone marrow, although the bone marrow did show a reduction in diversity following vaccination. Differences in Shannon indices were also detected between experiments and tissues, but no consistent pattern of CDR3 usage was found. Overall, the study was able to identify differences in Ab repertoire diversity between the experimental groups and tissues analyzed.

Title: Effects of spaceflight aboard the International Space Station on mouse estrous cycle and ovarian gene expression
Keywords: spaceflight, aboard, international, space, station, mouse
Resumen: study investigated the effects of 37 days of microgravity on the estrous cycle and ovarian function of adult female mice. The results showed that estrous cycle phases did not differ significantly between the flight mice and baseline and vivarium controls, although the habitat controls had more diestrus mice. No differences were observed in ovarian estradiol levels, but progesterone levels were lower in the habitat and flight groups compared to baseline. Genes involved in ovarian steroidogenic function did not show significant differences in expression. These findings suggest that females exposed to long-duration spaceflight likely maintain ovarian cyclicity and may remain fertile, which is crucial for astronaut health and future space research.

Title: Effect of spaceflight on Pseudomonas aeruginosa final cell density is modulated by nutrient and oxygen availability.
Keywords: spaceflight, pseudomonas aeruginosa, final cell density
Resumen: This study investigated how microgravity during spaceflight affects the final cell density of *Pseudomonas aeruginosa*, exploring the influence of phosphate concentration, carbon source, oxygen availability, and motility. The results showed that *P. aeruginosa* grown in microgravity reached a higher final cell density compared to controls in normal gravity, but only when culture conditions combined low phosphate concentrations and low oxygen availability. Increasing the availability of either of these nutrients eliminated this difference, and bacterial motility did not show a significant effect. These findings suggest that the differences in bacterial cell density observed in space are due to the interaction between microgravity conditions and the availability of essential growth substrates, indicating that microbes under nutritional limitations could achieve higher cell densities in microgravity. The study also identified discrepancies between cell counting methods, attributing them to post-growth storage conditions.

Title: Spaceflight promotes biofilm formation by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
Keywords: spaceflight promotes biofilm formation pseudomonas aeruginosa
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of spaceflight on Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacterial biofilm formation, a crucial challenge for crewed space missions. Spaceflight was found to increase viable cell numbers, biomass, and biofilm thickness, and to form biofilms with a novel spine and canopy structure never before observed on Earth. These effects were independent of carbon source and phosphate concentrations, but flagella-driven motility was essential for the formation of such architecture. The findings represent the first evidence that spaceflight affects bacterial behaviors at the community level, highlighting the importance of understanding altered human-microbial interactions during space missions.

Title: GeneLab: Omics database for spaceflight experiments
Keywords: genelab omics database for spaceflight experiments
Resumen: NASA GeneLab and its working groups have developed an RNA-seq Consensus Pipeline (RCP) to standardize the analysis of transcriptomic data from space experiments. This pipeline, which includes quality control, read trimming, mapping, quantification, and differential gene expression calculation, seeks to promote data transparency, reproducibility, and reuse. All results processed with the RCP are publicly available through the GeneLab database, facilitating meta-analysis and interpretation of the effects of spaceflight on diverse organisms.

Title: NASA GeneLab: Interfaces for the exploration of space omics data
Keywords: nasa, genelab, interfaces, for, exploration, space
Resumen: NASA's GeneLab database collects, organizes, and facilitates access to omics data (genomic, transcriptomic, proteomic, and metabolomic) from biospecimens exposed to space or simulations, for the study of molecular responses to space environments and to support risk management for human space exploration. The platform includes a novel web interface, the GEODE portal for data entry with accurate metadata (reducing curation effort), and an API designed for visualization of processed data. GeneLab adheres to the FAIR principles, offering open access, DOI identifiers for datasets, version tracking, and promoting community standards for metadata curation. It contains data from a variety of organisms and types of omics experiments, both from space and ground-based experiments, and seeks to maximize the use of these data to generate new discoveries in space biology.

Title: Comprehensive multi-omics analysis reveals mitochondrial stress as a central biological hub for spaceflight impact
Keywords: comprehensive, multi omics, reveals, mitochondrial, stress, central
Resumen: multi-omics and systems biology study analyzed the biomedical profiles of 59 astronauts and hundreds of samples from NASA's GeneLab to determine transcriptomic, proteomic, metabolomic, and epigenetic responses to spaceflight. Analyses revealed significant enrichment in mitochondrial processes, innate immunity, chronic inflammation, cell cycle, circadian rhythm, and olfactory functions. Evidence of altered mitochondrial function and DNA damage was confirmed, indicating mitochondrial stress as a consistent phenotype of spaceflight. The study also found that the effects of spaceflight are more evident in isolated cells than in whole organs, and that the liver experiences more gene and protein expression changes. These findings highlight mitochondrial dysregulation as a key focus of space biology, essential for understanding and countering the risks of long-duration missions.

Title: New Era for Space Life Science: International Standards for Space Omics Processing
Keywords: new era for space life science
Resumen: Human space exploration, with planned missions to the Moon and Mars, faces challenges from stressors such as radiation and microgravity, making it vital to understand their biological effects and develop countermeasures. Although space omics research produces large volumes of data, optimal extraction of scientific discoveries is only possible with greater standardization. To address this need, ISSOP (International Standards for Space Omics Processing), an international consortium of scientists, was established. Its goal is to develop, share, and foster sample processing and metadata standardization across space-based omics experiments globally, facilitating data harmonization and increasing knowledge. The document also details specific challenges facing the community, including logistical and financial constraints, limited crew time, and the critical need for space-specific hardware design and appropriately standardized ground/flight controls to mitigate confounding factors.

Title: Knowledge Network Embedding of Transcryptomic Data from Spaceflown Mice Uncovers Signs and Symptoms Associated with Terrestrial Diseases
Keywords: knowledge, network, embedding, transcriptomic, data, from
Resumen: meta-analysis of six mouse transcriptomic datasets from the NASA GeneLab repository was performed to understand how spaceflight hazards impact human health. These data were integrated with SPOKE (Scalable Precision Medicine Oriented Knowledge Engine), a heterogeneous knowledge graph that connects biological and clinical information from more than 30 databases. This methodology allowed for the identification of critical symptoms and significant physiological changes induced during spaceflight, demonstrating SPOKE's ability to deepen our understanding of space-associated health risks and serve as a bridge to integrate space-based and ground-based biological data.

Title: NASA GeneLab RNA-Seq Consensus Pipeline: Standardized Processing of Short-Read RNA-Seq Data
Keywords: nasa, genelab, rna seq, consensus, pipeline, standardized
Resumen: NASA GeneLab has developed a standardized, consensus-based pipeline for analyzing RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) data from spaceflight-related experiments. This tool seeks to unify data processing, including quality control, read trimming, gene mapping, and quantification, to detect genes with differential expression. By making both the pipeline and the processed data publicly available through the GeneLab database, this promotes transparency, reproducibility, and reusability of information, facilitating interpretation and meta-analysis of the effects of space on organisms.

Title: Spatially resolved multiomics on the neuronal effects induced by spaceflight in mice
Keywords: spatially, resolved, multiomics, neural, induced, spaceflight
Resumen: This study employed an innovative approach integrating single-cell multi-omics and spatial transcriptomics to investigate the impact of spaceflight on the mouse brain. The findings revealed significant alterations in neurogenesis, synaptogenesis, and synaptic transmission in key brain regions such as the cortex, hippocampus, and striatum, along with astrocytic activation and immune dysfunction. At the pathway level, spaceflight-induced changes showed similarities to neurodegenerative disorders, including oxidative stress and protein misfolding. This research provides a crucial foundation for understanding spaceflight-related central nervous system deterioration and developing countermeasures for future long-duration missions.

Title: Biological horizons: pioneering open science in the cosmos
Keywords: biological, horizons, pioneering, open, science, cosmos
Resumen: NASA actively promotes Open Science, with the Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) as a fundamental pillar for making valuable space-based biological and biomedical data accessible and reusable, ranging from model organisms to human astronauts. OSDR standardizes and organizes a wide range of information, including 'omics and physiological changes, facilitating advanced analysis and the use of artificial intelligence. This initiative is reinforced by NASA's Transform to Open Science (TOPS) program, which seeks to promote reproducible research and equity in science, supported by divisions such as the Biological and Physical Sciences divisions and validated by citizen scientists. The effectiveness of this strategy is demonstrated in collections such as "The Second Space Age," which show how collaboration and open access to data drive crucial discoveries for both space exploration and improving health on Earth.

Title: Inspiration4 data access through the NASA Open Science Data Repository
Keywords: inspiration4, data, access, through, nasa, open
Resumen: The increasing accessibility of commercial space travel requires understanding its impact on human health. NASA's Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) offers transparent access to relevant biological studies. In particular, the SpaceX Inspiration 4 (I4) mission collected extensive data from civilian astronauts, including omics and clinical trials, crucial for comprehensive research on space-induced biological responses. These data enable multimodal and longitudinal assessments, facilitating analysis with artificial intelligence and machine learning to yield valuable insights that inform future mission planning and health risk mitigation. This article provides guidance on how to access and analyze I4 mission data at the OSDR, setting a precedent for post-mission health monitoring programs. It is important to note that while the processed data are openly accessible, access to raw data from individual human subjects requires approval from an ethics board.

Title: NASA GeneLab derived microarray studies of Mus musculus and Homo sapiens organisms in altered gravitational conditions.
Keywords: nasa, genelab, derived, microarray, studies, mus
Resumen: This article summarizes a review of microarray gene expression data from NASA GeneLab to understand how altered gravity conditions affect human physiology, a critical challenge for space exploration. The spaceflight environment induces multiple alterations in systems such as the musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, immune, and central nervous systems. Although NASA Open Science data are valuable for identifying and validating mechanisms in mammalian organisms exposed to microgravity, the overlap and reproducibility of differentially expressed genes is limited across species, primarily due to the scarcity of human samples. The review details findings in mice and humans on changes in the nervous system (e.g., neuroinflammation, metabolic alterations) and musculoskeletal system (e.g., cartilage degradation, muscle and bone dysfunction, inhibition of cell proliferation), highlighting the importance of these studies for developing countermeasures and maintaining astronaut health on future missions.

Title: Celebrating 30 years of access to NASA space life sciences data
Keywords: celebrating, years, access, nasa, space, life
Resumen: NASA's space life sciences research programs have generated valuable data for the safe exploration of the cosmos. 2024 marks the 30th anniversary of the Ames Life Sciences Data Archive (ALSDA) and the 10th anniversary of GeneLab, an omics repository. The two merged in 2021 to create NASA's Open Science Data Repository (OSDR), unifying these data resources under a single platform. OSDR promotes open data principles and FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable) to support initiatives such as Thriving in Deep Space (TIDES), which seeks to mitigate health risks on future missions. The OSDR hosts more than 500 studies and registries and is powered by Analysis Working Groups (AWGs) that standardize data, drive discovery, and leverage artificial intelligence to foster a collaborative scientific community, marking a new era for open science in space biology.

Title: Dichotomous effects on lymphatic transport with loss of caveolae in mice.
Keywords: Dichotomous lymphatic transport with loss caveolae
Resumen: The study examined the impact of the absence of caveolae (mediated by caveolin-1) on lymphatic function. Although lymphatic vessel architecture remained unaltered, initial uptake of macromolecules into capillaries was significantly higher, and lymphatic endothelial cell permeability was also increased in caveolin-1-deficient mice. However, downstream transport to lymph nodes was dramatically reduced, which was attributed to a significant decrease in the physical contractility of the collecting lymphatic vessels. It was observed that nitric oxide synthase inhibition could partially restore this contractility ex vivo. These results demonstrate that, while caveolae loss increases lymphatic permeability, it compromises propulsion, revealing their fundamental role in regulating active lymphatic transport.

Title: Fungal diversity differences in the indoor dust microbiome from built environments on Earth and in space.
Keywords: fungal, diversity, differences, indoor, dust, microbiome
Resumen: This study compares the microbial (bacterial and fungal) communities present in dust from homes on Earth and on the International Space Station (ISS), as well as their response to high humidity conditions. Microbiomes were found to differ significantly between the two environments; homes on Earth harbor a greater diversity of fungi (465 OTUs) and bacteria (237 ASVs) than those on the ISS (102 OTUs and 102 ASVs, respectively). The dominant fungal communities also vary. Furthermore, exposure to high humidity caused substantial shifts in fungal composition on the ISS, with *Aspergillus* outcompeting other genera, while terrestrial communities remained more stable. Overall, diversity decreased at both locations with increasing humidity and exposure time. These findings are crucial for future spacecraft design, with the goal of maintaining healthy interior microbiomes that protect crew health, ship integrity, and planetary protection.

Title: Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station
Keywords: predicting, how, varying, moisture, conditions, impact
Resumen: This study investigates microbial growth in spacecraft dust, using samples from the International Space Station, to predict risks in future closed space environments. It was shown that even short exposures to high relative humidity facilitate rapid microbial growth and changes in community composition. Fungal growth was successfully modeled using the "time-of-wetting" framework, showing a significant increase in concentrations and a reduction in fungal diversity with increasing humidity. Although bacterial growth could not be modeled using the same framework, bacterial communities also showed changes and a decrease in diversity with increasing humidity. The results suggest that humidity conditions can predict changes in fungal growth on spacecraft, which is crucial for protecting astronaut health, spacecraft integrity, and planetary protection as human activity in space intensifies.

Title: Aging and estrogen status: A possible endothelium-dependent vascular coupling mechanism in bone remodeling.
Keywords: aging and estrogen status possible endothelium dependent
Resumen: This study investigated the relationship between aging- and menopause-associated bone loss and vascular endothelial dysfunction. The objective was to determine whether modifications in endothelium-dependent vasodilation of the main feeding artery (PNA) of the femur are associated with changes in trabecular bone volume (BV/TV) due to alterations in estrogen in young and old Fischer-344 rats. In young rats, ovariectomy (OVX) decreased vasodilation and BV/TV, effects that were restored with estrogen replacement. In aged rats, OVX did not affect vasodilation or BV/TV, but estrogen replacement significantly improved them. Furthermore, in aged animals with low estrogen levels, vasodilation correlated with BV/TV. These findings demonstrate parallel effects of estrogen on vascular endothelial function and bone volume, suggesting a possible coupling mechanism between endothelium-dependent vasodilation and bone remodeling.

Title: Chronic skeletal unloading of the rat femur: mechanisms and functional consequences of vascular remodeling.
Keywords: chronic skeletal unloading rat femur mechanisms
Resumen: This study investigated the impact of chronic skeletal unloading on bone blood flow and the structure of the main feeding artery (PNA) of the femur in rats. After 7 or 14 days of hindlimb unloading, femoral perfusion was significantly lower and vascular resistance higher in rats unloaded during acute unloading compared with controls. Specifically, PNAs from rats unloaded for 14 days showed reduced intraluminal diameter and thinner medial walls. These structural remodelings in the PNA compensated for the initial decreases in shear stress and circumferential strain, normalizing them. The findings conclude that chronic skeletal unloading decreases the ability to increase blood flow and nutrient delivery to bone and bone marrow during reloading, which is partially attributed to remodeling of bone's resistance vasculature.

Title: Differential effects of aging and exercise on intra-abdominal adipose arteriolar function and blood flow regulation.
Keywords: Differential aging and exercise intra abdominal adipose
Resumen: This study investigated the impact of aging on adipose tissue (AT) blood flow during exercise and how chronic exercise training can mitigate these effects. It was hypothesized that advancing age would cause an increase in AT perfusion during exercise, associated with a decrease in vasoconstriction, and that exercise training would attenuate these alterations. To this end, young and old rats were divided into sedentary and trained groups, and blood flow and vasoconstrictor responses were measured. It was found that sedentary old rats showed increased AT blood flow during exercise, while young rats showed decreased blood flow. This difference was associated with reduced vasoconstriction in the resistance arteries of the AT in aged rats. However, exercise training restored a similar blood flow response between age groups during exercise and improved vasoconstriction in the AT arteries of trained aged rats. The results conclude that aging impairs the ability to increase vascular resistance in the AT during exercise due to decreased vasoconstriction, and that exercise training can improve vasoconstriction and mitigate these age-related alterations in AT blood flow regulation.

Title: Effects of spaceflight and ground recovery on mesenteric artery and vein constrictor properties in mice.
Keywords: spaceflight and ground recovery mesenteric artery
Resumen: This study investigated the hypothesis that mouse mesenteric arteries and veins would exhibit decreased vasoconstrictor responses after spaceflight, contributing to the orthostatic hypotension observed in astronauts. Mesenteric arteries and veins were isolated from female mice that flew on the STS-131, STS-133, and STS-135 missions, and from ground control mice. Vasoconstrictor responses to norepinephrine (NE), potassium chloride (KCl), and caffeine in arteries, and to NE in veins, were measured both immediately postflight and at 1, 5, and 7 days postlanding. The results showed a significant reduction in maximal constriction to NE, KCl, and caffeine in arteries immediately and 1 day after spaceflight. Furthermore, reduced levels of ryanodine receptor-3 (RyR-3) mRNA were found in arteries. Mesenteric veins also showed decreased constriction to NE after flight. The study concludes that the impaired post-spaceflight vasoconstriction occurs through the ryanodine receptor-mediated intracellular Ca2+ release mechanism, and that these vascular changes could compromise blood pressure maintenance in astronauts during orthostatic stress.

Title: Spaceflight-induced alterations in cerebral artery vasoconstrictor, mechanical, and structural properties: Implications for elevated cerebral perfusion and intracranial pressure
Keywords: spaceflight induced, alterations, cerebral, artery, vasoconstrictor, mechanical
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of 13 days of spaceflight on the cerebral arteries of mice to understand the alterations in cerebral blood flow in astronauts. Contrary to the hypothesis, the results showed that spaceflight reduced myogenic vasoconstriction and arterial stiffness, and increased the maximum diameter of cerebral arteries compared to ground-based controls. These modifications suggest a possible increase in cerebral blood flow during spaceflight, which could contribute to the increased intracranial pressure and visual acuity problems observed in astronauts. The research also highlighted that the effects of real microgravity on brain arteries in mice differed from those observed in simulated microgravity models in rats, prompting further comparative study in mice.

Title: Exercise training increases regional bone and marrow blood flow during exercise.
Keywords: exercise, training, augmentations, regional, bone, and
Resumen: A study in rats investigated the effects of chronic treadmill exercise training on blood flow distribution in hindlimb bone and marrow. Trained rats (ET) showed increased blood flow during exercise in 7 of 9 bone regions tested, compared to only 3 of 9 in sedentary rats (SED). Although training did not appear to dramatically increase overall bone blood flow capacity, it did promote more widespread bone perfusion during physical activity, suggesting a potential benefit to bone integrity.

Title: Effects of Skeletal Unloading on the Vasomotor Properties of the Rat Femur Principal Nutrient Artery
Keywords: skeletal, unloading, vasomotor, properties, rat, femur
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of disuse (simulated by hindlimb unloading in rats) on the vasoconstrictor and vasodilator properties of the femoral main feeding artery (PNA), the major conduit of blood flow to the femur. Researchers sought to understand why disuse and spaceflight cause cardiovascular deconditioning and bone loss, with a reduction in bone perfusion. The results indicated that the vasoconstrictor capacity of the PNA was not increased in disused rats, but endothelium-dependent vasodilation (responsiveness to acetylcholine and flow-mediated vasodilation) was attenuated. Endothelium-independent vasodilation showed no changes. They concluded that the decrease in bone perfusion and increase in vascular resistance associated with disuse were not due to increased vasoconstriction, but rather to a reduction in endothelium-dependent vasodilation.

Title: Type 2 diabetes alters bone and marrow blood flow and vascular control mechanisms in the ZDF rat.
Keywords: type diabetes alters bone and marrow
Resumen: This study investigated whether skeletal vascular control mechanisms are altered during the progression of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in Zucker diabetic fatty (ZDF) rats, potentially affecting bone health. The responses of the main feeding artery of the femur to vasodilators and vasoconstrictors in vitro, and regional vascular perfusion and conductance of bone and marrow in vivo were assessed in pre-diabetic, short-term, and long-term diabetic rats. Few changes in vasomotor responses were found in the pre-diabetic and short-term diabetic stages. However, in rats with long-term diabetes, endothelium-dependent and -independent vasodilation was reduced, vasoconstriction was enhanced, and regional vascular perfusion and conductance in bone and marrow were significantly decreased. These findings suggest that profound impairment of bone circulation may contribute to the osteopenia observed in long bones with chronic T2DM.

Title: Spaceflight on the Bion-M1 biosatellite alters cerebral artery vasomotor and mechanical properties in mice
Keywords: spaceflight, bion m1, biosatellite, alters, cerebral, artery
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of 30 days of spaceflight on the functional, mechanical, and structural properties of cerebral arteries from C57BL/6N mice. The results showed that cerebral arteries from spaceflight mice exhibited decreased vasoconstriction (both through Ca2+ voltage-gated mechanisms and thromboxane A2 receptors), attenuated endothelium-dependent vasodilation, and a lower pressure-diameter relationship. No differences were found in elastin or collagen content or arterial wall structure. The findings suggest that microgravity attenuates vasoconstrictive and vasodilatory properties, which could limit vascular control of cerebral perfusion or affect the distribution of cerebral blood flow during stress.

Title: Apollo Lunar Astronauts Show Higher Cardiovascular Disease Mortality: Possible Deep Space Radiation Effects on the Vascular Endothelium
Keywords: apollo, lunar, astronauts, show, higher, cardiovascular
Resumen: recent study investigated mortality rates from cardiovascular disease (CVD), cancer, and accidents in astronauts, dividing them into three groups: those who had never flown, those who had only flown in low Earth orbit (LEO), and the Apollo lunar astronauts, the only humans to travel beyond Earth's magnetosphere. The findings revealed that the Apollo lunar astronauts had a CVD mortality rate 4–5 times higher than that of non-flying astronauts and those in LEO. To explore the underlying mechanism, a secondary study in mice demonstrated that simulated space irradiation induces sustained vascular endothelial cell dysfunction, a known risk factor for arterial occlusive disease. These results suggest that exposure to deep space radiation could significantly increase the risk of CVD for astronauts, exceeding previous estimates.

Title: Effects of age and exercise training on coronary microvascular smooth muscle phenotype and function
Keywords: age and exercise training coronary microvascular
Resumen: Aging impairs coronary arteriolar contractile function and causes vascular smooth muscle to shift toward a secretory and proliferative phenotype, contributing to impaired coronary blood flow response. A study in rats demonstrated that exercise training in old age reverses this contractile dysfunction in arterioles and restores a more youthful smooth muscle phenotype.

Title: Impact of Spaceflight and Artificial Gravity on the Mouse Retina: Biochemical and Proteomic Analysis.
Keywords: Impact spaceflight and artificial gravity mouse
Resumen: Astronauts have reported visual impairment during and after space missions. To investigate the causes, a study examined the ocular tissue of mice following a 35-day flight on the International Space Station. Mice exposed to microgravity showed significant apoptosis in retinal vascular endothelial cells and alterations in the expression of proteins related to cell death, repair, inflammation, and metabolic stress. The application of artificial gravity during spaceflight mitigated these changes. These results suggest that spaceflight induces retinal damage that could affect visual acuity and the integrity of the blood-retinal barrier, increasing the risk of degeneration, and that artificial gravity offers protection against these effects.

Title: Simulated microgravity induces regionally distinct neurovascular and structural remodeling of skeletal muscle and cutaneous arteries in the rat
Keywords: simulated, microgravity, induces, regionally, distinct, neurovascular
Resumen: The study investigated the effects of hindlimb deconditioning (HU) on the structure, function, and sympathetic innervation of small arteries in rats. HU was found to induce contrasting structural and functional adaptations in forelimb and hindlimb muscular arteries: forelimb arteries increased in diameter, the sural artery decreased in diameter, and the saphenous artery was unaffected. Maximal contractile responses to norepinephrine and serotonin increased in forelimb muscular arteries but decreased in hindlimb arteries, with no changes in cutaneous arteries. The saphenous artery showed increased sensitivity to vasoconstrictors, possibly due to a reduction in its sympathetic innervation density, which also impaired sympathetically induced arterial vasoconstriction. These results suggest diverse vascular adaptations to simulated microgravity.

Title: Spaceflight decelerates the epigenetic clock orchestrated with a global alteration in DNA methylome and transcriptome in the mouse retina
Keywords: spaceflight, decelerates, epigenetic, clock, orchestrated, with
Resumen: recent study investigated whether long-duration spaceflight induces epigenomic and transcriptomic reprogramming or alters the epigenetic clock in the retina, due to the ocular abnormalities observed in astronauts. Using retinas from mice deployed to the International Space Station for 37 days, the researchers found that a large number of genes were differentially methylated, and that spaceflight caused global hypomethylation. The retinal epigenetic clock of the space mice was significantly decelerated. Although to a lesser extent, differentially expressed genes were also identified, and alterations were observed in several biological pathways related to retinal diseases such as macular degeneration, as well as in cellular connectivity and inflammation. These findings demonstrate that spaceflight impacts the retina at the epigenomic and transcriptomic levels, which could contribute to the etiology of ocular disorders among astronauts.

Title: Development of otolith receptors in Japanese quail.
Keywords: development, otolith, receptors, japanese, quail
Resumen: This study examined the morphological development of otolithic vestibular receptors in quail, a species that requires a rapidly functioning vestibular system at hatching. The investigation focused on epithelial growth, hair cell density and polarization, and afferent nerve innervation. The otolithic maculae showed exponential growth of their epithelial area until day 7 post-hatch (P7), with an increase in hair cell density dependent on their location. Stereocilia polarization began early (embryonic day E8), with the formation of investment zones. Afferent innervation progressed from small fibers with growth cones (E6) to the formation of bouton terminals (E8), the appearance of goblet terminals (E10), and complete maturation of goblet and dimorphic terminals (E12–E14). In adults, goblet and dimorphic afferents were found mainly in the estrola, whereas bouton fibers were located in the extrastrola, exhibiting different innervation complexities. The study used scanning electron microscopy, immunohistochemistry, and neural tracing for comprehensive morphological characterization.

Title: Spatial and temporal characteristics of vestibular convergence
Keywords: Spatial and temporal characteristics, vestibular convergence
Resumen: This study investigated the convergence of signals from the semicircular canals and otolith organs onto neurons of the vestibular nuclear complex in the brainstem of awake pigeons, specifically those unrelated to eye movement. Using discrete rotational and translational stimuli, the response components of the neurons were characterized. It was found that although signals from the canals and otoliths converged and exhibited properties similar to individual afferent responses, neither a single component nor a simple linear combination of the two was sufficient to predict net neuronal responses during the combined stimulation. This suggests a complex integration of vestibular information in the brainstem.

Title: Bone remodeling is regulated by inner ear vestibular signals
Keywords: bone remodeling regulated inner ear vestibular
Resumen: This study investigated the role of the CaV1.2 calcium channel in regulating bone remodeling in the auditory ossicles and otic capsule, structures essential for hearing and balance. Decreased osteoprotegerin (OPG) expression in these areas is known to contribute to otosclerosis, a common cause of deafness. The researchers used Col2a1-Cre;CaV1.2TS mutant mice with increased CaV1.2 channel function to direct increased Ca2+ signaling in osteochondral/osteoblastic progenitors in the ear. The results showed that these mice developed osteopetrosis in the ear bones, exhibiting fewer osteoclasts and elevated OPG expression, suggesting both anti-catabolic and anabolic effects. Furthermore, they exhibited hearing loss and balance defects. These findings confirm that CaV1.2-mediated Ca2+ influx promotes OPG expression, influencing ear bone remodeling and auditory and vestibular functions, offering new insights into the pathological mechanisms of otosclerosis and potential therapeutic strategies.

Title: Simulated Microgravity Enhances Oligodendrocyte Mitochondrial Function and Lipid Metabolism
Keywords: Simulated microgravity enhances oligodendrocyte mitochondrial function
Resumen: This study investigates the impact of simulated microgravity (sim-Î¼G) on the energy and lipid metabolism of oligodendrocytes (OLs), myelin-forming cells in the central nervous system. Comparing cells exposed to sim-Î¼G with those exposed to Earth's gravity (1G) using a 3D clinostat, results revealed increased mitochondrial respiration, glycolysis, and Krebs cycle flux in OLs. Furthermore, a significant increase in the synthesis and secretion of fatty acids and complex lipids, essential components of myelin, was observed. These findings suggest that sym-Î¼G preserves and potentially enhances metabolic reactions necessary for membrane synthesis and myelinogenesis, opening new avenues for understanding the brain in health and disease.

Title: Human Neural Stem Cells Flown into Space Proliferate and Generate Young Neurons
Keywords: human neural stem cells flown into
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of the space environment on human neural stem cells (NSCs) for 39.3 days on the International Space Station. NSCs were shown to proliferate in space and maintain their specific markers. Upon return to Earth, they exhibited increased oxygen consumption and glycolysis, and retained the ability to differentiate into immature neurons with characteristic electrophysiological properties. These findings highlight that the space environment increases the proliferation and energy requirements of NSCs, which is crucial for designing measures to minimize health risks associated with long-duration spaceflight, such as intracranial pressure syndrome and visual impairment.

Title: Delayed Maturation of Oligodendrocyte Progenitors by Microgravity: Implications for Multiple Sclerosis and Space Flight
Keywords: delayed, maturation, oligodendrocyte, progenitors, microgravity, implications
Resumen: This text is a correction to an open-access scientific article, in which the authors correct an error in Figure 10. The bar graph legend incorrectly showed "Fer" (ferritin) instead of "Tf" (transferrin), even though the text and figure caption correctly referred to transferrin. The correction, which does not alter the data or scientific conclusions of the study, details the expression and co-expression of Tf and GPDH in GC-OLPs and SPC-OLPs.

Title: Space Microgravity Alters Neural Stem Cell Division: Implications for Brain Cancer Research on Earth and in Space
Keywords: space, microgravity, alters, neural, stem, cell
Resumen: This study investigates the impact of space microgravity (SPC-µG) on human neural stem cells (NSCs), which are critical for the neurological and cognitive health of astronauts. The research reveals that exposure to SPC-µG and its secretome significantly increases the incidence of abnormal cell divisions (ACD), including incomplete cell division (ICD) and multiple daughter cell division (MDCD), compared to ground-based control NSCs. Cells exposed to SPC-µG, especially up to two weeks after spaceflight, were found to show a higher number of ICD and MDCD cases. These findings are crucial to understanding the detrimental effects of prolonged space travel, the potential implications for neurological health and carcinogenic susceptibility, emphasizing the need to develop preventive measures.

Title: Oligodendrocyte Progenitors Display Enhanced Proliferation and Autophagy after Space Flight
Keywords: Oligodendrocyte progenitors display enhanced proliferation and
Resumen: This study examined the behavior of human oligodendrocyte progenitors (OLPs) following exposure to prolonged space missions, investigating the causes of intracranial hypertension (ICP) and visually impaired intracranial pressure (VIIP) in astronauts. Induced pluripotent stem cell-derived OLPs were flown to the International Space Station for 38 days. The results showed that most space-borne OLPs divided more than ground-based controls, although a subpopulation exhibited significantly increased autophagic cell death. Proteomic analysis of the secretome of space-borne OLPs revealed a notable enrichment of the stress protein HSP-90Î² and SPARC, the latter known to induce endoplasmic reticulum stress and autophagy. The findings suggest that the regulation of these two proteins could be crucial for modulating cell proliferation and autophagy, offering a path to mitigate ICP and VIIP during and after space missions.

Title: Metabolomics profile of the secretome of space-flown oligodendrocytes.
Keywords: metabolomics, profile, secretome, space flown, oligodendrocytes
Resumen: study investigated the impact of space microgravity on the metabolic profile and energetic status of oligodendrocyte progenitor cells (OLPs), responsible for forming myelin, in relation to the neurological consequences of prolonged space missions. Using human OLPs launched to the International Space Station, increased glutamate and energy metabolism was observed while in space, as well as the identification of gravity-sensitive metabolites. Upon return to Earth, the OLPs showed increased mitochondrial respiration and glycolysis, indicating an elevated energy demand. These results provide key insights into the energetic state of OLPs in and after space, suggesting potential therapeutic targets to prevent neurological deterioration during future space missions.

Title: Metabolomic profiling of the secretome from human neural stem cells flown into space.
Keywords: Metabolomic profiling secretome from human neural
Resumen: This study analyzed the effect of microgravity on neural stem cells (NSCs) flown to the International Space Station for three days. Metabolome analysis of the cells' secretome revealed increased glycolysis, with elevated levels of pyruvate and glycerate, and activated catabolism of branched-chain amino acids and glutamine. NSCs in space also showed increased NADH synthesis and spermidine formation, suggesting greater energetic demands. The results indicate that the microgravity environment increases energy production, primarily through the tricarboxylic acid cycle, and triggers stress response mechanisms as a means of cellular adaptation.

Title: Strategies, research priorities, and challenges for the exploration of space beyond low-Earth orbit
Keywords: strategies, research, priorities, and, challenges, for
Resumen: This text presents a roadmap to address critical research gaps related to human behavior and performance in altered gravity and space, essential for future long-duration space missions to the Moon and Mars. It underscores that the stressors of spaceflight affect the brain and behavior, posing significant risks to mission success and astronaut safety. The roadmap prioritizes understanding neurobehavioral challenges, considering sex as a biological variable, using integrative omics technologies, and studying the neural representation of gravity. It proposes the need for tailored countermeasures and interdisciplinary collaborations, highlighting that this research not only mitigates risks for astronauts but can also benefit the Earth-bound population. The document details the process of creating the roadmap through broad collaboration (such as ESA's SciSpacE initiative) and mentions the observed effects on brain function and performance, emphasizing the need for longer-term studies and targeted cognitive assessments.

Title: Spaceflight Induces Specific Alterations in the Proteomes of Arabidopsis
Keywords: spaceflight, induces, specific, alterations, proteomes, arabidopsis
Resumen: This study examined the response of *Arabidopsis thaliana* seedlings grown for 12 days on the International Space Station (ISS) to the spaceflight environment. Using large-scale iTRAQ proteomic procedures on leaves and roots preserved in RNAlater, researchers identified hundreds of proteins with statistically significant differential abundance compared to ground-based controls. Specifically, 256 leaf and 358 root proteins showed changes, indicating measurable, organ-specific proteomic responses to spaceflight. Comparison with transcriptomic data showed a positive but limited relationship between proteome and transcriptome regulation. The study also validated the use of RNAlater preservation for large-scale proteomic analysis of spaceflight samples.

Title: The effect of spaceflight on the gravity-sensing auxin gradient of roots: GFP reporter gene microscopy on orbit.
Keywords: spaceflight, gravity sensing, auxin, gradient, roots, gfp
Resumen: This study investigated the role of gravity in the establishment of the auxin-mediated gravity-sensing system in the primary roots of *Arabidopsis thaliana*. Using plants grown on the International Space Station and on the ground, the researchers monitored the distribution of auxin and cytokinins using fluorescent reporters. The results showed that the distribution of the auxin gradient at the root tip was identical in space and on Earth, confirming that this key system for gravity signaling is independent of gravity. However, differences in cytokinin distribution were observed between plants grown in space and on the ground, suggesting that spaceflight could influence cytokinin-related processes.

Title: Skewing in Arabidopsis roots involves disparate environmental signaling pathways.
Keywords: skewing, arabidopsis, roots, involves, nonsense, environmental
Resumen: This study investigated skewing and waving patterns of root growth in *Arabidopsis thaliana*, with the aim of identifying genes associated with skewing. By analyzing transcriptomic data from two ecotypes (WS and Col-0) grown under different tilting angles, 11 candidate genes were identified whose expression is associated with root skewing behavior. These genes are involved in cellular processes such as sugar transport, salt and hormone signaling, and cell wall organization, suggesting a role in signaling and sensing, rather than in the physical restructuring of the root. Future work is needed to elucidate their potential function.

Title: Data for characterization of SALK_084889, a T-DNA insertion line of Arabidopsis thaliana
Keywords: data for characterization salk 084889 t dna
Resumen: This article reports the identification of T-DNA insertion sites in the 3â€² UTR regions of the DREB2A gene and the LOX1 gene promoter in the genome of the Arabidopsis mutant line SALK_084889, verified by DNA PCR and Sanger sequencing. The expression levels of DREB2A and LOX1 were analyzed using qPCR, and drought and heat tolerance were compared between the mutant line and the wild type. The results indicate that DREB2A expression in SALK_084889 does not decrease under normal conditions but can be affected in roots under drought, whereas LOX1 is significantly downregulated in roots and shoots under all conditions tested. These original data are valuable for the genetic and mutation analysis of DREB2A and LOX1.

Title: Genetic dissection of the Arabidopsis spaceflight transcriptome: Are some responses dispensable for the physiological adaptation of plants to spaceflight?
Keywords: genetic, dissection, arabidopsis, spaceflight, transcriptome, are
Resumen: The CARA experiment, conducted on the International Space Station, investigated the adaptation of *Arabidopsis* plants to the space environment, focusing on whether the observed transcriptomic responses are necessary or if some are non-adaptive and costly. Comparing root tips of two *Arabidopsis* ecotypes (Col-0 and WS) and a Col-0 PhyD mutant, the study found that the PhyD mutant and the WS genotype exhibited significantly reduced transcriptomic responses in space under ambient light. This suggests that manipulating a single gene or the genotype can enhance adaptation by reducing the physiological cost. Furthermore, the space lighting environment influenced the magnitude of these responses, indicating that genetic and local habitat manipulations could substantially reduce the metabolic cost of adapting to spaceflight. The study raises the possibility that, in an environment outside their evolutionary history, plants may activate non-adaptive responses that could be genetically eliminated without compromising survival.

Title: Phenotypic characterization of an Arabidopsis T-DNA insertion line SALK_063500
Keywords: phenotypic characterization, arabidopsis, dna, insertion, line
Resumen: This article reports the identification of a homozygous lethal line with a T-DNA insertion in the coding region of the At1G05290 gene in the plant *Arabidopsis thaliana* (line SALK_063500). The T-DNA insertion is located in exon 1, but homozygous alleles could not be obtained. Heterozygous SALK_063500 plants displayed an aberrant siliqua phenotype, attributed to a reduction in pollen tube germination rate. These original data highlight the role of AT1G05290 in pollen development and provide insights into the mechanisms of male sterility in plants.

Title: Utilization of singleâ€šÃ„Ãªimage normalized difference vegetation index (SIâ€šÃ„ÃªNDVI) for early plant stress detection
Keywords: utilization, single, image, normalized, difference, vegetation
Resumen: This paper describes the development and validation of a single-image normalized difference vegetation index (SI-NDVI) imaging system for the early and cost-effective detection of plant stress under controlled conditions, such as indoor agriculture. Unlike traditional NDVI, which uses red light, SI-NDVI compares leaf reflectance in the blue and near-infrared (NIR) light spectra. The system uses a commercial camera modified with a special filter to capture both spectra in a single image, simplifying the process and reducing costs. Images are analyzed with open-source software and spreadsheets to generate qualitative (false-color images) and quantitative (graphs) representations. SI-NDVI was shown to detect stress in *Arabidopsis thaliana* seedlings and *Eruca sativa* plants within 15 minutes of stressor application (salinity, ammonium nitrate), well before it was visible to the naked eye. This technology offers a more accessible, cost-effective, and user-friendly tool than traditional NDVI or hyperspectral methods for monitoring plant health.

Title: Comparing RNA-Seq and microarray gene expression data in two zones of the Arabidopsis root apex relevant to spaceflight.
Keywords: comparing rna seq and microarray gene expression
Resumen: This study examined the feasibility of analyzing transcriptomes from tiny sections of the root tip of *Arabidopsis thaliana*—a crucial region for environmental sensing and of interest in spatial experiments—by comparing RNA sequencing (RNA-Seq) with microarrays. Roots were sectioned into two regions to compare differential gene expression. Both methods were found to be applicable to small samples, identifying 4,180 genes with differential expression between regions. RNA-Seq detected 771 unique genes and 19 novel regions not found by microarrays, but the microarrays identified spaceflight-relevant genes that RNA-Seq missed. The research concludes that root tip subsections can be used for transcriptome analysis with either technique, although RNA-Seq may miss some gene expression changes important for the space environment, suggesting the need to improve the techniques for small and rare samples.

Title: Spaceflight-induced alternative splicing during seedling development in Arabidopsis thaliana.
Keywords: spaceflight induced, alternative, splicing, during, seedling, development
Resumen: This study investigates the role of alternative splicing (AS) in the molecular adaptation of plants to the spaceflight environment. By analyzing RNA-seq data from *Arabidopsis thaliana* seedlings grown on the International Space Station and ground-based controls, significant differences in AS were detected between the two conditions. This research provides the first evidence that AS plays a role in the molecular processes of physiological adaptation to the space environment in higher eukaryotic organisms and is the first observation of spaceflight-induced AS at the transcriptome-wide level in any organism.

Title: The Plant Health Monitoring System of the EDEN ISS Space Greenhouse in Antarctica during the 2018 experiment phase
Keywords: plant, health, monitoring, system, eden, iss
Resumen: The EDEN ISS is a space-analog greenhouse located in Antarctica, designed to research plant breeding for future human space exploration missions. During its 2018 operating season, 26 different types of crops were grown on a 12.5 m² cultivation area, producing over 268 kg of edible biomass, with cucumbers, lettuce, leafy greens, and tomatoes as the main crops. The facility features advanced subsystems for environmental and nutrient control, and its unique location in Antarctica makes it a valuable testbed for space cultivation technologies and procedures. The detailed biomass production data generated by this project are critical for improving space greenhouse models and crop selection that will help reduce resupply mass on future space missions.

Title: Root skewing-associated genes impact the spaceflight response of Arabidopsis thaliana.
Keywords: root, skewing associated, genes, impact, spaceflight, response
Resumen: The APEX-03-2 study investigated the contribution of the SPIRAL1 (SPR1) and SKU5 genes to root behavior and gene expression in Arabidopsis under microgravity. Although previously thought to be gravity-dependent, root skewing occurs in space, suggesting that root morphology and cell wall remodeling are key to physiological adaptation. SPR1 is involved in directional cell expansion and microtubule dynamics, while SKU5 is a protein anchored to the plasma membrane and cell wall, linked to signaling stress responses. *spr1* and *sku5* mutants exhibited markedly different twisting behaviors and gene expression patterns in space. *spr1* mutants showed fewer differentially expressed genes than the wild type, suggesting that the loss of SPR1 positively impacts adaptation to spaceflight. In contrast, *sku5* mutants had significantly more differentially expressed genes, indicating a more complex stress response and the importance of SKU5 function for proper adaptation. Developmental age also had a significant influence, especially in *sku5* plants. These findings demonstrate that the torsional pathways represented by SKU5 and SPR1 make unique and opposing contributions to spatial physiological adaptation.

Title: Articular cartilage and sternal fibrocartilage respond differently to extended microgravity.
Keywords: Articular cartilage and sternal fibrocartilage respond
Resumen: study investigated the effects of 30 days of microgravity in mice, observing pathological changes in articular cartilage (AC) and sternal cartilage (SC). The AC of in-flight mice showed evidence of degradation, with loss of proteoglycans and reduced matrix protein expression, in addition to surface damage and osteophyte formation. In contrast, the SC showed no signs of deterioration or changes in gene expression suggestive of degradation. The findings indicate that the AC, a weight-bearing tissue, is negatively affected by microgravity unloading, while the SC, which receives a constant minimal load (from breathing), is not. This suggests that the response of cartilage tissue to microgravity depends on the biomechanical environment to which it is normally adapted, and it is proposed that maintaining physiological loading on the AC during spaceflight could minimize its damage.

Title: Host-microbe interactions in microgravity: assessment and implications.
Keywords: host microbe, interactions, microgravity, assessment, and, implications
Resumen: Spaceflight imposes unique stresses such as microgravity, which alters host-microbiome interactions crucial to health. Microgravity affects the physiology and genetics of plants and animals, causing effects ranging from bone loss in humans to increased susceptibility to pathogens. Although general effects have been observed in hosts, the impact on their microbiomes is still under investigation. Microgravity has been shown to increase the virulence and resistance of some pathogens such as Salmonella by altering their gene expression, although decreased virulence has been observed in other cases. Research into these phenomena is conducted both in realistic microgravity environments and in Earth-based simulations, such as rotating-wall bioreactors. Understanding microbial adaptation and maintaining homeostasis between humans, plants, and their microbiomes is essential for future long-duration space travel.

Title: Environmental cues and symbiont microbe-associated molecular patterns function in concert to drive the daily remodeling of the crypt-cell brush border of the Euprymna scolopes light organ
Keywords: environmental cues and symbiont microbe associated molecular
Resumen: The text describes how the microbiota influences the brush border microarchitecture of host epithelial tissues, using the squid-Vibrio symbiotic system. A daily effacement of microvilli is observed at dawn, coinciding with the expulsion of symbionts, and a subsequent repolarization with an increase in microvilli density. The investigation reveals that effacement is triggered by an environmental light signal and occurs independently of the presence of symbionts. Furthermore, the increase in microvillar density and repolarization after dawn require the presence of symbionts and are specifically induced by host exposure to phosphorylated lipid A from symbiont cells. These findings demonstrate that the brush border is shaped by a combination of environmental and microbial cues, with microbe-associated molecular patterns playing a crucial role in regulating its microarchitecture.

Title: Symbiotic organs shaped by distinct modes of genome evolution in cephalopods.
Keywords: symbiotic, organs, shaped, distinct, modes, genome
Resumen: Analysis of the genome of the Hawaiian squid *Euprymna scolopes* reveals extensive genomic reorganization in cephalopods and provides new insights into the evolution of specialized symbiotic organs. The two symbiotic organs of *E. scolopes*, the light organ (LO) and the accessory nidamental gland (ANG), were found to have arisen through distinct evolutionary mechanisms; the LO evolved by subfunctionalization of ocular genes, whereas the ANG was enriched with species-specific orphan genes.
