Genes associated with these symbiotic organs showed signs of recent duplications, unlike the older genes related to the brain and eyes.

Title: Modeled microgravity alters lipopolysaccharide and outer membrane vesicle production of the beneficial symbiont Vibrio fischeri
Keywords: Modeled microgravity alters lipopolysaccharide and outer
Resumen: This study examines the impact of simulated microgravity on the symbiotic bacterium *Vibrio fischeri*, demonstrating a significant increase in lipopolysaccharide (LPS) release and outer membrane vesicle (OMV) production. Although bacterial motility is not directly altered, simulated microgravity increases LPS release even in motility-deficient mutants. Furthermore, *V. fischeri* cells exposed to these conditions show increased susceptibility to membrane-disrupting agents, suggesting changes in membrane integrity. These results indicate that the physiology of symbiotic microbes can be altered under microgravity conditions, which could have important implications for host health during spaceflight.

Title: Emergence of novel cephalopod gene regulation and expression through large-scale genome reorganization
Keywords: emergence, novel, cephalopod, gene, regulation, and
Resumen: This study explores the genomic basis of the complex behaviors and large nervous systems of coleoid cephalopods (squid, cuttlefish, octopus) using the squid *Euprymna scolopes*. The research reveals extensive genomic restructuring in these animals, resulting in the emergence of hundreds of clusters of unique, tightly linked genes, termed microsyntenies. These novel microsyntenies form topological compartments with distinct regulatory structures and contribute to complex expression patterns. Microsyntenies associated with cephalopodal innovations (MACIs) enriched in nervous system expression were identified, suggesting that they were fundamental to their evolution. The study also noted larger and more variable topologically associated domains (TADs) in squid compared to humans, and proposes that microsynthetic profiling is key to understanding cephalopod innovations.

Title: Modeled microgravity alters apoptotic gene expression and caspase activity in the squid-vibrio symbiosis
Keywords: modeled microgravity alters apoptotic gene expression
Resumen: This study investigated the impact of simulated microgravity on beneficial microbe-induced apoptosis using the symbiosis between the bobtail squid (*Euprymna scolopes*) and the bacterium *Vibrio fischeri*. Host genome and transcriptome analysis revealed that microgravity altered the expression of extrinsic and intrinsic apoptosis genes, leading to earlier and higher activation, particularly of caspases, whose activity was shown to be increased. These effects could be mitigated by caspase inhibitors, suggesting that perturbations in apoptosis signaling can be controlled, with implications for maintaining animal-microbial homeostasis during spaceflight.

Title: In vitro generation of mechanically functional cartilage grafts based on adult human stem cells and 3D-woven poly(epsilon-caprolactone) scaffolds
Keywords: vitro, generation, mechanically, functional, cartilage, grafts
Resumen: This study explored functional cartilage tissue engineering in vitro using human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs) combined with three-dimensionally woven poly(Îµ-caprolactone) (PCL) scaffolds. The objectives included achieving cartilage-like mechanical properties, demonstrating cartilage formation by hMSCs on the scaffolds, and analyzing the impact of scaffold structure (loosely woven vs. tightly woven), culture vessel (static vs. rocking bioreactor), and medium composition. The results showed that constructs with tightly woven PCL scaffolds cultured in bioreactors achieved aggregate modules close to normal articular cartilage. The bioreactors produced constructs with higher collagen content and a more homogeneous matrix, while chondrogenic additives increased glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) and early collagen II messenger RNA expression, especially without serum. Chondrogenesis was verified histologically by rounded cells within a hyaline matrix that immunostained for type II but not type I collagen. These findings demonstrate the feasibility of engineering functional cartilage tissue from hMSCs and 3D woven PCL scaffolds.

Title: Chondrogenesis and mineralization during in vitro culture of human mesenchymal stem cells on three-dimensional woven scaffolds
Keywords: Chondrogenesis and mineralization during vitro culture
Resumen: This study investigates the use of human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs) on three-dimensional (3D) polycaprolactone (PCL) scaffolds for skeletal tissue engineering, evaluating how culture duration and medium additives influence the structure, composition, mechanical, and molecular properties of the generated tissues. Bone marrow hMSCs were seeded on PCL scaffolds and cultured for 1, 21, or 45 days, under chondrogenic or osteogenic conditions. In chondrogenic medium, cartilage tissue was formed by day 21, with hypertrophic mineralization observed at the interface with the scaffold by day 45. Glycosaminoglycan, hydroxyproline, and calcium contents, as well as alkaline phosphatase activity, depended on culture duration and additives, showing significant interactive effects. The 45-day-old constructs exhibited mechanical properties similar to native articular cartilage and gene expression characteristic of chondrogenesis and endochondral bone formation. In contrast, the osteogenic medium produced limited osteogenesis. These findings suggest that long-term culture of hMSCs on 3D scaffolds under chondrogenic conditions results in chondrogenesis and regional mineralization, which is relevant for graft development in the repair of osteochondral defects.

Title: Microbiome metadata standards: Report of the National Microbiome Data Collaborative's workshop and follow-on activities.
Keywords: microbiome, metadata, standards, report, national, data
Resumen: This text is a correction to a scientific article entitled "Microbiome metadata standards: report of the National Microbiome Data Collaborative's workshop and follow-on activities" by Vangay et al., published in the journal mSystems. The correction specifies how the article's authorship and affiliation should be read. This is an open access article under a Creative Commons license, provided by the American Society for Microbiology (ASM) and hosted on an official U.S. government website.

Title: Spaceflight alters host-gut microbiota interactions
Keywords: spaceflight, alters, host gut, microbiota, interactions
Resumen: This study investigates the impact of spaceflight on mammals, focusing on interactions between the gut microbiome and the host. Using a multi-omics approach in mice, the gut microbiota and gene expression in the colon and liver were analyzed after 29 and 56 days in space. The study revealed significant changes in 44 microbial species, such as a reduction in bile acid and butyrate-metabolizing bacteria (*Extibacter muris*, *Dysosmobacter welbionis*), and an overrepresentation of genes related to fatty acid and bile metabolism, extracellular matrix interactions, and antibiotic resistance. At the host level, corresponding alterations in bile acid and energy metabolism, as well as immune suppression, were observed. These results imply that interactions at the gut-microbiome interface contribute to spaceflight-associated pathologies and are crucial for human health and the viability of long-duration space missions.

Title: Asparagine biosynthesis as a mechanism of increased host lethality induced by Serratia marcescens in simulated microgravity environments
Keywords: asparagine biosynthesis mechanism increased host lethality
Resumen: This study investigates how simulated microgravity (LSMMG) increases the virulence of the opportunistic bacterium *Serratia marcescens*, a pathogen relevant to astronaut health. The findings show that LSMMG increases asparagine uptake and synthesis in *S. marcescens*, leading to a significant increase in host (*Drosophila melanogaster*) mortality. This effect is reproduced by adding aspartate and glutamine, precursors of asparagine, and is associated with overexpression of the *asnB* gene (asparagine synthase B) in the bacterium. Although accelerated bacterial growth contributes, the combination of aspartate and glutamine is required for maximum lethality and overexpression of key genes in the asparagine pathway. Furthermore, L-asparaginase, which breaks down asparagine, was identified as able to mitigate LSMMG-induced virulence, offering a potential countermeasure strategy. The research highlights the importance of the asparagine utilization pathway for understanding the molecular mechanisms of virulence in microgravity and developing solutions.

Title: Comparative genomic analysis of Cohnella hashimotonis sp. nov. isolated from the International Space Station.
Keywords: comparative genomic cohnella hashimotonis nov isolated
Resumen: A new bacterial strain, F6_2S_P_1T, was isolated in April 2018 from the wall behind the Waste Hygiene Compartment aboard the International Space Station (ISS). Through genomic analysis, it was identified as a novel species within the genus Cohnella, and the name *Cohnella hashimotonis* was proposed. This discovery, part of the Microbial Tracking mission, highlights the importance of studying the ISS microbiome for astronaut health and the development of biotechnological applications in future space habitats. Complete genome sequences of related Cohnella type strains have also been generated for characterization.

Title: Characterization of metagenome-assembled genomes from the International Space Station
Keywords: characterization, metagenome assembled, genomes, from, international, space
Resumen: This study generated and analyzed 46 metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) from 21 environmental samples from the International Space Station (ISS) to investigate microbial diversity and its evolution under spaceflight conditions. Eighteen bacterial species were identified, including one new genus/species and one new bacterial species, and fungal genomes were assembled from ISS metagenomes for the first time. The analyses revealed ISS-specific evolution in some bacterial species, enrichment of cell membrane genes, and the characterization of antimicrobial resistance and virulence genes, which are more prevalent in certain strains. Genetic variations observed in strains such as Pantoea/Kalamiella suggest their susceptibility to microgravity. These reconstructed genomes will facilitate future studies of microbial evolution in space.

Title: Biocontrol in built environments to reduce pathogen exposure and infection risk.
Keywords: biocontrol, built, environments, reduce, pathogen, exposure
Resumen: The built environment harbors diverse microbial communities, including antibiotic-resistant pathogens that pose infection risks. Despite a long history of disinfection methods, from ancient to modern practices, antimicrobial resistance has increased, rendering traditional cleaning solutions increasingly ineffective. A promising new strategy is microbial biocontrol, which involves the introduction of beneficial microbes, such as Bacillus spores, to inhibit pathogen survival and transmission. However, the exact mechanisms of this action are not fully understood. Continued research using advanced methods such as high-throughput sequencing and metabolomics, along with experimental studies and targeted interventions, is required to better understand the microbial ecology of built environments and develop effective and validated biocontrol solutions, especially in clinical settings where drug-resistant pathogens are a growing global health concern.

Title: Extracellular nucleotides elicit cytosolic free calcium oscillations in Arabidopsis.
Keywords: extracellular, nucleotides, elicit, cytosolic, free, calcium
Resumen: Extracellular purine nucleotides (ATP and ADP) regulate plant development, defense, and stress responses by activating plasma membrane calcium channels. This research reveals that, in addition to factors known as wounding or osmotic stress, abscisic acid (ABA) and L-glutamate also cause ATP accumulation around the roots of *Arabidopsis thaliana*. The release of ADP from the root epidermis triggers an ionotropic receptor-like activity, causing a transient increase in free cytosolic calcium that, unlike that induced by ATP, does not involve extracellular reactive oxygen species, as confirmed experimentally. The perception of these nucleotides also influences the net fluxes of Ca2+ and K+ in root cells.

Title: Calcium, mechanical signaling, and tip growth
Keywords: calcium, mechanical, signaling, and tip, growth
Resumen: This study investigated root gravitropism in rice plants, identifying a mutant (crw1) that exhibits root coiling in hydroponic culture but normal gravitropic growth in soil. The causative gene was found to be COILING ROOT IN WATER 1 (CRW1), which encodes an EIN3-binding F-box protein (OsEBF1). The absence of OsCRW1 amplifies ethylene signaling through the OsEIL1/2-OsERF82 module, resulting in overproduction of reactive oxygen species (ROS) at the root tip. This, in turn, compromises root cap stability, the polar localization of OsPIN2, and the symmetrical distribution of auxin, thereby impairing gravitropic growth. However, mechanical resistance, such as that found in waterlogged soil, impedes the ethylene signaling module. We show that mechanosensation-induced calcium signaling is crucial in antagonizing the ethylene signaling pathway, safeguarding gravitropism. The study reveals a complex and unexpected interplay between ethylene, auxin, and mechanosensation in the control of plant gravitropism.

Title: Gravitropism and mechanical signaling in plants.
Keywords: Gravitropism and mechanical signaling in plants
Resumen: A study identified a mutation in rice (crw1) that causes roots to coil in hydroponic culture but grow normally in soil. This mutation affects the COILING ROOT IN WATER 1 (CRW1) gene, which encodes an F-box protein, and results in amplified ethylene signaling. This in turn increases the production of reactive oxygen species, which affects root cap stability, the polar localization of OsPIN2, and auxin distribution, altering gravitropism. The study also demonstrated that mechanosensation, through calcium signaling, antagonizes ethylene signaling, restoring normal gravitropism in the soil and revealing a complex interplay between ethylene, auxin, and mechanosensation in the control of plant gravitropism.

Title: Salt stress-induced Ca2+ waves are associated with rapid, long-distance root-to-shoot signaling in plants.
Keywords: salt, stress induced, ca2, waves, are, associated
Resumen: The text describes a previously unknown plant signaling system based on the rapid long-distance transmission of Ca2+ waves. These waves, traveling up to 400 Âµm/s through the cortical and endodermal layers, are triggered by localized stress (such as salt in Arabidopsis roots) and activate systemic molecular responses in distant parts of the plant. The propagation of these Ca2+ waves depends on the vacuolar ion channel TPC1 and allows for rapid integration of activities throughout the organism, functioning as a sensory network that rapidly transmits information between distant sites.

Title: Gravitropic signaling in plants
Keywords: gravitropic signaling plants
Resumen: study of rice root gravitropism identified a mutant (`crw1`) that exhibits root coiling in hydroponics but normal gravitropic growth in soil. This phenotype is caused by a loss-of-function mutation in the `COILING ROOT IN WATER 1` (OsCRW1)` gene, which amplifies ethylene signaling. This leads to an overaccumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) at the root tip, affecting calyptra stability, OsPIN2 polar localization, and auxin distribution, severely impairing gravitropism. However, mechanical resistance and mechanosensation-induced calcium signaling antagonize ethylene signaling, safeguarding gravitropism and restoring normal growth in soil. This work reveals a complex interplay between ethylene, auxin, and mechanosensation in the control of plant gravitropism.

Title: Wortmannin-induced vacuole fusion enhances amyloplast dynamics in Arabidopsis zigzag1 hypocotyls.
Keywords: wortmannin induced, vacuole, fusion, enhances, amyloplast, dynamics
Resumen: This study investigates the role of the central vacuole in gravitropism in *Arabidopsis* hypocotyls, identifying the upper endodermal cells as the gravity sensors. It shows that the *zigzag-1* mutant (zig-1), with fragmented vacuoles, exhibits highly restricted amyloplast movement, which contributes to its agravitropic phenotype. Treatment with wortmannin induces fusion of these vacuoles, restoring amyloplast sedimentation, increasing transvacuolar strand formation, and enhancing the gravitropic response of the mutant. The findings suggest a close physical association between amyloplasts and vacuolar membranes that is independent of F-actin and microtubules, indicating that vacuolar membrane remodeling may regulate the association between vacuoles and amyloplasts during gravisensing.

Title: ROS-assisted calcium wave dependent on AtRBOHD and TPC1 propagates the systemic response to salt stress in Arabidopsis roots
Keywords: ros assisted, calcium, wave, dependent, atrbohd, and
Resumen: This study investigates the propagation of Ca2+ waves in plants as part of their systemic signaling systems in the face of stress. Through mathematical modeling and experiments in *Arabidopsis*, the authors conclude that a simple Ca2+-induced Ca2+ release (CICR) mechanism is insufficient to explain the observed transmission rates. They propose and demonstrate that systemic signaling in the root is supported by a reactive oxygen species (ROS)-assisted CICR mechanism, involving ROS production by AtRBOHD and Ca2+ release dependent on the vacuolar channel TPC1. Experiments with ROS inhibitors and *AtrbohD* mutants support this model, showing a reduction in Ca2+ wave velocity and systemic ROS propagation dependent on AtRBOHD and TPC1.

Title: ROS, calcium and electrical signals: Key mediators of rapid systemic signaling in plants
Keywords: ros, calcium, and, electric, signals, key
Resumen: This study reveals that expression of the RBOHD gene in phloem or xylem parenchyma cells (vascular bundles) is crucial for systemic reactive oxygen species (ROS) signaling, stress-response transcript expression, and systemic acquired acclimation (SAA) in Arabidopsis plants under light stress. Complementation experiments in rbohD mutants showed that restoring RBOHD specifically to these vascular tissues fully restored systemic responses, unlike its expression in the epidermis or mesophyll, which only partially restored it, or in the bundle sheath, which had no effect. This highlights a key role for RBOHD-mediated ROS production in vascular bundles in light stress- and SAA-induced systemic signaling, further suggesting that integration of ROS, calcium, electrical, and hydraulic signals occurs in these structures.

Title: Real-time In Vivo Recording of Arabidopsis Calcium Signals During Insect Feeding Using a Fluorescent Biosensor
Keywords: real time, live, recording, arabidopsis, calcium, signals
Resumen: This protocol presents a robust method for detecting calcium signals in *Arabidopsis thaliana* plants in real time during feeding by aphids (*Myzus persicae*), a hemipteran pest. By using a genetically encoded GFP-based calcium biosensor (GCaMP3) and fluorescence microscopy on detached leaves, high spatial and temporal resolution is achieved. The technique reveals a rapid and highly localized elevation of cytosolic calcium around the aphid feeding site within minutes, offering an adaptable tool for studying calcium dynamics in diverse biotic interactions.

Title: Orchestrating rapid long-distance signaling in plants with Ca2+ , ROS, and electrical signals
Keywords: orchestrating, rapid, long distance, signaling, plants, with
Resumen: Plants exhibit a rapid systemic response to a wide range of environmental stresses, transmitting signals from the point of perception to distal organs to prepare the entire plant for future challenges. This rapid communication involves a "trio signaling" network composed of reactive oxygen species (ROS), Ca2+, and electrical signals. Cell-to-cell communication in plants is facilitated through plasmodesmata, direct cytoplasmic connections that, despite the cell wall barrier, enable the regulated systemic transport of ions, metabolites, hormones, proteins, and RNA. Plasmodesmata permeability is regulated, for example, by callose deposition in response to stress, and this comprehensive signaling system, including systemic resistance and acclimatization, improves plant fitness.

Title: Glutamate triggers long-distance, calcium-based plant defense signaling.
Keywords: glutamate, triggers, long distance, calcium based, plant, defense
Resumen: This study explores the mechanisms of systemic communication in plants, which lack a nervous system but respond to environmental challenges. Contrary to the expectation that glutamate (Glu) activates plant defense, a glutathione (GSH)-deficient *Arabidopsis* mutant was found to accumulate Glu but display an attenuated defensive response. The findings reveal that GSH is a critical signaling molecule that, in dependence on the GLUTAMATE RECEPTOR-LIKE 3.3 (GLR3.3) receptor, triggers calcium-based long-distance defense signaling events in plants, offering new insights into sophisticated plant defense systems against herbivores and pathogens.

Title: Test of Arabidopsis Space Transcriptome: A discovery environment to explore multiple plant biology spaceflight experiments.
Keywords: test, arabidopsis, space, transcriptome, discovery, environment
Resumen: The text describes the creation of TOAST (Test Of Arabidopsis Space Transcriptome), a relational database that uses Qlik software to address the complexity of analyzing and visualizing the growing amount of plant omics data generated in spaceflight experiments. TOAST integrates data from NASA's GeneLab and other repositories, standardizing gene identifiers in Entrez to facilitate uniform and interactive comparisons. This tool makes it possible to explore genetic networks, confirm previously known gene expression patterns (such as responses to oxidative stress), and generate new hypotheses about how plants react to the space environment, making the information accessible to a broad scientific audience.

Title: Tonoplast-localized Ca2+ pumps regulate Ca2+ signals during pattern-triggered immunity in Arabidopsis thaliana.
Keywords: Tonoplast localized, ca2, pumps, regulate, signals, during
Resumen: This study investigates Ca2+ signaling in plant immune responses, focusing on the role of Ca2+ pumps (ACA4 and ACA11) located in the tonoplast. We found that aca4/11 mutant plants exhibited elevated basal Ca2+ levels and higher amplitude Ca2+ signals in response to the bacterial peptide flg22. These abnormal phenotypes, which included a constitutive defense response, could be suppressed by growing the plants at elevated temperatures or by relocating a plasma membrane Ca2+ pump (ACA8) to the tonoplast, provided it was catalytically active. These findings suggest that tonoplast Ca2+ pumps are crucial for proper Ca2+ dynamics in innate immune responses, and that the action of these pumps is fundamental, regardless of whether they possess specific regulatory elements not found in plasma membrane pumps.

Title: The fast and the furious: Rapid long-range signaling in plants.
Keywords: fast, and, furious, rapid, long range, signaling
Resumen: Plants possess a complex system of signaling to rapidly respond to local stimuli throughout the plant. This system includes chemical messengers such as hormones, peptides, RNA, and metabolites that travel through the vascular system, integrating physiology and development. In parallel, there are much faster communication pathways that utilize electrical, calcium (Ca2+), reactive oxygen species (ROS), and hydraulic signals. The latter are essential for immediate responses, such as defense against herbivores or rapid movements in plants like the Dionea flytrap and Mimosa pudica, where action potentials and variations, and even hydraulic pressure changes, allow the transmission of information at speeds that far exceed chemical transport. Current research focuses on unraveling the molecular machinery, such as ion channels and enzymes, that underpin this vital communication network.

Title: Rad-Bio-App: A discovery environment for biologists to explore spaceflight-related radiation exposures
Keywords: rad bio app discovery environment for biologists explore
Resumen: Exposure to ionizing radiation during spaceflight poses complex challenges for biological systems, with data that are difficult to access and understand. To address this, Rad-Bio-App, a web-based database that imports radiation metadata from experiments archived in NASA's GeneLab repository, has been developed. This tool allows users, including non-specialists, to visualize, filter, and compare dosimetry and other metadata, facilitating understanding of the impact of radiation on organisms in the space context and supporting scientific research.

Title: The vacuolar H+/Ca transporter CAX1 participates in submergence and anoxia stress responses.
Keywords: vacuolar transporter cax1 participates submergence and
Resumen: This study demonstrates that mutant Arabidopsis plants lacking the CAX1 gene (cax1) exhibit significantly increased tolerance to anoxic conditions and submergence compared to wild-type plants. The cax1 mutants exhibit increased survival, reduced chlorophyll loss, and improved recovery following oxygen deprivation. Investigations revealed that this tolerance is associated with altered metabolic processes, decreased post-anoxic reactive oxygen species production, and changes in hormonal and calcium signaling. These findings suggest that the CAX1 anoxia-response pathway could be genetically modified to improve crop resistance to the adverse effects of flooding.

Title: Meta-analysis of the space flight and microgravity response of the Arabidopsis plant transcriptome
Keywords: meta analysis, space, flight, and microgravity response
Resumen: This study reanalyzed fifteen *Arabidopsis thaliana* spaceflight experiments from NASA's GeneLab repository, employing a standardized computational pipeline and a curated metadata matrix. The research sought to understand plant responses to a complex space environment, including altered gravity and radiation. Findings revealed that factors such as the type of analysis (microarray vs. RNA-seq) and hardware or environmental conditions have a significant confounding effect, often surpassing the impact of spaceflight itself on gene expression patterns. Despite this, the standardized approach and metadata matrix allowed for the identification of known responses, such as oxidative stress, and the discovery of new response elements, such as COR78 gene expression, improving the robustness of comparisons between different plant transcriptomic datasets across space.

Title: Low-dose, ionizing radiation and age-related changes in skeletal microarchitecture
Keywords: low dose, ionizing, radiation, and age related changes
Resumen: A study evaluated the impact of low doses of gamma radiation on skeletal aging in mice, focusing on microarchitectural changes. The study demonstrated that acute exposure to 100 cGy of gamma radiation accelerated changes in cancellous bone, such as decreased trabecular number and connectivity, with changes observed within one month similar to those seen in four months of natural aging. However, doses of 1 cGy or 10 cGy had no significant effects, and radiation did not affect bone cell differentiation ex vivo.

Title: Ionizing Radiation Stimulates Expression of Pro-Osteoclastogenic Genes in Marrow and Skeletal Tissue
Keywords: Ionizing radiation stimulates expression of pro osteoclastogenic genes
Resumen: Total body irradiation, whether by gamma rays or heavy ions, causes rapid bone mineral loss and an increase in bone-resorbing osteoclasts. A study in mice showed that radiation exposure induces a rapid and persistent increase in the expression of the osteoclastogenic cytokine Rankl and other pro-osteoclastic cytokines in bone marrow cells, which precedes and overlaps with an increase in bone resorption markers. This results in a net pro-resorptive balance and a 16% decrease in cancellous bone after one week, contributing to the rapid and progressive deterioration of bone microarchitecture.

Title: Preservation of Multiple Mammalian Tissues to Maximize Science Return from Ground Based and Spaceflight Experiments
Keywords: preservation, multiple, mammalian, tissues, maximize, science
Resumen: This study aimed to optimize rodent tissue collection and preservation methods for experiments, especially in resource-limited settings such as spaceflight. The impact of post-euthanasia collection time, preservation methods, and storage duration on RNA quality and enzymatic activity in tissues such as liver and spleen was investigated, as well as the feasibility of dissecting multiple tissues from frozen cadavers. The results showed that fresh tissues could be collected up to one hour after euthanasia and stored for up to 11 months at -80°C with minimal effects on RNA quality from livers and spleens preserved in RNAlater. Liver enzyme activity remained similar to that of controls. The quality of RNA from liver, heart, and kidneys of cadavers frozen for up to 7 months was minimally affected, although other tissues such as small intestine and bone marrow showed earlier degradation. It is concluded that the developed protocols allow obtaining high-quality samples for RNA and some protein expression analysis, even with delayed preservation or prolonged storage, which is highly relevant for both ground-based experiments with sampling limitations and space missions.

Title: Hindlimb Unloading: Rodent Analog for Microgravity
Keywords: hindlimb unloading rodent analog for microgravity
Resumen: This study used single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) to generate a cellular atlas of the carotid and femoral arteries of rats subjected to three months of hindlimb unloading, a model that simulates microgravity. The objective was to understand the cell populations, dysregulated genes, cell communication, and key transcription factors involved in vascular remodeling caused by prolonged spaceflight. The findings revealed an increased percentage of endothelial cells in the carotid artery and a decrease in smooth muscle cells in both arteries following the simulation. Dysregulated genes related to extracellular matrix remodeling, inflammation, and vasoconstriction were identified, with notable variability in fibroblasts, and enhanced intercellular interactions were observed, especially between smooth muscle cells and fibroblasts. Furthermore, several influential transcription factors were predicted. This work provides the first cellular atlas of conduit arteries in hindlimb-unloaded rats, offering a valuable reference for future research on vascular deconditioning in space.

Title: Redox Signaling and Its Impact on Skeletal and Vascular Responses to Spaceflight
Keywords: redox signaling and its impact on skeletal
Resumen: The text examines how microgravity and radiation in space affect the mammalian skeleton and vasculature, highlighting the role of oxidative stress and redox signaling in tissue dysfunction. Microgravity is observed to contribute to osteopenia and vascular alterations, while ionizing radiation damages DNA and cells. In both astronauts and animal models, changes in redox status are evident, with increased oxidative damage and decreased antioxidant defenses during and after spaceflight, impacting bone, heart, liver, and eye health. Altered nitric oxide bioavailability, crucial for vascular function and bone remodeling, is a key mechanism. Understanding these effects is essential for developing interventions to mitigate spaceflight-induced deficits.

Title: Influence of social isolation during prolonged simulated weightlessness by hindlimb unloading
Keywords: influence, social, isolation, during, prolonged, simulated
Resumen: This study investigated the contribution of social isolation to tissue responses in mice subjected to a hindlimb unloading (HU) model, which simulates weightlessness. To do so, the traditional HU system was modified to allow for social pair housing and compared mice housed individually and socially for 30 days. The results showed that expected musculoskeletal deficits were similar in both social environments. However, immune and hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis responses were influenced by the social environment: unloading reduced CD4+ T cells in individual mice but not in social mice, and increased adrenal gland mass in social mice, an effect also observed for social isolation itself. The authors conclude that musculoskeletal responses to simulated weightlessness are consistent, but combined stressors may mask or differentiate other biological responses.

Title: Validation of a new Rodent experimental System to investigate consequences of Long Duration Space Habitation
Keywords: validation, new, rodent, experimental, system, investigate
Resumen: The text describes NASA's Rodent Research-1 (RR-1) experiment, the primary objective of which was to establish a new capability to conduct long-term studies with rodents in space and to retrieve samples in situ in orbit, avoiding the confounding factors associated with return to Earth. Female mice were housed on the International Space Station for 21/22 or 37 days in microgravity, where they were euthanized and their tissues (livers and spleens) dissected. The mice remained healthy, showed increased physical activity, and those exposed for 37 days showed increased liver mass and enzyme activity, with the expected atrophy of the soleus muscle. The quality of the RNA and enzymatic activity of the samples was acceptable, validating the system for long-term experiments and sample recovery in orbit without inducing chronic stress.

Title: Skeletal tissue regulation by catalase over-expression in mitochondria
Keywords: skeletal, tissue, regulation, catalase, over expression, mitochondria
Resumen: This study investigated disuse-related muscle atrophy in fast-twitch muscles, such as the gastrocnemius, and determined that mitochondrial dysfunction—manifested by defective fusion and compromised OXPHOS capacity—rather than oxidative stress, triggers muscle loss by activating the AMPK pathway. It was shown that overexpression of PGC-1 prevented atrophy by maintaining mitochondrial fusion proteins and inhibiting AMPK pathway activation and catabolic factor expression. This suggests that compounds that induce PGC-1Î± could be useful for treating and preventing muscle atrophy in fast-twitch muscles.

Title: Overexpression of catalase in mitochondria mitigates changes in hippocampal cytokine expression following simulated microgravity and isolation.
Keywords: overexpression, catalase, mitochondria, mitigates, changes, hippocampal
Resumen: This study examined the effects of isolation and simulated microgravity, individually or in combination, on the hippocampal inflammatory cytokine profile in mice, replicating spaceflight and prolonged rest conditions. Both isolation and simulated microgravity were found to regulate distinct repertoires of inflammation-associated cytokines in the hippocampus, and their combined effects were not additive. Mice genetically engineered to reduce mitochondrial reactive oxygen species (MCAT) showed protection against these isolation- and/or simulated microgravity-induced changes. These findings suggest a crucial role for mitochondrial reactive oxygen species (ROS) signaling in neuroinflammatory responses and highlight the importance of mitigating these species to protect the central nervous system during prolonged space exploration and other situations of isolation or inactivity on Earth.

Title: An extensive allelic series of Drosophila kae1 mutants reveals diverse and tissue-specific requirements for t6A biogenesis
Keywords: extensive, allelic, series, drosophila, kae1, mutants
Resumen: The universal RNA modification N6-threonylcarbamoyl-adenosine (t6A), crucial for the stability of codon-anticodon interactions in tRNA, is described. Kae1 is mentioned as a central factor in its biosynthesis, previously studied in unicellular organisms. This study investigated the Kae1 ortholog in *Drosophila melanogaster*, isolating an allelic series of *kae1* mutants that exhibited decreased t6A, growth defects, developmental delay, and melanotic masses. The requirement for t6A was found to be tissue-specific in metazoans, affecting mitotic tissues more than non-proliferating ones, and *kae1* acts as a tumor suppressor in larval hematopoietic tissue. These findings reveal the complexity of the biological roles of this fundamental RNA modification in animal development and disease.

Title: Novel Organelles with Elements of Bacterial and Eukaryotic Secretion Systems Weaponize Parasites of Drosophila
Keywords: novel organelles with elements, bacterial, and
Resumen: The success of parasitoid wasps depends on strategies to counteract their hosts' defenses. While *Leptopilina boulardi* (Lb) activates the immunity of *Drosophila melanogaster*, *L. heterotoma* (Lh) actively suppresses it. Proteomic studies reveal that the virus-like particles (VLPs) in Lh venom, crucial for its parasitism, are not viral but contain eukaryotic vesicular transport, immunity, and other novel proteins. Some of these Lh-specific proteins, such as p40, show similarities to bacterial type 3 secretion systems. This suggests that Lh VLPs are a new class of extracellular organelles, termed "Mixed Strategy Extracellular Vesicles" (MSEVs), that combine prokaryotic and eukaryotic properties for protein delivery and host immune suppression.

Title: combined computational strategy of sequence and structural analysis predicts the existence of a functional eicosanoid pathway in Drosophila melanogaster.
Keywords: combined, computational, strategy, sequence, and, structural
Resumen: This study challenges the current view that insects lack a functional eicosanoid biosynthesis pathway by investigating *Drosophila melanogaster* using systematic bioinformatics approaches. The researchers identified 20 candidate enzymes in the fruit fly that, although with low sequence identity to their human counterparts, demonstrated striking conservation in domain architecture, catalytic structure, and functional residues. Structural homology models were found for three fly cyclooxygenases, although no direct candidates for lipoxygenases were identified, suggesting the existence of a possible non-canonical pathway. The findings predict that the *D. melanogaster* likely encodes pathways for the synthesis of eicosanoids or similar biolipids, opening up new possibilities for studying the regulation of biological functions and inflammation in a model organism relevant to human health.

Title: Immune suppressive extracellular vesicle proteins of Leptopilina heterotoma are encoded in the wasp genome.
Keywords: immune, suppressive, extracellular, vesicle, proteins, leptopilin
Resumen: The research focused on mixed-strategy extracellular vesicles (MSEVs) from the parasitoid wasp *Leptopilina heterotoma*, which suppress the immunity of its *Drosophila* host. An additional 246 proteins were identified in the MSEV proteome, adding to the 161 previously known. An enrichment analysis confirmed the vesicular nature of these structures, and sequencing of the *L. heterotoma* genome revealed that more than 90% of MSEV proteins are encoded within the wasp genome. These results explain the stable association and vertical inheritance of MSEVs with wasps and, while not ruling out a viral origin, suggest that they are specialized vesicles that transfer virulence factors. This contributes to our understanding of immune suppression strategies in wasps and the evolution of related species.

Title: Spaceflight and simulated microgravity conditions increase virulence of Serratia marcescens in the Drosophila melanogaster infection model.
Keywords: spaceflight and simulated microgravity conditions increase
Resumen: study investigated the impact of the space environment on pathogenic bacteria, using the bacterium *Serratia marcescens* and the fruit fly *Drosophila melanogaster* as a model. *S. marcescens*, grown on the International Space Station or under simulated microgravity conditions on Earth, was found to become significantly more virulent and lethal to the flies, in addition to showing increased growth rates in vitro and in vivo at advanced stages. However, this increased virulence and growth were not persistent; they were reversed after the bacteria were recultured under normal Earth-based conditions, suggesting temporary physiological rather than genetic changes. The research also indicated that the increased virulence was due to alterations in the bacteria itself, and not primarily to changes in the host's immune system. These findings suggest that the space environment induces complex, reversible physiological changes in pathogens, increasing their pathogenicity.

Title: parasitoid wasp of Drosophila employs preemptive and reactive strategies to deplete its host's blood cells
Keywords: parasitoid wasp drosophila employs preemptive and
Resumen: The parasitoid wasp Leptopilina heterotoma (Lh) suppresses the immunity of its Drosophila host by releasing extracellular vesicles (EVs) in its venom, loaded with immunosuppressive proteins. These EVs are distributed throughout the host's hemolymphatic system, specifically targeting the larval lymphatic gland, a hematopoietic organ. The EVs converge and dismantle the lymphatic gland's posterior signaling center (PSC), which is crucial for the differentiation of lamellocytes, the immune cells necessary to encapsulate the wasp's eggs. Lymphatic gland progenitors internalize EVs, which then damage the endosomal and phagolysosomal compartments, resulting in the destruction of both mature and immature blood cells. This multifaceted strategy allows the wasp to block host cellular immunity, eliminating existing defenses and preventing the production of new, protective immune cells. These findings suggest a previously unrecognized phagocytic role for the lymphatic gland and have implications for agricultural pest control and therapeutic development.

Title: In Silico Analysis of a Drosophila Parasitoid Venom Peptide Reveals Prevalence of the Cationâ€šÃ„Ã¬Polarâ€šÃ„Ã¬Cation Clip Motif in Knottin Proteins
Keywords: silico drosophila parasitoid venom peptide reveals
Resumen: This study focuses on the peptide LhKNOT, identified in the venom of the parasitoid wasp *Leptopilina heterotoma*, known to suppress immunity in *Drosophila* flies. Through proteomic and structural analysis, LhKNOT was found to be a knottin peptide containing a Cation-Polar-Cation (CPC) clip motif. This CPC clip motif, thought to facilitate antimicrobial activity and heparin binding, is present in a surprising majority of knottins studied, including the *Drosophila* antifungal peptide Drosomycin. The findings suggest a possible defensive or virulence function for LhKNOT in the wasp, contributing to host immune suppression. The prevalence of this CPC clip motif in the structure of knottins indicates its importance in the biochemical functions of these proteins, with implications for host-parasite interactions and drug design.

Title: Drosophila parasitoids go to space: Unexpected effects of spaceflight on hosts and their parasitoids.
Keywords: drosophila, parasitoids, space, unexpected, spaceflight, hosts
Resumen: study investigated the effects of spaceflight on fruit flies (healthy and those with a tumor-predisposing mutation) and their natural parasitoid wasps. Healthy flies showed lower survival and increased sensitivity to spaceflight, with downregulation of many essential genes. Although overall survival was unaffected in the tumor-bearing mutant flies, they experienced increased tumor burden and activation of inflammation-related genes in space; these inflammatory genes were also activated in the healthy flies. In contrast, the parasitoid wasps proved more resilient, as their survival and virulence were not significantly affected, and mutants with visible alterations after flight were even isolated. The findings suggest that spaceflight alters host immunity and enhances tumor development in susceptible flies, while metazoan parasites maintain their infectivity and normal development, crucial data for future human space missions.

Title: Drosophila parasitoids go to space: Unexpected effects of spaceflight on hosts and their parasitoids
Keywords: drosophila, parasitoids, space, unexpected, spaceflight, hosts
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of spaceflight on healthy and tumor-bearing fruit flies (Drosophila melanogaster), as well as their natural parasitoid wasps, during a mission to the International Space Station. Results revealed that control flies were more sensitive to spaceflight, with lower survival and dysregulated essential genes, while mutant flies with tumors experienced increased tumor burden and activation of inflammation-related genes. Parasitoid wasps, in contrast, showed greater resilience; spaceflight did not significantly affect their survival or the expression of their virulence genes, although mutant wasps with visible post-flight alterations were isolated. These findings suggest that the spatial environment influences immune gene expression and tumor development in flies, but may have a limited impact on parasitoid virulence.

Title: Simultaneous exposure of cultured human lymphoblastic cells to simulated microgravity and radiation increases chromosome aberrations
Keywords: simultaneous exposure cultured human lymphoblastic cells
Resumen: This study investigates the combined effects of simulated microgravity and space radiation on human TK6 lymphoblastic cells, a crucial factor for astronaut health on long-duration missions. Using a novel system with a 3D clinostat for simultaneous and continuous exposure to radiation (X-rays or carbon ions) and microgravity, researchers observed a higher frequency of chromosomal aberrations in cells exposed to both factors simultaneously, compared to those exposed to radiation alone. The results suggest that current risk assessments based on 1G conditions may underestimate potential health risks to astronauts, emphasizing the need for more data on cellular responses to irradiation under microgravity.

Title: Genes required for survival in microgravity revealed by genome-wide yeast deletion collections cultured during spaceflight.
Keywords: genes required for survival microgravity revealed
Resumen: This study employed collections of yeast with genetic deletions, using molecular barcoding and specialized hardware, to quantitatively assess the biological effects of microgravity during spaceflight. Comparing the growth of thousands of strains in space and on the ground, with and without additional osmotic stress, found that the effects of spaceflight are consistent with those of DNA-damaging agents and redox state alterations. Affected biological processes were identified, including those related to mitochondria, DNA repair, translation, RNA transport, and replication, suggesting mechanisms by which microgravity impacts cellular fitness.

Title: Physical Forces Modulate Oxidative Status and Stress Defense Meditated Metabolic Adaptation of Yeast Colonies: Spaceflight and Microgravity Simulations
Keywords: physical, forces, modulate, oxidative, status, and
Resumen: This study investigated the impact of real and simulated microgravity on giant colonies of yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae), a model organism with genetic homology to human cells, used to study aging and drug action. Colonies grown on agar were examined under spatial microgravity, rotation, and random positioning machine (RPM), as well as in nutrient-rich and -poor media. The results showed that the effects of random positioning differed from rotation, and that both real and simulated microgravity exacerbated cellular redox responses and apoptosis. These changes were highly dependent on the response to shear stress, with each microgravity model exhibiting a unique response signature. These physical techniques allowed for the manipulation of ammonia convection and its signaling, which significantly contributes to the understanding of drug action mechanisms, cellular aging, and colony differentiation.

Title: Effects of space flight on mouse liver versus kidney: Gene pathway analyses.
Keywords: space, flight, mouse, liver, versus, kidney
Resumen: This study analyzed changes in gene expression in the liver and kidney of mice that flew in space for 12 days, comparing them with ground-based controls. The results revealed both tissue-specific gene responses and common pathways activated in both organs. Specifically, both the liver and kidney showed overexpression of genes in four key areas: cellular responses to peptides, hormones, and nitrogenous compounds; apoptosis and cell death; fat cell differentiation; and downregulation of protein kinases. In addition, unique pathways were identified for each organ, such as T cell activation in the liver and peptide binding in the kidney.

Title: Yeast in Space
Keywords: yeast, space
Resumen: The text describes a rare and successful case of *Cryptococcus albidus* meningitis in a severely obese patient, effectively treated with liposomal amphotericin B and 5-fluorocytosine. The importance of calculating the dose of liposomal amphotericin B based on ideal body weight, not actual weight, for obese patients is highlighted, given the risk of nephrotoxicity. *C. albidus* central nervous system infections are uncommon but have a high mortality rate, and only nine cases have been reported in the literature. Risk factors include immunodeficiency and animal exposure, and accurate diagnosis often requires mass spectrometry. In the absence of established treatment guidelines, amphotericin B is recommended as initial therapy, along with susceptibility testing to optimize therapeutic decisions.

Title: Endocrine Effects of Space Flight
Keywords: endocrine, space, flight
Resumen: Space exploration and prolonged microgravity pose physiological challenges to astronauts, particularly affecting the central nervous system. To simulate these ground-based conditions more effectively than existing models, a study was conducted using a three-dimensional (3D) clinostat in 18 mice. For eight weeks, mice in one group were exposed to simulated microgravity and subjected to behavioral testing, bone density analysis, brain transcriptomics, serum metabolomics, and fecal microbiome analysis. The results indicated that clinostat-treated mice showed decreased activity, altered gait, enhanced fear memory, bone loss, immune/endocrine changes in the brain transcriptome, and metabolic alterations in serum and gut microbiota. This model is considered valuable for studying microgravity-related neurological alterations, as it mimics spaceflight-induced transcriptomic changes and highlights the need to pay attention to emotional changes in space.

Title: Role of shear stress on renal proximal tubular cells for nephrotoxicity assays
Keywords: role, shear, stress, renal, proximal, tubular
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of contrast medium (CM) viscosity on contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) using a 3D "kidney-on-a-chip" model with proximal renal tubular epithelial cells (RPTEC) under fluid shear stress, compared with static conditions. The results showed that low-osmolar contrast medium (LOCM) exhibited a significantly greater dose-dependent cytotoxic effect than iso-osmolar contrast medium (IOCM) under static and low-to-moderate shear conditions. However, under high shear conditions, cell viability was also reduced with IOCM, with no differences found between LOCM and IOCM, as the high viscosity of IOCM slowed flow and increased shear stress. This suggests a vital role for viscosity-induced nephrotoxicity under high shear stress, contrary to the findings of conventional in vitro studies, and proposes the "kidney-on-a-chip" model as an alternative for CIN research.

Title: Bone hemodynamic responses to changes in external pressure.
Keywords: bone, hemodynamic, responses, changes, external, pressure
Resumen: double-blind, randomized controlled trial in 168 patients investigated the effect of four different concentrations of epinephrine/saline (1:5000, 1:10,000, 1:20,000, and 1:40,000) injected subcutaneously into the external auditory canal during otoendoscopic surgery. The study sought to determine the optimal concentration to ensure surgical field clarity and hemodynamic stability. The results showed no significant differences in surgical field clarity between groups. However, all concentrations increased hemodynamic parameters, with the highest concentrations (1:5000 and 1:10,000) having the most significant and lasting effect. Therefore, the use of lower concentrations (1:20,000 to 1:40,000) is recommended to minimize the impact on patient hemodynamics while maintaining satisfactory surgical clarity.

Title: Back pain in space and post-flight spinal injury: Mechanisms and countermeasure development
Keywords: back, pain, space, and, post flight, spine
Resumen: longitudinal study of six NASA astronauts on the International Space Station revealed that prolonged microgravity causes a decrease in lumbar lordosis and a reduction in active range of motion in the midlumbar discs. Most subjects experienced atrophy of the multifidus muscles, strongly correlated with lumbar flattening and increased stiffness. Only astronauts with preexisting vertebral endplate irregularities developed postflight lumbar symptoms, such as chronic pain or disc herniations. The findings suggest that multifidus atrophy, not disk swelling, is key to the biomechanical changes in the spine in space, increasing the risk of injury upon returning to gravity and offering valuable information for astronaut countermeasures and research on lower back pain on Earth.

Title: Fifteen days of microgravity causes growth in calvaria of mice
Keywords: fifteen, days, microgravity, causes, growth, calvaria
Resumen: A study investigated bone adaptation in non-weightbearing bones under microgravity, exposing seven mice to 15 days in space and comparing them with eight terrestrial controls. Analyzing their skulls, a statistically significant increase in bone volume was found in the microgravity group, as well as a trend toward increased cross-sectional thickness, while tissue mineral density remained unchanged. These findings suggest that microgravity induces adaptive growth in cranial bones, possibly due to changes in fluid distribution, independent of skeletal loading.

Title: Altered disc compression in children with idiopathic low back pain: an upright magnetic resonance imaging backpack study
Keywords: altered disc compression children with idiopathic
Resumen: study using upright MRI analyzed the response of the lumbar spine to backpack loads in children with idiopathic low back pain (ILBP) compared with that of healthy children. It was found that in children with ILBP, the 4 kg and 8 kg backpacks compressed only the L5-S1 intervertebral disc, unlike in healthy children, where compression was more widespread across other lumbar discs. Subjects with ILBP experienced significantly less disc compression at most lumbar levels (T12-L1 to L4-5) and less lumbar lordosis with increasing load, but reported significantly more pain, even preventing them from tolerating a 12 kg load. This suggests that children with ILBP may redistribute the load from the discs to the paraspinal muscles, causing muscle fatigue and increased pain.

Title: Spaceflight-induced bone loss alters failure mode and reduces bending strength in murine spinal segments.
Keywords: spaceflight induced, bone, loss, alters, failure, mode
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of microgravity on the flexural properties of spinal discs, due to the fourfold increase in disc herniation in astronauts following spaceflight. Using caudal segments from mice exposed to 30 days of spaceflight and controls, microgravity was observed to significantly shorten the nonlinear region of the force-displacement curve by 32% and reduce flexural strength by 17%. Segments from flight mice tended to fail within the growth plate and epiphyseal bone, unlike controls, which failed at the disc-vertebra junction. Spaceflight also reduced vertebral bone volume fraction, bone mineral density, and trabecular thickness. These results indicate that vertebral bone loss during spaceflight may impair the flexural properties of the spine and contribute to the increased risk of disc herniation in astronauts.

Title: Spaceflight-associated vascular remodeling and gene expression in mouse calvaria.
Keywords: Spaceflight associated vascular remodeling and gene expression
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of microgravity on vascular and bone remodeling in the skull of mice, a non-load-bearing region, during spaceflight. Comparing mice from 15- and 30-day missions with ground-based control groups, researchers observed a significant reduction in vessel diameter and increased capillarization after 15 days. After 30 days, although vessel number and diameter remained unchanged, significant increases in the expression of pro-angiogenic (VEGFA) and pro-osteogenic (BMP-2) genes were detected. The results suggest that angiogenesis is key in regulating pathological bone growth in non-weight-bearing regions in microgravity, which has implications for the development of countermeasures in long-duration spaceflight.

Title: Exposure of Mycobacterium marinum to low-shear modeled microgravity: Effect on growth, the transcriptome and survival under stress.
Keywords: exposure, mycobacterium, marinum, low shear, modeled, microgravity
Resumen: This study investigates the physiological changes in *Mycobacterium marinum*, a model for pathogenic mycobacteria, when grown under low-shear simulated micromobility (LSMMG) conditions relevant to astronaut health and spacecraft contamination. The results showed that *M. marinum* exposed to LSMMG entered exponential phase earlier and exhibited reduced culture density and slower doubling times compared to the control. Furthermore, it was more sensitive to hydrogen peroxide, but its resistance to gamma radiation or pH 3.5 did not change. Transcriptome analysis revealed significant alterations in gene expression, suggesting reduced translation, downregulation of metabolism, increased lipid degradation, and increased expression of chaperones and mycobactins. Sigma factor H (sigH) was the only sigma factor consistently induced by LSMMG. In summary, the study suggests that LSMMG could simulate a nutrient deprivation environment similar to that found in macrophages during infection, with SigH implicated in the transcriptomic response.

Title: Effects of mechanostimulation on gravitropism and signal persistence in flax roots.
Keywords: mechanostimulation, gravitropism and signal persistence flax
Resumen: study examined the persistence of the gravitational signal and the distinction between mechanostimulation and gravistimulation in flax roots. The roots were reoriented and then subjected to vertical or horizontal clinorotation at different speeds. It was observed that horizontal clinorotation did not affect growth rate, whereas vertical clinorotation reduced it by 7%. The angular velocity of clinorotation did not influence growth, but it did influence curvature: horizontal clinorotation increased curvature with angular velocity, whereas vertical clinorotation decreased it, resulting in straight roots at 5 rpm. The gravitropic signal saturated after 10 minutes of reorientation and persisted for approximately 120 minutes. The results suggest that mechanostimulation modifies the magnitude of the gravitropic response but does not affect the persistence of signal "memory."

Title: Oxygen dependency of germinating Brassica seeds.
Keywords: oxygen, dependency, germinating, brassica, seeds
Resumen: Cauliflower (Brassica oleracea L. var. botrytis), an important horticultural crop, is vulnerable to excessive soil salt concentrations, which reduce its growth and productivity. This study examined the effectiveness of hydroconditioning, haloconditioning, and osmoconditioning in mitigating the effects of salinity (100 mM NaCl) on cauliflower. The results showed that salinity had significant deleterious impacts on seed germination, seedling growth, and photosynthetic attributes, in addition to causing the production of reactive oxygen species. In contrast, the different conditioning strategies proved beneficial, mitigating the negative effects of salinity, boosting germination, growth, and physio-biochemical attributes, and suppressing oxidative damage. The study concludes that these conditioning approaches are useful for improving cauliflower germination, survival, and resilience in agroecosystems affected by salinity.

Title: Desiccation mitigates heat stress in the resurrection fern, Pleopeltis polypodioides
Keywords: desiccation, mitigates, heat, stress, resurrection, fern
Resumen: This study investigated the thermotolerance of the resurrection fern *Pleopeltis polypodioides* in hydrated (up to 50°C) and dehydrated (up to 65°C) fronds, evaluating morphological changes, photosynthetic efficiency, and metabolic responses. The results indicated that dry fronds exhibit significantly greater thermotolerance, close to 55°C, while hydrated fronds withstand temperatures at least 10°C lower. It was concluded that, although the oxidative and antioxidant systems are sensitive to heat in both states, dehydration confers greater thermal resistance to the plant.

Title: Transcription profile of auxin related genes during positively gravitropic hypocotyl curvature of Brassica rapa.
Keywords: transcription profile auxin related genes during
Resumen: This study investigated the role of auxin in the gravitropy of young *Brassica rapa* hypocotyls, which initially display positive (downward) curvature followed by the typical negative (upward) curvature. The researchers examined the transcription of the genes PIN1, PIN3, IAA5, and ARG1 in the curved tissue using tissue extraction and a high-resolution solid-phase gene extraction (SPGE) technique. They found that, during the initial phase of downward curvature, transcription of these genes was activated in the lower flank and deactivated in the upper flank. After 48 hours, when the hypocotyls were upright and exhibited negative gravitropy, this transcription profile reversed. The transcription profiles were spatially distinct within the tissue and comparable to those of root tips, suggesting similar physiological processes. The results indicate that temporal and spatial changes in the transcription of these auxin-regulated genes control both positive and negative hypocotyl gravitropy.

Title: High-gradient magnetic fields and starch metabolism: Results from a space experiment.
Keywords: high gradient magnetic fields and starch metabolism
Resumen: An experiment conducted on the International Space Station with Brassica rapa investigated how plants grow in weightlessness and the effect of high-gradient magnetic fields (HGMFs) on their orientation. The study confirmed that HGMFs can induce curvature in roots, allowing plants to orient themselves in space. Plants sense weightlessness, adjusting their metabolism with an increase in amyloplast size and changes in amylase transcription, which contrasts with the effects of mechanostimulation. These findings suggest that clinorotation is not an accurate substitute for simulating microgravity in space research.

Title: Lipid rafts and plant gravisensitivity.
Keywords: lipid rafts and plant gravisensitivity
Resumen: This text explores plant cell membranes and membrane microdomains, known as lipid rafts, whose investigation is crucial for optimizing plant growth in Bioregenerative Life Support Systems (BLSS) on space missions. These rafts are variable, stabilized microdomains within the membrane, characterized by a specific composition of lipids (such as sterols and sphingolipids) and proteins. They are involved in numerous vital processes, including signaling, transport, sensing of gravity and other stressors (such as drought or cold), cell division, adaptation to stress, and regulation of cell death. Microgravity and mechanical stress (simulated by clinorotation) alter their composition, for example, by increasing the saturated fatty acid content, suggesting increased stiffness and reduced membrane permeability. These rafts have been identified in various plant species, and their functioning is intrinsically linked to the organization of the cytoskeleton and the ability of plants to respond and adapt to changing environmental conditions.

Title: Expression and characterization of the bacterial mechanosensitive channel MscS in Xenopus laevis oocytes
Keywords: expression and characterization of bacterial mechanosensitive channel
Resumen: This study investigates the function of MscS-Like (MSL) proteins in *Arabidopsis thaliana* as mechanosensitive (MS) ion channels in plants. Researchers demonstrated that the MSL10 protein, when heterologously expressed in *Xenopus laevis* oocytes, exhibits MS channel activity. This channel has a conductance of approximately 100 pS, shows a moderate preference for anions (approximately six chloride ions for every one sodium ion), is modulated by positive and negative membrane potentials, and is reversibly inhibited by gadolinium. Furthermore, it exhibits asymmetric activation and inactivation kinetics, closing at voltages significantly lower than those required for its opening. This electrophysiological characterization of MSL10 provides a deeper understanding of the evolution of the structure and function of this important protein family in plants.

Title: United in Diversity: Mechanosensitive Ion Channels in Plants
Keywords: united, diversity, mechanosensitive, ion, channels, plants
Resumen: This study identifies the bioactive lipid sphingosine 1-phosphate (S1P) and its receptor 3 (S1PR3) as critical regulators of acute mechanical nociception. Genetic or pharmacological deletion of S1PR3, or blocking S1P production, significantly decreases the behavioral response to noxious mechanical stimuli, without affecting innocuous touch or thermal stimuli. These effects are mediated by rapidly conducting A-type mechanonociceptors, whose excitability is modulated by S1PR3 signaling through KCNQ2/3 channels. The findings establish that constitutive S1P/S1PR3 signaling is essential for establishing normal mechanical pain thresholds, as opposed to elevated S1P levels that only cause thermal hypersensitivity.

Title: Expressing and Characterizing Mechanosensitive Channels in Xenopus Oocytes
Keywords: expressing and characterizing mechanosensitive channels xenopus
Resumen: This text describes detailed methods for the heterologous expression and characterization of bacterial and plant mechanosensitive ion channels (MSCs) in *Xenopus laevis* oocytes. This system is widely used due to its simplicity, reliability, low background ion channel activity, large size, low cost, and ease of handling, allowing the study of channels such as *Escherichia coli* MscS and *Arabidopsis thaliana* MSL10 after inactivating endogenous MSCs in the oocyte. Key methodological steps include frog surgery, oocyte isolation and preparation, in vitro RNA production and injection, and electrophysiological characterization using patch-clamp and pressure-clamp techniques. The importance of water quality and proper storage of solutions is emphasized at all stages of the procedure.

Title: The ongoing search for the molecular basis of plant osmosensing
Keywords: ongoing search for molecular basis plant
Resumen: This text addresses the response of terrestrial plants to osmotic challenges, highlighting their dependence on water status for growth and development, and the importance of understanding these mechanisms to mitigate the effects of drought. Plants balance photosynthesis with water loss through stomata and maintain cell turgor, which is crucial for their structure and function. Water status is measured by water potential, and it is important to differentiate between low water availability and hyperosmotic stress, which elicit distinct cellular responses. Plants also experience hypoosmotic stress due to rewetting or pathogens. Three models for osmosensing are proposed: direct perception of osmotic imbalance in the membrane (possibly through histidine kinases or calcium channels such as OSCA1), mechanosensitive channels that respond to membrane tension (such as MCA channels), and mechanisms that monitor cell wall integrity. The interface between the plasma membrane and the cell wall is a critical point for detecting these stimuli.

Title: Plastid osmotic stress influences cell differentiation at the plant shoot apex.
Keywords: plastid, osmotic, stress, influences, cell, differentiation
Resumen: This study examines how plastid osmotic stress affects cell differentiation in the shoot apical meristem of *Arabidopsis thaliana*. *msl2 msl3* mutants, which exhibit constitutive osmotic stress in plastids, were found to develop a callus at the shoot apex with markedly enlarged and deformed plastids. This callus production requires the cytokinin receptor AHK2 and is associated with elevated cytokinin levels, downregulation of the cytokinin signaling inhibitors ARR7 and ARR15, and induction of the WUSCHEL gene. Furthermore, plastid stress-induced callus requires elevated plastid reactive oxygen species, ABA biosynthesis, and the retrograde signaling proteins GUN1 and ABI4. These results support a model where the cytokinin/WUSCHEL pathway and retrograde signaling control cell differentiation at the shoot apex in response to plastid stress.

Title: Spaceflight-induced synaptic modifications within hair cells of the mammalian utricle.
Keywords: spaceflight induced synaptic modifications within hair cells
Resumen: A study investigated synaptic modifications in the inner ear utricle of mice exposed to 15 days of microgravity on a space shuttle, comparing them with ground-based controls. Immunohistochemistry detected a decrease in synaptic density in the medial extrastriola of the utricle, a region linked to the encoding of static head position. These findings demonstrate localized structural plasticity of utricular hair cells to adapt to novel gravitational environments, consistent with previous reports of decreased utricular function in astronauts.

Title: Effects of angular frequency during clinorotation on mesenchymal stem cell morphology and migration
Keywords: angular frequency during clinorotation mesenchymal stem
Resumen: This study investigated the short-term effects of simulated microgravity, using different clinorotation speeds (0, 30, 60, and 75 rpm), on the behavior of human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs) using a novel lab-on-a-chip clinostat. The research addressed inconsistencies in previous studies by evaluating how clinorotation speed affected hMSC morphology, cytoarchitecture, and migration over 8 hours. The results showed that hMSCs responded by adopting more rounded and less spread morphologies, with higher angular frequencies inhibiting cell spreading more. Although the cells remained viable and were able to re-extend, clinorotation compromised their motility, causing retraction rather than migration. The angular frequency dependence suggests that the cells sense the rate of gravitational perturbation, which has implications for stem cell regulation, therapeutic applications, and understanding human health in microgravity.

Title: The role of FGF-2 and BMP-2 in regulation of gene induction, cell proliferation and mineralization.
Keywords: role, fgf 2, and, bmp 2, regulation, gene
Resumen: This study describes the sequential roles of FGF-2 and BMP-2 in bone repair after fractures. FGF-2 was found to stimulate osteoblast proliferation and the expression of growth- and angiogenesis-associated genes, while reducing the expression of mineralization-related genes. In contrast, BMP-2 significantly induces the expression of mineralization genes, with little or no effect on growth-associated genes. This suggests that FGF-2 is crucial for initial osteoblast growth in early fracture repair, and BMP-2 is critical for stimulating mineralization.

Title: Nutritional supplements, COX-2 and IGF-1 expression in men on active surveillance for prostate cancer.
Keywords: nutritional supplements cox 2 and igf 1 expression
Resumen: three-month, randomized, double-blind clinical study investigated the effects of lycopene (30 mg/day) and fish oil (3 g/day) supplements versus placebo on gene expression of the normal prostate microenvironment in 69 men with low-risk prostate cancer under active surveillance. Although lycopene and fish oil were hypothesized to reduce IGF-1 and COX-2 gene expression, respectively, the results showed no significant changes in IGF-1 expression in the lycopene group or COX-2 expression in the fish oil group compared with placebo. This suggests that a three-month intervention with these supplements does not significantly alter the expression of IGF-1 and COX-2 in the normal prostatic microenvironment in these patients.

Title: To Infinity and Beyond! Human space flight and life science.
Keywords: infinity and beyond human spaceflight life
Resumen: Space exploration, inspired by the science fiction of authors such as Verne and Wells, became a reality through technological advances. Early flights, including experiments with animals like the dog Laika, and the human missions Apollo and Skylab, revealed the profound effects of microgravity on the body. Among the most significant physiological changes are fluid displacement, causing "puffy face and bird's feet" syndrome, and "space anemia" due to reduced plasma volume and erythropoietin. Progressive space osteoporosis has also been documented, with bone and calcium loss continuing even with exercise, suggesting an underlying cellular mechanism. In addition, immunosuppression was observed, affecting lymphocyte and T cell activation. These findings underscore the significant challenges to human health during long-duration spaceflight.

Title: Hyperoxia inhibits T cell activation in mice
Keywords: Hyperoxia inhibits cell activation mice
Resumen: Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) is a severe lung disease in premature infants, where type II epithelial cell (AEC II) dysfunction is key. This study investigated the role of invariant natural killer T (iNKT) cells and their mechanisms in BPD. Using public data, clinical samples, a mouse model of hyperoxia-induced BPD, and a co-culture system, it was found that BPD patients and mice exposed to hyperoxia exhibited increased iNKT cell activation. Inhibition of iNKT cells alleviated abnormal lung development in mice, while their activation or transfer aggravated it. In a coculture system, the presence of iNKT cells under hyperoxia exacerbated the abnormal expression of SP-C and T1? in AEC II and promoted ferroptosis of these cells. The findings suggest that the recruitment and overactivation of iNKT cells in the lung are an important cause of alveolarization disturbance in BPD, by inducing ferroptosis in AEC II.

Title: Effects of gravitational mechanical unloading in endothelial cells: association between caveolins, inflammation and adhesion molecules
Keywords: gravitational mechanical unloading endothelial cells association
Resumen: study investigated the impact of gravitational mechanical unloading (MU) on endothelial cell (EC) function and gene expression. MU in human endothelial cells was found to significantly decrease the expression of adhesion molecules and proinflammatory cytokines, while increasing the expression of eNOS, caveolin-1, and -2. The cells also showed a reduction in size and cytoskeletal disorganization, with caveolin-1 localizing perinuclearly. Reintroduction of brief periods of mechanical loading (ML) during MU was sufficient to completely reverse these changes. Although MU increased nitrite production, nitric oxide synthase (NOS) inhibition did not mitigate the decrease in adhesion and inflammatory molecules. These findings highlight that gravitational forces dramatically affect EC function, with implications for cardiovascular disease and the effects of low-gravity environments.

Title: n-3 Polyunsaturated fatty acids supplementation in peripheral artery disease: the OMEGA-PAD trial
Keywords: n 3, polyunsaturated, fatty acids, supplementation, peripheral
Resumen: The OMEGA-PAD II trial investigated the effects of three months of high-dose oral supplementation of n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (fish oil) in 24 patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) and claudication. This double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled study found that patients receiving fish oil showed significant increases in their omega-3 index and plasma levels of specialized pro-resolving lipid mediators (SPMs), including lipoxin A5 and resolvin E3, compared with the placebo group. However, no significant changes were observed in markers of inflammation (high-sensitivity C-reactive protein), endothelial function, or walking ability. The study concludes that fish oil increases MPS in patients with PAD, but further research is needed to determine whether these changes translate into clinical improvements.

Title: Molecular mechanisms underlying the enhanced functions of three-dimensional hepatocyte aggregates
Keywords: molecular, mechanisms, underlying, enhanced, functions, three dimensional
Resumen: Three-dimensional (3D) culture of hepatocytes in rotating wall (RWV) bioreactors significantly improves their synthetic and metabolic functions compared to monolayer culture (TCD). A global analysis of gene expression revealed that the upregulated genes in 3D culture are hepatocyte-specific, with a notable overrepresentation of Hnf4a binding sites in their promoters and an increase in the expression of Hnf4a and its target genes. Simultaneously, suppression of mesenchymal and cytoskeletal genes was observed. These findings demonstrate that 3D cell-cell interactions are crucial for maintaining fundamental molecular pathways of liver function, providing a basis for designing biomaterials that optimize hepatocyte functions ex vivo for biomedical applications such as drug screening and tissue engineering.

Title: Spaceflight alters expression of microRNA during T-cell activation
Keywords: spaceflight alters expression microrna during t cell
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of spaceflight microgravity on immune function, specifically on T cell activation and microRNA (miRNA) expression, which represents a barrier to long-term space exploration. Using human leukocytes stimulated on the International Space Station with onboard normal gravity controls, miR-21 was found to be significantly upregulated in normal gravity during early T cell activation, but its expression was suppressed in microgravity. This finding, the first to report that spaceflight alters miRNA expression, was confirmed by quantitative real-time PCR.
