A global microarray analysis revealed the suppression of 85 genes under microgravity conditions. The data suggest that gravity regulates T cell activation not only by promoting transcription but also by blocking translation through noncoding RNA mechanisms, and imply that T cell activation may be a self-limiting process mediated by miR-21.

Title: Spaceflight impairs antigen-specific tolerance induction in vivo and increases inflammatory cytokines.
Keywords: spaceflight, impairs, antigen specific, tolerance, induction, vivo
Resumen: pioneering study investigated the health risks of a dysregulated immune response during spaceflight, essential for human travel plans to Mars. Using a mouse adoptive T cell transfer model, researchers induced an antigen-specific immune response in space. In-flight mice that received the antigen (ovalbumin) showed a significant (twofold) increase in specific T cells and a dramatic increase in pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IFN-? (5-fold) and IL-17 (10-fold) compared to ground-based control mice. These results suggest that spaceflight alters the induction of immune tolerance, which could lead to excessive inflammatory responses, a finding with important implications for the health of space travelers.

Title: From cellular mechanotransduction to biologically inspired engineering: 2009 Pritzker Award Lecture, BMES Annual Meeting October 10, 2009.
Keywords: from, cellular, mechanotransduction, biologically, inspired, engineering
Resumen: This article, based on the 2009 Pritzker Distinguished Lecture, summarizes over thirty years of research by Donald E. Ingber on cellular tensegrity architecture. Initially a cell biologist, Ingber incorporated engineering to test his theory that cells employ tensegrity (tensional integrity) to stabilize their shape and sense mechanical cues, which is crucial for cell function and tissue development. His work confirmed the fundamental role of physical forces in controlling cellular development and mechanotransduction, highlighting the central role of integrins and the cytoskeleton. This fundamental research has generated technological innovations such as micromagnetic actuators, microfluidic systems for sepsis therapy, and DNA-based nanobiotechnology for constructing artificial tensegrities with applications in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine. The author compares the cell to a tent, not a water balloon, and dedicates his work to his students and collaborators, emphasizing the importance of mutual learning.

Title: Crewmember microbiome may influence microbial composition of ISS habitable surfaces
Keywords: crewmember, microbiome, may, influence, microbial, composition
Resumen: The Microbial Tracking-2 study investigated the microbial interaction between the International Space Station (ISS) and a crew member using metagenomic sequencing. Body samples (mouth, nose, ear, skin, saliva) from the crew member were analyzed at different stages pre-, during, and post-flight, as well as from eight environmental surfaces on the ISS. The results revealed that the microbial composition of the crew member's skin, nose, and ear was more similar to that of ISS surfaces than that of the mouth and saliva. Furthermore, the species diversity in saliva decreased during flight and recovered upon return to Earth. This pioneering study concludes that the microbiome on ISS surfaces resembles that of crew skin, which is crucial for microbial surveillance and the design of preventive measures on future long-duration space missions.

Title: Sierra Nevada sweep: Metagenomic measurements of bioaerosols vertically distributed across the troposphere.
Keywords: Sierra Nevada sweep metagenomic measurements bioaerosols
Resumen: study using NASA's C-20A aircraft investigated microbial patterns in the air over the U.S. Sierra Nevada in June 2018. Bioaerosol samples were collected at four different altitudes (from 10,000 to 40,000 feet) and analyzed using metagenomic DNA sequencing and traditional cultivation methods. Results showed that microbial composition and diversity changed significantly with altitude and between sampling days, identifying distinct predominant genera at each altitude and detecting viable bacteria in the upper troposphere. The project also developed a model to estimate the probability of human exposure to bioaerosols, seeking to lay the groundwork for global monitoring of bioaerosol emissions and impacts.

Title: Draft Genome Sequences of Fungi Isolated from the International Space Station during the Microbial Tracking-2 Experiment
Keywords: draft, genome, sequences, fungi, isolated, from
Resumen: In the Microbial Tracking-2 study, the genomes of 94 fungal strains were isolated and sequenced from the surfaces of the International Space Station. The objective is to characterize these genomes to assess adaptation to microgravity, risks to human health and spacecraft operation, as well as potential biotechnological applications, given that fungi can be both beneficial (sources of nutrients) and harmful (infections, biocontamination). The identified fungi include species of Aspergillus, Aureobasidium pullulans, Cladosporium, Fusarium, Penicillium, and Rhodotorula mucilaginosa, some of which were already known on the ISS or in space environments. Samples were collected using moist wipes, DNA was extracted, and whole-genome shotgun sequencing was performed. The sequence data have been deposited in GenBank and the NASA GeneLab system.

Title: Microbial tracking-2, a metagenomics analysis of bacteria and fungi onboard the International Space Station.
Keywords: Microbial tracking 2, metagenomics, bacteria and fungi
Resumen: The Microbial Tracking 1 and 2 (MT-1 and MT-2) projects conducted a comprehensive analysis of the surface microbiome of the International Space Station (ISS) over a five-year period, using shotgun metagenomics and cultivation methods. The study characterized microbial communities, their temporal and spatial shifts, the prevalence of antimicrobial resistance genes, functional capabilities, and microbial interactions. The ISS microbiome was found to be dominated by bacteria (82%) and fungi (10%), primarily organisms associated with human skin such as Staphylococcus sp. and Malassezia sp. Significant temporal changes in the microbial population were observed, but not spatial differences, and antimicrobial resistance gene profiles remained stable over time, with resistance to macrolides/lincosamides/streptogramins being the most widespread. The data revealed a propensity for amino acid utilization and strong associations between bacterial and fungal genera. The findings are important for informing policies for future space missions and safeguarding astronaut health and spacecraft integrity.

Title: Detection of Target Genes for Drug Repurposing to Treat Skeletal Muscle Atrophy in Mice Flown in Spaceflight
Keywords: detection, target, genes, for, drug, repurposing
Resumen: The article investigates skeletal muscle atrophy, common in aging, diabetes, and microgravity spaceflight, with the goal of identifying existing drugs for therapeutic repurposing. To do so, it uses link prediction algorithms in gene-disease and disease-drug networks constructed from transcriptomic data from mice exposed to spaceflight (GeneLab). Using network analysis and machine learning, such as graph convolutional neural networks (GCNs), key genes regulating muscle atrophy, primarily associated with metabolic and neurodegenerative diseases, were identified. The GCN method proved to be the most effective for link prediction. The drugs selected for potential repurposing include nutrients, corticosteroids, anti-inflammatory drugs, and other insulin-related drugs.

Title: Release of CD36-associated cell-free mitochondrial DNA and RNA as a hallmark of spatial environment response
Keywords: release, cd36 associated, cell free, mitochondrial, dna, and
Resumen: recent study investigated the effects of spaceflight on human health using liquid biopsies to analyze cell-free RNA (cfRNA) in six astronauts who remained on the International Space Station for more than 120 days. Initial results confirmed previously reported mitochondrial dysregulation during spaceflight, observing a significant increase in mitochondrial DNA and cfRNA. A fraction enriched in mitochondrial DNA associated with the CD36 receptor was identified, suggesting that mitochondrial components from various tissues are released into the plasma. Comparison with data from mice exposed to artificial gravity established a link between microgravity and these mitochondrial responses. Furthermore, changes were detected in cfRNAs related to reactive oxygen species, the nervous system, skeletal muscle, and the vitamin D receptor signaling pathway, indicating systemic alterations. This minimally invasive approach is key to detailed longitudinal monitoring and the development of countermeasures for future long-duration space missions.

Title: Increasing the number of unloading/reambulation cycles does not adversely impac body composition and lumbar bone mineral density but reduces tissue sensitivity
Keywords: increasing, number, unloading, reambulation, cycles, does
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of repeated cycles of hindlimb unloading (HLU) and reambulation (RA) in mice, comparing one, two, or three exposures with controls. All HLU groups showed losses in body mass, abdominal adipose tissue (primarily visceral), and vertebral bone mineral density. However, the first cycle of HLU resulted in significantly greater initial losses of body mass and total adipose tissue compared with subsequent cycles, indicating an attenuation of the response. Both abdominal adipose tissue and vertebral bone mineral density recovered to levels similar to those of controls after the final period of RA, regardless of the number of cycles. In contrast, hindlimb muscle cross-sectional area remained significantly smaller than in controls even after reambulation. The results suggest that abdominal tissues are more resilient to multiple episodes of unloading and more prone to recovery than the peripheral musculoskeletal system.

Title: Bone shaft bending strength index is unaffected by exercise and unloading in mice
Keywords: bone, shaft, bending, strength, index, unaffected
Resumen: Anthropologists often use the femoral flexural strength index (Imax/Imin) to infer the physical activity levels of past humans from skeletal remains, assuming that high values indicate greater activity and low values indicate sedentary behavior. However, a study in mice tested this assumption using treadmill exercise experiments to simulate high activity and limb suspension exercises to simulate low activity. The results showed that while activity altered bone robustness (Imax and Imin), there was no significant change in the Imax/Imin ratio in either group. This suggests that caution should be exercised when using this index to reconstruct past activity levels in humans.

Title: Focal enhancement of the skeleton to exercise correlates to mesenchymal stem cell responsivity rather than peak external forces.
Keywords: focal enhancement, skeleton, exercise, correlates, mesenchymal
Resumen: This study in mice investigated bone adaptation to exercise and mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) responsiveness. Although the forelimbs generated significantly greater peak forces than the hindlimbs during locomotion, the effects of exercise on the skeleton were site-specific and not defined by the magnitude of the load. The bone structures of the femur, tibia, and ulna showed significant improvements after exercise, whereas the humerus and radius, which experienced greater forces, did not. Bone marrow-derived MSCs in the femur were more sensitive to exercise-induced loads than those in the humerus, with their population decreasing. This suggests that the ability of progenitor populations to differentiate toward osteogenesis may better correlate with bone structural adaptation than maximum external forces.

Title: Cytoskeletal configuration modulates mechanically induced changes in mesenchymal stem cell osteogenesis, morphology, and stiffness.
Keywords: cytoskeletal configuration modulates mechanically induced changes
Resumen: This study investigated the response of human bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells (hBMSCs) to low-intensity vibrations (LIV) applied horizontally or vertically in 2D culture. All LIV signals were found to enhance hBMSC proliferation, osteogenic differentiation, and the expression of genes associated with cytoskeletal structure. However, the cellular response was more pronounced at higher frequencies (100 Hz vs. 30 Hz) and when LIV was applied horizontally, realigning the cytoskeleton and increasing cell stiffness. The results suggest that applying small oscillatory movements within the plane of cell adhesion is more effective than perpendicularly, facilitating a more efficient transfer of intracellular forces and emphasizing the importance of cytoskeletal configuration in the detection of high-frequency, low-intensity mechanical signals.

Title: Genetic and tissue level muscle-bone interactions during unloading and reambulation.
Keywords: genetic, and, tissue, level, muscle bone, interactions
Resumen: study involving 352 genetically heterogeneous mice investigated the interaction between muscle and bone during three weeks of hindlimb unloading, followed by three weeks of reambulation. The objective was to determine whether muscle changes are associated with bone changes and whether their genetic regulation overlaps. The results showed that while most mice lost muscle and cortical bone during unloading and regained them at different rates during reambulation, morphological changes between muscle and bone (cortical and trabecular) were not correlated. Furthermore, quantitative trait loci (QTLs) identified for muscle area and cortical bone during unloading and reambulation showed largely distinct genetic regulation. These low correlations and genetic divergence suggest that the hypothesis of a "muscle-bone unit" that co-adjusts its size in response to mechanical loading may need to be re-evaluated.

Title: Osteocyte apoptosis caused by hindlimb unloading is required to trigger osteocyte RANKL production and subsequent resorption of cortical and trabecular bone in mice femurs.
Keywords: osteocyte apoptosis caused hindlimb unloading required
Resumen: This study investigated the role of osteocyte apoptosis in bone remodeling and loss caused by disuse. Contrary to previous debate, the researchers demonstrated that hindlimb unloading (HLU) in mice significantly increases osteocyte apoptosis and RANKL expression in cortical and trabecular bone, events that precede bone resorption. Pharmacological inhibition of this apoptosis with QVD not only prevented HLU-induced increases but also halted RANKL production, bone resorption activation, and subsequent trabecular bone loss. This establishes that osteocyte apoptosis plays a central and controlling role in the initiation of disuse bone resorption and loss.

Title: Differential Single Cell Responses of Embryonic Stem Cells Versus Embryoid Bodies to Gravity Mechanostimulation
Keywords: differential, single, cell, responses, embryonic, stem
Resumen: This study investigated how a 60-minute hypergravity (HG) pulse affects the transcriptomic regulation of developmental processes in embryonic stem cells (ESCs) and embryoid bodies (EBs) using single-cell RNA sequencing. It was found that, although overall transcriptomic changes were limited, HG induced greater positional changes in EBs compared to ESCs, suggesting that mechanotransduction is more pronounced at advanced stages of cellular commitment. Specifically, HG resulted in the upregulation of self-renewal and angiogenesis genes in ESCs, while in EBs, it was associated with the activation of multicellular developmental pathways, mechanistic signal transduction, and DNA damage repair, promoting the maintenance of transient cellular phenotypes. The study concludes that ESC maintenance and EB development can be regulated by gravitational mechanostimulation, and that stem cells committed to a differentiation program are more sensitive to gravity-induced transcriptomic changes.

Title: Macrophages inhibit Aspergillus fumigatus germination and neutrophil-mediated fungal killing.
Keywords: macrophages, inhibit, aspergillus, fumigatus, germination, and
Resumen: This study investigates how the immune system controls *Aspergillus fumigatus* infection using transparent zebrafish larvae. The findings reveal a novel role for macrophages, which form clusters around spores and inhibit their germination, promoting fungal persistence. Direct spore germination was found to boost their clearance, with faster-growing strains (such as CEA10) being better killed by neutrophils than slower-growing strains (such as Af293). Furthermore, host inflammatory activation is crucial for the elimination of the CEA10 strain, but insufficient for Af293, underscoring the intrinsic differences in fungal virulence. The study highlights the diverse modes of virulence of *A. fumigatus* and offers valuable information for future strategies in the treatment of fungal infections in immunocompromised individuals.

Title: Contributions of spore secondary metabolites to UV-C protection and virulence vary in different Aspergillus fumigatus strains
Keywords: contributions, spore, secondary, metabolites, uv c, protection
Resumen: study investigated the role of secondary metabolites, especially melanin, in spores of the pathogenic fungus *Aspergillus fumigatus* against UV-C radiation and their virulence. Melanin was found to protect spores from UV-C radiation in some clinical strains of *A. fumigatus*, but not in a strain isolated from the International Space Station (ISS). Furthermore, fumiquinazoline also showed UV-C protective properties, whereas other metabolites such as monomethylsulocrine and fumigaclavine did not. Regarding virulence, melanin was a factor in some strains, but not all, and the deletion of monomethylsulocrine showed a slight increase in virulence. The results suggest that secondary metabolites play variable roles in spore protection, depending on the environmental stress and the fungal strain, with implications for developing safety measures for future human space travel.

Title: Regulation of hemocytes in Drosophila requires dappled cytochrome b5.
Keywords: regulation, hemocytes, drosophila, requires, dappled, cytochrome
Resumen: This study identifies the *dappled* gene in *Drosophila* as an essential gene encoding cytochrome b5, a conserved hemoprotein crucial for electron transfer in diverse biochemical reactions. Viable *dappled* mutations cause melanotic tumors (nodules of abnormal, overproliferated blood cells) and dysregulation of hemocytes during development. The *dappled* gene offers a tractable genetic model for investigating cytochrome b5 function, which is difficult to study in higher organisms, and initial evidence indicates that compounds such as curcumin may modulate its melanotic phenotype.

Title: A novel phototropic response to red light is revealed in microgravity.
Keywords: novel phototropic response red light revealed
Resumen: study conducted on the International Space Station investigated the interaction between light-mediated growth responses (phototropism) and gravity (gravitropism) in *Arabidopsis thaliana* roots. The researchers discovered a novel positive phototropy of roots to blue light under microgravity, a response that is masked by gravity on Earth and attenuates as fractional gravity increases. Furthermore, a positive phototropic response to red light was observed in roots, the magnitude of which correlated with the magnitude of gravity. Red light pretreatment also enhanced positive phototropic curvature to blue light, and both phototropic responses were determined to be influenced by directional light intensity. This work represents the first characterization of a positive phototropic response to blue light in *Arabidopsis* roots and the first description of the relationship between these phototropic responses under reduced or fractional gravities.

Title: Plant cell proliferation and growth are altered by microgravity conditions in spaceflight.
Keywords: plant cell proliferation and growth are
Resumen: Understanding plant adaptation mechanisms to the space environment, especially altered gravity and cosmic radiation, is critical for human space exploration. Transcriptomic analyses have revealed that processes such as cell wall remodeling, oxidative stress, defense response, and photosynthesis are commonly affected in plants grown in space or microgravity simulators. Although space research faces significant limitations, decades of study, including experiments such as BRIC-16 in *Arabidopsis thaliana*, have shown that microgravity alters gene expression related to stress responses and cellular metabolism, suggesting an imbalance in gravitational signaling systems. Light is also identified as a crucial factor in adaptation, with European contributions highlighting its role and cellular response mechanisms.

Title: Phototropism of Arabidopsis thaliana in microgravity and fractional gravity on the International Space Station.
Keywords: phototropism, Arabidopsis thaliana, microgravity and fractional
Resumen: This study investigated the interplay between phototropism and gravitropism in *Arabidopsis thaliana* roots under various gravity conditions on the International Space Station. A novel positive phototropism of roots to blue light was observed in microgravity, masked by gravity and attenuated at 0.1 g. The magnitude of positive phototropic curvature to red light in roots decreased correlatedly with increasing gravity, and a red light pretreatment enhanced positive phototropic curvature to blue light. Both phototropic responses to red and blue light were influenced by the intensity of the directional light. This work represents the first characterization of positive phototropism to blue light in *Arabidopsis* roots and its relationship with fractional gravity.

Title: Light and gravity signals synergize in modulating plant development
Keywords: Light and gravity signals synergize modulating
Resumen: Plants perform directed growth movements, known as tropisms, to adapt to environmental stimuli such as gravity (gravitropism) and light (phototropism), phenomena that have been shown to be interconnected. Current research, including experiments in microgravity, seeks to decouple these processes to better understand their molecular mechanisms. Microgravity has been observed to alter meristematic cells, affecting cell proliferation, the cell cycle, and ribosome biogenesis. Light, especially red light mediated by phytochromes, and phytohormones such as auxin, significantly influence these responses. Charles Darwin pioneered the study of these movements, postulating the existence of a factor that mediated the growth response. Gravity perception is localized to specialized cells (statocytes) and is primarily explained by the starch-statolith hypothesis, where dense amyloplasts sediment, guiding the distribution of auxin for directed growth (roots downward, stems upward). An alternative hypothesis, the protoplast pressure hypothesis, suggests that the cytoplasmic mass exerts tension. Future experiments on the International Space Station will continue to elucidate these complex mechanisms and their implications for plant development.

Title: novel blue-light phototropic response is revealed in roots of Arabidopsis thaliana in microgravity.
Keywords: novel, blue light, phototropic, response, revealed, roots
Resumen: This study, conducted on the International Space Station, investigated the interplay between phototropism and gravitropism in Arabidopsis thaliana roots under different gravity levels (from microgravity to 1g) and exposure to blue and red light. The researchers discovered a novel positive phototropism of roots to blue light in microgravity, a response that is normally masked by gravity. Furthermore, they observed that the magnitude of the positive phototropic bending to red light in roots decreases as gravity increases, and that a red light pretreatment intensifies the phototropic response to blue light. The results also confirmed the positive phototropism of hypocotyls to red light and showed that the intensity of the directional light affects both responses. This work represents the first characterization of positive phototropism to blue light in Arabidopsis roots and the relationship of these phototropic responses to fractional gravity.

Title: Comparative transcriptomics indicate changes in cell wall organization and stress response in seedlings during spaceflight
Keywords: comparative, transcriptomics, indicate, changes, cell, wall
Resumen: This study investigated the transcriptome of *Arabidopsis thaliana* in microgravity during the Space Shuttle mission STS-131, using BRIC-16 hardware. Changes in gene expression related to hypoxia, heat shock, DNA repair, and cell wall structure were detected in the spaceflight samples, supported by glycomic profiling that showed differences in cell wall components. Comparison with two other BRIC-16 experiments performed simultaneously with the same hardware revealed that, despite similarities, differences in gene expression results were found due to variations in genotypes, tissues, and analytical techniques. However, a common theme among the three studies was the deregulation of water stress-responsive genes and cell wall remodeling. These findings are crucial for understanding plant responses to the space environment and developing bioregenerative life support systems.

Title: RNAseq analysis of the response of Arabidopsis thaliana to fractional gravity under blue-light stimulation during spaceflight
Keywords: rnaseq, response, arabidopsis, thaliana, fractional, gravity
Resumen: The study investigated the transcriptional response of *Arabidopsis thaliana* seedlings under microgravity and various partial gravity levels on the International Space Station after being stimulated with blue light, seeking to understand plant adaptation to reduced gravity for future space life support systems. A single differentially expressed gene was identified across all FDR-corrected gravitational conditions, while 14 genes showed consistent differential expression when comparing microgravity, low gravity, or lunar gravity to the 1g control. The number of differentially expressed genes varied with gravity, distinctively affecting gene ontology clusters related to light and photosynthesis in microgravity, stress and hormones in low gravity, and cell wall/membrane structure at lunar gravity. The research suggests that root phototropism to blue light could mitigate gravitational stress in microgravity, and that competition between tropisms generates an intense perturbation that progressively decreases with increasing gravity. A significant effect on cell wall and membrane remodeling is highlighted, a possible key to resistance to gravity.

Title: Comparison of Microgravity Analogs to Spaceflight in Studies of Plant Growth and Development
Keywords: comparison, microgravity, analogs, spaceflight, studies, plant
Resumen: The text explores how Earth's gravity influences plant development and morphology, and the methods used to study these effects. Spaceflight experiments, which offer true weightlessness, are mentioned, providing crucial insights into plant biology. Analogous ground-based methods are also described, such as clinostats, random positioning machines (RPMs), and magnetic levitation, which attempt to simulate altered gravity by rotating specimens to constantly change the direction of the gravitational vector. However, it is noteworthy that these analogs do not reduce gravity but only change its direction, introducing artifacts such as centrifugal forces, mechanical stress, and sedimentation, which limits the fidelity of their results compared to real-world space experiments, especially in long-term studies of plant growth. Despite these limitations, clinostats remain a common tool due to their simplicity and availability, useful for comparisons, although their results should be interpreted with caution.

Title: The importance of Earth reference controls in spaceflight-omics research: Characterization of nucleolin mutants from the Seedling Growth experiments
Keywords: importance, earth, reference, controls, spaceflight omics, research
Resumen: This study investigates plant adaptive responses to environmental stresses, crucial for space agriculture, focusing on ribosomal biogenesis and nucleolin genes (NUC1 and NUC2) in Arabidopsis thaliana. Using mutants from ground-based studies, it was found that the NUC2 gene can compensate for darkness stress in nuc1 plants, while nuc2 plants are completely unresponsive to red light. Red light tends to mitigate genotypic differences in gene expression. These ground-based control findings, part of spaceflight experiments, are critical for identifying genetic traits that will enable plants to better adapt in future space experiments and for developing more efficient agriculture under suboptimal conditions.

Title: Conducting plant experiments in space and on the Moon
Keywords: conducting plant experiments in space and moon
Resumen: This study investigated the response of *Wolffia globosa* (duckweed) to different gravity levels (simulated microgravity, partial gravity, hypergravity, and 1g control) to assess its potential as a space crop. *Wolffia globosa* is a promising plant for bioregenerative life support systems due to its rapid growth and high nutritional value. The experiments, which used random positioning machines and large-diameter centrifuges, showed that the plant reacts mildly to gravitational changes. Although relative growth rates were reduced in microgravity and partial gravity, they remained substantial, and morphological differences were observed. In conclusion, the study underscores the adaptability of *Wolffia globosa* to diverse gravitational conditions, confirming its potential for sustainable food production in future space missions.

Title: Red light enhances plant adaptation to spaceflight and Mars g-levels.
Keywords: red, light, enhances, plant, adaptation, spaceflight
Resumen: Human space exploration relies on cultivating plants for bioregenerative life support systems that provide food, oxygen, and improved psychological well-being. Although plants can complete their life cycle in space, they face challenges such as microgravity and radiation. Experiments have revealed that microgravity disrupts cell growth and proliferation in the root meristem, reprograms gene expression, and alters hormonal pathways such as the auxin pathway. However, research also demonstrates that red light can partially reverse microgravity-induced genetic reprogramming, paving the way for targeted mutagenesis strategies to design crops adapted to space colonization.

Title: EUK-134 ameliorates nNOSÂ¬Âµ translocation and skeletal muscle fiber atrophy during short-term mechanical unloading.
Keywords: euk 134 ameliorates nnos translocation and skeletal
Resumen: Abstract generated: This article focuses on euk-134 ameliorates nnosÂ¬Âµ translocation and skeletal muscle fiber atrophy during short-term mechanical unloading.. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3962621/)

Title: MnSOD Overexpression Reduces Fibrosis and Pro-Apoptotic Signaling in the Aging Mouse Heart
Keywords: MNSOD overexpression reduces fibrosis and pro apoptotic
Resumen: Aging affects cardiac function through mechanical remodeling, myocyte loss through apoptosis, and collagen fiber accumulation. Although exercise protects against fibrosis and apoptosis in the aging heart, the mechanisms are not well understood. This study investigated whether overexpression of the enzyme manganese superoxide dismutase (MnSOD) is the cause of this protection. In aged mice with overexpression of the MnSOD gene, elevated levels of MnSOD were found in the left ventricle, along with lower oxidative stress, mitigation of age-related cardiac remodeling and fibrosis, and a reduction in pro-apoptotic markers and apoptosis. It is concluded that elevated MnSOD is effectively protective against oxidative stress, fibrosis, and apoptosis in the aging heart.

Title: Lifelong wheel running exercise and mild caloric restriction attenuate nuclear EndoG in the aging plantaris muscle.
Keywords: lifelong, wheel, running, exercise, and mild
Resumen: Abstract generated: This article focuses on lifelong wheel running exercise and mild caloric restriction attenuate nuclear endog in the aging plantaris muscle.. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5026643/)

Title: Age-related alterations in the sarcolemmal environment are attenuated by lifelong caloric restriction and voluntary exercise.
Keywords: age related, alterations, sarcolemmal, environment, are, attenuated
Resumen: This study investigated whether mild lifelong calorie restriction (8%) and the combination of calorie restriction with voluntary exercise could mitigate age-related alterations in the membrane environment of skeletal muscle fibers, which contribute to sarcopenia. Researchers used Fischer-344 rats to compare the effects of aging, calorie restriction, and exercise on the plantaris muscle. Aging resulted in discontinuous membrane expression of dystrophin-glycoprotein complex (DGC) proteins, decreased neuronal nitric oxide synthase (nNOS) content, increased key membrane repair proteins, and reduced NADPH oxidase isoform 2 (Nox2) subunits. However, lifelong caloric restriction and exercise significantly protected against these age-related DGC disruptions, maintaining membrane repair proteins and Nox2 subunits near the levels of young animals. The results suggest that caloric restriction and exercise are effective countermeasures against aging-associated myofiber membrane alterations.

Title: The impact of SRT2104 on skeletal muscle mitochondrial function, redox biology, and loss of muscle mass in hindlimb unloaded rats.
Keywords: impact srt2104 skeletal muscle mitochondrial function
Resumen: The present study investigated whether the SIRT1 activator, SRT2104, could rescue mechanical unloading-induced mitochondrial dysfunction in skeletal muscle, which causes muscle atrophy in microgravity. In rats subjected to hindlimb unloading, mitochondrial function in the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles was compared between control, unloaded, and SRT2104-unloaded groups. The results showed that SRT2104 preserved mitochondrial function in the unloaded gastrocnemius muscle, as evidenced by reduced proton leak and attenuation of the decrease in cytochrome c oxidase activity observed in the untreated group. Although hydrogen peroxide production and concentration were higher in the SRT2104-treated group in both muscles, accompanied by increased superoxide dismutase activity in the gastrocnemius, the study concludes that SRT2104 has the potential to maintain muscle cell health in microgravity by promoting necessary mitochondrial energy production.

Title: Bioreactor development for skeletal muscle hypertrophy and atrophy by manipulating uniaxial cyclic strain: Proof of concept.
Keywords: Bioreactor development for skeletal muscle hypertrophy
Resumen: Skeletal muscles atrophy in microgravity due to reduced tensile loads. This study addresses the challenge of modeling this with a bioreactor, testing a StrexCell® system that uses uniaxial cyclic stretch to induce hypertrophy and its cessation to induce atrophy in murine myotubes (C2C12). The results showed that cyclic stretch significantly increased myotube diameter and elevated anabolic markers such as talin and Akt phosphorylation. In contrast, stopping the stretching process caused a decrease in myotube diameter and an increase in inflammatory and catabolic markers, consistent with atrophy. This demonstrates the feasibility of this bioreactor for research into the effect of tensile loading on muscles in spaceflight contexts.

Title: Genomic and phenotypic characterization of Burkholderia isolates from the potable water system of the International Space Station
Keywords: Genomic and phenotypic characterization of Burkholderia isolates
Resumen: Microbial assessments were conducted on two flexible lines (UPA95 and UPA115) from the International Space Station (ISS) water recovery system following their return to Earth. Culture and molecular analyses revealed the presence of bacteria such as Burkholderia, Paraburkholderia, and Leifsonia, as well as fungi such as Fusarium and Lecythophora. Genomic analysis identified Burkholderia contaminans and Paraburkholderia fungorum, with the detection of chromate resistance genes indicating unique populations. Environmental scanning electron microscopy confirmed the formation of fungal-bacterial biofilms in these lines, marking the first evidence of biofilms in the ISS UPA flexlines. The B. contaminans isolates demonstrated considerable potential for biofilm formation. These findings identify the UPA flexlines as a distinct ecological niche and a novel area for biofilm growth within the water recovery system, which is crucial for developing engineering controls to prevent biofilms in future space station water systems.

Title: CAMDLES: CFD-DEM Simulation of Microbial Communities in Spaceflight and Artificial Microgravity
Keywords: camdles, cfd dem, simulation, microbial, communities, spaceflight
Resumen: This paper presents CAMDLES, a computational model that extends CFDEM® Coupling software to simulate biological flows, growth, and mass transfer in microbial communities under microgravity, both real and artificial (in devices such as rotating-wall bioreactors or RWVs). The aim is to investigate how ground-based simulation methods replicate the microbial experience in space, integrating fluid and particle dynamics with metabolism and biological growth. By simulating a cooperative community of Escherichia coli and Salmonella enterica, it was found that the greatest difference in growth rates between microgravity, an RWV, and 1g gravity occurs when species are colocalized in dense aggregates. This model provides a basis for future laboratory experiments and a framework for hypothesis generation and the design of biological experiments in microbial communities.

Title: Hardware validation of the Advanced Plant Habitat on ISS: Canopy photosynthesis in reduced gravity.
Keywords: hardware, validation, advanced, plant, habitat, iss
Resumen: The Advanced Plant Habitat (APH) is the largest plant growth facility deployed on the International Space Station (ISS), designed by NASA to conduct fundamental and applied plant research in microgravity. This closed system, assembled in 2018, enables complete environmental control (light intensity, spectral quality, humidity, CO2, photoperiod, temperature, and root zone humidity) and the execution of complex experimental profiles. A seven-week hardware validation test using Arabidopsis and wheat confirmed its operational capability to control these factors, measure gas exchange, evaluate crew procedures, and contain plant debris. The APH is designed for a ten-year mission, collecting physiological data that will improve our understanding of Earth's biology in reduced gravity, which is vital for future human space missions and the development of bioregenerative life support systems, enabling teleoperation from the ground with minimal crew intervention.

Title: Trimeric structure of (+)-pinoresinol-forming leading protein at 1.95 A resolution with three isolated active sites.
Keywords: trimeric, structure, pinoresinol forming, directing, protein, resolution
Resumen: The first three-dimensional structure of a (+)-pinoresinol-forming targeting protein (DP), PsDRR206, has been obtained at 1.95 ×… resolution. This protein forms a compact trimer, where each monomer presents an eight-stranded beta-barrel. Three putative substrate-binding sites were identified on the surface of the trimer, which are spatially separated, suggesting that each site directly facilitates monomeric coupling to achieve stereoselectivity. This discovery provides new insights into the radical-radical coupling of monolignols in plants, which is fundamental for the biosynthesis of lignans, including compounds of medicinal importance.

Title: Reduced Arogenate Dehydratase Expression: Ramifications for Photosynthesis and Metabolism
Keywords: reduced arogenate dehydratase expression, ramifications, for
Resumen: This study investigates the effects of modulating the enzyme arogenate dehydratase (ADT) in *Arabidopsis thaliana* on photosynthesis and secondary metabolism. The results show that a reduction in the carbon flux towards phenylalanine biosynthesis in ADT mutants impairs the consumption of photosynthetically produced ATP. This leads to an increased ATP/ADP ratio, a transient accumulation of starch, and lower rates of photosynthetic electron transport, due to an increase in the proton-motive force that dysregulates photosystem II activity. Furthermore, significant changes in secondary metabolites were observed, including a reduction in flavonoids, phenylpropanoids, lignans, and glucosinolates, and an increase in galactolipids and apocarotenoids. Although the most extreme mutant (*adt3/4/5/6*) showed a slight decrease in growth at an intermediate stage, there were no significant differences in respiration and carbon fixation rates. In conclusion, these findings reveal the profound impact of altered ADT activity and phenylalanine metabolism on secondary metabolites and photosynthesis, with implications for plant breeding.

Title: New insights into lignification via network and multi-omics analyzes of arogenate dehydratase knock-out mutants in Arabidopsis thaliana
Keywords: new, insights, into, lignification, via, network
Resumen: study investigated how reducing arogenate dehydratase (ADT) in Arabidopsis knockout mutants, which have up to 70% less lignin, disrupts their systems biology. Using integrated omics (metabolome, transcriptome, and proteome) and network analyses, it was found that lignin levels are regulated not only at the transcriptional level, but also through post-transcriptional and translational processes, such as those involving ribosomes and the spliceosome. Significant changes were identified in metabolic pathways related to glucosinolates, fatty acids, carotenoids, and phenylpropanoids, with an increase in some metabolites (carotenoids, galactolipids) and a decrease in others (glucosinolates, phenylpropanoids) observed in the mutants. These findings propose a new hypothesis for lignin biosynthesis, offering potential targets for bioengineering.

Title: Functional consequences of radiation-induced oxidative stress in cultured neural stem cells and the brain exposed to charged particle irradiation
Keywords: functional, consequences, radiation induced, oxidative, stress, cultured
Resumen: Exposure to low doses of charged particle radiation, such as those found in space, causes acute and persistent oxidative stress in neural stem and precursor cells, even at very low fluences. This stress, which can last for weeks or months, is associated with significant impairment in cognitive function, as demonstrated in mice. The findings suggest that astronauts may face an increased risk of decreased performance during missions and long-term neurocognitive sequelae due to space radiation.

Title: Exploration of space to achieve scientific breakthroughs
Keywords: exploration, space, achieve, scientific, breakthroughs
Resumen: Beta cell replacement therapy for type 1 diabetes is in a transformative phase, with advances in stem cells and gene editing showing potential for restoring insulin production. However, the text emphasizes that the "last mile" is the crucial challenge, as scientific feasibility does not guarantee large-scale accessibility. Current limitations include a shortage of donors for islet transplants, immune rejection, and the complexity of the procedure. The analogy of space exploration is used to illustrate that, although feasibility has been demonstrated, "colonization" or mass implementation requires entirely different engineering and faces obstacles of scalability and cost. Examples of gene therapies for rare diseases that failed in the market due to unsustainable pricing models are cited, warning that without a strategic shift, beta cell therapy could become an elite intervention. To overcome these challenges, the author proposes adopting a "Quality by Design" (QbD) approach from the outset, prioritizing scalability, ease of use, and economic viability over academic achievement or corporate interests, so that the therapy can move from proof of concept to an accessible treatment for millions.

Title: Network Analysis of Gene Transcriptions of Arabidopsis thaliana in Spaceflight Microgravity.
Keywords: network, gene, transcriptions, arabidopsis, thaliana, spaceflight
Resumen: The study analyzed transcriptomic data from *Arabidopsis thaliana* grown on the International Space Station to identify genes that influence root growth and cell wall biosynthesis under space microgravity. Using computational tools and graph theory approaches such as LASSO, Pearson correlation, and the HITS algorithm, gene regulatory networks were inferred. The analysis revealed that space microgravity significantly alters core genes involved in cell wall synthesis, protein transport, auxin response, stress responses, and catabolic processes. Key core genes regulating root growth and genes encoding nucleotide-diphospho-sugar interconversion enzymes with higher transcriptional regulation, important for cell wall biosynthesis, were highlighted. This research is crucial for understanding plant adaptation in space, which is essential for long-duration space missions.

Title: Detection of Genes in Arabidopsis thaliana L. Responding to DNA Damage from Radiation and Other Stressors in Spaceflight
Keywords: detection, genes, arabidopsis, thaliana, responding, dna
Resumen: This study analyzes the effects of ionizing radiation on the plant *Arabidopsis thaliana* in real and simulated spatial environments, using gene regulatory network inference and topological and spectral analysis. Genetic subnetworks involved in the DNA damage response were identified, highlighting ATR/ATM protein interactions that suggest novel mechanisms under low radiation doses and the involvement of non-radiation-induced genes in stress response, root growth, and plant development. Key genes involved in DNA repair were detected, and high-energy radiation was shown to intensify the damage response. Furthermore, activation of pigments such as flavonoids and carotenoids was found under low doses of radiation, but not under very high doses.

Title: The Effect of spaceflight on mouse olfactory bulb volume, neurogenesis, and cell death indicates the protective effect of novel environment.
Keywords: spaceflight, mouse, olfactory, bulb, volume, neurogenesis
Resumen: This study examined the impact of spaceflight on the olfactory bulb (OB) and neurogenesis in mice. It was found that mice maintained in confinement modules simulating spacecraft conditions on Earth (AEM-Earth) showed larger OB volume and more neuroblasts compared to mice in standard housing. However, mice that actually flew on the space shuttle for 13 days (AEM-Flight) did not show these positive effects and even had a higher density of apoptotic cells than mice in the AEM-Earth group. The findings suggest that factors present during spaceflight may negate the positive effects of an enriched environment and have contrary effects on OB size and neurogenesis.

Title: Effects of low-dose rate Å'â‰¥-irradiation combined with simulated microgravity on markers of oxidative stress, DNA methylation potential, and remodeling in the mouse heart
Keywords: low dose rate irradiation combined with simulated
Resumen: This study investigated the short- and long-term cardiac effects of simulated microgravity (hindlimb suspension) and low-dose gamma irradiation, individually and in combination, in a mouse model. Female mice were exposed for 21 days, and their cardiac tissues were analyzed at various intervals for markers of oxidative stress, inflammation, and remodeling. Results indicated that the combined exposure initially increased oxidative stress, but many markers returned to normal over a 9-month period, suggesting recovery. This study, the first of a large analysis, highlights the need for future research with larger numbers of animals to fully characterize these effects.

Title: Characterization of mouse ocular response to a 35-day spaceflight mission: Evidence of blood-retinal barrier disruption and ocular adaptations.
Keywords: characterization, mouse, ocular, response, 35 day, spaceflight
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of prolonged spaceflight on the retina and blood-retinal barrier (BRB) of mice, sending specimens to the International Space Station for 35 days. Results revealed a significant decrease in post-flight intraocular pressure, a significant increase in apoptosis in the retina and its endothelial cells, and alterations in the integrity of the BRB. Increased expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP-4) and PECAM-1 was observed, along with a reduction in the protein ZO-1, crucial for tight junctions. Proteomic analysis identified changes in 485 proteins related to cell death, the cell cycle, immune response, and metabolic stress. These findings indicate a complex cellular response that compromises retinal structure and BHR integrity following prolonged exposure to space.

Title: Mice Exposed to Combined Chronic Low-Dose Irradiation and Modeled Microgravity Develop Long-Term Neurological Sequelae.
Keywords: mice, exposed, combined, chronic, low dose, irradiation
Resumen: This study evaluated the long-term effects of spaceflight-analogous conditions on the brain using a mouse model, exposing mice to simulated microgravity (HLU) and/or low-dose irradiation (LDR) for 21 days, followed by a 4-month readaptation. Results showed minimal alterations in gene expression and cytosine methylation following single HLU or LDR treatments. However, combined HLU+LDR exposure induced significant changes in multiple pathways related to neurogenesis, neuroplasticity, neuropeptide regulation, and cellular signaling. They conclude that neurological readaptation after chronic combined exposure to LDR and HLU is a dynamic process involving pathways that regulate neuronal function and structure, which could lead to late-onset neurological sequelae.

Title: Spaceflight influences gene expression, photoreceptor integrity, and oxidative stress-related damage in the murine retina.
Keywords: spaceflight, influences, gene, expression, photoreceptor, integrity
Resumen: A study investigated the effects of 35 days of spaceflight on the retina of mice, revealing 600 differentially expressed genes related to visual perception and phototransduction, including twelve associated with retinitis pigmentosa. Cone photoreceptor degradation, increased retinal oxidative stress, and a significant decrease in retinal layer thickness were observed. These findings suggest that prolonged spaceflight may decrease retinal performance and cause visual impairment.

Title: Evaluating ocular response in the retina and optic nerve head after single and fractionated high-energy protons
Keywords: evaluating ocular response, retina and optic
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of high-energy proton radiation exposure (single or fractionated doses of 0.5 Gy) on apoptosis, oxidative stress, and blood-retinal barrier (BRB) integrity in the retina and optic nerve head (ONH) of mice. A significant increase in apoptotic cells and oxidative stress was documented in the retina and ONH, with more pronounced changes after a single dose. An alteration in BRB integrity was also found in the retina, evidenced by an increase in the expression of AQP-4 and PECAM-1 and a decrease in ZO-1. The study concludes that exposure to 0.5 Gy proton radiation induces oxidative stress-associated apoptosis in the retina and ONH, and alters BRB integrity in the retina. Furthermore, it suggests that cellular responses may be differentially regulated depending on the ocular region and dosing schedule.

Title: Characterization of gene expression profiles in the mouse brain after 35 days of spaceflight mission.
Keywords: characterization, gene, expression, profiles, mouse, brain
Resumen: study investigated the effects of spaceflight on the brains of mice, finding that a 35-day trip to the International Space Station significantly altered gene expression profiles. A decrease was observed in genes important for neuronal function, plasticity, myelin sheath maintenance, and innate immune responses, including antiviral and bacterial defense. Conversely, there was an increase in the expression of genes related to DNA damage and cellular stress. The results suggest that altered immune reactions are closely associated with spaceflight-induced stress responses and have a negative impact on neuronal function, highlighting the risks that the space environment poses to the central nervous system.

Title: A multi-omics longitudinal study of the murine retinal response to chronic low-dose irradiation and simulated microgravity.
Keywords: multi omics, longitudinal, murine, retinal, response, chronic
Resumen: This multi-omics study investigated the epigenomic and transcriptomic impacts of radiation and hindlimb unloading (an analogue of microgravity) on the retina of mice. A NASA GeneLab dataset was analyzed in which mice were exposed for 21 days and their retinas were examined at 7 days, 1 month, or 4 months post-exposure. A total of 4,178 differentially methylated loci or regions and 457 differentially expressed genes were identified, with the highest correlation in methylation differences observed between conditions at the same time point. Changes in nucleotide metabolism, as well as alterations in Notch and Wnt signaling, were detected. A total of 23 genes showed significant changes in methylation and expression related to retinal function and inflammatory response, with some of these changes persisting up to 4 months after exposure. The study highlights important molecular mechanisms at various stages of post-exposure.

Title: Evidence of spaceflight-induced adverse effects on photoreceptors and retinal function in the mouse eye.
Keywords: evidence spaceflight induced adverse photoreceptors and retinal
Resumen: This study investigated acute oxidative damage to ocular structure and retinal function in mice exposed to 35 days of spaceflight, also evaluating the efficacy of an antioxidant (BuOE). Mice that flew on the ISS showed significantly increased retinal oxidative stress and apoptotic cell death, as well as a marked reduction in electroretinogram (ERG) a and b wave amplitudes, indicating impaired photoreceptor and retinal function. Although BuOE treatment markedly decreased oxidative stress biomarkers, there were no significant differences in intraocular pressure and no complete recovery of retinal function between the flight groups. The findings suggest that spaceflight induces oxidative stress in the retina, which can lead to photoreceptor damage and impaired visual function.

Title: Effects of spaceflight on the brain
Keywords: spaceflight, brain
Resumen: The study investigated how gravity affects human position sense, employing three methods (two-arm pairing, one-arm pointing, and one-arm repositioning) in 12 participants during parabolic flights, simulating hypergravity (1.8G) and microgravity (0G). The results showed that in hypergravity, errors in the pairing and pointing tasks increased significantly. In microgravity, matching errors decreased markedly, while pointing errors decreased nonsignificantly. The repositioning task did not show significant changes in any of the gravitational conditions. It is suggested that errors in pairing and signaling are a consequence of the action of gravity on the elbow joint, altering the signal to muscle and joint receptors, while repositioning relies on a central memory independent of changes in gravity.

Title: Routine omics collection is a golden opportunity for European human research in space and analog environments.
Keywords: routine, omics, collection, golden, opportunity, for
Resumen: The text proposes establishing a routine omics data collection program for European astronauts and spaceflight participants, highlighting that this revolutionary technology in terrestrial medicine has untapped potential to improve occupational health in space. It argues that longitudinal and standardized collection of this data is feasible and represents a "golden opportunity" to understand the molecular mechanisms of space-induced physiological changes. This would enable the development of personalized medicine and artificial intelligence-based analyses, improving risk assessment and countermeasures for future missions (including long-duration and those beyond low-Earth orbit). Practical, scientific, ethical, and legal considerations (such as GDPR) are also discussed for creating policies that balance open data for research with subject protection.

Title: Spatial omics technologies at multimodal and single cell/subcellular level.
Keywords: spatial, omics, technologies, multimodal, and, single
Resumen: This text reviews the current and future landscape of spatial omics technologies, which enable a deep understanding of cellular organization and interactions at single-cell and subcellular resolution. The various methodologies, classified into targeted (antibody- or RNA-probe-based) and whole-transcriptome approaches, are explored, highlighting their differences in spatial resolution, multiplexing capacity, and coverage. The review analyzes the capabilities, advantages, and limitations of these techniques, with examples of specific methods and their relevance to research and clinical applications.

Title: Genomic characterization and radiation tolerance of Naganishia kalamii sp. nov. and Cystobasidium onofrii sp. nov. from Mars 2020 mission assembly facilities.
Keywords: genomic characterization and radiation tolerance naganishia
Resumen: This study describes the discovery of two new yeast species, *Naganishia kalamii* sp. nov. and *Cystobasidium onofrii* sp. nov., isolated from NASA cleanrooms during Mars 2020 mission assembly. Their classification was performed using a multiphase taxonomic approach that included morphology, multi-locus sequence analysis, and whole-genome sequencing. Both yeasts showed resistance to UV-C radiation and possess genes associated with tolerance to stresses such as dehydration, desiccation, osmotolerance, and psychrotolerance, underscoring the need to characterize extreme-tolerant microbes to improve NASA's planetary protection techniques and prevent contamination of other celestial bodies.

Title: Genome and clonal hematopoiesis stability contrasts with immune, cfDNA, mitochondrial, and telomere length changes during short duration spaceflight
Keywords: Genome and clonal hematopoiesis stability contrasts
Resumen: This study investigated the physiological, immunological, and genetic effects of short-duration spaceflight on the crew of the Inspiration 4 (I4) mission, the first all-civilian crew. Using a multi-omics approach and analyzing preflight, intraflight, and postflight blood samples, telomere length, genomic stability, and immune adaptations were examined. Key findings include telomere lengthening during spaceflight, telomere shortening upon return to Earth, and increased immune cell signatures that persisted months after return. No significant genomic instability or clonal hematopoiesis of undetermined potential (CHIP) was observed. This research provides valuable information for future civil and commercial space missions, serving as a benchmark for human adaptation.

Title: Inspiration4 data access through the NASA Open Science Data Repository
Keywords: inspiration4, data, access, through, nasa, open
Resumen: With commercial space travel becoming increasingly accessible, understanding its impact on human health is crucial. NASA's Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) offers transparent and fair access to biological studies, highlighting the SpaceX Inspiration 4 (I4) mission, which collected a wealth of omics and clinical data from civilian astronauts. These data facilitate comprehensive investigations into space-induced biological responses, enabling multimodal and longitudinal assessments. Its open access, coupled with community-driven data standards, leverages artificial intelligence and machine learning to yield valuable insights, guiding future mission planning and health risk mitigation. The article presents a concise guide for accessing and analyzing I4 data at OSDR, setting a precedent for post-mission health monitoring programs. Although much of the information is publicly available, raw data from sensitive human subjects requires an application and ethics approval process for access.

Title: Molecular and physiological changes in the SpaceX Inspiration4 civilian crew
Keywords: molecular and physiological changes spacex inspiration4
Resumen: SpaceX's Inspiration 4 mission, the first with an all-civilian crew in low-Earth orbit, aimed to study physiological, neurovestibular, and neurocognitive changes, as well as the feasibility of biomedical data collection. Findings revealed a variety of physiological and stress responses, neurovestibular changes, and neurocognitive alterations during the 3-day mission. Although molecular changes such as telomere lengthening and increased virus abundance were observed in flight, nearly all parameters returned to pre-flight levels after return to Earth. This suggests that short-duration civilian missions do not pose a significant health risk and offer a valuable opportunity to investigate the early stages of human adaptation to space, laying the groundwork for an expanding biomedical database that can inform the development of countermeasures.

Title: Telomeric RNA (TERRA) increases in response to spaceflight and high-altitude climbing
Keywords: telomeric, rna, terra, increases, response, spaceflight
Resumen: The study investigated telomeric RNA (TERRA) in the radiation-induced DNA damage response (DDR) in astronauts, mountaineers, and cell models. Radiation exposure was found to increase TERRA transcription, which plays a protective role by forming hybrids at telomeric double-strand breaks and facilitating recombination-mediated telomere lengthening. These findings have important implications for scenarios of chronic telomeric DNA damage, such as aging or oxidative stress, and suggest TERRA as a potential therapeutic strategy against ALT-positive tumors.

Title: Spatial multi-omics of human skin reveals KRAS and inflammatory responses to spaceflight
Keywords: spatial, multi omics, human, skin, reveals, kras
Resumen: A pioneering study examined the impact of short-duration spaceflight on human skin, using biopsies and multi-omics analyses from the Inspiration4 crew before and after the mission. The findings revealed significant upregulation of inflammation-associated genes and KRAS signaling across all skin regions. Altered interferon responses, DNA damage, epithelial barrier disruptions, T cell migration, and impaired regeneration, predominantly in external tissue compartments, were also observed. These changes were correlated with alterations in microbial and immune cell activity, providing the first comprehensive insights into astronaut skin for future missions and countermeasures.

Title: Longitudinal multi-omics analysis of host microbiome architecture and immune responses during short-term spaceflight
Keywords: longitudinal, multi omics, host, microbiome, architecture, and
Resumen: six-month longitudinal study of four individuals on the SpaceX Inspiration 4 mission characterized the human microbiome and immune system response to three days in orbit. Using metagenomics, metatranscriptomics, and immune cell profiling on 750 samples from 10 body sites before, during, and after flight, most microbial alterations were found to be transient, such as increased virus shedding on skin during flight. However, longer-term changes in the oral microbiome were detected, including an increase in dental plaque-associated bacteria, correlated with immune cell gene expression. Microbial genes related to phage activity and stress response were also enriched. These detailed findings on changes in astronauts' microbiomes and immune responses during short spaceflights are crucial for future missions, spacecraft design, and space habitat planning.

Title: Spatiotemporal expression and control of haemoglobin in space
Keywords: spatiotemporal expression and control haemoglobin space
Resumen: This study investigates how the space environment affects hemoglobin gene regulation by analyzing multi-omics data from astronauts on NASA, JAXA, and Inspiration4 missions. The results confirm "space anemia" by showing significant down-regulation of globin genes during flight, with levels returning to normal after landing, which could be due to a combination of hemolysis and reduced erythroid cell production. Furthermore, the study observed the activation of a switch from adult to fetal globin in space, a phenomenon similar to the one sought to induce hemoglobinopathies on Earth. This work provides valuable insights into the dynamic nature of globin gene regulation in space and its implications for space medicine.

Title: Single-cell multi-ome and immune profiles of the Inspiration4 crew reveal conserved, cell-type, and sex-specific responses to spaceflight
Keywords: single cell, multi ome, and, immune, profiles, inspiration4
Resumen: This study analyzed astronauts' immune responses to spaceflight using multi-omic and single-cell data from civilian crew members of the SpaceX Inspiration4 (I4) mission. Eighteen cytokines/chemokines related to inflammation, aging, and muscle homeostasis were found to change postflight. A "spaceflight signature" in gene expression was identified, enriched in pathways such as oxidative phosphorylation and immune function, the presence of which was confirmed in independent datasets. Key observations included upregulation of FOXP3 in T cells, long-term suppression of MHC class I genes, and the association of infection-related immune pathways with changes in the microbiome. The study reveals conserved and distinct immune disruptions, providing a roadmap for potential countermeasures to preserve astronaut health on future missions.

Title: Single-cell analysis identifies preserved features of immune dysfunction in simulated microgravity and spaceflight
Keywords: single cell, identifies, preserved, features, immune, dysfunction
Resumen: recent study investigated the impact of short-term simulated microgravity on human immune cells using single-cell analysis of PBMCs, validating the findings with data from real space missions. Microgravity was found to significantly alter pathways essential for optimal immunity, such as interferon signaling, the cytoskeleton, and innate inflammation, while also affecting T and NK cell function. The study also identified that microgravity mimics inflammatory aging processes and induces transcription of latent pathogens. Using machine learning, compounds like quercetin were found to be capable of reversing many of these alterations, offering potential countermeasures for maintaining immunity in space.

Title: The Space Omics and Medical Atlas (SOMA) and international astronaut biobank
Keywords: space omics and medical atlas soma
Resumen: The Space Omics and Medical Atlas (SOMA) is an integrated data and sample repository designed to address the biomedical challenges of spaceflight, where aerospace medicine is currently in its infancy. SOMA brings together clinical, cellular, and multi-omics profiles from diverse missions such as the NASA Twin Study and SpaceX Inspiration4, increasing the publicly available human omics data more than tenfold. This resource includes extensive molecular and physiological profiles (genomics, epigenomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, metabolomics, and microbiome), revealing consistent features such as cytokine changes and telomere elongation, even on short, three-day missions. SOMA seeks to Accelerate precision aerospace medicine by providing crucial data for health monitoring, risk mitigation, and countermeasure development for future lunar, Mars, and exploration missions.

Title: Secretome profiling reveals acute changes in oxidative stress, brain homeostasis, and coagulation following short-duration spaceflight
Keywords: secretome, profiling, reveals, acute, changes, oxidative
Resumen: study profiled the secretomes (plasma proteins, metabolites, and vesicles/extracellular particles) of the SpaceX Inspiration4 crew to analyze the effects of short-duration spaceflight on human physiology. The results showed significant differences in coagulation, oxidative stress, and brain proteins. Although most altered proteins and metabolites in vesicles recovered within six months, a large portion of plasma proteins remained altered postflight, and these alterations were best correlated with peripheral blood mononuclear cells. A complementary study in space mice indicated a potential disruption of the blood-brain barrier. These findings demonstrate that even brief spaceflight impacts human and mouse physiology, providing crucial biomarkers for future countermeasures.

Title: Astronaut omics and the impact of space on the human body at scale
Keywords: astronaut omics and impact space human
Resumen: The text proposes the creation of a "Human Cell Space Atlas" and the application of high-resolution omics technologies as open global resources, essential for developing precision space-based healthcare. These advances are crucial for future long-duration planetary missions, which will involve a more diverse space population. The importance of international collaboration to standardize omics data and address the complex ethical, cultural, and legal challenges inherent to human omics in space is emphasized.

Title: Transcriptomics analysis reveals molecular alterations underpinning spaceflight dermatology.
Keywords: transcriptomics, reveals, molecular, alterations, underpinning, spaceflight
Resumen: This study investigates common dermatological problems in astronauts, the underlying biology of which is poorly understood, despite the fact that they pose a significant risk. Using a systems biology approach, transcriptomic data from the skin of space-exposed mice and biochemical and transcriptomic profiles from astronauts were analyzed. The findings suggest that changes in skin health, DNA damage and repair, and mitochondrial dysregulation are potential drivers of these risks, including alterations in skin barrier function and collagen formation. The study also highlights the ability of organisms to readapt to Earth following spaceflight, and its results may guide the development of countermeasures.

Title: Cosmic kidney disease: an integrated pan-omic, physiological and morphological study into spaceflight-induced renal dysfunction
Keywords: cosmic, kidney, disease, integrated, pan omic, physiological
Resumen: The paper describes research on the effects of spaceflight on kidney health, particularly during long-duration deep-space missions. Using biomolecular, chemical, and morphological analyses of samples from mice exposed to spaceflight and simulated cosmic radiation, as well as from humans, it was found that spaceflight induces dephosphorylation of renal transporters, which could increase the risk of kidney stones, and causes nephron remodeling with distal convoluted tubule expansion and loss of tubule density. Furthermore, simulated cosmic radiation, equivalent to a mission to Mars, caused kidney damage and dysfunction. These findings suggest that spaceflight directly contributes to kidney stone formation and that space radiation can cause significant kidney damage.

Title: Spaceflight induces changes in gene expression profiles linked to insulin and estrogen
Keywords: spaceflight, induces, changes, gene, expression, profiles
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of spaceflight on insulin and estrogen signaling in mice and humans. Significant changes were observed in both groups, particularly in the mouse liver, where inhibition of insulin and estrogen signaling, hepatic insulin resistance, and steatosis were found. In humans, spaceflight induced alterations in genes and pathways related to insulin and estrogen, insulin resistance, stress response, and viral infection. These findings highlight the need for further research into the metabolic and reproductive endocrinological impacts of spaceflight for the future of the species.

Title: Protective alleles and precision healthcare in crewed spaceflight
Keywords: Protective alleles and precision healthcare crewed
Resumen: The text addresses the growing need to understand and protect human health during deep and long-duration space missions, given the greater diversity of the astronaut population. It emphasizes that health risks in space, such as radiation exposure and bone demineralization, require more personalized and effective countermeasures. To this end, the paper proposes the use of "omics" technologies to identify protective alleles and develop individualized nutrition, exercise, and treatment recommendations, benefiting both space explorers and people in challenging terrestrial environments, although technical and ethical challenges remain.

Title: To boldly go where no microRNAs have gone before: Spaceflight impact on risk for small-for-gestational-age infants
Keywords: boldly, where, micrornas, have, gone, before
Resumen: The text describes an official U.S. government website (.gov, secured with HTTPS) and the details of a scientific article. This article, published in Communications Biology (October 5, 2024) and covering topics in systems biology, systems analysis, and reproductive disorders, has been corrected to include an omitted acknowledgment to the U.S. Army Medical Research Command for support of LIG. It is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives 4.0 International License, which permits noncommercial use, dissemination, and reproduction with proper attribution, but not adaptation of the material. Content is provided by Nature Publishing Group through the National Library of Medicine.

Title: Growth chambers on the International Space Station for large plants
Keywords: growth, chambers, international, space, station, for
Resumen: study compared wheat grains grown on the International Space Station (ISS) with a ground-based control group to assess the impact of microgravity on their characteristics. The ISS grains were found to be significantly smaller in weight, area, length, and width, although the differences in perimeter, depth, and roundness were not statistically significant. Contrary to hypothesis, no significant increase in fluctuating skewness was found in the space grains; both groups showed low to very low skewness. Differences in starch composition were identified, with larger type A granules in the ISS grains, but a higher ratio of type B to type A starch in the terrestrial grains, suggesting better baking qualities in the latter. Furthermore, the aleurone layer was inferior in the ISS grains. The study also proposed a new, non-traumatic method for assessing grain asymmetry, with potential for future computerized scanning developments.

Title: Microbiological and nutritional analysis of lettuce crops grown on the International Space Station
Keywords: microbiological, and, nutritional, lettuce, crops, grown
Resumen: This study evaluates the microbiological safety and nutritional quality of red romaine lettuce grown in the Veggie Modules of the International Space Station (ISS) to supplement astronaut diets, comparing it with plants grown on Earth under similar environmental conditions. Microbiological analyses of leaves and roots (bacterial and fungal counts, isolate identification, and community characterization by sequencing) and nutritional analyses (elemental composition, phenolic levels, anthocyanins, and antioxidant capacity) were performed. Although some differences in total bacterial and yeast/mold counts and microbial diversity were observed between tissues and specific experiments, no human pathogens were found. There were also differences in the content of some elements (Fe, K, Na, P, S, Zn) and in the levels of total phenolics between the flight and ground plants. The study concludes that leafy green vegetables can produce fresh, safe, and edible foods for astronauts' diets, providing reference data for the continued operation of veggie cultivation systems on the ISS.

Title: Natural variation in the expression of ORGANIC CATION TRANSPORTER 1 affects root length responses to cadaverine in Arabidopsis.
Keywords: natural, variation, expression, organic, cation, transporter
Resumen: The study investigates how cadaverine, a polyamine, affects plant development, focusing on root length sensitivity in *Arabidopsis thaliana*. It shows that natural variation in ORGANIC CATION TRANSPORTER 1 (OCT1) influences this response. Resistant *Arabidopsis* accessions, such as those from the Cape Verde Islands (Cvi), showed increased OCT1 expression compared to sensitive ones, such as Landsberg erecta (Ler). Furthermore, *oct1* mutants were more sensitive to cadaverine, and the level of OCT1 expression, rather than its specific accession origin, correlated with the response to cadaverine. These findings suggest that reduced OCT1 expression contributes to cadaverine sensitivity in certain accessions.

Title: Auxin: Shape matters.
Keywords: auxin, shape, matters
Resumen: This study evaluated the effect of AsiMax 50®, a commercial formulation of the herbicide 2,4-D, on the structure of freshwater microbial communities, including micro + nano phytoplankton, photosynthetic picoplankton, and bacterioplankton. Using microcosms, two microbial assemblages, from clear and turbid water systems, were exposed to seven concentrations of the herbicide for seven days. Results indicated a greater impact in the turbid system, where the total abundance of live micro + nano phytoplankton increased significantly at low concentrations, while in both systems, species richness and abundance decreased at higher concentrations. This suggests that 2,4-D may mimic a hormonal function. The study concludes that using community-scale approaches in ecotoxicology is crucial for predicting changes in freshwater ecosystems, although caution is warranted when extrapolating laboratory results to real-life scenarios.

Title: Gravity signaling in flowering plant roots
Keywords: gravity, signaling, flowering, plant, roots
Resumen: This study identifies a rice mutant (*crw1*) that exhibits root coiling in hydroponics but normal gravitropic growth in soil. It is caused by a loss of function of the gene *COILING ROOT IN WATER 1 (CRW1)*, which encodes an OsEBF1 protein, which amplifies ethylene signaling. This signaling increases reactive oxygen species (ROS) at the root tip, affecting root tip stability, OsPIN2 polar localization, and auxin distribution, ultimately impairing gravitropism.
