However, mechanosensation induced by growth in soil or mechanical resistance generates calcium signaling that antagonizes the ethylene pathway, safeguarding gravitropism. The work reveals an unexpected interaction between ethylene, auxin, and mechanosensation in the control of plant gravitropism.

Title: Cadaverine regulates biotin synthesis to modulate primary root growth in Arabidopsis
Keywords: cadaverine, regulates, biotin, synthesis, modulate, primary
Resumen: study in *Arabidopsis thaliana* revealed that cadaverine, a polyamine, modulates root growth by inhibiting biotin biosynthesis. A genetic screen identified the *cadaverine hypersensitive 3* (cdh3) mutation, which confers cadaverine hypersensitivity and affects the BIO3-BIO1 gene, which is key in biotin production. The research demonstrated that cadaverine directly reduces BIO3-BIO1 activity and the biotinylation of essential proteins for fatty acid synthesis, such as BCCP1, thereby affecting lipid metabolism and root growth. Supplementation with biotin or its intermediates reversed this sensitivity, confirming the role of cadaverine as a regulator of the biotin pathway.

Title: Low-speed clinorotation of Brachypodium distachyon and Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings triggers root tip curvatures that are reminiscent of gravitropism.
Keywords: low speed, clinorotathione, brachypodium, distachyon, and arabidopsis
Resumen: This study investigates the effect of low-speed clinorotation on root tip curvature in *Arabidopsis thaliana* and *Brachypodium distachyon* seedlings. Experiments demonstrate that low-speed clinorotation triggers root tip curvature, the direction of which is dictated by gravitropism during the first half-turn and the angle of which is modulated by the rotation speed. Mutations affecting gravity perception or transduction alter this response, and relocalization of the PIN3 protein and the formation of a lateral auxin gradient are observed. These observations suggest that gravitropism plays a key role in modulating root curvature responses to clinorotation.

Title: New device for high-throughput viability screening of flow biofilms
Keywords: new, device, for, high throughput, viability, screening
Resumen: The text describes a novel high-throughput method for screening continuous-flow biofilms, which are more representative of natural biofilms than static ones. This method employs a BioFlux device with microfluidic channels and a pneumatic pump that allows the cultivation of 96 individual biofilms with controlled fluid flow. Viability is rapidly determined using GFP-expressing bacteria, propidium iodide staining, and fluorescence measurement with a plate reader. This technique has demonstrated high concordance with traditional plate counts and microscopy, thus facilitating the efficient screening of antimicrobial effects in flow biofilms, such as those of *Pseudomonas aeruginosa*.

Title: Sigma S-dependent antioxidant defense protects stationary-phase Escherichia coli against the bactericidal antibiotic gentamicin
Keywords: sigma, s dependent, antioxidant, defense, protects, stationary phase
Resumen: Loss of the ÏƒS protein in stationary-phase Escherichia coli increases their sensitivity to gentamicin, an effect also observed in vivo in mice. This increased vulnerability is due to a weakened antioxidant defense, resulting in elevated accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and increased oxidative stress when treated with the antibiotic. Administration of antioxidants or treatment under anaerobic conditions reduces the lethality of the drug, and disruption of antioxidant defense pathways potentiates the damage. These findings indicate that gentamicin, in addition to its direct action, kills stationary-phase bacteria by generating oxidative stress, suggesting that targeting the antioxidant defense of E. coli may be detrimental to the immune system. coli* could improve its effectiveness and help combat antibiotic resistance.

Title: Plasma membrane disruption (PMD) formation and repair in mechanosensitive tissues
Keywords: plasma, membrane, disruption, pmd, formation, and
Resumen: Plasma membrane breaks (PMDs) are small, transient discontinuities in the cell membrane, induced by mechanical loading in the cellular environment, that initiate signaling cascades in various cells and tissues. The repair of these PMDs is essential for cell survival, as without it, cells are vulnerable to uncontrolled toxin entry and leakage of important molecules. The repair process, which varies depending on the size of the PMD, involves an influx of extracellular calcium, cytoskeletal reorganization, and vesicle fusion, with the participation of proteins such as calpains and annexins. PMDs have been observed in a wide range of mechanosensitive tissues, from skin and muscle to bone, where they influence physiological behavior and tissue adaptation. This review focuses on describing the formation and repair of PMDs in these tissues, highlighting their role in skeletal mechanobiology and their implications for disease and potential therapeutic applications.

Title: Microgravity alters the expression of salivary proteins
Keywords: microgravity alters expression salivary proteins
Resumen: study determined that spaceflight alters the expression of secretory proteins in the submandibular gland of mice, although no significant morphological changes were observed. While females showed few changes after 13-15 days in space, males showed increased expression of salivary androgen-binding protein alpha, epidermal growth factor, and nerve growth factor after 30 days. These findings suggest that the submandibular gland's response to microgravity depends on the sex of the animal and the duration of flight, and that individual salivary glands react differently. Saliva, which is easy to collect, is proposed as a useful biofluid for monitoring astronaut physiology and health.

Title: Salivary Gland Protein Expression after Bion-M1 and Space Shuttle STS-135 Missions
Keywords: salivary gland protein expression after bion m1
Resumen: study examined the impact of spaceflight on the morphology and biochemistry of mouse submandibular glands. Glands from female mice (13–15 days on U.S. space shuttles) and male mice (30 days on a Russian biosatellite) were analyzed using electron microscopy and immunohistochemistry. No morphological changes were found; and while there were no significant changes in protein expression in females, an increase in specific secretory proteins (such as SABP, EGF, and NGF) was observed in males after 30 days in space. These results indicate that spaceflight alters the expression of secretory proteins and suggest that the sex of the animals and the duration of the flight may influence the response. They also demonstrate that different salivary glands react differently. Saliva could be a useful biofluid for monitoring astronaut physiology and health.

Title: Response of the mouse sublingual gland to spaceflight.
Keywords: response, mouse, sublingual, gland, spaceflight
Resumen: This study examined the ultrastructure and secretory protein expression in the sublingual glands of mice that flew on U.S. space shuttles. No structural differences were observed in the acinar mucous or serous demilune cells between flight mice and ground controls. However, protein expression varied: parotid secretory protein (PSP) was significantly increased in STS-131 mice but decreased in STS-135 mice. Similarly, mucin (Muc19) and PKA-RII expression was increased in STS-131 and decreased in STS-135, although not statistically significant. The demiluna and parotid protein (DCPP) was slightly reduced on both flights, and nuclear PKA-RII was slightly increased. These findings suggest that salivary gland response to spaceflight varies among different glands, cell types, and proteins, and that the microgravity environment modifies protein expression, which could lead to the development of noninvasive methods to assess astronaut physiological status.

Title: Effects of spaceflight on the mouse submandibular gland
Keywords: spaceflight mouse submandibular gland
Resumen: This study investigated the impact of lunar gravity (1/6 g) on mouse salivary glands using an artificial gravity system on the International Space Station. The results showed that lunar gravity induced the expression of the salivary amylase gene (Amy1) and genes involved in the exocrine system (Vamp8, Rap/Rab), suggesting upregulation of salivary amylase secretion. The study concludes that Amy1 could be a potential marker for stress regulation in salivary glands under lunar gravity environments.

Title: Reactivation of Latent Epstein-Barr Virus: A Comparison after Exposure to Gamma, Proton, Carbon, and Iron Radiation
Keywords: reactivation, latent, epstein barr, virus, comparison, after
Resumen: Astronauts are exposed to cosmic radiation, which can affect their immune systems and reactivate latent viruses such as Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). This study directly investigated the effect of four types of radiation (gamma rays, protons, carbon ions, and iron ions) on EBV reactivation in infected cells in vitro. The findings revealed that all types of radiation induced transcription of lytic genes and significantly increased viral load compared to controls. Although gamma rays were more effective in initial reactivation, high-energy particles (protons, carbon, iron) caused a more sustained and delayed reactivation of EBV lytic gene transcription, challenging the concept of relative biological effectiveness (RBE) for this type of response. This suggests that radiation can directly reactivate latent viruses, independent of changes in the immune system.

Title: The influence of spaceflight on the astronaut salivary microbiome and the search for a microbiome biomarker for viral reactivation
Keywords: influence, spaceflight, astronaut, salivary, microbiome, and
Resumen: This study investigated changes in the salivary microbiome of ten astronauts before, during, and after spaceflight, and their relationship with viral reactivation. The overall diversity and richness of the salivary microbiome was observed to increase during flight, returning to pre-flight levels thereafter. Specifically, the diversity of Streptococcus decreased, while Proteobacteria and Fusobacteria increased, and Actinobacteria decreased. Genera such as Catonella, Megasphaera, and Actinobacillus were detected or increased in abundance during flight. Furthermore, correlations were identified between certain bacterial groups and viral titers, including a positive relationship between microbiome richness and Epstein-Barr virus titers. This pioneering research seeks bacterial biomarkers for viral reactivation, crucial to astronaut health on future missions.

Title: The cyclic nucleotide-gated channel CNGC14 regulates root gravitropism in Arabidopsis thaliana.
Keywords: cyclic, nucleotide gated, channel, cngc14, regulates, root
Resumen: This study investigates the regulation of the pH gradient at the root surface of *Arabidopsis thaliana*, identifying distinct acidic and alkaline zones using an enhanced fluorescein-5-(and-6)-sulfonic acid visualization method. The results indicate that these zones are not primarily determined by the activity of AHA H+-ATPases. Instead, the alkaline domain in the root transition zone is controlled by a rapid auxin-responsive module composed of the transporter AUX1, the coreceptor AFB1, and the calcium channel CNCG14. This rapid auxin-responsive pathway is critical for efficient root tip navigation.

Title: Telomere length assessments of muscle stem cells in rodent and human skeletal muscle sections
Keywords: telomere length assessments muscle stem cells
Resumen: The text describes a protocol, CRYO MuQ-FISH, for measuring telomere length in muscle stem cells (MuSCs) directly from skeletal muscle cryosections, preserving their natural environment. This method, which uses free software such as Telometer for single-cell analysis, overcomes the limitations of traditional techniques by not requiring cell isolation and is suitable for archived samples. The protocol details tissue preparation, hybridization, imaging, and data analysis, including telomere intensity normalization.

Title: Persistent NF-Å'âˆ«B activation in muscle stem cells induces proliferation-independent telomere shortening
Keywords: persistent, nf, activation, muscle, stem, cells
Resumen: The article investigates muscle stem cell (MuSC) dysfunction in disorders such as Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), where these cells lose efficiency in repair. The study reveals that the early telomere shortening in diseased MuSC, observed in mice and young patients with DMD, is associated with aberrant and prolonged activation of the factor NF-?. This sustained activation of NF-? in MuSCs during chronic injury leads to telomere shortening, Ku80 dysregulation, increased DNA damage (specifically at telomeres), MuSC loss, and severe defects in skeletal muscle, culminating in regenerative failure. Importantly, this mechanism acts independently of cell replication. These findings propose a crucial and previously unknown role for NF-? in regulating stem cell-specific telomere length and contributing to MuSC dysfunction and DMD progression, which could have implications for other diseases characterized by chronic systemic inflammation.

Title: Piezo1 regulates the regenerative capacity of skeletal muscles via orchestration of stem cell morphological states.
Keywords: Piezo1 regulates regenerative capacity, skeletal muscles
Resumen: The authors investigated the contribution of muscle stem cell (MuSC) morphology to their in vivo function. They found that quiescent MuSCs are morphologically heterogeneous, exhibiting different patterns of cellular processes, and classified them into three distinct functional states: responsive, intermediate, and sensory. They demonstrated that the protein Piezo1 regulates the transition between these states, promoting regeneration. Pharmacological activation of Piezo1 renders MuSCs more responsive, whereas its deletion mimics the dysfunction observed in dystrophic muscles. Reactivation of Piezo1 ameliorated the morphological and regenerative defects of MuSCs in these muscles. These findings reveal how stem cells respond to injury and identify Piezo1 as a key regulator of stem cell states essential for regeneration.

Title: Impacts of radiation exposure, hindlimb unloading, and recovery on murine skeletal muscle cell telomere length.
Keywords: impacts, radiation, exposure, hindlimb, unloading, and
Resumen: This study investigated telomere changes in muscle cells from mice subjected to a terrestrial model simulating spaceflight conditions, combining radiation exposure and hindlimb unloading. The results showed significant telomere lengthening in muscle stem cells and myofiber nuclei, but not in resident endothelial cells, under the combination of radiation and unloading. Furthermore, this lengthening did not return to baseline values after a recovery period. These findings suggest that telomeres play a role in muscle acclimatization, which is relevant to astronauts' well-being in space and upon their return to Earth.

Title: Ethylene-induced flavonol accumulation in guard cells suppresses reactive oxygen species and modulates stomatal aperture
Keywords: ethylene induced, flavonol, accumulation, guard, cells, suppresses
Resumen: This study demonstrates that flavonols accumulate specifically in the guard cells of *Arabidopsis* leaves, where they act as antioxidants and reduce levels of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which are crucial for abscisic acid (ABA)-induced stomatal closure. The presence of flavonols slows the rate of ABA-mediated stomatal closure; mutant plants lacking flavonols display faster stomatal closure. Furthermore, ethylene upregulates flavonol accumulation in guard cells, with increased ethylene resulting in higher flavonol levels, lower ROS, and slower stomatal closure. These results suggest that flavonols suppress ROS accumulation and decrease the rate of ABA-dependent stomatal closure, with ethylene-induced increases in flavonols in guard cells modulating these responses.

Title: Transcriptional and Hormonal Regulation of Gravitropism of Woody Stems in Populus.
Keywords: transcriptional and hormonal regulation, gravitropism, woody
Resumen: This study investigates the fundamental mechanisms of gravitropism in woody stems of Populus, where angiosperm trees reorient themselves by producing tension tissue at the top of the stem. Initial gravity perception involves amyloplast sedimentation and relocalization of the auxin transporter PIN3. Gibberellin (GA) stimulates tension wood formation and gravitational bending, while the transcription factor ARBORKNOX2 (ARK2) influences contractile fiber maturation and the response to GA. The researchers generated transcriptomes to model the transcriptional networks of wood formation, identifying that ARK2 expression modulates the gravitational bending capacity and maturation rate of wood tensile fibers, specifically G-layers, which are crucial for generating strength. They observed that overexpression of ARK2 accelerates G-layer maturation and enhances bending, while its decrease delays it and reduces bending, even if more fibers are produced, suggesting that fiber functionality and maturation speed are more important than their quantity. A model is proposed in which auxin transport to the cambium at the top of the stem, influenced by the location of PIN3-expressing cells, triggers tension wood formation.

Title: Endosidin2 targets conserved exocyst complex subunit EXO70 to inhibit exocytosis
Keywords: endosidin2, targets, conserved, exocyst, complex, subunit
Resumen: This study investigated the role of the exocyst complex in protein delivery to the plant plasma membrane. Using the inhibitor Endosidin2 (ES2) in Arabidopsis seedling roots and quantitative proteomic analysis, we found that ES2 treatment significantly reduced the abundance of 145 plasma membrane proteins. These proteins, which serve diverse roles in cell growth, cell wall biosynthesis, hormone signaling, and stress response, are likely exocyst-mediated cargoes, indicating that the exocyst complex mediates the constitutive dynamic transport of subsets of plasma membrane proteins during normal root growth.

Title: conditional mutation in SCD1 reveals linkage between PIN protein trafficking, auxin transport, gravitropism, and lateral root initiation.
Keywords: conditional mutation scd1 reveals linkage between
Resumen: This study used a temperature-sensitive mutation (*scd1-1*) in *Arabidopsis thaliana* to investigate the role of SCD1 in auxin transport and plant development. Polar auxin transport, essential for root growth, lateral root formation, and gravitropism, depends on the correct localization of PIN proteins. Unlike non-conditional mutants with complex phenotypes, *scd1-1* showed that, at the restrictive temperature of 25°C, the mutant exhibited reduced auxin transport, lateral root development, and gravitropic responses. Crucially, PIN2 protein accumulation in endomembranes occurred within just 20 minutes of the shift to 25°C, while developmental defects and gravitropism only became apparent hours later. This demonstrates that altered PIN2 trafficking precedes and causes subsequent defects in auxin transport and related developmental processes, with these effects being reversible upon return to the permissive temperature.

Title: comprehensive SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19 review, Part 1: Intracellular overdrive for SARS-CoV-2 infection.
Keywords: comprehensive, sars cov 2, and, covid 19, review, part
Resumen: SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has had a significant global impact and continues to evolve rapidly. It is an RNA betacoronavirus that infects cells by binding to the hACE2 receptor, displaying broad tropism in diverse organs such as the lungs, intestines, kidneys, and heart. The virus's high mutation rate, especially in the S protein, generates variants of concern that influence transmissibility, immune evasion, and disease severity. This text reviews the intracellular infection mechanisms of SARS-CoV-2, its adaptive capacity, and host responses to gain a deeper understanding of its varied clinical manifestations.

Title: Changes in nuclear shape and gene expression in response to simulated microgravity are LINC complex-dependent.
Keywords: changes nuclear shape and gene expression
Resumen: This study investigates the role of the Linker of Nucleoskeleton and Cytoskeleton (LINC) complex in cellular responses to simulated microgravity. Using a 3D clinostat and mammary epithelial cells (with either the intact or disrupted LINC complex), the researchers demonstrated that both nuclear shape and differential gene expression are sensitive to simulated microgravity in a LINC-dependent manner, and that these responses vary with the duration of exposure. Cells with the dysfunctional LINC complex showed significant alterations in nuclear morphology compared to control cells, and differential modulation in the regulation of a greater number of genes. These results suggest that the LINC complex is a crucial mediator of cellular responses to altered gravity environments.

Title: Growth of Carnobacterium spp. from permafrost under low pressure, temperature, and anoxic atmosphere has implications for Earth microbes on Mars
Keywords: Growth Carnobacterium spp from permafrost under
Resumen: The research identified terrestrial microorganisms capable of growing under conditions simulated on the Martian surface (low temperature, low pressure, an anoxic and CO2-rich atmosphere), using Siberian permafrost as an analogue. Six bacterial strains were isolated from permafrost that demonstrated growth under these extreme conditions. All were identified as species of the genus *Carnobacterium*, related to other *Carnobacterium* species found in polar environments. Tests confirmed that both the isolated strains and nine other type species of *Carnobacterium* can thrive in cold, low-pressure, and anoxious environments, even showing enhanced growth in some, extending the known limits of low-pressure life and highlighting their importance for astrobiology and planetary protection.

Title: Complete Genome Sequence of Carnobacterium gilichinskyi Strain WN1359T (DSM 27470T)
Keywords: complete genome sequence carnobacterium gilichinskyi strain
Resumen: The complete genome sequencing of the Carnobacterium gilichinskyi WN1359 strain, isolated from Siberian permafrost and capable of growing under conditions simulating the Martian atmosphere (cold, anoxic, CO2-dominated, and low pressure), is reported. The study seeks to investigate the molecular basis of its response to these conditions. The genome consists of a circular chromosome of 2,347,813 bp with a GC content of 35.26% and five plasmids, and includes 2,152 protein-coding ORFs, 74 tRNAs, and 8 rRNA operons. The results have been deposited in GenBank, and the work was funded by a NASA astrobiology program.

Title: Exposure of Bacillus subtilis to low pressure (5 kilopascals) induces several global regulons, including those involved in the SigB-mediated general stress response
Keywords: exposure, bacillus, subtilis, low, pressure, kilopascals
Resumen: This study investigates the global response of microorganisms to low pressure (LP), an area less explored than high pressure. Using transcription microarrays in *Bacillus subtilis* grown at 5 kPa (equivalent to 20 km altitude) versus normal atmospheric pressure, the researchers observed altered levels of 363 transcripts, affecting several global regulons. Notably, the SigB-mediated general stress response (GSR) regulon showed the highest number of overexpressed genes, confirming this. The findings reveal cellular mechanisms that respond to BP and are important for understanding microbial life in extreme terrestrial environments (such as clouds) and in astrobiology (such as Mars), as well as for practical applications in storage.

Title: Resistance of Bacillus subtilis Spore DNA to Lethal Ionizing Radiation Damage Relies Primarily on Spore Core Components and DNA Repair, with Minor Effects of Oxygen Radical Detoxification
Keywords: resistance, bacillus, subtilis, spore, dna, lethal
Resumen: This study investigated the resistance of *Bacillus subtilis* spores to different types of ionizing radiation (X-rays, protons, and iron ions). DNA repair mechanisms (NHEJ and AP endonucleases), SASP proteins (small acid-soluble spore proteins), dipicolinic acid (DPA), and low nuclear water content were found to be critical for their protection. DNA repair was found to be the most important defense mechanism. The ?/?-type SASPs also offered synergistic radioprotective effects by binding to DNA, unlike the ?-type SASPs. In contrast, oxygen radical detoxification played a very minor role in the resistance of dormant spores, which showed the greatest sensitivity to high-energy charged iron ions.

Title: Cultivation of Staphylococcus epidermidis in the human spaceflight environment leads to alterations in the frequency and spectrum of spontaneous rifampicin-resistance mutations in the rpoB gene
Keywords: cultivation, staphylococcus epidermidis, human, spaceflight, environment
Resumen: study investigated the effect of the spaceflight environment on the growth and frequency of antibiotic resistance mutations in *Staphylococcus epidermidis*. Cultures of the bacteria were grown for 122 hours on the International Space Station (ISS) and compared with ground-based controls. The results showed that, although there were significantly fewer viable cells in space, the frequency of rifampicin resistance mutations was significantly higher, and the spectrum of mutations in the *rpoB* gene was altered. This suggests that the space environment induces physiological stress that alters the bacterial mutagenic potential. This phenomenon is crucial for future long-duration space missions, as the stress of spaceflight can compromise astronauts' immune systems and alter the pathogenic and antibiotic-resistant potential of microorganisms, such as the ubiquitous *S. epidermidis*, increasing the risk of resistant infections.

Title: Experimental Evolution of Bacillus subtilis
Keywords: experimental, evolution, bacillus subtilis
Resumen: This study investigated the thermal adaptation capacity of Bacillus bacteria, essential to ecosystems, in the face of gradually rising global temperatures. Seven strains from the B. cereus and B. subtilis lineages were exposed to increasingly warming conditions in experimental evolution. The results showed that, despite some minor improvements, none of the strains managed to significantly adapt to grow at temperatures just three degrees Celsius above their natural range, and only one B. subtilis line extended its thermal niche by four degrees. Convergent mutations in genes regulating the synthesis of c-di-AMP, a molecule related to potassium transport, were found to play a crucial and previously unknown role in heat tolerance. The findings caution about the limited ability of these bacteria to develop substantial thermal tolerance, even under gradual selection, raising concerns about the resilience of bacterial communities and the potential impacts on biogeochemical cycles and ecosystem stability in the face of climate change.

Title: Cultivation in space flight produces minimal alterations in the susceptibility of Bacillus subtilis cells to 72 different antibiotics and growth-inhibiting compounds
Keywords: cultivation, space, flight, produces, minimal, alterations
Resumen: study cultured *Bacillus subtilis* cells on the International Space Station and on Earth to compare their susceptibility to 72 antibiotics and growth inhibitors. Although initial phenotypic microarray screening identified significant differences in resistance to 9 compounds, subsequent broth dilution testing revealed no statistically significant differences in inhibitory concentrations. The results suggest that the susceptibility of *B. subtilis* to a wide range of antimicrobial agents is not dramatically altered by spaceflight, contradicting concerns that bacteria may develop increased resistance in space.

Title: Alterations in the Spectrum of Spontaneous Rifampicin-Resistance Mutations in the Bacillus subtilis rpoB Gene after Cultivation in the Human Spaceflight Environment
Keywords: alterations, spectrum, spontaneous, rifampicin resistance, mutations, bacillus
Resumen: This study investigated the effect of the human spaceflight environment on the growth, frequency, and mutation spectrum of Bacillus subtilis for rifampicin resistance (RifR). B. subtilis cells were cultured on the International Space Station and in ground-based controls, finding no significant differences in growth or RifR mutation frequency. However, nucleotide sequencing of the rpoB gene revealed dramatic differences in the mutation spectrum between in-flight and control samples, including two novel alleles discovered in space samples. These findings reinforce the idea that exposure to the space environment imposes a unique stress on bacteria, altering their mutagenic potential.

Title: Mechanotransduction in Prokaryotes: A Possible Mechanism of Spaceflight Adaptation
Keywords: mechanotransduction, prokaryotes, possible, mechanism, spaceflight, adaptation
Resumen: This hypothesis article addresses the limited understanding of microgravity perception and response mechanisms in prokaryotes (bacteria and archaea) compared to eukaryotes. It reviews how eukaryotic cells detect and respond to mechanical stress, and notes that prokaryotic cells possess analogous structures and active mechanisms of mechanosensation and mechanotransduction. The paper proposes a comprehensive model of mechanotransduction for prokaryotes, suggesting that mechanical signals can be transduced into the gene expression apparatus through alterations in bacterial nucleoid architecture, DNA supercoiling, and epigenetic pathways.

Title: Environmental dependence of competitive fitness in rifampin-resistant rpoB mutants of Bacillus subtilis.
Keywords: environmental, dependence, competitive, fitness, rifampin resistant, rpob
Resumen: The text explores how mutations in the Bacillus subtilis rpoB gene, which confer resistance to rifampicin (Rifr), affect the competitive fitness of bacteria, demonstrating that this effect is significantly dependent on the environment. Historically, Rifr was associated with reduced fitness, but this investigation, using deep sequencing and competition assays in rich and minimal media, revealed that the competitive advantage of specific rpoB alleles varies depending on the environment. For example, in rich medium the wild type dominates, whereas in minimal medium a particular Rifr mutant may prevail, and compensatory mutations can even arise that dramatically increase fitness. These findings underscore the importance of environmental context in understanding the evolution of antimicrobial resistance, even in the absence of direct selection by antibiotics.

Title: Analysis of interactions of Salmonella type three secretion mutants with 3-D intestinal epithelial cells.
Keywords: interactions, salmonella, type, three, secretion, mutants
Resumen: This study used a 3-D organotypic model of human intestinal epithelium to investigate Salmonella enteropathogenesis, demonstrating that, contrary to monolayer studies but in line with in vivo observations, Salmonella Type Three Secretion Systems (T3SSs) (including SPI-1 and SPI-2) are not essential for initial invasion of intestinal cells. However, T3SSs were required for substantial intracellular bacterial replication once the bacteria have invaded. These findings underscore the utility of 3-D models for predicting pathogenetic mechanisms that more closely resemble in vivo infection.

Title: Organotypic 3D cell culture models: using the rotating wall vessel to study host-pathogen interactions.
Keywords: organotypic, cell, culture, models, rotating, wall
Resumen: This document details two complementary methods for culturing differentiated, three-dimensional epithelial tissues that mimic the in vivo environment, critical for studying human papillomavirus (HPV) infection and host-pathogen interactions. These approaches include organotypic raft culture and the use of a rotating-wall vessel bioreactor, applied to oral and cervical epithelial cells. The resulting models are used for microscopic and omics analyses, providing a deep understanding of the HPV life cycle and epithelial biology. The protocol also covers the isolation, maintenance, and various characterization techniques of these 3D structures, emphasizing necessary biosafety precautions.

Title: Induction of attachment-independent biofilm formation and repression of Hfq expression by low-fluid-shear culture of Staphylococcus aureus
Keywords: induction, attachment independent, biofilm formation, and repression
Resumen: This study investigated how the opportunistic pathogen *Staphylococcus aureus* responds to physiologically relevant low-shear fluid environments such as those of the human gut using rotating-wall vessel bioreactors. *S. aureus* grown under these conditions was found to initiate an adhesion-independent biofilm phenotype, display slower growth, and suppressed virulence traits, including lower carotenoid production and increased susceptibility to oxidative stress. Gene expression analysis revealed metabolic alterations and downregulation of the RNA chaperone Hfq, suggesting a conserved response among prokaryotes. The collective results indicate that *S. aureus* responds to a low fluid shear environment by adopting a colonization/biofilm phenotype with decreased virulence, which could help understand the divergence between infection and colonization.

Title: Characterization of the Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium ydcI gene which encodes a conserved DNA binding protein required for full acid stress resistance.
Keywords: characterization, salmonella, enterica, serovar, typhimurium, ydci
Resumen: The *ydcI* gene (STM1625) of *Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium*, identified in a low-shear stimulus study, encodes a highly conserved DNA-binding protein in Gram-negative bacteria. This gene autoregulates its expression, specifically binds to its own promoter sequence, and is crucial for acid resistance, being part of the *rpoS* regulon. Although its deletion did not affect cell invasion, induction of *ydcI* increased cell invasion and biofilm formation. The findings demonstrate that *ydcI* is involved in aspects of prokaryotic biology related to stress resistance and virulence, with observable effects outside of low-shear environments.

Title: Evaluation of microorganisms cultured from injured and repressed tissue regeneration sites in endangered giant aquatic Ozark Hellbender salamanders.
Keywords: evaluation, microorganisms, cultured, from, injured, and
Resumen: This study examined the causes of decline and injury of the Ozark newt (Cryptobranchus alleganiensis bishopi), an endangered species whose population and health in the North Fork of White River have declined dramatically since the 1960s, coinciding with habitat degradation. Microorganisms were cultured from injured and non-injured tissues, identifying several opportunistic bacterial pathogens (such as Aeromonas hydrophila and various Pseudomonads) and environmental fungi unique to the injuries. The findings suggest that multiple microbial factors, along with habitat deterioration, may be contributing to the lack of regeneration and poor health of these amphibians. This is the first external microbial profile of a cryptobranchid salamander.

Title: Transcriptional and proteomic responses of Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1 to spaceflight conditions involve Hfq regulation and reveal a role for oxygen.
Keywords: transcriptional and proteomic responses, pseudomonas aeruginosa
Resumen: This pioneering study characterized the global transcriptional and proteomic responses of *Pseudomonas aeruginosa* to the microgravity of spaceflight, a crucial field for assessing and preventing infectious diseases on space missions and understanding bacterial virulence in low fluid shear environments. *P. aeruginosa* was found to differentially regulate 167 genes and 28 proteins, with Hfq acting as a global transcriptional regulator influencing multiple bacterial species. The virulence genes *lecA*, *lecB*, and *rhlA* were induced, and the bacteria adopted an anaerobic growth mode. Comparisons with microgravity simulations showed important similarities, suggesting that low fluid shear impacts pathogenicity. This research is critical to determining whether these changes alter the virulence of *P. aeruginosa*, which is vital for assessing infection risks both in space and for public health.

Title: New insights into the bacterial fitness-associated mechanisms revealed by the characterization of large plasmids of an avian pathogenic E. coli
Keywords: new, insights, into, bacterial, fitness associated, mechanisms
Resumen: This study focused on the sequencing and characterization of plasmids pChi7122-2, pChi7122-3, and pChi7122-4 from the model strain *APEC Ï‡7122*, an extraintestinal pathogenic *Escherichia coli* (ExPEC) that poses a threat to human and animal health. The aim was to understand the role of these plasmids in pathogenicity and, in particular, in bacterial persistence under stress conditions, given that pChi7122-1 had previously been linked to systemic infection. Sequencing revealed that pChi7122-2 encodes an iron ABC transport system (eitABCD), sugar catabolic pathways, and antibiotic resistance genes, while pChi7122-3 encodes type IV fimbriae; pChi7122-4 was found to be a cryptic plasmid. Both pChi7122-2 and pChi7122-3 were shown to be self-conjugating. In vitro evaluations indicated that the nature and combinations of the plasmids, as well as the genetic background of the host strain, affect phenomena such as biofilm formation, bile and acid tolerance, and interaction with epithelial cells. This work offers new insights into how extrachromosomal sequences contribute to the fitness and phenotypic diversity of ExPECs, although the expression of some iron systems would require specific conditions such as those in vivo.

Title: Lack of norovirus replication and histo-blood group antigen expression in 3-dimensional intestinal epithelial cells
Keywords: lack norovirus replication and histo blood group
Resumen: This study sought to replicate previous findings on norovirus (NV) replication in a 3D intestinal model derived from INT-407 cells, a system that has proven elusive in in vitro studies. Using the same 3D model and highly purified Norwalk norovirus (NV), results showed no evidence of viral replication, either by real-time PCR of viral RNA or by immunocytochemical detection of viral proteins. Immunocytochemical analysis also revealed the absence of blood group antigens that are crucial for NV binding. To explain the cytopathic effects (CPE) observed in the previous study, the researchers exposed the 3D cultures to lipopolysaccharides, finding morphological changes similar to CPE. They conclude that the 3D INT-407 cell model is not suitable for norovirus replication.

Title: Conservation of the low-shear modeled microgravity response in Enterobacteriaceae and analysis of the trp genes in this response.
Keywords: conservation, low shear, modeled, microgravity, response, enterobacteriaceae
Resumen: This study systematically analyzed the response of diverse Gram-negative Enterobacteriaceae bacteria to modeled microgravity (MSMM) using phenotypic and molecular assays. The results indicate that the response to MSMM is conserved within this family, although the direction of regulation of phenotypes such as acid stress resistance and gene expression can vary between genera. Resistance to oxidative stress, however, was decreased in all tested genera. Contrary to previous hypotheses, targeted mutations in the trp operon genes and the TrpR regulator did not alter the response to MSMM in S. Typhimurium and E. coli. This pioneering work for several genera, including Citrobacter, Enterobacter, and Serratia, improves our understanding of the impact of LSMMG on bacteria.

Title: Mimicking the host and its microenvironment in vitro for studying mucosal infections by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
Keywords: mimicking host and its microenvironment vitro
Resumen: The text addresses why healthy individuals are protected from *Pseudomonas aeruginosa* infections, while those with cystic fibrosis or damaged epithelium are particularly susceptible to this opportunistic pathogen. It emphasizes the importance of understanding the dynamic interplay between the host microenvironment and *P. aeruginosa*, highlighting that mucosal tissue factors such as polarity, cell junctions, extracellular matrix, mucus, and microbiota, as well as physicochemical factors, affect bacterial pathogenesis. It reviews increasingly complex *in vitro* models used to study the disease, primarily pulmonary models, and their advantages and limitations. The paper details how physical, chemical, and cellular barriers in a healthy host protect against infection, and how disruption of these factors in conditions such as cystic fibrosis or damaged epithelium leads to adhesion, invasion, increased virulence, biofilm formation, and antimicrobial resistance of *P. aeruginosa*. The ultimate goal is to improve *in vitro* models to better reflect *in vivo* phenotypes of *P. aeruginosa*, thereby advancing our understanding of its pathogenic mechanisms and the development of treatments, with the goal of reducing and eventually replacing animal models.

Title: Effects of Sex and Gender on Adaptation to Space: Immune System
Keywords: sex, and, gender, adaptation, space, immune
Resumen: The paper proposes that chronic suboptimal hydration in the weeks prior to COVID-19 infection could increase the risk of mortality, linking it to known risk factors such as older age, male sex, ethnic origin, and chronic disease. It is hypothesized that this condition causes physiological adaptations that result in a greater abundance of ACE2 receptors in the lung, an exaggerated pulmonary immune response, increased capillary fluid leakage into the airways, and a decreased ability to clear said fluid. These mechanisms suggest that excessive fluid accumulation in the lungs, characteristic of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), is exacerbated by chronic dehydration. The article advocates for low-cost and accessible public health strategies, such as increased drinking water intake, hydration screening, and personalized treatments, to reduce mortality and disparities associated with COVID-19.

Title: Recellularization of decellularized lung scaffolds is enhanced by dynamic suspension culture.
Keywords: recellularization, decellularized, lung, scaffolds, enhanced, dynamic
Resumen: This study demonstrates that dynamic culture in a low-shear fluid suspension bioreactor, known as a rotating vessel (RWV), significantly improves the repopulation of decellularized mouse lung scaffolds. Compared with static conditions, lungs recellularized in the RWV contained more cells, showed less apoptosis, increased proliferation, and elevated total RNA levels, both with mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) and type II alveolar epithelial cells (C10). Genetic and immunohistochemical analyses suggested that MSCs differentiated into collagen I-producing fibroblast-like cells in the bioreactor, indicating an enhanced potential for scaffold matrix remodeling. These findings suggest that dynamic suspension culture is a promising strategy to enhance repopulation of decellularized lungs and may contribute to extracellular matrix remodeling and the differentiation and functionality of inoculated cells.

Title: Three-dimensional organotypic co-culture model of intestinal epithelial cells and macrophages to study Salmonella enterica colonization patterns.
Keywords: three dimensional, organotypic, co culture, model, intestinal, epithelial
Resumen: Researchers developed and validated a novel 3D coculture model of colonic epithelial cells and macrophages, using a NASA Rotating Wall Vessel bioreactor, to study Salmonella infections in a more physiologically relevant manner than 2D models. This model replicates in vivo features such as 3D architecture, polarity, and the presence of multiple cell types, including functional macrophages with antimicrobial activity. When the model was infected with different Salmonella pathovars, they observed decreased colonization in the presence of macrophages and pathovar-specific differences in replication and intracellular localization patterns. This advance offers a powerful tool for understanding enteric pathogenesis and uncovering previously unidentified mechanisms and therapeutic targets.

Title: Modeling Host-Pathogen Interactions in the Context of the Microenvironment: 3-D Cell Culture Comes of Age.
Keywords: modeling, host pathogen, interactions, context, microenvironment, 3 d
Resumen: The text addresses the evolution of in vitro models for studying host-pathogen interactions. It highlights that two-dimensional (2D) models are limited by lacking the three-dimensional (3D) complexity, cellular diversity, biomechanical forces, and other essential factors of the native microenvironment that regulate infections. Therefore, it underscores the importance of 3D models, such as rotating-wall bioreactor (RWV) cultures, organoids, and organs-on-a-chip, to more accurately recreate the in vivo environment of the intestinal mucosa. These models enable more physiologically relevant investigation of infectious disease mechanisms and antimicrobial therapies, considering tissue architecture, cell types, microbiota, and physical forces.

Title: Evaluating the effect of spaceflight on the hostâ€šÃ„Ã¬pathogen interaction between human intestinal epithelial cells and Salmonella Typhimurium
Keywords: evaluating, spaceflight, host, pathogen, interaction, between
Resumen: The STL-IMMUNE study investigated how spaceflight alters the responses of human intestinal epithelial cells to Salmonella Typhimurium infection when both the host and pathogen are simultaneously exposed to this environment. This was the first in-flight infection and dual RNA-seq analysis using human cells. The results showed that spaceflight induced significant physiological changes in epithelial cells, including activation of type I interferon signaling and antiviral defense, upregulation of DNA replication and differentiation genes, and downregulation of genes related to glycolysis and fatty acid metabolism. These findings suggest altered proliferation, differentiation, and possible DNA damage, as well as changes in immune defenses, underscoring the need to better understand host-pathogen interactions in space for future space missions.

Title: Rapid phenotypic response of LSMMG-'primed' Candida albicans.
Keywords: rapid, phenotypic, response, lsmmg, primed, candida
Resumen: This study demonstrates that *Candida albicans* colonization of the gastrointestinal tract in mice significantly reduces ethanol consumption and preference, an effect mediated by elevated serum prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) levels. Injection of a PGE2 derivative decreased ethanol consumption in non-colonized mice, and blockade of PGE2 receptors EP1 and EP2 reversed the reduction in consumption in mice colonized with *C. albicans*. Furthermore, colonized mice showed altered expression of dopamine receptors, faster acquisition of conditioned aversion to ethanol taste, and increased sensitivity to alcohol-induced motor impairment, indicating that this microbiome fungus alters ethanol-related behavior through PGE2 signaling.

Title: Spaceflight enhances cell aggregation and random budding in Candida albicans.
Keywords: spaceflight, enhances, cell, aggregation, and, random
Resumen: This study presents the first global transcriptional profile and phenotypic characterization of the opportunistic fungal pathogen *Candida albicans* grown under spaceflight conditions. The analysis revealed that *C. albicans* differentially regulated 452 genes, induced cell aggregation, and displayed a random budding pattern. Differential regulation of genes involved in resistance to antifungal agents and stress, including the transcriptional regulator Cap1, was also observed. Despite these genetic and phenotypic changes, no increase in virulence was detected in a murine infection model. The findings provide an important basis for assessing the risk of commensal flora during space missions and for identifying new mechanisms of infectious disease that are also relevant on Earth.

Title: Growth and antifungal resistance of the pathogenic yeast, Candida albicans, in the microgravity environment of the International Space Station: An aggregate of multiple flight experiences.
Keywords: growth, and, antifungal, resistance, pathogenic, yeast
Resumen: This study investigates the cellular and physiological adaptations of the opportunistic fungal pathogen *Candida albicans* grown in microgravity aboard the International Space Station, comparing it with ground-based controls. The objective is to understand its response to the space environment, crucial for crew safety on long-duration flights. The experiments, conducted with two types of bioreactors over several missions, analyzed growth, filamentation, colonial morphology, and resistance to antifungal agents. The main findings revealed that *C. albicans* exhibited a slightly shorter generation time and a greater propensity for growth in microgravity. Notably, it demonstrated increased resistance to the antifungal agent amphotericin B when challenged during spaceflight, but not to caspofungin. Overall, yeast cells grown in microgravity exhibited a set of characteristics associated with increased virulence. The report also includes an analysis of biological reproducibility between flight opportunities and compares two space hardware systems.

Title: NASA GeneLab RNA-Seq Consensus Pipeline: Standardized Processing of Short-Read RNA-Seq Data
Keywords: nasa, genelab, rna seq, consensus, pipeline, standardized
Resumen: NASA GeneLab and its working groups have developed a consensus pipeline for the analysis of RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) data from spaceflight-related experiments. This initiative stems from the need to standardize the processing of complex and variable omics data from diverse sources and experimental conditions in space. The goal is to promote transparency, reproducibility, and reusability, facilitating meta-analysis and interpretation of the effects of spaceflight on organisms. The pipeline includes quality control steps, read trimming, genomic mapping, and gene quantification using dedicated bioinformatics tools. All details of this pipeline, as well as the processed data, are publicly available through the GeneLab database.

Title: Challenges and considerations for single-cell and spatially resolved transcriptomics sample collection during spaceflight.
Keywords: Challenges and considerations for single cell spatially
Resumen: The text highlights the rapid development of single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) and spatially resolved transcriptomics (SRT) on Earth, contrasting with their limited implementation in spaceflight studies. These technologies are crucial for understanding the effects of the space environment on the human body, vital knowledge for future long-duration missions to the Moon and Mars, given that the genomic impact of microgravity and radiation is poorly understood. Although most space-based "omics" experiments have used bulk RNA sequencing (bulk RNA-seq), scRNA-seq and SRT offer much higher resolution, allowing for the identification of specific cell types and their responses, as well as maintaining spatial information about the tissue. Currently, only a limited number of space-based experiments have applied scRNA-seq (such as RRRM-2 in mice and the NASA Twins Study in humans), and even fewer have applied SRT, facing significant challenges in tissue preservation and sample processing in space. To advance space biology, it is imperative to optimize experimental design protocols, especially in tissue preservation and data analysis, to fully exploit the potential of these high-resolution techniques.

Title: Direct RNA sequencing of astronaut blood reveals spaceflight-associated m6A increases and hematopoietic transcriptional responses
Keywords: direct, rna, sequencing, astronaut, blood, reveals
Resumen: This study used long-read nanopore RNA sequencing to longitudinally analyze blood samples from four astronauts on the SpaceX Inspiration4 mission, seeking to understand the effects of spaceflight on human physiology at the molecular and cellular levels. The findings revealed significant changes in key genetic pathways, including red blood cell regulation, stress induction, and immune modifications. For the first time, a notable increase in m6A methylation levels was identified immediately after flight, with a high density of these changes in red blood cell-associated pathways. These pioneering data provide the first longitudinal long-read RNA profiles and RNA modification maps for astronauts, dramatically improving our understanding of the dynamic response of the human transcriptome to spaceflight.

Title: Collection of biospecimens from the inspiration4 mission establishes the standards for the space omics and medical atlas (SOMA)
Keywords: collection, biospecimens, from, inspiration4, mission, establishes
Resumen: This text details the standardized biological sample collection methodology developed by the Space Omics and Medical Atlas (SOMA) initiative, implemented on the SpaceX Inspiration4 mission. A total of 2,911 aliquots of diverse biospecimens, including venous and capillary blood, saliva, urine, feces, body and environmental swabs, and skin biopsies, were obtained longitudinally from four crewmembers (pre-, during, and postflight). The samples were processed, biobanked, and prepared for future molecular assays, with the goal of generating high-quality multi-omics data that will help better understand the impact of spaceflight on human and microbial health, overcoming the limitations of previous studies.

Title: Microfluidics-enabled method to identify modes of Caenorhabditis elegans paralysis in four anthelmintics.
Keywords: microfluidics enabled, method, identify, modes,caenorhabditis, elegans
Resumen: This paper describes a study addressing the increasing resistance of parasites to existing drugs and the need for improved technology platforms for drug discovery. A novel multiparameter extraction method is presented using a microfluidic device with real-time imaging to characterize paralysis modes in *Caenorhabditis elegans* exposed to four anthelmintic drugs (pyrantel, levamisole, tribendimidine, and methyridine) at equipotent concentrations (EC75). Unlike traditional methods that quantify drug effects with a single parameter at a single endpoint, this study measured behaviors such as curls per second, types of paralysis, and duration of active/immobile periods over an extended period. The results showed distinct differences in how the worms paralyzed in the presence of different drugs, even at the same potency, highlighting the need to evaluate drug effects in small animal models with multiple parameters quantified at regular intervals and over extended periods to better understand resistance and adaptability in chemical environments.

Title: Multiparameter behavioral analyzes provide insights to mechanisms of cyanide resistance in Caenorhabditis elegans.
Keywords: multiparameter, behavioral, analyses, provide, insights, mechanisms
Resumen: This study uses the nematode *Caenorhabditis elegans* as a powerful model to investigate cyanide toxicity and resistance mechanisms, developing novel microfluidics and real-time imaging technologies. It was shown that cyanide resistance exhibited by *egl-9* mutants is entirely dependent on HIF-1 (hypoxia-inducible factor) and mediated by the cysteine synthase *cysl-2*, which likely inactivates cyanide through metabolic pathways. *cysl-2* expression correlates with the degree of resistance observed. Microfluidics, combined with real-time imaging, enabled high-resolution analysis of behavioral parameters, which is useful for studying subtle phenotypes. These multiparameter analyses of C. elegans behavior offer great potential for monitoring the effects of toxicants or chemical interventions in real time and for studying the biological networks that underlie toxicant resistance.

Title: Growth performance and root transcriptome remodeling of Arabidopsis in response to Mars-like levels of magnesium sulfate.
Keywords: growth, performance, and root, transcriptome, remodeling
Resumen: This study focuses on developing Martian soil-compatible plants for bioregenerative life support systems, given that Martian regolith contains high levels of magnesium sulfate that inhibit plant growth. It was determined that inactivation of the ion transporters AtMRS2-10 and AtSULTR1;2 does not confer tolerance to magnesium sulfate. Instead, a global approach was used to identify novel genes by characterizing the response of the Arabidopsis root transcriptome to elevated magnesium sulfate concentrations. The results showed that *cax1* mutants exhibit partial tolerance to magnesium sulfate, establishing a foundation for understanding plant metabolic responses and providing a subset of candidate genes for improving tolerance and facilitating plant growth in Martian environments.

Title: The 14-3-3 proteins of Arabidopsis regulate root growth and chloroplast development as components of the photosensory system.
Keywords: 14 3 3, proteins, arabidopsis, regulate, root, growth
Resumen: 14-3-3 proteins influence important pathways such as flowering time via the photosensory system. This study investigated their roles in root and chloroplast development in *Arabidopsis* using T-DNA insertion mutants. The 14-3-3Î¼-1 mutant was found to develop shorter roots than the wild type, a length influenced by light intensity. 14-3-3Î½ mutants also exhibited shorter roots, but only under narrowband red light. Furthermore, the roots of the 14-3-3 and CO mutants showed an increase in greenness and chloroplast number, which was also affected by light wavelength and intensity. These results reveal novel roles for 14-3-3 proteins in root and chloroplast development, likely through their association with the photosensory system.

Title: 14-3-3 phosphoprotein interaction networks - does isoform diversity present functional interaction specification?
Keywords: 14 3 3, phosphoprotein, interaction, networks, does, isoform
Resumen: This article examines the diversity of 14-3-3 proteins, essential regulators of cellular signaling in eukaryotes such as *Arabidopsis*, and addresses the question of whether the variability of their isoforms translates into functional diversity or redundancy. Despite considerable evolutionary conservation, the article suggests that functional specificities exist among 14-3-3 isoforms in *Arabidopsis*. It is proposed that phosphorylation at sites not universally conserved among isoforms could be a key mechanism defining these specific functions, by influencing their interaction with client proteins, conformation, or dimerization capacity.

Title: Plant growth strategies are remodeled by spaceflight
Keywords: plant, growth, strategies, are, remodeled, spaceflight
Resumen: study investigated the effects of ginseng total saponins (GTSs) on the imbalance of intestinal homeostasis induced by simulated microgravity using a hindlimb suspension rat model. The results showed that GTSs intervention effectively ameliorated intestinal damage, reducing pathological damage and inflammation, increasing the expression of tight junction proteins, restoring intestinal immune genes, and remodeling the gut microbiota. Specifically, GTSs increased the abundance of short-chain fatty acid (SCFA)-metabolizing bacteria, elevating the levels of propionic, butyric, and isobutyric acids. These findings suggest that GTSs improve intestinal microecological disorders and immune function compromised by weightlessness simulation, possibly through the "gut immune-microbiota-metabolism" pathway, providing a theoretical basis for the development of space health products.

Title: Spaceflight transcriptomes: unique responses to a novel environment.
Keywords: spaceflight, transcriptomes, unique, responses, novel, environment
Resumen: This study investigates the molecular and physiological responses of *Arabidopsis* plants to the spaceflight environment, focusing on complex stressors such as microgravity and radiation. Using an integrated transcriptomics (RNA-seq) and proteomics (TMT-LC-MS/MS) approach, researchers analyzed seedlings grown aboard the International Space Station (ISS) in BRIC LED hardware, compared to a ground-based control. The findings reveal alterations in the photosynthetic machinery, changes in the activities of ribosomes, spliceosomes, and proteasomes, a reduction in cellulose synthases, and an increase in enzymes related to non-cellulosic cell wall polysaccharides. Furthermore, changes in polar auxin redistribution, intracellular lipid and ion transport, and increased metabolic energy requirements in space were observed. The study provides valuable insights into how plants adapt to these extreme conditions, representing a crucial step toward achieving sustainable crop production in space, highlighting the importance of multi-omic approaches and organ-specific resolution.

Title: Fundamental plant biology enabled by the space shuttle.
Keywords: fundamental, plant, biology, enabled, space, shuttle
Resumen: This study characterized an *Aspergillus niger* strain (JSC-093350089) isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) and compared it to a terrestrial strain. Genomic analysis revealed its phylogenetic placement within the *A. niger* clade and that its genome lies within the genetic variance of other strains. The ISS strain displayed increased growth rate and pigment distribution. Proteomic analysis identified significant differences in the molecular phenotype, with increased abundance of proteins involved in starvation response, oxidative stress resistance, cell wall modulation, and nutrient acquisition. These data reveal a distinct strain of *A. niger* on the ISS and provide crucial insights into the fungi's adaptation mechanisms to extreme environments, which is vital for crew health and the success of long-duration space missions.

Title: Organ-specific remodeling of the Arabidopsis transcriptome in response to spaceflight.
Keywords: organ specific, remodeling, arabidopsis, transcriptome, response, spaceflight
Resumen: study on the International Space Station investigated the adaptation of monocot plants, specifically three varieties of *Brachypodium distachyon*, to microgravity, an underexplored area. Roots of all varieties were observed to grow slower and develop longer root hairs under microgravity, while shoot growth varied. Transcriptomic analyses revealed significantly diverse genetic responses between varieties and organs, with very few shared differentially expressed genes, involving oxidative stress, cell wall remodeling, and photosynthetic inhibition. Although the general characteristics of these responses are similar to those of the dicot *Arabidopsis*, cultivar- and organ-specific differences highlight the need to directly evaluate candidate crops to understand their adaptability and develop breeding strategies for space travel.

Title: method for preparing spaceflight RNAlater-fixed Arabidopsis thaliana (Brassicaceae) tissue for scanning electron microscopy.
Keywords: method, for, preparing, spaceflight, rnalater fixed, arabidopsis
Resumen: Spaceflight experiments, as well as field studies, often require separate fixatives for molecular (RNAlater) and morphological analyses, which restricts the use of limited samples. Given this, the objective was to develop a protocol for using RNAlater-fixed samples in scanning electron microscopy (SEM). A method was developed with *Arabidopsis thaliana* that included desalting, methanol dehydration, liquid ethane immersion, cryosubstitution, critical point drying, and SEM imaging. The resulting protocol allowed for acceptable SEM images of RNAlater-fixed tissues, preserving gross morphology and fine details such as root hairs and trichomes, comparable to fresh-frozen samples. This maximizes the use of data from a single sample, offering experimental flexibility and being a cost-effective solution for situations with limited biological resources, such as space experiments or field studies.

Title: ARG1 Functions in the Physiological Adaptation of Undifferentiated Plant Cells to Spaceflight
Keywords: arg1, functions, physiological, adaptation, undifferentiated, plant
Resumen: This study investigates the role of the *Altered response to gravity 1* (Arg1) gene in the physiological adaptation of undifferentiated *Arabidopsis thaliana* plant cells to spaceflight. We compared gene expression profiles of wild-type and *Arg1*-deleted cell lines grown on both Earth and the International Space Station. Preliminary results suggest that most of the genes with altered expression in wild-type cells during spaceflight are dependent on *Arg1*, indicating a critical role for this gene in the adaptation of undifferentiated cells to microgravity. The work seeks to understand how cells without specialized organs detect and respond to gravity, which is crucial for long-term space exploration.

Title: A Member of the CONSTANS-Like Protein Family is a Putative Regulator of ROS Homeostasis and Spaceflight Physiological Adaptation
Keywords: member, constans like, protein, family, putative, regulator
Resumen: The physiological adaptation of *Arabidopsis thaliana* plants to spaceflight is characterized by the induction of reactive oxygen species (ROS)-associated gene expression. Analysis of the responses of different *Arabidopsis* ecotypes in space led to the discovery of a previously uncharacterized gene, OMG1, which is consistently induced in microgravity. This investigation revealed that OMG1 belongs to the CONSTANS-Like protein family and is involved in maintaining the ROS pathway, suggesting an important role for this signaling in plant adaptation to the space environment. The study also demonstrates that spaceflight experiments can serve as a platform for discovering new gene functions and gaining insight into terrestrial plant biology.

Title: HSFA2 Functions in the Physiological Adaptation of Undifferentiated Plant Cells to Spaceflight.
Keywords: hsfa2, functions, physiological, adaptation, undifferentiated, plant
Resumen: This study investigated the role of heat shock factor A2 (HsfA2) in the adaptation of Arabidopsis thaliana plant cells to the spaceflight environment. Wild-type and HsfA2-deficient mutant cells were cultured on both the International Space Station and on Earth. The results of gene expression analysis revealed that HsfA2-deficient cells experience endoplasmic reticulum stress independently of the environment and that HsfA2 has specific functions in space adaptation beyond the universal stress response, related to cell wall remodeling, signal transduction, and starch biosynthesis. The findings suggest a non-thermal role for the HsfA2 network in physiological adaptation to spaceflight.

Title: Neutrophil to Lymphocyte ratio: A biomarker to monitor the immune status of astronauts.
Keywords: neutrophil lymphocyte ratio biomarker monitor immune
Resumen: NASA seeks to understand immune dysfunction in space and find biomarkers for astronaut health in flight. The study proposes that an elevated neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio (NLR) is a potential biomarker, as leukocyte counts are altered during spaceflight. Elevated NLR was observed in rodents and astronauts in space, and similar results were replicated in simulated microgravity models using human leukocytes and mice. Simulated microgravity caused redox imbalance and inflammatory neutrophil activation, effects that were reversed with antioxidants. Additionally, genetically modified mice with lower oxidative stress showed a reduced inflammatory response. In conclusion, spaceflight and simulated microgravity consistently elevate NLR, indicating it as a promising biomarker for monitoring astronaut immune health, with oxidative stress as a key mechanism.

Title: Beyond low-Earth orbit: Characterizing immune and microRNA differentials following simulated deep spaceflight conditions in mice.
Keywords: beyond, low earth, orbit, characterizing, immune, and
Resumen: study evaluated immune responses in mice under simulated deep spaceflight conditions (microgravity and cosmic/solar radiation), comparing them with data from astronauts. Unique immunological diversity was found for each experimental condition, indicating distinct circulating immune responses, and the involvement of plasma microRNAs in immune dysregulation was observed. The experiments in mice, which revealed decreases in the immune system, were supported by data from astronauts with elevated inflammation on low-Earth orbit missions. These findings define immune biomarkers related to specific types of radiation and microgravity, crucial for future space health initiatives.

Title: Immunological and hematological outcomes following protracted low dose/low dose rate ionizing radiation and simulated microgravity
Keywords: Immunological and hematological outcomes following protracted
Resumen: This study investigated immune and hematological system responses in mice one week after simulated spaceflight conditions in a terrestrial model. Analyses revealed negligible differences in blood immune differentials, but large disparities in red blood cell differentials and morphology, suggesting anemia. Transcriptomic analysis of the spleen showed differentially expressed genes associated with signal transduction, metabolism, cell cycle, chromatin organization, and DNA repair, as well as expression profiles related to inflammation and immune dysfunction. Specific regulatory pathways linked to orthologs of human blood disease genes, such as blood pressure regulation and TGF-Î² receptor signaling, were also observed. Overall, the study indicates differential immunologic and hematologic outcomes one week after simulated spaceflight, suggesting that recovery from these conditions is a persistent and complex process.

Title: Epigenomic regulators elongator complex subunit 2 and methyltransferase 1 differentially condition the spaceflight response in Arabidopsis
Keywords: epigenomic, regulators, elongator, complex, subunit, and
Resumen: An experiment conducted on the International Space Station investigated the role of DNA methylation in the adaptation of Arabidopsis plants to spaceflight, comparing a wild type (Col-0) with mutants of methylation-regulating genes (elp2-5 and met1-7). The results revealed that elp2-5 plants suffered significantly impaired development and a drastically reprogrammed transcriptomic response in space. Met1-7 plants showed less severe morphological effects, but also a uniquely reprogrammed transcriptomic response. The study concludes that the physiological adaptation of Arabidopsis to spaceflight involves differential DNA methylation in an organ-specific manner, and that disruption of methylation functions profoundly alters plant growth and gene expression responses in this environment.

Title: Plants grown in Apollo lunar regolith present stress-associated transcriptomes that inform prospects for lunar exploration
Keywords: plants, grown, apollo, lunar, regolith, present
Resumen: recent study investigated the ability of the plant *Arabidopsis thaliana* to grow in authentic lunar regolith from the Apollo 11, 12, and 17 missions, compared to a lunar simulant. Although the plants managed to germinate and develop normal stems and cotyledons, their growth was significantly challenged, displaying stunted roots, slow aerial development, and stressed morphologies. Transcriptomic analysis revealed differential gene expression indicating strong responses to ionic stress, similar to those caused by salt, metals, and reactive oxygen species. The results suggest that while lunar regolith may be useful for plant production in lunar habitats, it is not a benign substrate, and further research and mitigation are required for its efficient use in life support systems.

Title: Artificial gravity partially protects space-induced neurological deficits in Drosophila melanogaster.
Keywords: artificial, gravity, partially, protects, space induced, neurological
Resumen: study aboard the International Space Station used fruit flies (Drosophila) to investigate the effects of spaceflight on the central nervous system (CNS) and the effectiveness of artificial gravity (AG) as a countermeasure. Flies were exposed to microgravity (SFÎ¼g) and artificially simulated Earth gravity (SF1g) via centrifugation. Although flies in SFÎ¼g showed increased activity during flight, they exhibited significant postflight climbing defects, with males more affected. Multi-omic analyses revealed metabolic, oxidative stress, and synaptic transmission alterations in SFÎ¼g and SF1g. However, immediate post-flight neurological changes, such as neuronal loss, glial cell alterations, oxidative damage, and apoptosis, were only observed in SFÎ¼g. After acclimatization to terrestrial conditions, progressive neuronal loss and a glial phenotype were observed in the brains of both SF1g and SFÎ¼g groups, being more pronounced in SFÎ¼g. The results suggest that artificial gravity partially protects the CNS from the adverse effects of spaceflight.

Title: Utilizing the KSC fixation tube to conduct human-tended plant biology experiments on a suborbital spaceflight
Keywords: utilizing, ksc, fixation, tube, conduct, human tended
Resumen: This study proposes a method for conducting biological research in human suborbital spaceflight, overcoming the limitations of automated experiments. It details the use of KSC fixation tubes (KFTs) to safely transport and fix biological samples, specifically *Arabidopsis* plants, at various stages of simulated suborbital flight. Plants were grown in special coupons and inserted into the KFTs, which contained RNAlater for rapid and safe fixation. RNA-seq analysis demonstrated that plants in KFTs exhibited consistent and predictable transcriptomic responses, adapting to the encapsulated environment of the tubes, validating this approach for investigating biological alterations induced by suborbital spaceflight.

Title: Changes in Mouse Thymus and Spleen after Return from the STS-135 Mission in Space
Keywords: changes mouse thymus and spleen after
Resumen: This text is from an official U.S. government website and is an open-access article under the Creative Commons Attribution license. It includes a correction to its funding statement, indicating that the work was supported by a grant from NASA and the LLUMC Department of Radiation Medicine, clarifying that the funders had no role in study design, data collection, analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript. No conflicts of interest were declared, and the articles are from PLoS ONE, courtesy of the National Library of Medicine.

Title: Post-Spaceflight (STS-135) Mouse Splenocytes Demonstrate Altered Activation Properties and Surface Molecule Expression.
Keywords: post spaceflight, sts 135, mouse, splenocytes, demonstrate, altered
Resumen: This study investigated alterations in immune function in mice after 13 days of spaceflight (STS-135 mission) by analyzing lymphocyte and monocyte activity. Splenocytes from mice that flew showed unique phenotypic changes compared to ground-based controls, including decreased expression of CD4+CD25+ and CD8+CD25+ cells, a lower percentage of CD11c+MHC II+ cells, and a higher percentage of CD11c+MHC I+ cells. An increase in phagocytic activity was observed, and after stimulation, a decrease in the CD4+ population but an increase in CD4+CD25+ cells, as well as a reduction in certain CD11c+ populations and an alteration in cytokine production (decreased IFN-? and increased IL-2). These findings demonstrate that spaceflight conditions affect the expression of surface molecules and that the altered immune response persists in vitro, contributing to the understanding of crew health risks during deep space missions.

Title: Changes in the distribution and function of leukocytes after whole-body iron ion irradiation.
Keywords: changes, distribution, and function, leukocytes, after
Resumen: A study evaluating the long-term (40-day) effects of total body irradiation with 56Fe26+ in mice revealed significant, compartment-dependent immunological abnormalities. An increase in thymic mass was observed. In the blood, there was a reduction in red blood cells, hemoglobin, hematocrit, and CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, with an increase in the CD4:CD8 ratio and spontaneous blastogenesis. However, in the spleen, white blood cells, lymphocytes, B cells, and T helper cells were elevated, while Tc cells were decreased. Bone marrow stem cells showed low percentages. These findings suggest that immune dysfunction persists for more than a month after radiation exposure.

Title: Is spaceflight-induced immune dysfunction linked to systemic changes in metabolism?
Keywords: spaceflight induced, immune, dysfunction, linked, systemic, changes
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of spaceflight on female C57BL/6J mice that flew on the STS-135 mission aboard the Space Shuttle Atlantis. Researchers analyzed splenic immune function, adrenal stress hormone levels, and hepatic transcriptomic/metabolic profiles. Results showed a decrease in splenic leukocyte subpopulations along with an increase in reactive oxygen species-related activity, and increased corticosterone levels without changes in catecholamines. Functional analysis suggested that the changes were not due to oxidative or physiological stress, but rather to gene expression patterns indicating increased phagocytic activity and fatty acid oxidation, with decreased glycolysis. A link between spaceflight-induced immune dysfunction and metabolic alterations is proposed. It is noteworthy that a shipping error affected the processing time of some ground-based control spleen samples.

Title: Spaceflight Activates Autophagy Programs and the Proteasome in Mouse Liver
Keywords: spaceflight activates autophagy programs and proteasome
Resumen: study investigated the effects of spaceflight on the liver of mice using multi-omics analyses (metabolomics and transcriptomics) after 13.5 days of exposure. The results revealed increased oxidative stress, decreased glutathione levels, and significant alterations in hepatic metabolism. Changes in aminoacyl-tRNA biosynthesis, purine metabolism, autophagy, and the ubiquitin-proteasome system were found, as well as alterations in osmolyte concentrations and lipid metabolism (with possible choline deficiency). Histology also confirmed steatosis and inflammatory cell infiltration. These findings suggest that decreased hepatic oxidative defense could lead to aberrant tRNA processing, the induction of degradation programs, and senescence-associated mitochondrial dysfunction in response to the space environment.

Title: Vive la radiorâˆšÂ©sistance!: Converging research in radiobiology and biogerontology to enhance human radioresistance for deep space exploration and colonization.
