Keywords: lives, radior, sistance, converging, research, radiobiology
Resumen: This text addresses the serious health risks that cosmic radiation poses to human exploration and colonization of deep space, exceeding current safety limits and rendering conventional shielding ineffective. It proposes a roadmap for enhancing human radiation resistance by enhancing endogenous repair and radioprotection mechanisms, gene therapy to introduce exogenous mechanisms, replacing organic molecules with fortified isoforms, and slowing metabolic activity, such as hibernation. It is argued that increasing radiation resistance is linked to increased longevity and could extend the healthy lifespan of space travelers. Galactic cosmic rays (GCRs), particularly high-charge, high-energy (HZE) particles, are highlighted as the primary threat due to their high linear energy transfer (LET) and ability to induce complex DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs). Organisms such as *Deinococcus radiodurans* and tardigrades are cited for their exceptional radiation resistance.

Title: Proteomic analysis of mouse brain subjected to spaceflight.
Keywords: proteomic, mouse, brain, subjected, spaceflight
Resumen: This study investigated spaceflight-induced proteomic changes in the brains of mice, analyzing both gray and white matter. Twenty-six significantly altered proteins were identified; although there was no overlap between individual proteins between the two, there was agreement in functional categories such as synaptic plasticity, vesicular activity, protein/organelle transport, and metabolism. The findings indicate that exposure to the space environment causes alterations in the expression of proteins linked to neuronal structure and metabolic function, which could compromise brain integrity and the success of future space missions.

Title: Transcryptomic effects on the mouse heart following 30 days on the International Space Station.
Keywords: transcriptomic, mouse, heart, following, days, international
Resumen: This study investigated transcriptomic changes in the hearts of C57BL/6J mice after 30 days of spaceflight on the International Space Station. RNA sequencing was performed, identifying 1147 significantly regulated transcripts, with predicted activation of MAPK, PI3K-Akt, and GPCR signaling pathways. The results showed upregulation of transcripts related to cytoskeletal breakdown and organization and the cell cycle, while no significant changes in extracellular matrix components or oxidative stress were observed, nor was there evidence of cellular senescence. Most of the affected transcripts were related to cell maintenance and survival, suggesting an adaptive response of the cardiovascular transcriptome to prolonged spaceflight.

Title: Spaceflight-induced gene expression profiles in the mouse brain are attenuated by treatment with the antioxidant BuOE
Keywords: spaceflight induced, gene, expression, profiles, mouse, brain
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of spaceflight on gene expression in four specific mouse brain regions (cortex, frontal cortex, cornu ammonis I, and dentate gyrus) and the ability of an antioxidant, BuOE, to attenuate these changes. Spaceflight was found to induce hundreds of differentially expressed genes in each brain region, with both common and region-specific responses. Metabolic pathways and pathways sensitive to oxidative stress were enriched, and many affected genes were associated with neurological diseases such as Alzheimer's. Treatment with BuOE significantly reduced the transcriptomic effects of spaceflight, bringing gene expression levels closer to ground controls and attenuating changes in pathways related to oxidative stress and disease, suggesting its potential to mitigate spaceflight-induced brain damage.

Title: Basal signaling regulates plant growth and development
Keywords: basal signaling regulates plant growth and
Resumen: This study identified 50 genes of the proline-rich extensin-like receptor kinase (PERK) family in *Brassica napus*, investigating their evolution, structure, and function. The genes were grouped into four classes and unequally distributed across 18 chromosomes, showing purifying selection and diversification in length, molecular weight, and isoelectric points, with conserved tyrosine kinase domains. Cis-element analysis predicted their involvement in hormonal signaling and stress responses, while expression profiling revealed diverse patterns across tissues and hormone treatments. Protein-protein interaction networks suggested their involvement in multiple biological processes. The decreased expression of four BnPERK genes during *Plasmodiophora brassicae* infection and the increased disease resistance in *Arabidopsis perk9* mutants indicated a negative role for PERK9 in plant immunity. This study highlights the potential of BnPERKs to improve crops against cabbage leaf streak disease.

Title: Phosphoinositide-signaling is one component of a robust plant defense response
Keywords: phosphoinositide signaling, one, component, robust, plant, defense
Resumen: This study investigates the role of the phosphoinositide signaling pathway and inositol-1,4,5-trisphosphate (InsP3) in plant responses to biotic stress. Using transgenic *Arabidopsis* plants with reduced levels of InsP3, they were shown to exhibit attenuated flagellin-induced Ca2+ release, decreased defense gene expression, and increased susceptibility to virulent and avirulent strains of *Pseudomonas syringae*. Furthermore, the modified plants had lower basal levels of salicylic acid and a reduced and delayed induction of systemic acquired resistance (SAR). The findings suggest that phosphoinositide-mediated signaling is an essential component of the plant defense network, affecting Ca2+ release, modulating defense gene expression, and compromising both basal and systemic immune responses.

Title: Uncovering transcriptional responses to fractional gravity in Arabidopsis roots
Keywords: uncovering, transcriptional, responses, fractional, gravity, arabidopsis
Resumen: This study investigated the transcriptional response of *Arabidopsis* seedlings to microgravity and partial gravity (0.53 to 0.88 g) using the European Modular Crop System (EMCS) on the International Space Station. The objective is to understand how fractional gravity, relevant to plant cultivation on the Moon and Mars, affects gene expression. Through transcriptional profiling of root samples, 101 genes were identified whose expression correlates with changes in fractional gravity levels. These genes include transcription factors, defense proteins, cell wall-related proteins, and heat shock proteins, and showed diverse response patterns, such as linear increases or decreases, peaks at intermediate values, or threshold responses.

Title: Conserved plant transcriptional responses to microgravity from two consecutive spaceflight experiments.
Keywords: preserved, plant, transcriptional, responses, microgravity, from
Resumen: This study compares two spaceflight experiments, Plant Signaling (PS) and Plant RNA Regulation (PRR), conducted on the International Space Station using the European Modular Crop System (EMCS), which allowed onboard control of 1g. The results revealed a significant overlap in differential gene expression in microgravity between the two experiments. Up-regulation of genes involved in transcriptional regulation, shoot development, and response to auxin and light was observed, while down-regulation of genes related to defense response, abiotic stress, Ca++ signaling, and cell wall modification was observed. Furthermore, specific microRNAs (miR319c, miR398b, and miR8683) were identified as upregulated in microgravity, with their target genes, often enzymes and proteins located in chloroplasts, being downregulated. The research underscores the validity and importance of onboard 1g monitoring to identify microgravity-specific transcriptional changes, which is crucial for understanding plant adaptation to long-duration space missions.

Title: RNAseq analysis of rodent spaceflight experiments is founded by sample collection techniques
Keywords: rnaseq, rodent, spaceflight, experiments, confounded, sample
Resumen: study of physiological changes in mice during spaceflight revealed that the method of preserving biological samples introduces significant confounding factors, overshadowing the actual effects of space. Changes in the transcriptome of mouse tissues were found to be predominantly the result of preservation (immediate dissection in orbit versus frozen carcasses upon return to Earth), making data interpretation difficult. This variability is exacerbated by the use of polyA selection in RNA library preparation and affects transcriptional integrity. These findings have crucial implications for the interpretation of existing data sets and the design of future experiments, suggesting ribodepletion as a more suitable alternative to mitigate these biases.

Title: Functional changes in the snail statocyst system elicited by microgravity
Keywords: functional, changes, snail, statocyst, system, elicited
Resumen: This study investigated how the gravity-sensing system (statocyst) of land snails (Helix lucorum and Helix aspersa) adapts to microgravity exposure during uncrewed orbital missions. The experiments, performed shortly after return to Earth, analyzed negative gravitaxis behavior, statocyte electrophysiological responses, and neuropeptide gene expression. The results showed that post-flight snails exhibited reduced reorientation latency (enhanced negative gravitaxis), increased sensitivity to acceleration in statocyte responses, and a significant increase in statocyte mRNA expression of the Helix pedal peptide (HPep) gene. These findings, which are similar to those observed in vertebrates, suggest an upregulation of statocyst function in response to microgravity, underscoring fundamental and conserved principles in sensing gravity and adapting to its changes.

Title: Simulated microgravity impairs human NK [natural killer] cell cytotoxic activity against space radiation-relevant leukemic cells
Keywords: simulated, microgravity, impairs, human, natural, killer
Resumen: This study investigated how simulated microgravity affects the ability of human natural killer (NK) cells to fight cancer, a crucial factor for astronauts on extended space missions. Brief exposure to simulated microgravity was found to significantly reduce NK cell cytotoxicity against leukemia cells, an effect that was even more pronounced when the cytotoxicity assay was performed under continuous microgravity. Given previous concerns about the risk of space radiation-induced leukemia, these findings suggest that microgravity could increase astronauts' risk of developing leukemia during long missions, highlighting the need for further research and countermeasures.

Title: Multi-analyte biochip (MAB) based on all-solid-state ion-selective electrodes (ASSISE) for physiological research
Keywords: multi analyte, biochip, mab, based, all solid state, ion selective
Resumen: A lab-on-a-chip multi-analyte biochip (MAB) was developed that integrates a microfabricated solid-state ion-selective electrode (ASSISE). This ASSISE uses the conductive polymer PEDOT as the transducer layer, instead of Ag/AgCl, for longer lifetime and stability in complex biological media. The biochip was designed to quantify H+, Ca2+, and CO32- ions. Calibrations demonstrated its ability to monitor these species with stable responses, even after prolonged storage. It was successfully used to monitor the photosynthetic activity of the microalga *Chlorella vulgaris*. The MAB offers significant advantages in miniaturization, versatility, and multi-analyte detection capabilities, making it ideal for monitoring applications in confined environments, both on Earth and in space.

Title: Lab-on-a-chip approaches for space-biology research.
Keywords: lab on a chip, approaches, for, space biology, research
Resumen: The rise of space exploration and the need for in-situ analytical measurements with low payload requirements make traditional methods unfeasible. Lab-on-a-chip (LoC) nanobiosensors are emerging as a revolutionary technology due to their small size, high accuracy, rapid detection capability, and low power consumption, making them ideal for monitoring astronaut health and environmental/microbiological variables. These devices are crucial for future space missions and research in extreme terrestrial environments, which simulate space conditions and serve as testing grounds. Although promising and with significant advances in the LoC sector, their application in the exploration of extreme environments is still under-researched, with colorimetric and electrochemical biosensors, combined with microfluidics, being the most relevant future directions for cost-effective and efficient systems.

Title: Plant chemical genomics: gravity sensing and response.
Keywords: plant, chemistry, genomics, gravity, sensing, and
Resumen: The genomic study of Zygomycetes, the first terrestrial fungi now classified in Mucoromycota and Zoopagomycota, has advanced significantly since the first genome was sequenced in 2008, with over a thousand sequenced. These data have revealed profound phylogenetic separations and provided valuable insights into fungal evolution on land, including adaptations to terrestrial challenges and coevolution with plants. Despite historical difficulties in their study due to their parapyletic nature or the impossibility of cultivation, genomics has clarified their diversity and ecological, biotechnological, and medical relevance. Sequencing is performed from diverse DNA sources using technologies such as Illumina for short reads and PacBio for long reads, which are then assembled. Genomes vary in size and gene count, and their quality depends on coverage. Major projects have boosted research on zygomycetes, highlighting their fundamental role in understanding early life in terrestrial ecosystems.

Title: The interaction of vortical flows with red cells in venous valve mimics.
Keywords: interaction vortical flows with network cells
Resumen: This study investigates how blood flow patterns affect red blood cell (RBC) distribution in venous valves, given their relevance to thrombosis and cell sorting efficiency. Using an in vitro microfluidic model of a venous valve, the spatial distribution of RBCs was quantified by microscopy and image analysis, and complex flow patterns were analyzed with microparticle image velocimetry (PIV) and 3D computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations. The results revealed that the local hematocrit in the valve pockets is heterogeneous and distinct from that of the inflow. Above a threshold shear rate, inertial streamline separation and lift forces contribute to uneven RBC distribution in vortices, their trapping, and nonmonotonic shear stresses on pocket walls. This experimental and computational characterization offers a better understanding of the complex interactions between fluid flow, RBC distribution, and shear rates in venous valve models, which is crucial for understanding the pathophysiology of thrombosis and improving the efficiency of cell separation.

Title: Mammalian and Invertebrate Models as Complementary Tools for Gaining Mechanistic Insight on Muscle Responses to Spaceflight
Keywords: mammalian and invertebrate models, complementary tools
Resumen: This study compared the transcriptomic responses of the soleus and extensor digitorum longus (EDL) muscles of mice exposed to spaceflight, revealing shared stress responses and circadian rhythm disruptions, with the EDL showing greater resistance to atrophy and more robust growth signals. The utility of invertebrate models such as C. elegans and D. melanogaster was also investigated. The results indicated common gene regulations between spaceflight mice, bed-rested humans, and hindlimb-unloaded mice, suggesting potential targets to mitigate muscle atrophy. C. elegans responses were found to more closely resemble those of the EDL, and invertebrate models can complement the mechanistic knowledge from rodent and ground-based studies, helping to predict mammalian responses to spaceflight.

Title: Investigation of simulated microgravity effects on Streptococcus mutans physiology and global gene expression.
Keywords: investigation, simulated, microgravity, streptococcus, mutans, physiology
Resumen: recent study investigated the response of *Streptococcus mutans*, the primary caries-causing bacterium, to simulated microgravity, seeking to understand dental problems in astronauts. The results showed that *S. mutans* cultures grown in simulated microgravity conditions were more susceptible to hydrogen peroxide, tended to form more compact cell aggregates, and exhibited significant changes in the expression of approximately 250 genes, many of them involved in carbohydrate metabolism, translation, and stress responses. These findings suggest that the microgravity environment alters the physiology and cariogenic potential of *S. mutans*, which could explain the increased risk of dental disease in astronauts during space missions.

Title: Altered quorum sensing and physiology of Staphylococcus aureus during spaceflight detected by multi-omics data analysis
Keywords: altered quorum sensing and physiology staphylococcus
Resumen: The BRIC-23 experiment investigated the response of *Staphylococcus aureus* to the spaceflight environment on the International Space Station. RNA-Seq, proteomic, and metabolomic analyses revealed that under these conditions, *S. aureus* exhibits significantly increased quorum sensing (Agr system, with highly regulated RNAIII and AgrA), increased expression of secreted virulence factors such as proteases and EsxA, and metabolic alterations including changes in urease activity and amino acid metabolism. These findings collectively suggest that the space environment may increase the pathogenicity of *S. aureus* by altering its metabolism and virulence factor expression.

Title: Homotypic vacuole fusion requires VTI11 and is regulated by phosphoinositides
Keywords: homotypic, vacuole, fusion, requires, vti11, and
Resumen: This study investigates the role of the homotypic fusion and vacuolar protein sorting (HOPS) complex in the fusion of plant vacuoles, organelles crucial for growth and development. The research demonstrates that HOPS mediates vacuolar fusion in plants by interacting with SNARE proteins, identifying the subunits VPS33 and SYP22 as key sites of interaction. VPS33 and VPS41 were found to localize to late endosomes, while only VPS41 was found to localize to the tonoplast. Unlike other eukaryotes, HOPS recruitment to liposomes in plants is inhibited by phosphoinositides, suggesting a specific regulatory mechanism. VPS41 knockdown leads to significant vacuolar fragmentation, confirming the importance of HOPS in this process. The findings reveal both conserved and plant-specific mechanisms in HOPS function during vacuolar fusion.

Title: REGULATOR OF BULB BIOGENESIS1 (RBB1) Is Involved in Vacuole Bulb Formation in Arabidopsis.
Keywords: regulator, bulb, biogenesis1, rbb1, involved, vacuole
Resumen: This paper describes research on plant vacuoles, highlighting their dynamic structures such as trans-vacuolar strands (TVS) and bulbs. A novel Arabidopsis mutant, *rbb1-1*, is introduced, which exhibits an increased number of bulbs and a decreased number of TVS compared to control plants. It is hypothesized that the gene RBB1, encoding a large, plant-specific protein of unknown function, is involved in TVS formation and stability, and that the increased bulb number in *rbb1-1* could be due to impaired TVS formation, suggesting that bulbs may function transiently to accommodate membranes and proteins when TVS fail to elongate.

Title: Phosphoinositides control the localization of HOPS subunit VPS41, which together with VPS33 mediates vacuole fusion in plants.
Keywords: phosphoinositides, control, localization, hops, subunit, vps41
Resumen: The text describes how the HOPS (Homotypic Fusion and Vacuolar Protein Sorting) complex mediates vacuole fusion in plants, a process essential for their growth and development. Unlike other eukaryotes, HOPS recruitment to liposomes in plants is inhibited by phosphoinositides, suggesting a distinct regulatory mechanism. The results show that the HOPS subunits VPS33 and VPS41 are critical for vacuolar fusion, interact with SNARE proteins, and localize to late endosomes, with VPS41 also present in the tonoplast. The study reveals both conserved and plant-specific mechanisms in HOPS function and recruitment during vacuole fusion.

Title: Microgravity enhances the phenotype of Arabidopsis zigzag-1 and reduces the Wortmannin-induced vacuole fusion in root cells.
Keywords: microgravity, enhances, phenotype, arabidopsis, zigzag 1, and
Resumen: This study investigated the effect of microgravity on plant vacuole fusion, an essential process for growth, using the *Arabidopsis zigzag-1 (zig-1)* mutant on the International Space Station. Researchers used Wortmannin to induce vacuolar fusion and developed a formaldehyde-based fixation protocol for subsequent analysis. The results indicate that microgravity accentuates the *zig-1* phenotype, slowing hypocotyl growth and reducing vacuole fusion in some cells. Furthermore, the experiment demonstrated the feasibility of chemical inhibitor treatments for plant cell biology studies in space.

Title: Hypergravity disruption of homeorhetic adaptations to lactation in rat dams include changes in circadian clocks
Keywords: hypergravity, disruption, homeorhetic, adaptations, lactation, rat
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of hypergravity (2-g) during gestation and lactation in rats, proposing that it disrupts essential maternal homeorrhetic responses. Exposure to hypergravity significantly reduced the body weight of both dams and pups, and dramatically increased pup mortality (decreasing from 95% to 48% survival between day of delivery and postnatal day 3). Alterations in mammary, hepatic, and adipose tissue metabolism were observed, including decreased glucose oxidation and lipid synthesis in the mammary gland. Plasma levels of prolactin, corticosterone, and insulin were also affected. Hypergravity altered the expression of circadian clock genes in the breast and liver, and impacted maternal behavioral circadian rhythms, affecting activities such as feeding, nest building, and pup care. These findings suggest that gravity-induced alterations in the maternal circadian system may limit the homeorrheal adaptations necessary for successful lactation.

Title: Intrauterine exposure to maternal stress alters Bdnf IV DNA methylation and telomere length in the brain of adult rat offspring.
Keywords: intrauterine, exposure, maternal, stress, alters, bdnf
Resumen: This study examined the long-term impact of unpredictable and variable maternal prenatal stress in rats by measuring Bdnf-associated DNA methylation and telomere length in the brains of adult offspring. Findings showed that males exposed to prenatal stress had increased methylation (Bdnf IV) in the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC), and overall, prenatally stressed animals had shorter telomeres in the mPFC compared to controls. These results suggest that prenatal stress has a lasting impact on brain DNA methylation and telomere biology, with significant implications for offspring behavior and health.

Title: Influence of gonadectomy on muscle health in micro- and partial-gravity environments in rats.
Keywords: influence, gonadectomy, muscle, health, micro, and
Resumen: This study investigated how biological sex and sex steroid hormones influence muscle atrophy in male and female rats exposed to microgravity and partial gravity environments. One hundred twenty male and female Fisher rats, some castrated or ovariectomized, were divided into microgravity (0g), partial gravity (0.4g), or full weight-bearing (1g) groups for 28 days, and muscle strength and size were measured. Results showed that females lost more dorsiflexion strength, plantarflexion strength, and other muscle size metrics compared to males at both 0g and 0.4g, and these differences were not dependent on the presence of sex steroid hormones. The study concludes that astronauts may require additional interventions to mitigate musculoskeletal loss in reduced gravity environments.

Title: Sex differences in muscle health in simulated micro- and partial-gravity environments in rats.
Keywords: sex, differences, muscle, health, simulated, micro
Resumen: This study investigated how biological sex and sex steroid hormones influence the progression of muscle atrophy in rats exposed to simulated microgravity and partial gravity environments. Male and female rats, some castrated or ovariectomized, were subjected to microgravity (0g), partial gravity (0.4g), or Earth gravity (1g) for 28 days, and their muscle strength and size were assessed. The results showed that females lost significantly more strength (dorsiflexion and plantar flexion) and muscle size than males in both microgravity and partial gravity. These differences were not dependent on the presence of sex steroid hormones. Therefore, it is concluded that females exhibit greater musculoskeletal aberrations in reduced gravity environments, implying the need for additional interventions to mitigate musculoskeletal loss in female astronauts.

Title: Brassinazole resistant 1 (BZR1)-dependent brassinosteroid signaling pathway leads to ectopic activation of quiescent cell division and suppresses columella stem cell differentiation
Keywords: brassinazole, resistant, bzr1, dependent, brassinosteroid, signaling
Resumen: This paper examines how brassinosteroids (BRs), through BZR1- and BES1-mediated signaling pathways, regulate the activities of the Arabidopsis root apical meristem. We show that BZR1 promotes the division of quiescent center (QC) cells but suppresses the differentiation of columella stem cells (CSCs), in contrast to the stimulatory effect of BES1 on CSCs. BRs and BZR1 signaling alter the distribution of PIN proteins, influencing auxin movement, and BZR1 accumulates in the nucleus to modulate gene expression. These mechanisms lead to ectopic activation of the QC and differential differentiation of CSCs, depending on the concentration of BR and the signaling molecule.

Title: Proteomic study of microsomal proteins reveals a key role for Arabidopsis Annexin 1 in mediating heat stress-induced increase in intracellular calcium levels.
Keywords: proteomic, microsomal, proteins, reveals, key, role
Resumen: study using two-dimensional electrophoresis and mass spectrometry in Arabidopsis seedling microsomes identified 19 proteins upregulated early during heat stress. Among them, annexin 1 (AtANN1) was rapidly upregulated. Loss-of-function mutants of AtANN1 and its homolog AtANN2 showed increased sensitivity to heat stress, while overexpression of AtANN1 conferred increased resistance. The expression of heat shock proteins and factors, as well as the heat-induced increase in cytoplasmic calcium concentration, were inhibited or severely impaired in AtANN1 and AtANN2 mutants. These results suggest that AtANN1 is critical in the regulation of heat-induced cytoplasmic calcium increases and in the response of *Arabidopsis* seedlings to heat stress.

Title: Apyrase inhibitors enhance the ability of diverse fungicides to inhibit the growth of different plant-pathogenic fungi
Keywords: apyrase, inhibitors, enhance, ability, diverse, fungicides
Resumen: This study investigated the ability of apyrase inhibitors to enhance the action of fungicides against plant pathogenic fungi. The addition of four apyrase inhibitors was found to significantly increase the potency of three common fungicides (copper octanoate, myclobutanil, and propiconazole) in inhibiting the growth of five fungal species, with improvements observed in 53 of the 60 combinations tested. The inhibitors were most effective with copper octanoate and least effective with propiconazole, with *Sclerotinia sclerotiorum* being the most sensitive pathogen. It is suggested that these inhibitors act by blocking the efflux transporters that fungi use to detoxify fungicides, offering a new strategy to increase the efficacy of antifungal treatments.

Title: ANN1 and ANN2 Function in Post-Phloem Sugar Transport in Root Tips to Affect Primary Root Growth
Keywords: ann1, and, ann2, function, post phloem, sugar
Resumen: This study reveals that the annexins ANN1 and ANN2 regulate primary root growth in Arabidopsis by facilitating the transport of post-phloem sugars to root tips. Mutants deficient in these annexins showed reduced root growth and cap defects when grown without sugar, effects that were reversed by the addition of sucrose or other sugars. Despite increased photosynthetic expression in the cotyledons, mutant roots accumulated more sugar, but its transport to the tips was impaired, as evidenced by impaired dye transport and increased reactive oxygen species and callose that restrict plasmodesmal passage. These findings demonstrate the importance of ANN1 and ANN2 in the distribution of sugars to root tips and their indirect influence on photosynthesis.

Title: Mitochondria-targeted human catalase in the mouse longevity MCAT model mitigates head-tilt bedrest-induced neuro-inflammation in the hippocampus.
Keywords: mitochondria targeted, human, catalase, mouse, longevity, mcat
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of simulated microgravity, using head-tilt bed rest and hindlimb unloading (HU), in socially housed mice, focusing on neuroinflammation and microglial activation. The findings showed that HU elevated the CD68 marker of activated microglia in the hippocampus, an effect that was mitigated in MCAT mice, which overexpress human catalase in mitochondria to scavenge reactive oxygen species (ROS). Furthermore, significant correlations were observed between hippocampal cytokine levels, microglial activation, and exploratory behaviors. These results suggest a link between neuroinflammation and the behavioral consequences of microgravity and highlight the role of ROS-mediated oxidative stress, which could lead to the development of biomarkers and treatments for cognitive changes associated with prolonged space missions or muscle disuse on Earth.

Title: Structural and functional properties of bone are compromised in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis mice.
Keywords: structural, and, functional, properties, bone, are
Resumen: This study investigated bone fragility in a mouse model of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), SOD1G93A mice, previously known to exhibit decreased bone mass. The results revealed that, compared with controls, SOD1G93A mice with end-stage ALS had significantly reduced trabecular and cortical bone mass and microarchitecture, including less trabecular mass, thinner trabeculae, and reduced cortical thickness and area. These structural deficiencies translated into reduced functional properties of the skeleton, such as decreased femoral flexural stiffness, lower moment at failure, and reduced fracture toughness. It was concluded that this is the first study to demonstrate functional deficits in the skeleton of mice with advanced ALS, implicating multiple mechanisms for the increased skeletal fragility and fracture risk in ALS patients and providing a strong rationale for interventions aimed at reducing this risk.

Title: Longitudinal time course of muscle impairments during partial weight-bearing in rats
Keywords: longitudinal time course muscle impairments during
Resumen: This study investigated the long-term effects of partial gravity on muscle function, a crucial aspect of astronaut health on future extended missions to the Moon and Mars. Using an enhanced partial weight-bearing (PWB) rat model, researchers assessed muscle function and mass at various levels of simulated gravity for one month. The results demonstrated that both muscle mass and function were significantly impaired in reduced-weight environments as early as 7 days. These muscle alterations correlated with the level of PWB and did not reach a plateau over the study period, underscoring the critical need to implement countermeasures to ensure the safety and success of space exploration.

Title: The partial weight-bearing rat model using a pelvic harness does not impact stress or hindlimb blood flow.
Keywords: partial weight bearing rat model pelvic harness
Resumen: Blood flow restriction training (BFRT) is a technique used in rehabilitation and injury prevention to improve muscle strength and size (hypertrophy), especially in individuals with load limitations. It allows significant muscle gains to be achieved with low loads, accelerating recovery and mitigating disuse atrophy. It works by restricting venous return and partial arterial flow with a tourniquet, creating a hypoxic environment and accumulating metabolites that promote muscle growth. Although useful in various performance and rehabilitation applications, its use requires caution and rigorous evaluation, as there are numerous contraindications, especially cardiovascular ones, and potential adverse effects. Additional training is recommended for professionals using it.

Title: Dose-dependent skeletal deficits due to varied reductions in mechanical loading in rats.
Keywords: dose dependent, skeletal, deficits, due, varied, reductions
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of partial weight-bearing (PWB) on the skeleton of male Wistar rats, exposing them to different loading levels (20%, 40%, 70%, 100% of body weight) and durations (1, 2, or 4 weeks). The results showed that trabecular bone density of the proximal tibia decreased progressively and proportionally to the degree of unloading, without reaching a plateau by four weeks, and the trabecular microarchitecture of the distal femur also deteriorated in a dose-dependent manner. These alterations were associated with a decrease in osteoblast numbers and surface mineralization (reduced bone formation). In contrast, cortical bone density and microarchitecture showed little or no change, and the functional properties of the femur shaft showed modest or no reductions. The study concludes that this PWB model in rats causes progressive deterioration of trabecular bone, generally proportional to the degree of unloading, with minimal effects on cortical bone, which is relevant for understanding bone loss in partial loading situations such as space.

Title: Approaching Gravity as a Continuum Using the Rat Partial Weight-Bearing Model
Keywords: approaching, gravity, continuum, rat, partial, weight bearing
Resumen: The text addresses the need for animal models to investigate physiological changes during space travel, such as microgravity and partial gravity. It describes the hindlimb unloading (HU) model in rats to simulate microgravity and presents a new partial weight-bearing (PWB) model for rats, designed to replicate reduced-gravity environments such as those on the Moon or Mars. Technical improvements made to the PWB model in rats are detailed, including housing design, suspension apparatus, and the use of a pelvic harness, which have resulted in increased reliability and better correlation with human physiology. The goal is to use these models to anticipate physiological changes and astronaut needs, especially muscle atrophy and bone density loss, on future space missions.

Title: Hindlimb suspension in Wistar rats: Sex-based differences in muscle response
Keywords: hindlimb, suspension, wistar, rats, sex based, differences
Resumen: The study evaluated the impact of sex on disuse-induced muscle deconditioning using the hindlimb suspension (HLS) model in rats, which simulates the effects of microgravity. Although this model has been valuable, there have been few direct comparisons between males and females. Wistar rats (male and female) were exposed to 14 days of HLS or normal loading, revealing that females maintained muscle function better than males. They exhibited a more moderate reduction in grip strength, muscle mass, cross-sectional area, and force production. These findings suggest that females experience less muscle deconditioning during disuse, emphasizing the need to consider sex-based differences to develop effective and tailored countermeasures for all astronauts.

Title: Adaptation to full weight-bearing following disuse in rats: The impact of biological sex on musculoskeletal recovery
Keywords: adaptation, full, weight bearing, following, disuse, rats
Resumen: This text describes an official U.S. government website (.gov, secured with HTTPS) and references an open-access article licensed under a Creative Commons license. It cites a 2024 article on musculoskeletal recovery in rats following inactivity, published in Physiological Reports by Issertine, M. et al. It corrects a spelling error in the name of the second author, Megan E. Rosa-Caldwell, and thanks Wiley and the National Library of Medicine.

Title: Effects of liquid cultivation on gene expression and phenotype of C. elegans.
Keywords: liquid cultivation gene expression and phenotype
Resumen: This study investigated the transcriptomic and phenotypic responses of *Caenorhabditis elegans* (strains N2 and AB1) to rapid shifts between agar and liquid cultures. The findings revealed significant variations in gene expression among strains in response to liquid culture, with 8–34% of environmentally induced transcriptional responses being passed on to the next generation. Genotype was found to have a substantial impact on adaptive responses, and noncoding RNA expression was enriched in condition-specific transcripts, with condition-specific gene expression influenced by genotype, while gene expression transmission was dependent on genotype-environment interactions. Furthermore, transcriptomic evidence was found for approximately 21% of the computationally predicted genes. The results offer standard controls for future studies in C. elegans liquid culture and support condition-specific gene discovery.

Title: Transcriptomic Signature of the Simulated Microgravity Response in Caenorhabditis elegans and Comparison to Spaceflight Experiments.
Keywords: transcriptomic, signature, simulated, microgravity, response,caenorhabditis
Resumen: study investigated the transcriptomic response of the worm *Caenorhabditis elegans* to simulated microgravity and the persistence of these effects upon return to terrestrial conditions. The findings reveal that 75% of the gene expression changes induced by simulated microgravity persist after four days on Earth, although most are reversed after twelve days. RNA-seq and mass spectrometry analyses suggest that simulated microgravity affects insulin/IGF-1 and sphingolipid signaling pathways, which regulate longevity. Additionally, 118 genes were identified whose expression is commonly altered in both simulated microgravity and space conditions, providing insight into the impact of microgravity on biological systems during and after exposure.

Title: Enabling clonal analyzes of yeast in outer space by encapsulation and desiccation in hollow microparticles.
Keywords: enabling, clonal, analyses, yeast, outer, space
Resumen: The text presents a novel method for studying microorganisms at the single-cell level in space using "PicoShells," hollow hydrogel microparticles that encapsulate and preserve microbes through desiccation. This system is crucial for developing biotechnologies and understanding cellular responses to space conditions, overcoming the limitations of bulk population analyses. PicoShells maintain their morphology and porosity after weeks of storage and rehydration, demonstrating high viability of the encapsulated yeast *Saccharomyces cerevisiae*. The method offers a robust and resource-efficient solution for the preservation and simple analysis of microbial heterogeneity, with the potential to accelerate human space exploration.

Title: Caenorhabditis elegans in microgravity: An omics perspective
Keywords: caenorhabditis, elegans, microgravity, omics, perspective
Resumen: Spaceflight induces significant physiological maladaptations in humans, similar to accelerated aging. Due to limitations in human or rodent studies, *Caenorhabditis elegans* emerges as a cost-effective and biologically relevant model organism for this research, thanks to its ease of cultivation and genetic similarities. The application of "omics" technologies (transcriptomics, proteomics, etc.) to study *C. elegans* in space is increasing, revealing reproducible molecular alterations in metabolic and neuromuscular gene regulation, findings consistent with those observed in other species. The integration of advanced omics approaches is crucial for identifying candidate regulatory molecules for therapeutic interventions, benefiting both the safety of space travel and health on Earth, supported by initiatives such as NASA's GeneLab.

Title: Dried plum diet protects from bone loss caused by ionizing radiation
Keywords: dried plum diet protects from bone
Resumen: Exposure to ionizing radiation, whether in space, during radiation therapy, or in accidents, can cause bone loss due to oxidative damage and increased bone resorption. One study evaluated several interventions, including an antioxidant cocktail, dihydrolipoic acid, ibuprofen, and dried prunes, to mitigate these effects in mice exposed to gamma rays or simulated space radiation. The results showed that the dried prunes were the most effective at reducing the expression of genes related to bone resorption and preventing radiation-induced cancellous bone loss. This suggests that dietary supplementation with dried prunes could prevent the skeletal effects of radiation exposure.

Title: Dietary countermeasure mitigates simulated spaceflight-induced osteopenia in mice
Keywords: dietary, countermeasure, mitigates, simulated, spaceflight induced, osteopenia
Resumen: A study investigated whether dietary supplementation with prune powder (DP) can prevent bone loss in mice exposed to simulated spaceflight conditions (microgravity and radiation). The results showed that a DP diet was effective in preventing most of the deterioration in bone microarchitectural and mechanical properties caused by simulated microgravity and the combination of microgravity and radiation. Furthermore, the DP diet protected osteoprogenitors from deterioration. These findings suggest that DP could be an effective countermeasure against skeletal deficits in astronauts during spaceflight.

Title: Simulated microgravity alters gene regulation linked to immunity and cardiovascular disease
Keywords: simulated, microgravity, alters, gene, regulation, linked
Resumen: This study investigated cardiac responses to prolonged exposure to simulated microgravity using a hindlimb unloading (HU) model in rats of different ages and sexes, with the goal of understanding oxidative damage and gene expression. The results showed sex-dependent changes in the oxidative damage marker 8-OHdG and antioxidant gene expression in left ventricular tissue. Young females (3 months old) exhibited elevated 8-OHdG levels after 14 days of HU, unlike age-matched males. RNAseq analysis in nine-month-old males revealed upregulation of proinflammatory signaling pathways and immune cell activation, as well as differential expression of genes associated with cardiovascular disease progression. These findings suggest the need to consider sex differences and target antioxidant and immune pathways when developing countermeasures to maintain cardiovascular health during space missions.

Title: Autophagy and its consequences for platelet biology
Keywords: Autophagy and its consequences for platelet
Resumen: This study identified novel drug targets for chronic kidney disease (CKD), a progressive condition with limited treatments. Using Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis, druggable genes were investigated from cis-eQTL data and genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of CKD from the eQTLGen and FinnGen databases, respectively. Gene Ontology (GO) and KEGG enrichment analyses, along with colocalization analysis, revealed 12 genes to be significantly associated with CKD risk. Among them, the TUBB gene emerged as the most promising drug target, sharing a causal variant with CKD with a high probability, offering valuable insights for future drug development.

Title: A new role of NAP1L1 in megakaryocytes and human platelets
Keywords: new role nap1l1 megakaryocytes and human
Resumen: This study investigated the expression and functionality of the NAP1L1 protein in platelets (PLTs) and megakaryocytes (MKs). NAP1L1 was found to be expressed in both cells, at the mRNA and protein levels, and localized to the cytoplasm of MKs and perigranularly in PLTs, suggesting non-nuclear functions. The investigation revealed that NAP1L1 dynamically interacts with PDC-E2, a subunit of the mitochondrial pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex, crucial for cellular respiration. Increased NAP1L1 expression and PDH activity were observed in platelets from septic patients. However, overexpression of NAP1L1 in MKs significantly decreased proplatelet formation (thrombopoiesis) and PDH activity in a simulated septic environment. These findings suggest that NAP1L1 plays roles other than nucleosome assembly, acting as a potential chaperone or regulator of the mitochondrial protein PDC-E2, and influencing PDH activity and platelet production.

Title: Evaluation of rodent spaceflight in the NASA animal enclosure module for an extended operational period (up to 35 days)
Keywords: evaluation, rodent, spaceflight, nasa, animal, enclosure
Resumen: This study evaluated the ability of NASA's Animal Enclosure Module (AEM), designed for short-haul flights, to support rodents on missions of up to 35 days on the International Space Station. Researchers tested the hardware with 12 C57BL/6 mice and 5 Sprague-Dawley rats, monitoring their health, growth, intake, and environmental parameters. The AEM was shown to support the mice for 35 days with self-contained food and water, and the rats for the same period with external resupply of diet and water, maintaining their well-being and health parameters comparable to vivarium controls. The study concludes that the AEM is flexible and capable of operating for up to 35 days with minor modifications, making it suitable for longer-term space science research with rodents, although additional studies are needed for durations longer than 35 days.

Title: Morphology of Penicillium rubens Biofilms Formed in Space
Keywords: morphology, penicillium, rubens, biofilms, formed, space
Resumen: This study examined the impact of microgravity on the formation of *Penicillium rubens* fungal biofilms on seven materials relevant to spacecraft and hospital environments, a critical concern for spaceflight due to potential damage to spacecraft and health risks to astronauts. Spore-inoculated materials were flown to the International Space Station (ISS) for development for 10, 15, and 20 days, compared to ground-based controls. Although microgravity did not significantly alter the overall morphology, biomass, or surface coverage of biofilms, it did influence their formation, increasing or decreasing the amount of biofilm in some cases, in a time- and material-dependent manner. The Nanograss material showed a significant reduction in biofilm formation both in microgravity and on Earth, making it a potential solution. These findings are essential for understanding and mitigating fungal contamination on space missions.

Title: Explainable machine learning identifies multi-omics signatures of muscle response to spaceflight in mice
Keywords: explainable, machine, learning, identifies, multi omics, signatures
Resumen: This study uses multi-omic and physiological data from mice exposed to microgravity to identify molecular biomarkers associated with muscle atrophy during spaceflight. Using the symbolic regression algorithm QLattice, data from the soleus and tibialis anterior muscles were analyzed to predict calcium reuptake levels. The results indicate that Acyp1 and Rps7 proteins are the most predictive biomarkers for tibialis anterior muscle resilience in space, with Acyp1 negatively correlated with calcium reuptake. These findings offer potential targets for future interventions aimed at reducing muscle atrophy during spaceflight.

Title: Microbial adaptation to spaceflight is correlated with bacteriophage-encoded functions
Keywords: Microbial adaptation spaceflight correlated with bacteriophage encoded
Resumen: The article investigates microbial adaptation on the International Space Station (ISS), highlighting the role of latent bacteriophages (prophages) as mediators of such adaptation. An analysis of 245 bacterial genomes isolated from the ISS revealed that phage-associated genes are significantly different between space-borne and ground-based strains. A total of 283 complete prophages were identified, 21% of which are novel, and encode functions that correlate with increased persistence in extreme environments, such as antimicrobial resistance, virulence, DNA repair, and dormancy. These findings suggest that microbial adaptation in space is linked to bacteriophage-encoded functions, which could have implications for human health during extended space missions.

Title: Influence of the spaceflight environment on macrophage lineages
Keywords: influence, spaceflight, environment, macrophage, lineages
Resumen: This article reviews the impact of space and its unique risk factors, such as radiation and altered gravity, on the immune system, with a focus on macrophages. Macrophages are immune cells crucial for innate and adaptive immunity, homeostasis, defense against infection, and wound healing. Research indicates that spaceflight can alter leukocyte count and function, causing chronic low-grade inflammation. Changes in monocyte count, phagocytic activity, cytokine production, and macrophage differentiation/polarization have been observed in both humans and rodents, although with some differences between species. Furthermore, spaceflight affects specialized macrophages such as osteoclasts, contributing to bone loss, and microglia, which could induce neuroinflammation. A thorough understanding of these responses is critical for astronaut health and for developing countermeasures for future missions, although further in-flight research is required to fully characterize their altered phenotypes and functions.

Title: MARSBOx: Fungal and bacterial resistance from a balloon-flown analog mission in the stratosphere
Keywords: Marsbox fungal and bacterial endurance from
Resumen: study investigated the ability of terrestrial life to withstand the Martian environment via a NASA science balloon mission to the mid-stratosphere (âˆ¼38 km altitude) in September 2019. This altitude simulates the radiation, dehydration, hypoxia, and low temperature and pressure conditions of the equatorial surface of Mars. Samples of fungal spores (Aspergillus niger) and bacterial cells (Salinisphaera shabanensis, Staphylococcus capitis subsp. capitis, and Buttiauxella sp. MASE-IM-9) were exposed in the MARSBOx module, some to full UV-VIS radiation and others shielded. After five hours, A. niger spores and S. shabanensis cells showed the greatest resistance, while Buttiauxella sp. was completely inactivated and S. capitis only survived when protected from UV radiation. The results highlight a wide variation in microbial survival and suggest that pigmented fungi could be resistant to the Martian surface if inadvertently transported by spacecraft, which is relevant for planetary protection.

Title: In situ linkage of fungal and bacterial proliferation to microbiologically influenced corrosion in B20 biodiesel storage tanks.
Keywords: situ linkage, fungal and bacterial proliferation
Resumen: Biodiesel (B20) is a promising renewable fuel, but it is susceptible to biodegradation and microbial corrosion, an understudied problem *in situ*. This study, the first of its scale, conducted a year-long investigation in operational U.S. Air Force B20 tanks to assess microbial proliferation, fuel degradation, and microbiologically influenced corrosion. Diverse and unique bacterial populations were identified for each location, while eukaryotic populations, such as the filamentous fungi Trichocomaceae and the yeasts Saccharomycetaceae, were consistent across sites. A key finding was the correlation between increased Trichocomaceae abundance and visible fouling and pitting corrosion. The study was able to establish a relationship between B20 fouling, increased corrosion, and the responsible microorganisms, primarily at the bottom of the tanks.

Title: Identification of metagenome-assembled genomes containing antimicrobial resistance genes, isolated from an advanced water treatment facility.
Keywords: identification, metagenome assembled, genomes, containing, antimicrobial, resistance
Resumen: This study identified 95 metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) containing 185 antimicrobial resistance genes (ARGs) in samples from an Orange County Water District (OCWD) advanced wastewater treatment plant, taken before microfiltration. MAGs were not found after barrier filtration, suggesting the effectiveness of the treatment. The research, which uses DNA sequencing and bioinformatics tools, expands knowledge about microbial lineages harboring ARGs in ultrapure water facilities and offers a useful resource for the water treatment community.

Title: Nature of pre-earthquake phenomena and their effects on living organisms
Keywords: nature, pre earthquake, phenomena, and, their, living
Resumen: The text addresses the difficulty of predicting earthquakes, highlighting that although traditional seismology is based on past data, numerous non-seismic signals exist prior to the events. It criticizes mechanistic explanations such as microfracturing and the electrokinetic effect for being inconsistent with depth conditions. Instead, it proposes a theory involving the activation of "positive holes" (hâ€¢), electronic charge carriers formed in silicate minerals under stress. These positive holes are highly mobile, generating ultra-low frequency (ULF/ELF) electromagnetic waves that can reach the surface. Upon arrival, they ionize the air and oxidize the water, which could explain the unusual animal behavior and other physical and chemical anomalies observed before earthquakes.

Title: The rapid diagnosis and effective inhibition of coronavirus using spike antibody attached gold nanoparticles
Keywords: Rapid diagnosis and effective inhibition of coronavirus
Resumen: Gold nanoparticles functionalized with anti-spike antibodies have been developed for the rapid diagnosis of COVID-19 and the inhibition of SARS-CoV-2. This system detects the virus or its antigen within 5 minutes through a colorimetric change from pink to blue, observable with the naked eye. It also employs surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) for ultrasensitive detection within the same timeframe, identifying the antigen at concentrations of picograms per milliliter and the virus at very low particles per milliliter. Beyond diagnosis, these nanoparticles demonstrate the ability to block SARS-CoV-2 entry into human cells by binding to its spike protein, preventing infection and spread, and can even destroy its lipid membrane.

Title: Blocking SARS-CoV-2 Delta variant (B.1.617.2) spike protein receptor-binding domain binding with the ACE2 receptor of the host cell and inhibiting virus infections using human host defense peptide-conjugated graphene quantum dots.
Keywords: blocking, sars cov 2, delta, variant, 617, spike
Resumen: study reveals that graphene quantum dots (GQDs) conjugated with human defense peptides (HNP1 and LL-37) can block the entry of the SARS-CoV-2 delta variant (B.1.617.2) into host cells. These bioconjugates prevent the binding of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the viral S protein to the ACE2 receptor, showing a high binding affinity (9 nM), comparable to that of the ACE2-S protein interaction, and a higher affinity for the delta variant than for other variants. Experimental assays confirm complete inhibition of delta variant pseudovirion entry and low cytotoxicity in cell lines, offering a potential new strategy against infection.

Title: Safety and pharmacokinetics of intranasally administered heparin
Keywords: Safety and pharmacokinetics intranasally administered heparin
Resumen: This study investigated the safety and pharmacokinetics of intranasally administered unfractionated heparin (UFH) as a potential prophylactic agent for COVID-19. Daily intranasal doses of UFH were administered to mice for 14 days, and its safety was tested in a small group of healthy human subjects. The results showed no evidence of toxicity in mice at any of the measured doses, nor significant changes in blood coagulation or minor irritant events. Similarly, human subjects did not present significant changes in coagulation parameters or serious adverse events. Pharmacokinetic analysis in mice revealed a single-phase clearance, with potentially protective levels of UFH remaining in the nasal cavity for up to 12 hours after administration. Overall, UFH demonstrated no toxic effects with prolonged daily intranasal use in both mice and humans.

Title: Inhibition of SARS-CoV-2 wild-type (Wuhan-Hu-1) and Delta (B.1.617.2) strains by marine sulfated glycans.
Keywords: inhibition, sars cov 2, wild type, wuhan hu 1, and, delta
Resumen: The COVID-19 pandemic has prompted the search for anti-SARS-CoV-2 molecules, focusing on the virus's S protein, whose binding to heparan sulfate proteoglycans (HSPGs) and angiotensin-converting enzyme-2 is key to infection. However, rapid mutations in the SARS-CoV-2 S protein, such as those observed in the Delta variant, present a challenge for inhibitor design. Marine sulfated glycans (MSGs) have shown promise by competitively disrupting the interaction between the S protein and HSPGs. This study evaluated seven different MSGs against the wild-type (Wuhan-Hu-1) and Delta (B.1.617.2) SARS-CoV-2 strains. Although all MSGs displayed strong inhibitory activity against both strains (generally similar to or slightly lower than heparin), no correlation was found between their structural characteristics and viral inhibition. Nevertheless, the study shows that MSGs maintain their inhibitory activity against evolving SARS-CoV-2 strains, suggesting their potential as effective prophylactic and therapeutic molecules with low cytotoxicity.

Title: Inhibition of Cytomegalovirus by Pentacta pygmaea Fucosylated Chondroitin Sulfate Depends on Its Molecular Weight
Keywords: inhibition cytomegalovirus pentacta pygmaea fucosylated chondroitin
Resumen: recent study investigated fucosylchondroitin sulfate from the starfish Pentacta pygmaea (PpFucCS) as a potential antiviral agent against human cytomegalovirus (HCMV). HCMV binds to host cells via heparan sulfate (HS) proteoglycans prior to entry, and PpFucCS was shown to potently inhibit this viral entry by blocking interactions between HS and the virus. Antiviral activity was found to be proportional to the chain length of PpFucCS, with its high molecular weight being a key structural element for maximal effect. Furthermore, PpFucCS and its derivatives did not show significant cytotoxicity and protected infected cells. These findings suggest that this novel marine sulfated glycan could be developed as a prophylactic and therapeutic antiviral agent against HCMV infection.

Title: Effect of simulated cosmic radiation on cytomegalovirus reactivation and lytic replication
Keywords: simulated, cosmic, radiation, cytomegalovirus, reactivation, and
Resumen: Space exploration exposes astronauts to galactic cosmic radiation (GCR), which has previously been linked to the reactivation of latent herpesviruses. One study investigated how GCR and other types of radiation affect cytomegalovirus (CMV) reactivation in human cells. It was found that radiation exposure, including simulated GCR, significantly increased viral copy numbers, indicating CMV reactivation. Although no substantial genomic changes were detected, transcriptomic analysis revealed significant upregulation of the UL49 gene, suggesting it as a key factor in the shift from the latent to the lytic phase of the virus. These findings support the hypothesis that GCR is an important contributor to the CMV reactivation observed in the International Space Station crew.

Title: Tissue Retrieval and Postharvest Processing Regimen for Rodent Reproductive Tissues Compatible with Long-Term Storage on the International Space Station and Postflight Biospecimen Sharing Program
Keywords: tissue retrieval and postharvest processing regimen
Resumen: The text details the development of a strategy for collecting and processing animal tissues after spaceflight, with the aim of preserving the effects of flight and minimizing post-flight alterations. The research focused on establishing optimal time windows for post-euthanasia tissue collection, specific to each species and tissue (primarily reproductive), as well as long-term storage methods compatible with the International Space Station (10 months at -80°C) that ensure the recovery of high-quality RNA and proteins. The results indicate that histological integrity is maintained between 1 and 3 hours post-euthanasia, depending on the tissue and species, and RNA quality is preserved for up to 40 minutes in RNAlater. This strategy, which also standardizes post-fixation processing for shipping, is adaptable to biospecimen exchange programs and seeks to maximize the information obtained from animals on space missions given limited study opportunities.

Title: Effects of sex and gender on adaptations to space: reproductive health
Keywords: sex, and, gender, adaptations, space, reproductive
Resumen: The text describes how spaceflight affects insulin and estrogen signaling in mice and humans. In mice, pronounced changes were detected in the liver, resulting in signaling inhibition, insulin resistance, and hepatic steatosis. In humans, alterations in genes and pathways related to insulin and estrogen were observed, associated with insulin resistance, stress response, and viral infections. These findings highlight the need to further investigate the metabolic and endocrinological effects of spaceflight for the success of future interplanetary missions.

Title: Effects of spaceflight on the muscles of the murine shoulder.
Keywords: spaceflight, muscles, murine, shoulder
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of mechanical unloading on the shoulder enthesis, the junction between bone and tendon, in adult mice. The shoulders of mice were paralyzed for 21 days with botulinum toxin A, revealing a significant increase in mechanical failure and hierarchical structural changes. At the millimeter scale, unloading caused bone loss; at the micrometer scale, it decreased the size and alignment of bioapatite crystals; and at the nanometer scale, it induced compositional changes that stiffened the tissue composed of bioapatite and collagen. Mathematical modeling and mechanical testing indicated that these combined factors increased local stress levels and decreased the tissue's ability to absorb energy before failure, thereby increasing the risk of injury. These observations provide new insights into how unloading affects the adult enthesis and its characteristics that confer resistance to failure.

Title: Multiscale effects of spaceflight on murine tendon and bone
Keywords: multiscale spaceflight murine tendon and bone
Resumen: This study investigated the effects of spaceflight on the composition, structure, mechanics, and gene expression of the enthesis (the tendon-bone junction) in mice from the STS-131, STS-135, and Bion-M1 space missions. Nanoscale results showed decreased carbonate levels in bone, possibly due to increased remodeling, and a shift in tendon collagen fibril size toward smaller diameters, which could be due to increased collagen degradation. However, these nanoscale changes did not translate into significant alterations in micro- and milliscale structure and mechanics, as no changes were observed in bone volume, trabecular structure, failure load, or stiffness. This suggests that the tendon enthesis could be robust against the negative tissue effects of spaceflight, perhaps due to its anatomical location in the limbs.

Title: Reproducible changes in the gut microbiome suggest a shift in microbial and host metabolism during spaceflight.
Keywords: reproducible, changes, gut, microbiome, suggest, shift
Resumen: This study examined the effects of spaceflight on the gut microbiota of mice, analyzing fecal samples following a 37-day mission on the International Space Station. The results showed an increase in microbial alpha diversity and an alteration in community structure, changes that were reproducible with data from previous space missions but not with ground-based radiation studies, suggesting the influence of other factors. Significant alterations in the abundance of specific microbial taxa and in microbial energy metabolism capacity were identified. Furthermore, a correlation was found between host liver genes related to protein metabolism and gut microbial genes involved in putrescine degradation. These findings are crucial for understanding the role of gut microbiota in mammalian health in space and developing countermeasures for future space missions.

Title: Failure to Generate Bone Marrow Adipocytes Does Not Protect Mice from Ovariectomy-Induced Osteopenia
Keywords: failure, generate, bone, marrow, adipocytes, does
Resumen: A study investigated whether bone marrow fat contributes to ovariectomy-induced osteopenia (ovx) in mice, comparing wild-type (WT) mice with mice deficient in marrow adipocytes (kitW/Wv). It was found that although ovx increased body fat and bone marrow adiposity in WT mice (whereas kitW/Wv mice lacked marrow adipocytes), the surgery-induced changes in bone mass and formation were statistically indistinguishable between the two genotypes. The findings do not support a causal role for increased bone marrow fat as a mediator of ovariectomy-induced osteopenia in mice.

Title: Acute exposure to high dose gamma-radiation results in transient activation of bone lining cells
Keywords: acute exposure high dose gamma radiation results
Resumen: The studies investigated the cellular mechanisms underlying the detrimental effects of high-dose whole-body gamma irradiation on bone, and the efficacy of radioadaptation and bone marrow transplantation as interventions. Irradiation with 6 Gy resulted in increased trabecular thickness and separation, and reduced cancellous bone volume, connectivity density, and number of trabeculae in the tibia and vertebrae. At the cellular level, a decrease in marrow cell density, a transient increase in bone formation (associated with marrow cell death and activation of bone lining cells), and an increase in bone resorption were observed. Radioadaptation (priming dose of 0.5 mGy) had a minimal effect on cellular responses and did not prevent bone changes. However, bone marrow transplantation normalized marrow cell density, bone turnover, and most bone architectural indices after irradiation. In summary, radiation-induced bone marrow cell death is associated with a transient increase in bone formation and increased bone resorption, and bone marrow transplantation is effective in mitigating these detrimental effects.

Title: Morbid obesity attenuates the skeletal abnormalities associated with leptin deficiency in mice
Keywords: morbid, obesity, attenuates, skeletal, abnormalities, associated
Resumen: study evaluated the skeletal effects of leptin deficiency, differentiating them from those associated with morbid obesity, in wild-type mice, ad libitum-fed ob/ob mice, and pair-fed ob/ob mice. Ob/ob mice showed lower bone mass and density, as well as reduced bone turnover resulting in pathological cartilage retention. Pair-fed ob/ob mice, although less obese than ad libitum ob/ob mice, also showed reductions in bone mass and turnover, but with greater bone marrow adiposity and greater cancellous bone and cartilage volume at certain sites. The findings demonstrate that skeletal abnormalities caused by leptin deficiency are significantly attenuated in morbidly obese ob/ob mice.

Title: Hypothalamic leptin gene therapy reduces body weight without accelerating age-related bone loss
Keywords: hypothalamic leptin gene therapy reduces body
Resumen: Given the challenges of conventional weight control methods and their adverse effects such as bone loss, this study investigated the efficacy of hypothalamic leptin gene therapy in adult female rats for weight reduction and its impact on bone health. Over 18 weeks, rats treated with rAAV-leptin lost weight, unlike control rats, which gained weight, resulting in a significant reduction in body weight and abdominal adipose tissue in the leptin group. Although weight loss occurred, no significant differences in bone mass, density, microarchitecture, or bone remodeling biomarkers were detected between groups, indicating that leptin therapy maintained a lower body weight with minimal effects on the skeleton.

Title: Hypothalamic Leptin Gene Therapy Reduces Bone Marrow Adiposity in ob/ob Mice Fed Regular and High-Fat Diets.
Keywords: hypothalamic leptin gene therapy reduces bone
Resumen: The study examined the long-term impact of hypothalamic leptin, delivered via gene therapy (rAAV-Lep), on bone marrow adiposity (BMA) and bone formation in ob/ob (leptin-deficient) mice fed regular or high-fat diets. Given the association between low bone mass and elevated BMA, and the common origin of osteoblasts and adipocytes from mesenchymal stem cells, the study sought to determine whether leptin, a regulatory hormone, could mitigate the increased BMA and reduced bone formation observed in leptin deficiency and diet-induced obesity. The findings revealed that this therapy reduced TMA in ob/ob mice to levels similar to those in wild-type mice and increased osteoblast and osteoclast perimeters, albeit with minor changes in bone architecture. This suggests a crucial role for leptin in regulating mesenchymal stem cell differentiation, a process possibly dysregulated by high-fat diets. However, it was observed that reducing TMA by increasing leptin does not always lead to increased bone mass.

Title: Room temperature housing results in premature cancellous bone loss in growing female mice: implications for the mouse as a preclinical model for age-related bone loss.
Keywords: room, temperature, housing, results, premature, cancellous
Resumen: This study investigated the impact of housing temperature on bone growth, turnover, and microarchitecture in female mice, used as preclinical models for osteoporosis. Mice housed at standard room temperature (22°C) were observed to experience significant cancellous bone loss during growth, in contrast to humans. However, when housed at a thermoneutral temperature (32°C), mice maintained or even increased their cortical and cancellous bone mass. These beneficial effects were associated with lower expression of the Ucp1 gene in brown adipose tissue, greater adiposity in bone marrow, higher rates of bone formation, higher expression of osteogenic genes, and lower bone resorption. The findings suggest that failure to account for species differences in thermoregulation, particularly ambient temperature, may bias osteoporosis studies in mice, and that thermoneutral housing could improve their usefulness as models.

Title: Spaceflight-induced vertebral bone loss in ovariectomized rats is associated with increased bone marrow adiposity and no change in bone formation
Keywords: spaceflight induced, vertebral, bone, loss, ovariectomized, rats
Resumen: The study evaluated the effects of a 14-day spaceflight on bone mass, resorption, formation, and marrow adipose tissue (MAT) in the lumbar vertebrae of ovariectomized (OVX) rats. The results showed that spaceflight rats had a 32% reduction in cancellous bone area and a 306% increase in MAT, due to a greater number and size of adipocytes. Bone loss was associated with a significant increase in bone resorption (16% more resorption and 229% more osteoclast perimeter), but there were no changes in the rate of mineral apposition or osteoblast activity or differentiation. This suggests that cancellous bone loss during spaceflight is accompanied by an increase in bone resorption and TMA, without a compensatory increase in bone formation, indicating defective coupling. The findings do not support the hypothesis that elevated MAT directly reduces osteoblast activity or lifespan, but are consistent with the idea that, in the context of ovarian hormone deficiency, mesenchymal stem cells are skewed toward adipocytes at the expense of osteoblast formation.

Title: Role of estrogen receptor signaling in skeletal response to leptin in female ob/ob mice.
Keywords: role estrogen receptor signaling skeletal response
Resumen: The study examines how leptin deficiency in ob/ob mice results in contrasting bone growth patterns, with shorter femurs but longer spines, and explores the role of estrogen receptors (ERs) in regulating these patterns. It was confirmed that ob/ob mice have shorter femurs and longer spines than wild-type mice, with contrasting expression patterns of chondrocyte proteins in the growth plates. The analysis indicated a positive relationship between body length and ER expression in the growth plate. However, treatment with ERÎ± and ERÎ² antagonists in ob/ob mice revealed that leptin deficiency disrupts the expected regulatory effects of these antagonists on longitudinal bone growth. This suggests that specific ERÎ± expression may be associated with the contrasting axial and appendicular bone growth phenotypes, although ER signaling is attenuated by leptin deficiency in these mice, requiring further investigation of the complex interplay between the two.

Title: Effects of hypothalamic leptin gene therapy on osteopetrosis in leptin-deficient mice.
Keywords: hypothalamic, leptin, gene, therapy, osteopetrosis, leptin deficient
Resumen: This study investigated whether mild osteopetrosis in ob/ob mice, caused by leptin deficiency, is self-limiting and reversible. Histomorphometric analyses of femurs showed that cartilage persisted in ob/ob mice even at six months of age, suggesting that the condition is not completely self-limiting. However, gene therapy that restored leptin signaling in ob/ob mice resulted in the elimination or significant reduction of cartilage in the bone, associated with increased bone turnover. The findings conclude that leptin is essential for normal cartilage replacement with bone and that osteopetrosis in ob/ob mice is bone compartment-specific and reversible with leptin treatment at sites with robust bone turnover.

Title: Leptin stimulates bone formation in ob/ob mice at doses having minimal impact on energy metabolism.
Keywords: leptin stimulates bone formation, mice, doses
Resumen: This study in ob/ob mice investigated the peripheral effects of leptin on bone formation, differentiating them from its central effects on energy metabolism due to limited transport across the blood-brain barrier. Leptin was found to increase bone formation parameters at lower serum doses (EC50 of 7–17 ng/h) compared with indices of energy metabolism (EC50 of 40–80 ng/h). Specifically, a 12 ng/h leptin infusion increased the expression of genes associated with Jak/Stat signaling and bone formation in the tibia, with minimal impact on the hypothalamus. The results suggest that leptin acts peripherally to couple bone acquisition with energy availability, and its restricted transport across the blood-brain barrier ensures that its growth-promoting actions are not mitigated by its central nervous system-mediated anorectic effects.

Title: Bone Marrow Adipose Tissue Deficiency Increases Disuse-Induced Bone Loss in Male Mice
Keywords: bone, marrow, adipose, tissue, deficiency, increases
Resumen: study investigated the hypothesis that bone marrow adipose tissue (MAT) deficiency would protect against disuse-induced bone loss. MAT-deficient mice (KitW/W?¹v) and wild-type mice were subjected to a hindlimb (HU) unloading model. Contrary to the hypothesis, MAT-deficient mice experienced a significantly greater reduction in bone volume fraction and more exaggerated loss of cancellous bone after unloading, despite having better initial bone quality. They also showed elevated cancellous bone formation and resorption and a distinct genetic profile. An additional experiment involving adoptive transfer of wild-type hematopoietic stem cells into KitW/W?¹v mice (maintaining MAT deficiency) confirmed unloading-induced bone loss. The results suggest that MAT deficiency does not protect against disuse bone loss but is instead associated with exaggerated cancellous bone loss.

Title: Metabolic Coupling Between Bone Marrow Adipose Tissue and Hematopoiesis
Keywords: metabolic coupling between bone, marrow, adipose
Resumen: study investigated the role of the C-type mannose receptor 1 (Mrc1) in obesity using Mrc1-deficient (Mrc1?/?) and wild-type (WT) mice fed a high-fat diet (HFD). Mrc1?/? mice showed impaired bone marrow hematopoiesis, with fewer myeloid progenitors and mature cells, but increased adipocytes in the bone marrow. Furthermore, they had reduced levels of circulating neutrophils and proinflammatory monocytes, along with decreased macrophage infiltration in visceral adipose tissue and the liver. This was associated with decreased hepatic steatosis, improved glucose and insulin response, and reduced weight gain. The results suggest that Mrc1 deficiency during a HFD diet impacts bone marrow and circulating immune cells, leading to reduced systemic inflammation and resistance to the development of obesity, indicating a role for Mrc1 in the immunometabolic response associated with diet-induced obesity.

Title: Maintenance of near normal bone mass and architecture in lethally irradiated female mice following adoptive transfer with as few as 750 purified hematopoietic stem cells.
Keywords: maintenance, near, normal, bone, mass, and
Resumen: This study sought to establish an approach to reconstitute bone marrow using small numbers of purified donor hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) following lethal total body irradiation (TBI) without adversely affecting bone metabolism. Mice were irradiated and transplanted with whole bone marrow cells or purified HSCs. Analysis confirmed that both methods were effective in reconstituting the hematopoietic compartment with donor cells. Minimal differences were observed in the skeleton of wild-type mice transplanted with HSCs and fractionated doses of radiation, whereas radiosensitive KitW/Wv mice developed osteopenia at high doses, but not at lower doses, and transplantation of wild-type cells restored normal Kit expression. These findings provide strong evidence of efficient engraftment with purified HSCs after lethal TBI, with minimal collateral bone damage, which will be useful for investigating how hematopoietic lineage cells regulate bone metabolism.

Title: Effect of leptin deficiency on the skeletal response to hindlimb unloading in adult male mice.
Keywords: leptin, deficiency, skeletal, response, hindlimb, unloading
