Resumen: This study investigated the role of leptin in the bone response to weight-bearing, comparing wild-type (WT) mice with leptin-deficient ob/ob mice subjected to hindlimb unloading (HU). Ob/ob mice showed higher body weight, more adipose tissue, and alterations in bone microarchitecture and mass compared with WT mice. Limb unloading resulted in lower bone density and volume in the femur and a reduction in bone volume fraction in the distal femur and lumbar vertebrae in both genotypes, associated with an increase in osteoclast-lined bone perimeter. However, leptin deficiency did not attenuate unloading-induced osteopenia, suggesting that leptin is not required for bone loss caused by non-weight-bearing.

Title: Thermoneutral housing attenuates premature cancellous bone loss in male C57BL/6J mice
Keywords: thermoneutral, housing, attenuates, premature, cancellous, bone
Resumen: This study determined whether housing at thermoneutral temperature (32°C) prevents premature bone loss in male mice, an effect previously observed in females. Male C57BL/6J mice maintained at standard room temperature (22°C) exhibited reductions in cancellous bone volume in the distal femur and fifth lumbar vertebra, effects that were abolished under thermoneutral conditions. Thermoneutral housing was associated with increased levels of bone formation and decreased levels of bone resorption. The magnitude of room temperature-induced bone loss did not differ between males and females. The findings highlight housing temperature as a critical experimental variable in studies of aging-related bone metabolism in mice of both sexes.

Title: Effects of Spaceflight on Cancellous and Cortical Bone in Proximal Femur in Growing Rats
Keywords: spaceflight cancellous and cortical bone proximal
Resumen: The text describes how spaceflight affects bone microarchitecture, specifically in the femoral head of growing rats. Across three spaceflight missions (STS-41, STS-57, STS-62) with ovariectomized male and female rats, spaceflight was consistently observed to result in cancellous osteopenia, that is, a reduction in the volume fraction of cancellous bone. This bone loss was significant in flight rats compared to controls, and was more evident in ovariectomized females, where net bone loss was reported. However, no differences in cortical thickness were found. These findings suggest a generalized response of cancellous bone in the femoral head to microgravity.

Title: Evidence for increased thermogenesis in female C57BL/6J mice housed aboard the international space station
Keywords: evidence for increased thermogenesis female c57bl
Resumen: study using female C57BL/6J mice aboard the International Space Station (ISS) for 37 days revealed that spaceflight induces significant changes in adipose tissue gene expression. Differential gene expression was observed in brown adipose tissue (BAT), consistent with increased non-shivering thermogenesis (including 1.5-fold higher levels of Ucp-1), and in white adipose tissue (WAT), indicating increased glucose uptake and metabolism, adipogenesis, and Î²-oxidation, in addition to possible WAT browning. The researchers conclude that adaptive thermogenesis is enhanced in mice in microgravity, which is relevant because it could exacerbate or alter other physiological responses to spaceflight (such as bone loss or radiation response) and affect the applicability of these studies to astronauts due to differences in thermoregulation between species.

Title: Leptin and environmental temperature as determinants of bone marrow adiposity in female mice
Keywords: Leptin and environmental temperature determinants bone
Resumen: The text describes an investigation into the effects of ambient temperature and leptin on bone marrow adipose tissue (BMAT) in mice, addressing previous conflicting findings. Two experiments were conducted in female mice housed at 32°C (thermoneutral). The first experiment indicated that leptin supplementation reduced BMAT and increased bone formation. The second revealed that increased temperature elevated BMAT in wild-type and leptin-deficient mice, suggesting a leptin-independent response to temperature, but that leptin infusion attenuated this increase. In summary, elevated housing temperature and increased leptin have independent but opposing effects on BMAT in mice.

Title: Small changes in thermoregulation influence cancellous bone turnover balance in distal femur metaphysis in growing female mice
Keywords: small, changes, thermoregulation, influence, cancellous, bone
Resumen: Mice are routinely housed at temperatures below their thermoneutral zone, which causes cold stress and cancellous bone loss, and can alter experimental results. This study evaluated how small temperature differences (22°C vs. 26°C) or group housing with nests at 22°C affect bone health in growing C57BL/6 J mice. Mice housed individually at 22°C experienced significant cancellous bone loss in the distal femoral metaphysis. This loss was attenuated, but not completely prevented, by housing them individually at 26°C or in groups with nests at 22°C. The results conclude that modest differences in housing conditions, by influencing thermogenesis or heat loss, can affect experimental results, especially in the bone study.

Title: Bone Marrow Adipose Tissue Is Not Required for Reconstitution of the Immune System Following Irradiation in Male Mice
Keywords: bone, marrow, adipose, tissue, not, required
Resumen: This study investigated whether bone marrow adipose tissue (BMAT) is required for immune reconstitution and maintaining bone turnover balance after severe injury, such as lethal irradiation, in mice. Wild-type mice were compared with BMAT-deficient mice after adoptive hematopoietic stem cell transfer. The findings revealed excellent immune system reconstitution in both groups, with no significant differences in magnitude. Similarly, minimal differences in bone parameters and microarchitecture were observed between mice with and without BMAT. This suggests that BMAT is not a requirement for immune system reconstitution after lethal radiation, nor a major contributor to skeletal characteristics in Kit signaling-deficient mice in this setting.

Title: Simulated Microgravity Promotes Horizontal Gene Transfer of Antimicrobial Resistance Genes between Bacterial Genera in the Absence of Antibiotic Selective Pressure
Keywords: simulated microgravity promotes horizontal gene transfer
Resumen: This study investigated horizontal gene transfer (HGT), a key mechanism in the spread of antimicrobial resistance (AMR), in a simulated microgravity (SMG) environment. Donor bacteria (*Acinetobacter pittii*) with resistance genes (*blaOXA-500* and *ISAba1*) and antibiotic-susceptible recipient *Staphylococcus aureus* strains, both isolated from the International Space Station, were co-cultured under SMG and normal gravity (1G). The results showed that *S. aureus* strains co-cultured in SMG acquired significantly more antibiotic resistance genes than those grown in 1G, developing phenotypic resistance to oxacillin. This suggests that microgravity may promote increased gene shedding among bacterial communities, posing a potential health risk to astronauts on extended space missions.

Title: Understanding the Complexities and Changes of the Astronaut Microbiome for Successful Long-Duration Space Missions
Keywords: Understanding complexities and changes astronaut microbiome
Resumen: This article examines the impact of spaceflight conditions on astronaut health, focusing on the human microbiome, a microbial community essential for regulating health. Space missions induce significant physiological changes in astronauts, many of them at the microbiome level, which can have a considerable impact on their health and increase risks during long-duration missions. The review addresses factors such as microgravity, radiation, immunity, bone health, and cognitive function, discussing how these elements affect microbiome composition and how the microbiome, in turn, can promote or mitigate these conditions. Understanding these interactions is crucial for developing countermeasures and ensuring the success of future space explorations to the Moon and Mars, seeking to integrate microbiome data into planning to ensure crew health.

Title: Toward sustainable space exploration: a roadmap for harnessing the power of microorganisms.
Keywords: toward, sustainable, space, exploration, roadmap, for
Resumen: The text emphasizes the importance of finding sustainable approaches to space exploration, seeking independence from terrestrial resources, minimizing waste, and preserving extraterrestrial environments. To this end, it proposes a series of microbial biotechnologies designed for in situ resource utilization (ISRU) and loop-closure (resource recycling and reuse), essential for missions beyond low-Earth orbit and for ethical considerations. These biotechnologies can be applied in life support systems, human waste management (transforming it into food or nutrients), food production (harnessing the plant microbiome and probiotics), and pharmaceutical manufacturing in space, reducing dependence on terrestrial supplies. It is emphasized that while these innovations are based on existing Earth-based technologies, they require extensive research and development to adapt to space conditions, and that their advances could also be beneficial for terrestrial applications, supporting the UN Sustainable Development Goals.

Title: Roll maneuvers are essential for active reorientation of Caenorhabditis elegans in 3D media
Keywords: roll, maneuvers, are, essential, for, active
Resumen: This study investigates the three-dimensional locomotion of the nematode *Caenorhabditis elegans*, a model organism whose 3D mobility has been little explored. The authors identify and mathematically describe a unique 3D "rolling" maneuver that, combined with two-dimensional turning, allows the nematode to explore voluminous media while swimming and burrowing. This rolling maneuver involves a body twist that rotates the undulation plane, facilitating complete reorientation in space. The faster rolls during swimming are observed due to a hydrodynamic improvement, not a change in gait. The results provide crucial insights into 3D neuromuscular performance and can improve locomotion phenotype analyses by generalizing the harmonic curvature model to 3D motion descriptions by introducing curve torsion.

Title: Microfluidic Device for Studying Nematodes
Keywords: microfluidic device for studying nematodes
Resumen: The text presents an improved protocol for synchronizing *Caenorhabditis elegans* embryos using mesh filters, overcoming the limitations of traditional bleaching methods, which can be damaging, and microfluidic devices, which are expensive and poorly scalable. This new method exploits size differences between developmental stages, employing sequential filtration with 40 Âµm and 20 Âµm meshes to isolate embryos. The optimized protocol, which includes the use of OP50 bacteria and the addition of polyethylene glycol (PEG), results in a higher embryo yield per plate and produces healthier larvae, without deleterious effects on their subsequent development, making it ideal for high-throughput assays.

Title: NemaFlex: A microfluidics-based technology for standardized measurement of muscular strength of C. elegans.
Keywords: nemaflex microfluidics based technology for standardized measurement
Resumen: novel microfluidic system, dubbed "NemaFlex," has been developed to measure muscle force in the nematode *C. elegans*, overcoming the inconsistencies of previous methods that relied on the animal's behavior and locomotion. NemaFlex quantifies force through micropillar deflection as the worm crawls, providing a measure of maximum exertable force (MEF) that is robust, behavior-independent, and includes a scaling factor to compensate for variations in animal size. Validated with muscle contractile agents and mutants, this system offers a reliable platform for genetic and pharmacological screening, the study of neuromuscular circuits, and the investigation of degenerative processes related to disuse, aging, and disease.

Title: Swim exercise in Caenorhabditis elegans extends neuromuscular and gut healthspan, enhances learning ability, and protects against neurodegeneration
Keywords: swim, exercise, caenorhabditis, elegans, extends, neuromuscular
Resumen: Exercise is a potent anti-aging intervention with broad health benefits, although its systemic mechanisms are not well understood. This study establishes a swimming exercise regimen for the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans that induces neuromuscular, intestinal, and cognitive improvements, as well as protecting against neurodegeneration in models of tauopathy, Alzheimer's, and Huntington's diseases. Exercise performed exclusively in early adulthood was found to produce lasting systemic benefits detectable into middle age, with multiple daily swimming sessions being essential for adaptation. This training improves health parameters such as muscle gene expression, locomotor performance, mitochondrial morphology, and mid-life survival, establishing C. elegans as a powerful genetic model for unraveling the molecular circuitry underlying the systemic benefits of exercise.

Title: Molecular muscle experiment: Hardware and operational lessons for future astrobiology space experiments
Keywords: molecular muscle experiment hardware and operational
Resumen: Space biology seeks to understand how life adapts outside of Earth and how spaceflight affects physiology, causing (mal)adaptations such as muscle decline. The Molecular Muscle Experiment (MME) uses the model organism *Caenorhabditis elegans* to investigate space-induced muscle atrophy. Because previously used hardware was unavailable, researchers had to design and validate new flight equipment, including containment bags and cassettes, in addition to optimizing experimental conditions on the ground to ensure high-quality data collection and resilience to potential launch delays. These experiences and operational solutions are described so that other researchers can replicate and improve experimental designs on future missions.

Title: Tart Cherry Increases Lifespan in Caenorhabditis elegans by Altering Metabolic Signaling Pathways
Keywords: tart, cherry, increases, lifespan,caenorhabditis, elegans
Resumen: Tart cherry extract (TCE) was investigated in C. elegans for its potential anti-aging effects. Supplementation with TCE, at concentrations of 6 ?g or 12 ?g/mL, was found to significantly increase the average lifespan of wild-type worms. These benefits were associated with increased expression of longevity-related genes, such as daf-16 and aak-2, and genes linked to oxidative stress, such as sod-2. Furthermore, TCE improved mitochondrial function by increasing reserve respiration. However, TCE did not alter the lifespan of *daf-16* and *aak-2* mutant worms, suggesting that its effects were primarily mediated through the DAF-16 pathway. In conclusion, the findings indicate that TCE confers health benefits and reduces oxidative stress in *C. elegans* through improved mitochondrial function and the DAF-16 axis.

Title: region of UNC-89 (obscurin) lying between two protein kinase domains is a highly elastic spring required for proper sarcomere organization
Keywords: region, unc 89, obscurin, lying between, two
Resumen: This study investigates the giant muscle protein UNC-89 from *C. elegans*, homologous to mammalian obscurin and SPEG, essential for muscle sarcomeric organization and locomotion. It focuses on the "interkinase" (IK) region, a segment between its two kinase domains, characterized by low complexity and high proline content. In vitro experiments using single-molecule force spectroscopy demonstrated that a 571-residue portion of the UNC-89 IK functions as both an entropic coil and a random coil. Using CRISPR/Cas9, nematodes with an in-frame deletion of this IK region were generated, which displayed severe muscle sarcomere disorganization, defective locomotion, and reduced muscle strength, with super-resolution microscopy revealing abnormal A-banding. Additionally, an N-terminal HA tag introduced during the CRISPR process unexpectedly reduced levels of giant UNC-89 isoforms and caused muscle dysfunction independent of the IK deletion. This work is the first to elucidate the critical functional role of the interkinase region within the UNC-89/obscurin family.

Title: NemaLife chip: a micropillar-based microfluidic culture device optimized for aging studies in crawling C. elegans
Keywords: nemalife, chip, micropillar based, microfluidic, culture, device
Resumen: The NemaLife chip is a novel microfluidic device designed for the lifelong cultivation of the nematode *Caenorhabditis elegans*, enabling the study of its survival and health measures in a more efficient and physiologically relevant manner. This chip addresses the limitations of traditional methods (such as agar plates and liquid chamber microfluidic devices) by eliminating the need for manual transfers, avoiding the use of brood-blocking chemicals, and preventing swimming-induced stress. It features an optimized micropillar arena that mimics the worm's natural crawling motion, sieving channels that separate brood, and ports for feeding and reagent introduction. The device has been validated with aging mutants and RNAi studies, demonstrating its ability to generate reliable data on lifespan and health, and accelerate research into aging.

Title: Spaceflight affects neuronal morphology and alters transcellular degradation of neuronal debris in adult Caenorhabditis elegans
Keywords: Spaceflight affects neuronal morphology and alters
Resumen: study using the nematode *Caenorhabditis elegans* on the International Space Station revealed that spaceflight significantly affects adult neuronal health. Worms that lived 5 days in space exhibited "hyperbranching" in PVD neurons and touch receptor neurons, showing morphological changes such as increased branching of different orders and defects in self-avoidance. Furthermore, under neuronal proteotoxic stress, spaceflight promoted a notable accumulation of neuronal debris in surrounding tissues, suggesting impaired degradation of this debris. These findings underscore the need to carefully assess the risks of long-duration spaceflight to the nervous system and develop countermeasures for safe space exploration.

Title: Microfluidics-integrated spaceflight hardware for measuring muscle strength of Caenorhabditis elegans on the International Space Station.
Keywords: microfluidics integrated spaceflight hardware for measuring muscle
Resumen: This study addresses muscle atrophy in microgravity, a major challenge in human spaceflight, using the nematode *Caenorhabditis elegans* as a genetic model. Previous research has shown that genes associated with muscle junctional complexes decrease in microgravity, but it was unknown whether this affected muscle strength across generations. To investigate this, the NemaFlex microfluidic device (called NemaFlex-S) was redesigned to measure C. elegans muscle strength in space. Technical improvements include a design that allows for animal sorting and housing, a fluid handling protocol that prevents clogging, and a customized worm loading apparatus, all optimized for the constraints of space missions and the International Space Station (ISS), including crew time and safety. Additionally, a robust protocol was developed for the multigenerational cultivation of *C. elegans* in a specific liquid medium and oxygen-permeable bags, overcoming the challenges of traditional cultivation methods. Following validation on Earth, this integrated hardware was sent to the ISS to measure *C. elegans* strength over eight generations, with the goal of assessing short- and long-term muscle adaptation to microgravity.

Title: Compact Imaging Platform for Conducting C. elegans Phenotypic Assays on Earth and in Spaceflight.
Keywords: compact imaging platform for conducting elegans
Resumen: This study presents a 3D-printed Compact Imaging Platform (CIP), integrating a smart device camera, for whole-organism phenotyping of *Caenorhabditis elegans*. Designed to be compact, portable, and low-power (USB-powered), the CIP lacks external optics or mechanical focusing, simplifying setup. It is compatible with various *C. elegans* substrates and enables parallel operation and temperature control within incubators. The system has been validated on Earth with behavioral and movement assays, showing agreement with previous data and the ability to distinguish mutants. Its ease of use, coupled with its lightweight and compact design, makes it ideal for both research and education on Earth and future research on the International Space Station, where crew size, weight, and time are critical factors.

Title: Mitochondrial sulfide promotes life span and health span through distinct mechanisms in developing versus adult treated Caenorhabditis elegans.
Keywords: mitochondrial sulfide promotes life, span, and
Resumen: Research demonstrates that low doses of a mitochondria-targeted sulfur donor (AP39) extend healthy lifespan in *Caenorhabditis elegans* by maintaining mitochondrial integrity. AP39 is observed to improve health even when administered in adulthood, when mitochondrial deterioration is already present, being more potent than untargeted hydrogen sulfide (H2S). Treatment with AP39 preserves mitochondrial structure, improves neuromuscular strength, and reverses aging-associated molecular profiles under the regulation of specific transcription factors. The results suggest that modulating mitochondrial sulfide is a promising and translatable intervention to promote healthy aging in mammals.

Title: Bisphosphonates attenuate age-related muscle decline in Caenorhabditis elegans.
Keywords: bisphosphonates, attenuate, age related, muscle, decline,caenorhabditis
Resumen: A study investigated the efficacy of zoledronate (ZA), a bisphosphonate, as a therapy for sarcopenia, the age-related muscle decline, using *Caenorhabditis elegans* as a model. Low concentrations of ZA (100 nM and 1 ?M) were found to significantly increase the lifespan and health (movement rate) of the worms by improving myofibril structure and the mitochondrial network. Higher concentrations were detrimental or lethal. ZA-mediated health enhancement involved genes such as *fdps-1/FDPS-1*, *daf-16/FOXO*, and *agxt-2/BAIBA*. The results suggest that ZA delays sarcopenia by improving neuromuscular function, implying that bisphosphonates could be a viable anti-sarcopenic therapy.

Title: Spaceflight Induces Strength Decline in Caenorhabditis elegans
Keywords: spaceflight, induces, strength, decline, Caenorhabditis, elegans
Resumen: This study investigated the consequences of spaceflight on neuromuscular strength using the worm *Caenorhabditis elegans* on the International Space Station (ISS). The results showed a significant decrease in strength in the worms in space, with an even greater impairment in mutants predisposed to muscle weakness. Transcriptomic analysis revealed activation of stress-response pathways and decreased mitochondrial and cytoskeletal processes, as well as decreased neuronal function and alterations in calcium and acetylcholine signaling. These reproducible genetic signatures and the neuronal changes associated with the loss of neuromuscular strength in space are crucial for the development of targeted therapies, facilitating future deep space exploration missions.

Title: Metabolic model predictions enable targeted microbiome manipulation through precision prebiotics.
Keywords: metabolic, model, predictions, enable, targeted, microbiome
Resumen: The text addresses the lack of targeted approaches to modulate the microbiota and proposes the concept of "precision prebiotics" that specifically increase the abundance of beneficial microbial species. Using metabolic modeling, the researchers identified and predicted prebiotics for a two-member community in *Caenorhabditis elegans*, composed of the protective species *Pseudomonas lurida MYb11* and *Ochrobactrum vermis MYb71*. Four of the predicted compounds (L-serine, L-threonine, D-mannitol, and Î³-aminobutyric acid) were experimentally confirmed, showing that they specifically increase the abundance of MYb11 *in vitro* and, in the case of L-serine, also *in vivo* in the host. The findings demonstrate the effectiveness of metabolic modeling for designing precision prebiotics, a critical step toward future microbiota-targeted therapies.

Title: Transcriptomics analysis reveals molecular alterations underpinning spaceflight dermatology.
Keywords: transcriptomics, reveals, molecular, alterations, underpinning, spaceflight
Resumen: This study addressed the lack of understanding about common dermatological problems in astronauts due to the risks of spaceflight. Using a systems biology approach, transcriptomic data from mouse skin in space, biochemical profiles of NASA astronauts, and human transcriptomic data from various missions were analyzed. Key findings include biological changes related to skin health, DNA damage and repair, and mitochondrial dysregulation as possible causes. Alterations were also identified in genes linked to skin barrier function and collagen formation, but the ability to readapt to Earth was observed through post-flight gene expression adjustment. These results are critical for guiding future research and developing countermeasures against space-associated skin damage.

Title: Identification and characterization of a skin microbiome on Caenorhabditis elegans suggests environmental microbes confer cuticle protection
Keywords: Identification and characterization, skin, microbiome, Caenorhabditis
Resumen: The study identifies and characterizes a distinct cuticular microbiome in the nematode *C. elegans*, an aspect that has been little explored until now, as most research has focused on gut or pathogenic microbes. Using a consortium of ecologically relevant microbes (mCeMbio), novel microswab tools, and 16S rRNA gene sequencing, the researchers demonstrated the existence of bacteria adherent to the surface of *C. elegans*. They found that the composition of this skin microbiome is significantly different from that of the gut and environment, with strains such as *Enterobacter sp. JUb101* predominating on the cuticle, while others such as *Stenotrophomonas indicatrix JUb19* predominate in the gut. Furthermore, the study reveals that this cuticular microbiome promotes the integrity of the host cuticle and confers protection in adverse environments, positioning *C. elegans* as a new model for research on skin and host-microbe interactions.

Title: Protein kinase 2 of the giant sarcomeric protein UNC-89 regulates mitochondrial morphology and function
Keywords: protein kinase giant sarcomeric unc 89 regulates
Resumen: The study examines the giant sarcomeric protein UNC-89 in C. elegans, which is critical for muscle function and contains a PK2 kinase domain, confirmed to be catalytically active. It was found that PK2 inactivation does not alter muscle organization or function, but results in fragmented mitochondria, elevated ATP levels, and changes in energy metabolism. These findings suggest sarcomere-to-mitochondrial signaling, with PK2 from UNC-89 playing a key role in fine-tuning energy production and demand.

Title: New perspectives on viable microbial communities in low-biomass cleanroom environments
Keywords: new, perspectives, viable, microbial, communities, low biomass
Resumen: This study presents a method for assessing microbial cell viability and phylogenetic affiliation in low-biomass environmental samples, addressing the problem that existing DNA detection techniques fail to distinguish between live and dead cells. The researchers coupled pre-PCR treatment with propidium monoazide (PMA), which binds to the DNA of nonviable cells, with high-throughput pyrosequencing and PhyloChip microarray analysis. They applied this methodology in spacecraft assembly cleanrooms to understand the frequency, diversity, and distribution of viable bacteria. Samples without PMA treatment showed high bacterial abundance and diversity, while those treated with PMA revealed only 1–10% of reads, corresponding to a few robust bacterial lines. Cleanrooms without spatial hardware were observed to have a more diverse viable bacterial population than those with hardware, which were dominated by resistant organisms. This work marks the first comprehensive effort to correlate differential viability with phylogenetic affiliation in these environments.

Title: Microbial existence in controlled habitats and their resistance to space conditions
Keywords: Microbial existence controlled habitats and their
Resumen: This study investigated whether the gut microbiota of wild-type mice modifies tuberculosis (TB) immunopathology in BALB/c mice, comparing conventional mice (LabC) with mice reconstituted with wild-type mouse microbiota (WildR). The results showed that WildR mice controlled the initial TB infection better than LabC mice. Although the gut microbial communities of both groups had similar richness but different composition before infection, TB reduced the richness in both, indicating a general disease-induced dysbiosis. However, the wild-type mouse gut microbiota did not alter the typical TB lung histopathology. Both groups mounted robust T cell responses, and the immunopathology and kinetics of the TB pathogen largely overlapped, with WildR mice showing better control of early acute infection.

Title: Microbiomes of the dust particles collected from the International Space Station and Spacecraft assembly facilities
Keywords: microbiomes, dust, particles, collected, from, international
Resumen: The study characterized the viable microbiome of the International Space Station (ISS) and compared it to terrestrial cleanrooms to assess whether the latter are a suitable environmental model. Using various molecular and culturing techniques, the phyla Actinobacteria, Firmicutes, and Proteobacteria were found to be dominant, but their abundance varied, with Actinobacteria predominating on the ISS and Proteobacteria in terrestrial cleanrooms. Microorganisms associated with human skin, such as Corynebacterium and Propionibacterium, were observed to contribute significantly to the ISS microbiome, which is not the case in terrestrial cleanrooms. This demonstrates that terrestrial cleanrooms are not an appropriate model for the ISS's microbial environment, and the results will facilitate future studies on the stability of the ISS environment, helping to improve astronaut health and maintenance practices.

Title: Draft genome sequences of two Aspergillus fumigatus strains, isolated from the International Space Station
Keywords: draft, genome, sequences, two, aspergillus, fumigatus
Resumen: The study determined the preliminary genome sequences of two strains of *Aspergillus fumigatus* (ISSFT-021 and IF1SW-F4) isolated from the International Space Station (ISS). These strains, considered opportunistic pathogens, proved to be significantly more lethal and resistant to UV radiation than their Earth-based clinical counterparts. The research, which included whole-genome sequencing, seeks to understand the molecular mechanisms behind their enhanced virulence. The findings could be crucial for developing countermeasures to protect the health of astronauts, whose immune systems are compromised in microgravity, if a causal relationship is confirmed. The genomic sequences obtained have been deposited in public databases.

Title: Characterization of Aspergillus fumigatus isolates from air and surfaces of the International Space Station.
Keywords: Characterization Aspergillus fumigatus isolates from air
Resumen: Proteomic characterization of two Aspergillus fumigatus strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) revealed significant differences compared to clinical strains. The ISS strains showed a higher abundance of proteins involved in stress response, carbohydrate metabolism, and secondary metabolism, including virulence components such as trypacidin and Asp-hemolysin. This suggests a molecular adaptation of these filamentous fungi to the unique environment of low nutrition, increased irradiation, and microgravity of the ISS.

Title: Draft genome sequences of biosafety level 2 opportunistic pathogens isolated from the environmental surfaces of the International Space Station.
Keywords: draft, genome, sequences, biosafety, level, opportunistic
Resumen: Generated abstract: This article focuses on draft genome sequences of biosafety level 2 opportunistic pathogens isolated from the environmental surfaces of the international space station.. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5201052/)

Title: Draft Genome Sequences of Several Fungal Strains Selected for Exposure to Microgravity at the International Space Station.
Keywords: draft, genome, sequences, several, fungal, strains
Resumen: Abstract generated: This article focuses on draft genome sequences of several fungal strains selected for exposure to microgravity at the international space station. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5391430/)

Title: Human presence impacts fungal diversity of inflated lunar/Mars analog habitat.
Keywords: human, presence, impacts, fungal, diversity, inflated
Resumen: The study characterized the succession of the viable fungal mycobiome in an inflatable lunar/martian analogue habitat (ILMAH), a closed environment simulating conditions for future space missions or the International Space Station. During 30 days of human occupancy, surface samples were collected and analyzed with molecular and culture techniques, using propidium monoazide (PMA) to differentiate viable populations. The results showed significant changes in the structure of the viable fungal community, with an increase in diversity and a decrease in the overall fungal load, and an increase in certain families and genera during occupancy. The study underscores the importance of proper maintenance of closed habitats to prevent their deterioration and ensure the health of their inhabitants.

Title: Whole metagenome profiles of particles collected from the International Space Station
Keywords: whole, metagenome, profiles, particulates, collected, from
Resumen: This text describes a correction to an open-access article, published on an official US government website, where the X-axis label was reported to be missing in Figure 4. This figure illustrates microbial gene pathways observed in metagenomes, with details on KEGG orthologies and read abundance. The article is distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.

Title: Microbial Characteristics of ISS Environmental Surfaces
Keywords: microbial characteristics iss environmental surfaces
Resumen: This study performed an extensive phenotypic characterization of microbes present in the International Space Station (ISS) drinking water system, using isolates archived by NASA from 2009 to 2015. The goal was to understand community interactions and properties beyond sequencing, given the health risks to astronauts and life support systems. Researchers profiled phenotypes such as antibiotic resistance, metabolism, hemolysis, and biofilm formation. They found that many isolates were multidrug-resistant to antibiotics and formed robust biofilms. The data also revealed a temporal dependence in interactive behaviors, suggesting microbial adaptation, and identified subpopulations of Burkholderia species with hemolytic activity. The findings underscore the need to understand these dynamic interactions for microbial risk assessments in closed environments, both in space and on Earth.

Title: Draft Genome Sequences from a Novel Clade of Bacillus cereus Sensu Lato Strains, Isolated from the International Space Station.
Keywords: draft, genome, sequences, from, novel, clade
Resumen: The draft genome sequences of six Bacillus strains isolated from the International Space Station, belonging to the *Bacillus cereus sensu lato* group, are presented. These strains were sequenced and assembled using Illumina MiSeq and PacBio RSII data. Despite their high genomic similarity with the *B. anthracis* type strain, analyses revealed that they lack the pathogenicity elements characteristic of *B. anthracis*, including a specific allele and the absence of plasmids pXO1 and pXO2. The results suggest that these six strains represent a new Bacillus species within the *B. cereus sensu lato* group.

Title: Draft Genome Sequences of Acinetobacter and Bacillus Strains Isolated from Spacecraft-Associated Surfaces
Keywords: draft genome sequences acinetobacter and bacillus
Resumen: This article presents the preliminary genome sequences of four bacterial strains (two Bacillus and two Acinetobacter) isolated from spacecraft-associated surfaces, which exhibit increased resistance to stressors such as UV radiation and hydrogen peroxide. The sequenced and annotated genomes revealed the presence of key genes related to dormancy, sporulation, DNA repair, stress resistance (oxidative and thermal), and persister cell formation, which contribute to their survival in extreme environments.

Title: KatharoSeq enables high-throughput microbiome analysis from low-biomass samples
Keywords: katharoseq, enables, high throughput, microbiome, from, low biomass
Resumen: The text describes the challenge of analyzing microbiomes in low-biomass samples, which often produce erroneous results due to contamination and technical limitations. To address this, we introduce KatharoSeq, a novel high-throughput protocol that integrates laboratory and bioinformatics methods. This protocol, which incorporates positive and negative controls, is capable of differentiating a true signal in samples with as few as 50 to 500 microbial cells, outperforming single-tube extraction methods and being at least five times faster. Its utility was demonstrated in diverse settings, including a Spacecraft Assembly Facility (SAF), a Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU), and an abalone breeding facility, where it enabled the acquisition of unique and reproducible microbiomes. KatharoSeq facilitates large-scale metagenomic analyses in low-biomass environments, crucial for applications that require characterizing the composition of microbial communities.

Title: Draft genome sequence of a clinical isolate of Fusarium fujikuroi isolated from a male patient with acute myeloid leukemia.
Keywords: draft, genome, sequence, clinical, isolate, fusarium
Resumen: This article presents the draft whole genome sequence of *Fusarium fujikuroi* strain COH1152, an emerging opportunistic pathogen isolated from a 68-year-old patient with refractory acute myeloid leukemia who developed an invasive infection during chemotherapy. The sequencing and assembly methods of the 48 Mb genome are detailed. Additionally, the sequencing of strain COH1141, identified as *Aspergillus niger* and possibly a laboratory contaminant, with a 32 Mb genome is reported. Both genome sequences are publicly available.

Title: Draft Genome Sequence of Solibacillus kalamii, Isolated from an Air Filter Aboard the International Space Station
Keywords: draft genome sequence solibacillus kalamii isolated
Resumen: This article presents the draft genome of *Solibacillus kalamii ISSFR-015*, a new bacterial species isolated from a high-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filter onboard the International Space Station. Analysis of its 3.8 million base pair genome, with a G+C content of 38.61%, reveals the presence of genes associated with stress resistance, including superoxide dismutase and resistance to vancomycin, copper, hydrogen peroxide, and arsenic, suggesting its ability to survive in harsh environments such as that of the ISS.

Title: Detection of antimicrobial resistance genes associated with the International Space Station environmental surfaces
Keywords: detection, antimicrobial, resistance, genes, associated, with
Resumen: This study, which spanned five years across the MT-1 and MT-2 projects, conducted a comprehensive analysis of the surface microbiome of the International Space Station (ISS). Eight surfaces were sampled to investigate species prevalence, temporal and spatial changes, and antimicrobial resistance. The microbiome was found to be dominated by human skin-associated organisms, with Staphylococcus sp. and Malassezia sp. being the most represented bacterial and fungal species. Although there were significant temporal changes in the microbial population, no spatial differences were detected. Antimicrobial resistance gene profiles remained stable throughout the five-year period. The results of this research are critical for informing policies that ensure astronaut health and the integrity of spacecraft on future space missions.

Title: Draft genome sequences of two Fusarium oxysporum isolates cultured from infected Zinnia hybrida plants grown on the International Space Station.
Keywords: draft, genome, sequences, two, fusarium, oxysporum
Resumen: The whole-genome sequences of two Fusarium oxysporum isolates obtained from infected Zinnia hybrida plants grown onboard the International Space Station are presented. These genomes were sequenced and assembled for analysis. Genomic comparison revealed that the ISS isolates are closely related to a F. oxysporum strain recovered after the Chernobyl disaster, as well as to a clinical strain isolated from a patient with fusarium wilt. It is suggested that comparison of these strains could provide insight into the genes that enable growth in extreme environments and their potential relationship to human pathogenicity.

Title: Characterization of Aspergillus niger Isolated from the International Space Station
Keywords: Characterization Aspergillus niger isolated from international
Resumen: This article investigates secondary metabolite (SM) production in *Aspergillus niger* JSC-093350089, a strain isolated from the International Space Station (ISS), comparing it with a standard laboratory strain. The ISS strain showed significantly enhanced production of several therapeutically relevant SMs, most notably a 6000% increase in the antioxidant pyranonigrin A, as well as higher levels of naphtho-Î³-pyrones, bicoumanigrin A, and aurasperones A and B. Genetic analysis identified variants, including INDELs in the *flbA* promoter region, that may be responsible for this increased SM production, and confirmed the involvement of a novel gene, *pyrE*, in pyranonigrin A biosynthesis. Furthermore, pyranonigrin A was characterized as a UV-resistant agent in the ISS isolate, which underscores how fungi adapt to extreme environments by altering their SM profiles.

Title: Multi-drug resistant Enterobacter bugandensis species isolated from the International Space Station and comparative genomic analyzes with human pathogenic strains
Keywords: multi drug resistant enterobacter bugandensis species isolated
Resumen: study characterized five *Enterobacter bugandensis* strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) and compared them with three clinical strains to analyze their antimicrobial resistance (AMR) phenotypic properties, multidrug resistance (MDR) gene profiles, and genes related to their virulence and pathogenicity. Through whole genome sequencing and phylogenetic analysis, the ISS strains were confirmed to be *E. bugandensis* and highly similar to clinical strains, identifying 112 genes associated with virulence, disease, and defense, as well as genes related to resistance to antibiotics and toxic compounds. Given the multidrug resistance and a pathogenicity probability greater than 79%, these findings raise important health considerations for future space missions, highlighting the need for in vivo studies to understand the influence of microgravity on pathogenicity.

Title: Succession and persistence of microbial communities and antimicrobial resistance genes associated with International Space Station environmental surfaces
Keywords: succession and persistence microbial communities antimicrobial
Resumen: The text explains how to identify secure U.S. government websites and describes the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 license under which the article is distributed. Primarily, it announces a correction to an article in *Microbiome* (2018) for a typographical error in the number of reads. The correct figures are approximately 7.3 × 10^8 reads generated, normalized to 3.1 × 10^8 total and 7.4 × 10^6 per sample, without affecting taxonomic diversity. The articles are offered by BMC, courtesy of the National Library of Medicine.

Title: International Space Station conditions alter genomics, proteomics, and metabolomics in Aspergillus nidulans.
Keywords: international, space, station, conditions, alter, genomics
Resumen: This study investigates how the filamentous fungus *Aspergillus nidulans* adapts to the conditions of the International Space Station (ISS), exposing wild-type and mutant strains to microgravity and radiation. The results revealed genomic alterations in specific regions, such as the loss of a stop codon in strain CW12001, and changes in the expression of proteins related to stress response, carbohydrate metabolism, and secondary metabolite biosynthesis. A decrease in the production of prenylated xanthones was observed in the wild-type strain and an increase in asperthecin production in DNA repair-deficient strains. These findings provide crucial information about the adaptation of *A. nidulans* to space environments, which is vital for crew health and potential drug production on future interplanetary missions.

Title: Proteomic characterization of Aspergillus fumigatus isolated from air and surfaces of the International Space Station.
Keywords: Proteomic characterization, Aspergillus fumigatus isolated from
Resumen: This study investigated the molecular adaptation of two *Aspergillus fumigatus* strains (ISSFT-021 and IF1SW-F4) isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) to its unique environment, characterized by low nutrients, radiation, and microgravity. Using proteomic characterization, these strains were compared to clinical control isolates. The analysis revealed significant variations in the proteome of the ISS strains, with increased abundances of proteins involved in stress responses, carbohydrate metabolism, and secondary metabolism, including proteins related to oxidative stress, fermentation, the glyoxylate cycle, the trypacidin biosynthetic pathway, and a toxin. This report provides insights into the potential molecular adaptation of filamentous fungi to the unique environment of the ISS.

Title: Genomic Characterization and Virulence Potential of Two Fusarium oxysporum Isolates Cultured from the International Space Station
Keywords: genomic characterization and virulence potential two
Resumen: This study details the isolation and genomic characterization of two *Fusarium oxysporum* strains (ISS-F3 and ISS-F4) cultured from the mess hall table of the International Space Station (ISS), marking the first time that *F. oxysporum* has been characterized from a constructed, space-exposed environment. Genomic analyses indicated that these strains are genomically distinct from 65 other known strains, are clonally derived from each other, and exhibit increased abundance of polyketide synthase domains, suggesting the production of previously unreported secondary metabolites. Although they are unlikely to be plant pathogens, a virulence test in an immunocompromised *Caenorhabditis elegans* model revealed that they were virulent and could be opportunistic pathogens in animals, including humans, warranting further studies of their health effects on immunocompromised individuals. These findings have important implications for the medical, agricultural, and food industries, as well as for the health of the ISS crew.

Title: Characterization of the total and viable bacterial and fungal communities associated with the International Space Station surfaces.
Keywords: Characterization total and viable bacterial fungal
Resumen: This study characterized microbial diversity on surfaces within the International Space Station (ISS) using molecular and culture methods over 14 months at eight locations. A diverse population of bacteria and fungi was found, with microbial loads varying temporally but remaining constant across locations. The bacterial community composition changed over time, while the fungal community composition remained similar. Molecular methods detected greater bacterial diversity than culture methods, although similar for fungi. A significant portion of the DNA analyzed was confirmed to be from intact, viable organisms, many of which were culturable. The dominant microorganisms are associated with the human microbiome and may include opportunistic pathogens. This is the first comprehensive catalog of total and viable bacteria and fungi on surfaces of closed space systems, essential for developing safety measures for human habitation in deep space and with implications for confined environments on Earth.

Title: Proteomic and Metabolomic Characteristics of Extremophilic Fungi Under Simulated Mars Conditions.
Keywords: Proteomic and metabolomic characteristics, Extremophilic fungi
Resumen: This study investigated the survival of filamentous fungal conidia isolated from Chernobyl and the International Space Station exposed to simulated Martian conditions (SMC) and UV-C radiation. Survival was strain-dependent, with ISSFT-021-30 and IMV 00236-30 surviving 30 minutes of SMC. Proteomic analysis of these strains revealed differential expression of proteins involved in ribosomal biogenesis, translation, and carbohydrate metabolism, with no significant alterations in the metabolome. Furthermore, conidia from ISSFT-021-30 showed increased UV-C resistance following SMC exposure. This is the first report to evaluate the survival of filamentous fungal conidia monolayers under SMC, highlighting their remarkable adaptability to extreme environments.

Title: MetaMiner: A Scalable Peptidogenomics Approach for Discovery of Ribosomal Peptide Natural Products with Blind Modifications from Microbial Communities
Keywords: metaminer, scalable, peptidogenomics, approach for discovery
Resumen: This text presents MetaMiner, a novel software tool designed to overcome limitations in the discovery of post-translationally modified peptides (RiPPs), an important class of natural products that includes antibiotics. MetaMiner combines computational mass spectrometry and genome/metagenome mining to identify RiPPs, even those with unknown post-translational modifications, from large datasets of diverse microbial communities. The tool is compatible with large-scale screening platforms and is significantly faster than previous methods. By analyzing millions of spectra on the GNPS infrastructure against eight genomic and metagenomic datasets, MetaMiner was able to discover 31 known and 7 unknown RiPPs, from environments such as the human microbiome and the International Space Station.

Title: Draft Genome Sequences of Sphingomonas Species Associated with the International Space Station
Keywords: draft, genome, sequences, sphingomonas, species, associated
Resumen: This text describes the assembly of preliminary genome sequences of three *Sphingomonas* strains (two *S. sanguinis* and one *S. paucimobilis*) isolated from the International Space Station (ISS). These genome sequences are intended to aid in understanding the influence of microgravity conditions on their potential production of bioactive compounds and other important characteristics, compared to their terrestrial counterparts. Methods for sample collection, DNA extraction, library preparation, and whole-genome sequencing, as well as their assembly and annotation, are detailed. The whole-genome sequence data have been deposited in BioProject and GeneLab for public access.

Title: Draft Genome Sequences of Tremellomycetes Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
Keywords: draft, genome, sequences, tremellomycetes, strains, isolated
Resumen: Draft genome sequences were assembled from six eukaryotic microbial strains of the Tremellomycetes class isolated from the International Space Station. The objective is to characterize these sequences to understand the influence of microgravity conditions on their pathogenic potential, especially in non-neoformans Cryptococcus species. The samples were processed, and DNA was extracted and sequenced using Illumina technology, then assembled. The genomic data and raw information have been deposited in GenBank and NASA GeneLab, and the research was funded by NASA.

Title: Draft Genome Sequences of Rhodotorula mucilaginosa Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
Keywords: draft, genome, sequences, rhodotorula, mucilaginosa, strains
Resumen: This article describes the whole-genome sequencing of 28 strains of *Rhodotorula mucilaginosa*, a pigmented yeast isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) and classified as an emerging human pathogen. This yeast, the most common on ISS surfaces, is relevant due to its ability to form biofilms, which, under the harsh space conditions that enhance antimicrobial resistance, makes it a potential threat to life support systems. Characterizing their complete genome sequences is crucial for developing countermeasures. The article details the methods for sample collection, DNA extraction, and sequencing, the data for which have been deposited in GenBank.

Title: Draft Genome Sequences of Enterobacteriales Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
Keywords: draft, genome, sequences, enterobacteriales, strains, isolated
Resumen: Whole-genome sequences were obtained from 26 bacterial strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS), identifying them as members of the Enterobacteriales order, including Pantoea brenneri, Pantoea agglomerans, Kalamiella piersonii, and Enterobacter bugandensis. These bacteria are of concern due to their potential pathogenicity, their ability to adapt to extreme conditions such as microgravity and radiation, and the risk they pose to the health of immunocompromised astronauts. The characterization of their genomes seeks to identify genetic processes responsible for their potential pathogenicity and adaptation for the development of countermeasures.

Title: Draft Genome Sequences of Lactobacillales Isolated from the International Space Station
Keywords: draft, genome, sequences, lactobacillales, isolated, from
Resumen: This study generated whole genome sequences (WGS) of nineteen strains of the order Lactobacillales, including *Enterococcus faecalis*, *Enterococcus faecium*, and *Aerococcus urinaeequi*, isolated from the International Space Station and a commercial resupply vehicle. The objective is to characterize these potentially pathogenic bacteria that are adapted to the extreme conditions of space, posing a health risk to astronauts. Understanding their genomic composition is crucial for developing appropriate countermeasures and mitigation strategies.

Title: Draft Genome Sequences of Klebsiella Species Isolated from the International Space Station
Keywords: draft, genome, sequences, klebsiella, species, isolated
Resumen: study sequenced the genomes of ten bacterial strains of the genus Klebsiella (including K. aerogenes, K. pneumoniae, and K. quasipneumoniae) isolated from four locations on the International Space Station (ISS). These bacteria, known for their pathogenicity and antibiotic resistance on Earth, could become more virulent under space conditions (microgravity, radiation), posing a risk to astronauts. The primary objective was to genetically characterize these strains to understand their adaptation to space through comparative genomic studies with their terrestrial counterparts. The genomes obtained have already been deposited in GenBank and NASA GeneLab.

Title: Draft Genome Sequences of Bacillaceae Strains Isolated from the International Space Station.
Keywords: draft, genome, sequences, bacillaceae, strains, isolated
Resumen: Preliminary genome sequences were obtained and analyzed from 29 bacterial isolates from the Bacillaceae family, collected from various surfaces on the International Space Station. These isolates, which include species such as Bacillus amyloliquefaciens, Bacillus cereus, and Paenibacillus polymyxa, are of interest due to their ability to form endospores and survive in extreme environments, which is crucial for NASA's planetary protection and contamination prevention efforts. The study seeks to understand their role in space and biotechnology applications. The genome sequences and raw data are available on GenBank and NASA GeneLab.

Title: Assessing the risk of transfer of microorganisms at the International Space Station due to cargo delivery by commercial resupply vehicles
Keywords: assessing risk transfer microorganisms international space
Resumen: This study analyzed the microbiome of the internal surfaces and ground support equipment of Commercial Resupply Vehicles (CRVs) prior to launch to assess the risk of microbial contamination on future interplanetary missions, using the International Space Station (ISS) as a model. The findings revealed that the internal surfaces of CRVs were significantly cleaner, with fewer microbes than ground support equipment, and contained microorganisms capable of tolerating ultraviolet radiation. Compared to the ISS microbiome, the CRV microbiome showed significant differences and was a negligible part of the station's microbial environment. These findings indicate that maintenance and cleaning protocols for CRV surfaces are highly effective in controlling the contaminating microbial population during cargo transfer to the ISS.

Title: Methylobacterium ajmalii sp. Nov., isolated from the International Space Station
Keywords: Methylobacterium ajmalii nov isolated from international
Resumen: Four strains of bacteria from the Methylobacteriaceae family were isolated on the International Space Station (ISS). Through genomic, phylogenetic, biochemical, and fatty acid analyses, three of these strains (IF7SW-B2T, IIF1SW-B5, and IIF4SW-B5) were identified as new species within the genus Methylobacterium, for which the name Methylobacterium ajmalii sp. nov. is proposed. The fourth strain was identified as Methylorubrum rhodesianum.

Title: Draft Genome Sequences of Aspergillus and Penicillium Species Isolated from the International Space Station and Crew Resupply Vehicle Capsule
Keywords: draft, genome, sequences, aspergillus, and, penicillium
Resumen: Whole genome sequences (WGS) were assembled from 30 fungal strains of the genera Penicillium and Aspergillus isolated from the International Space Station (ISS). These sequences will allow for detailed genomic characterization to determine their potential applications and importance in the space and biotechnology industries, and to study how microgravity and irradiation affect these organisms. The text details the methodology for sample collection, DNA extraction, and sequencing, and confirms that the data have been deposited in GenBank and the NASA GeneLab system.

Title: Advances in Space Microbiology
Keywords: advances, space, microbiology
Resumen: This text highlights the importance of Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) genetic diversity for infectious disease resistance and the evolutionary fitness of wild populations. It explores how factors such as parasite-mediated selection, genetic drift, and sexual selection shape these patterns, noting that MHC diversity is typically lower at geographic margins or at high latitudes and altitudes. It emphasizes that lower immunogenetic diversity poses a threat to wildlife resilience in the face of climate change and novel parasites. It proposes integrating immunogenetic data with environmental and parasitic information for effective conservation and to better understand host-parasite coevolution.

Title: Effects of simulated microgravity on the proteome and secretome of the polyextremotolerant black fungus Knufia chersonesos.
Keywords: simulated microgravity proteome and secretome polyextremotolerant
Resumen: Black fungi, known for their remarkable polyextremotolerance and ability to survive in harsh environments, including space, were the focus of a study investigating their molecular mechanisms. The *Knufia chersonesos* strain (melanized wild-type and a melanin-deficient mutant) was exposed to simulated microgravity. Qualitative and quantitative proteomic analyses revealed differential expression of proteins related to carbohydrate and lipid metabolism, transport, and ribosomal biogenesis, although no significant activation of stress or starvation response components was detected, except for a melanin-synthesis enzyme that was upregulated in the wild-type strain. Differences in protein modulation were observed between the two strains, but without significant morphological alterations or negative impact on survival. This work is the first to characterize the response of black fungi to simulated microgravity, which has important implications for future astrobiological missions.

Title: Draft Genome Sequences of Various Bacterial Phyla Isolated from the International Space Station
Keywords: draft, genome, sequences, various, bacterial, phyla
Resumen: This text describes a study that generated whole-genome sequences of 96 bacterial strains from 14 species, isolated from surfaces on the International Space Station (ISS) during the Microbial Tracking 2 study. The objective is to characterize the microbiome of this enclosed habitat to track the spread and evolution of secondary pathogens, which is vital for astronaut health, given that microgravity affects immune function. Many of the identified species are common in the human microbiome and can act as opportunistic pathogens, including members of Actinobacteria, coagulase-negative staphylococci, and Proteobacteria, as well as other species relevant in extreme environments. The genomic data have been deposited in GenBank and the NASA GeneLab system.

Title: Evaluating the lettuce metatranscriptome with MinION sequencing for future spaceflight food production applications
Keywords: evaluating lettuce metatranscriptome with minion sequencing
Resumen: The text describes the development of a metatranscriptomics methodology to monitor the functional activity of the plant microbiome, crucial for crop health on long-duration space missions. The transcriptional activities of the microbiome of red romaine lettuce grown under conditions similar to those on the International Space Station were investigated using the Oxford Nanopore MinION handheld sequencing platform to enrich and analyze microbial transcripts. The results demonstrate that this approach is highly reproducible and efficient for the in situ detection of microbial transcriptional activity, enabling the characterization of microbial communities and facilitating the maintenance of plant health for food production on orbit. This technology promises early detection of opportunistic pathogens, informing mitigation strategies and improving safety on future space missions.

Title: Investigation of Spaceflight Induced Changes to Astronaut Microbiomes
Keywords: investigation, spaceflight, induced, changes, astronaut, microbiomes
Resumen: study used a 3D-clinostat to simulate microgravity in mice, revealing its role in liver and brain abnormalities. Simulated microgravity was found to cause abnormal gut morphology, imbalances in gut microbiota and serum metabolite profiles, as well as impaired metabolism and liver and brain function. Fecal microbiota transplantation replicated these dysfunctions, suggesting that microgravity induces an imbalance in gut microbiota, which in turn triggers alterations in the liver and brain. Valeric acid was identified as a key metabolite in this process. This microgravity model, which also caused bone loss and organ changes, is valuable for understanding the adaptability of organisms in the space environment.

Title: Genomic Characterization of Potential Plant Growth-Promoting Features of Sphingomonas Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
Keywords: genomic, characterization, potential, plant, growth promotion, features
Resumen: Research was conducted on Sphingomonas strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) and the Kennedy Space Center. Genomic and metagenomic analyses identified these strains, including S. sanguinis and S. paucimobilis, as having the potential to promote plant growth. Genes associated with the production of phytohormones such as indole-3-acetic acid, phosphate metabolism and solubilization, and resistance to various abiotic stresses, such as heavy metals, heat shock, and oxidative or osmotic stress, were identified. These discoveries underscore the biotechnological importance of these microorganisms for the development of long-term, self-sustaining space missions, facilitating the cultivation of plants in space.

Title: Genomic Characterization of the Titan-like Cell Producing Naganishia tulchinskyi, the First Novel Eukaryote Isolated from the International Space Station
Keywords: genomic, characterization, titan like, cell, producing, naganishia
Resumen: Multiple strains of a novel yeast in the genus *Naganishia* were isolated from environmental surfaces on the International Space Station (ISS). These strains, proposed as *Naganishia tulchinskyi*, displayed cell morphology similar to Titan cells (~10 Âµm in diameter) when grown under a combination of simulated microgravity and 5% CO2. Microscopic analyses revealed significant morphological differences between microgravity- and Earth-gravity-grown cells, including larger size, thicker cell walls, and intracellular alterations. Phylogenetic analyses confirmed that these ISS strains represent a single species, grouping with *Naganishia diffluens*. Genomic analyses suggested that these yeasts possess phenotypes well-adapted to respond to microgravity and radiation, with genes associated with Titan-like cellular plasticity and cold resistance.

Title: Metabolic modeling of the International Space Station microbiome reveals key microbial interactions.
Keywords: metabolic, modeling, international, space, station, microbiome
Resumen: This study analyzed microbial interactions onboard the International Space Station (ISS), focusing on *Klebsiella pneumoniae*, using a computational approach and experimental validation. *K. pneumoniae* was found to exhibit beneficial interactions with many coexisting microorganisms, including the genus *Pantoea* and the family *Enterobacteriaceae*, but also parasitic or amensalistic interactions with fungi such as *Aspergillus* and *Penicillium*. Experimental coculture confirmed the parasitic effect of *K. pneumoniae* on *Aspergillus fumigatus*, compromising its morphology and biofilm structures. The study underlines the importance of *K. pneumoniae* on the ISS and its complex interactions, both positive and negative, with other microbes.

Title: Microbial Burden Estimation of Food Items, Built Environments, and the International Space Station Using Film Media
Keywords: Microbial burden estimation food items built
Resumen: This study evaluated film-based media plates, such as Easy Plates and Petrifilm, as alternatives to traditional agar media for enumerating culturable microbes, highlighting their advantages in reducing waste, space, and preparation. Their performance was compared across three sample types: food, surfaces in built environments on Earth (homes), and surfaces on the International Space Station (ISS). For bacteria in food and terrestrial environments, film-based media showed high comparability with agar. For fungi in terrestrial environments and both bacteria and fungi in ISS samples (low-biomass environments), the correlation was lower, influenced by factors such as detection limits. The composition of isolated species was similar between both media types. Overall, film-based media proved to be viable and effective alternatives for microbial enumeration in food samples and low-biomass environments, with particular potential for microgravity applications.

Title: Multidrug-resistant Acinetobacter pittii is adapting to and exhibiting potential succession aboard the International Space Station.
Keywords: Multidrug resistant Acinetobacter pittii adapting and exhibiting
Resumen: study of microbial adaptation on the International Space Station (ISS) revealed that *Acinetobacter pittii*, an opportunistic pathogen isolated from ISS missions, has evolved a genetically and functionally distinct clade from terrestrial strains. ISS strains displayed increased resistance to antibiotics, particularly broad-spectrum cephalosporins, with no genomic prediction of this increase. An increase in the relative abundance of viable *A. pittii* was observed on the ISS, suggesting succession, and these strains acquired functions that allow them to survive in harsh environments, such as the transcriptional regulator LexA and a high mutational load in specific genes. These findings are critical to understanding microbial evolution and the development of antibiotic resistance in extreme, resource-limited environments, which is crucial for crew safety on extended space missions.

Title: Characterization of metagenome-assembled genomes from the International Space Station.
Keywords: characterization, metagenome assembled, genomes, from, international, space
Resumen: This study generated 46 metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) from 21 environmental samples from the International Space Station (ISS) to analyze microbial diversity and functional properties. Eighteen bacterial species were identified, including a novel genus/species combination (Kalamiella piersonii) and a novel bacterial species (Methylobacterium ajmalii), and, for the first time, fungal genomes were assembled from ISS metagenomes. Phylogenetic analyses revealed ISS-specific evolution in some bacteria, enrichment of cell membrane-related genes, and antimicrobial resistance (AMR) and virulence genes were characterized. Pantoea/Kalamiella strains showed the greatest variation, suggesting a high susceptibility to changes in microgravity. These reconstructed genomes facilitate the study of the evolution of microorganisms under microgravity and low irradiation, in contrast to Earth.

Title: Comparative genomic analysis of Cohnella hashimotonis sp. nov. isolated from the International Space Station
Keywords: comparative genomic cohnella hashimotonis nov isolated
Resumen: A new bacterial strain, F6_2S_P_1T, was isolated in April 2018 from the wall behind the Waste Hygiene Compartment of the International Space Station (ISS) as part of the Microbial Tracking mission. This Gram-positive, rod-shaped bacterium has been identified, through genomic and phenotypic analyses, as a novel species of the genus *Cohnella*, and the name *Cohnella hashimotonis* has been proposed. This finding represents the first isolation of a *Cohnella* bacterium from an ISS surface and is crucial for the study of the microbiome in space habitats, which has vital implications for astronaut health and the development of future biotechnological applications. For its characterization, the complete genome sequencing of the strain and other related *Cohnella* species was carried out.

Title: Genomic analysis reveals the presence of emerging pathogenic Klebsiella lineages aboard the International Space Station
Keywords: genomic, reveals, presence, emerging, pathogenic, klebsiella
Resumen: study performed a comprehensive genotypic and phenotypic analysis of Klebsiella species (K. pneumoniae, K. aerogenes, K. quasipneumoniae) isolated from the International Space Station (ISS), examining their mobile genetic elements (MGEs). The findings revealed emerging pathogenic lineages; K. quasipneumoniae ST138 displayed spatial and temporal persistence, attributed to disinfectant and heavy metal resistance genes, and genetic divergence. In addition, a K. pneumoniae high-risk clone ST101 encoding a virulence factor (yersiniabactin) was isolated. The presence of MGEs with virulent loci suggests a potential risk of dissemination of hypervirulent strains among the crew and of horizontal genetic transfer that could enhance the virulence of other microorganisms. The genetic divergence observed in some Klebsiella genomes is postulated to be a result of the unique environmental pressures of space, underscoring the importance of monitoring microbial communities on the ISS to understand their survival mechanisms and implications for human health.

Title: Phylogenomics, phenotypic, and functional traits of five novel (Earth-derived) bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station and their prevalence in metagenomes
Keywords: phylogenomics, phenotypic, and functional traits, five
Resumen: This study, part of a series of microbial surveillance missions, has monitored the microbiome of the International Space Station (ISS) for nearly a decade. Six unique strains of Gram-positive bacteria were isolated from its environmental surfaces and, through a multifaceted characterization that included whole-genome sequencing, phylogenetic analysis, and phenotypic testing, identified as five new species. These species, named Arthrobacter burdickii, Leifsonia virtsii, Leifsonia williamsii, Paenibacillus vandeheii, and Sporosarcina highlanderae, although rare in ISS metagenomes, contain genes related to metabolism, virulence (resistance to antibiotics and toxic compounds), and secondary metabolite biosynthesis. The identification and characterization of these novel microbes is critical for expanding genomic databases of space-relevant species, allowing for the determination of microbial composition, tracking of dispersal, and anticipation of potential threats to human health and the integrity of spacecraft on future missions.

Title: Genomic, functional, and metabolic enhancements in multidrug-resistant Enterobacter bugandensis facilitating its persistence and succession in the International Space Station
Keywords: genomic, functional, and, metabolic, enhancements, multidrug resistant
Resumen: This article details a comprehensive study of *Enterobacter bugandensis*, a multidrug-resistant bacterium isolated from the International Space Station (ISS). The study compared the genomes of 13 *E. bugandensis* strains from the ISS with their terrestrial counterparts, specifically those associated with clinical infections, to understand their genomic adaptations to the unique space environment. The results revealed that the ISS strains exhibit significant genetic and functional differences, forming a distinct clade with increased numbers of genes and unique Clusters of Orthologous Genes (COGs) related to amino acid transport, mobilome elements, and transcription, suggesting an adaptation to the extreme conditions of space. The study also mapped the prevalence and distribution of bacteria on the ISS over time and analyzed their interactions with other microbial communities. These findings are vital for understanding microbial behavior and evolution in isolated and extreme environments, highlighting the need to implement robust preventive measures to protect astronauts' health from potential pathogenic threats.

Title: Phylogenomics, phenotypic, and functional traits of five novel (Earth-derived) bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station and their prevalence in metagenomes
Keywords: phylogenomics, phenotypic, and functional traits, five
Resumen: The text describes the discovery and characterization of six new bacterial strains, proposed as five new species, isolated from environmental surfaces of the International Space Station (ISS) over a decade of microbial monitoring. Although initial analysis of the 16S rRNA gene showed high similarity to known species, whole genome sequencing and detailed analyses (gyrB gene, average nucleotide identity, and digital DNA-DNA hybridization) confirmed their novelty. Phenotypic testing supported this classification. While rare in ISS metagenomes (0.1% of reads), their genomes revealed genes associated with diverse metabolic pathways and an average of 46 genes linked to virulence, disease, and defense, including antibiotic resistance. The proposed new species, which include *Arthrobacter burdickii*, *Leifsonia virtsii*, *Leifsonia williamsii*, *Paenibacillus vandeheii*, and *Sporosarcina highlanderae*, are crucial for expanding genomic databases of space-relevant microbes. This research is critical for understanding microbial adaptation to space conditions, monitoring contamination, predicting potential threats to astronaut health, and ensuring the safety of future space missions, especially in light of long-term planning for new habitats.

Title: Adaptation to space conditions of novel bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station revealed by functional gene annotations and comparative genome analysis
Keywords: adaptation, space, conditions, novel, bacterial, species
Resumen: This study analyzed five new species of Gram-positive bacteria isolated from the International Space Station (ISS), and functionally annotated their genomes to understand their adaptations to this extreme environment. Genomic and proteomic analyses revealed common features across species, indicating adaptations to life in space. These include hypoosmotic stress management, enhanced DNA repair activity against radiation, and mobile genetic elements that enhance metabolism. Furthermore, potential pathogenic capabilities are suggested, which could explain the increased antibiotic resistance and pathogenicity observed in space microbes. Unique genetic traits and new biosynthetic gene clusters were identified compared to their terrestrial relatives. These findings suggest a convergent adaptation of microorganisms to life in space, with implications for the bioproduction of essential biomolecules or as potential drug targets if they pose health risks.

Title: Spatial regulation of a common precursor from two distinct genes generates metabolite diversity
Keywords: spatial regulation common precursor from two
Resumen: This study demonstrates that in *Aspergillus terreus*, two NRPS-like genes, *atmelA* and *apvA*, produce the same metabolite, aspulvinone E, but its fate differs according to the tissue: in hyphae it is converted to aspulvinones, whereas in conidia it is transformed into melanin, a process controlled by spatial gene expression. Additionally, a single trans-prenyltransferase, AbpB, is capable of prenylating multiple substrates, such as aspulvinones and butyrolactones, expanding the diversity of metabolites. The findings reveal that the diversity of secondary metabolites can be expanded by targeting a single product to different pathways depending on the cellular compartment and by using enzymes that modify multiple compounds, offering new perspectives for the design of biosynthetic pathways.

Title: Recent advances in the genome mining of Aspergillus secondary metabolites (covering 2012â€šÃ„Ã¬2018).
Keywords: recent, advances, genome, mining, aspergillus, secondary
Resumen: This text summarizes the progress made in genomic mining of secondary metabolites (SMs) produced by *Aspergillus nidulans, Aspergillus fumigatus, Aspergillus niger* and *Aspergillus terreus* between 2012 and 2018.
