Fungal SMs are valuable drug candidates due to their diverse bioactivities, but many of their biosynthetic gene clusters remain "silent" under laboratory conditions. The research seeks to activate these "cryptic" pathways and link them to their products for the discovery of new drugs and the optimization of existing ones, detailing the genetic identification, molecular characterization of the clusters, and proposed biosynthetic pathways for various SMs, with a variable percentage of core synthase enzymes already linked to their products in each species.

Title: Cortical thinning and structural bone changes in non-human primates after single-fraction whole-chest irradiation.
Keywords: cortical thinning and structural bone changes
Resumen: study investigated the effects of whole-thoracic radiation in rhesus macaques, demonstrating rapid post-irradiation bone deterioration in the vertebrae. Sixteen macaques were irradiated with 10 Gy, and bone mineral density (BMD) and cortical thickness (Ct.Th) were measured in thoracic and lumbar vertebrae for 8 months. Younger animals (less than 50 months old) showed higher mortality and a significant decrease in Ct.Th and BMD in both irradiated and non-irradiated vertebrae at 2 months. Older animals (over 50 months old) lost ThCt in irradiated vertebrae at 2 months and BMD in irradiated vertebrae at 4 months, and only BMD in non-irradiated vertebrae at 6 months. Histologically, areas with greater cortical thinning also showed greater porosity. The study concludes that bone is sensitive to high doses of radiation, with rapid loss of structure and density that could facilitate fractures, with age being an influencing factor.

Title: Knee and Hip Joint Cartilage Damage from Combined Spaceflight Hazards of Low-Dose Radiation Less than 1 Gy and Prolonged Hindlimb Unloading.
Keywords: knee and hip joint cartilage damage
Resumen: This study investigated the individual and combined effects of reduced weight-bearing (simulated by hindlimb suspension) and low-dose radiation exposure (?1 Gy) on knee and hip cartilage in mice, replicating spaceflight conditions. The results showed that, both individually and in combination, reduced weight-bearing and spaceflight-relevant radiation doses lead to knee and hip cartilage degradation, manifesting an arthritic phenotype. Specifically, decreased cartilage volume and thickness, lower collagen content, increased serum COMP protein (a biomarker of cartilage degradation), and decreased cartilage compositional proteins indicative of osteoarthritis were observed in the irradiated groups. The study concludes that low-dose irradiation induces an active catabolic response in cartilage and underscores the need to investigate preventative measures to maintain joint health in astronauts.

Title: The individual and combined effects of spaceflight radiation and microgravity on biological systems and functional outcomes
Keywords: individual and combined spaceflight radiation microgravity
Resumen: This text describes the health and performance risks to astronauts during spaceflight, such as microgravity and radiation exposure. It highlights the need to study the combined effects of these hazards, as astronauts will face them simultaneously on missions beyond low-Earth orbit. The review focuses on the biological and functional outcomes of terrestrial animal models, such as hindlimb suspension (HLU) and partial weight bearing (PWB) in rodents, to simulate microgravity and radiation, analyzing their impacts on the skeletal, ocular, central nervous, cardiovascular, and stem cell systems. It also addresses the types of space radiation (galactic cosmic rays and solar particle events) and highlights the importance of these studies for developing countermeasures for future missions to the Moon and Mars.

Title: Spaceflight and hind limb unloading induces an arthritic phenotype in knee articular cartilage and menisci of rodents
Keywords: spaceflight and hind limb unloading induces
Resumen: This study investigated how reduced weight bearing, either through spaceflight or hindlimb unloading (HLU), affects knee cartilage and menisci in mice. The findings showed that both prolonged spaceflight and HLU induce cartilage degradation, manifested as thinning and volume loss at contact sites, and a decrease in meniscal volume. A reduction in glycosaminoglycan (GAG) content and an increase in catabolic enzymes (such as MMP-13 and ADAMTS5), along with oxidative stress, were observed in the menisci, even after a short spaceflight. During exercise rehabilitation, cartilage volume and thickness recovery was observed. In summary, weight-bearing reduction induces an arthritic phenotype in the cartilage and menisci, while exercise promotes recovery.

Title: Å'Â±Klotho decreases after reduced weight-bearing from both spaceflight and hindlimb unloading
Keywords: klotho, decreases, after, reduced, weight bearing, from
Resumen: This study investigated the protein Alpha(?)Klotho, a potential biomarker of bone and kidney health, under microgravity conditions. Both spaceflight to the International Space Station and hindlimb offloading were found to reduce plasma Klotho levels in mice. However, exercise, particularly climbing, was able to reverse this deficiency following hindlimb offloading, suggesting that Klotho is a crucial marker for musculoskeletal health in non-weight-bearing environments and that exercise is an effective countermeasure.

Title: Prolonged exposure to particulate chromate inhibits RAD51 nuclear import mediator proteins.
Keywords: Prolonged exposure, particulate, chromate, inhibits, rad51
Resumen: Particulate hexavalent chromium (Cr(VI)) is a known human lung carcinogen that induces chromosomal instability by inhibiting homologous recombination (HR) repair. Previous studies indicated that Cr(VI) misregulates the HR-essential protein RAD51, preventing its proper nuclear localization and causing its cytoplasmic accumulation. This study examined the effect of Cr(VI) on RAD51C and BRCA2, mediators of RAD51 nuclear import. Acute (24 h) exposure to Cr(VI) was found to induce proper localization of RAD51C and BRCA2. However, prolonged exposure (120 h) increased the cytoplasmic localization of both proteins, with RAD51C more severely affected, correlating with the previously reported cytoplasmic accumulation of RAD51. Furthermore, Cr(VI) does not inhibit the interaction between RAD51 and its nuclear import mediators. The findings suggest that prolonged exposure to Cr(VI) inhibits the nuclear import of RAD51C and, to a lesser extent, BRCA2, resulting in the cytoplasmic accumulation of RAD51. This inhibition of nuclear import could play a crucial role in the carcinogenic mechanism of Cr(VI).

Title: Transcriptomics, NF-Å'âˆ«B Pathway, and Their Potential Spaceflight-Related Health Consequences.
Keywords: transcriptomics, nf, pathway, and their potential
Resumen: The text addresses how spaceflight stressors, such as microgravity and radiation, affect human health, causing problems such as bone loss and immune dysfunction. It emphasizes that understanding these mechanisms at the molecular level is vital for assessing risks and developing countermeasures. A key finding is that the nuclear factor kappa-light-enhancer of activated B cells (NF-?B) pathway is commonly affected in various cells and tissues under real or simulated space conditions. This pathway is of particular interest due to its association with spaceflight-related health consequences, including immune dysfunction, bone and muscle loss, central nervous system dysfunction, and radiation risks. Activation or inhibition of NF-?B varies by cell type, but its health implications are consistently negative. The article summarizes transcriptomic studies that identify NF-?B as a response pathway and emphasizes the need for further research to benefit crew health in space.

Title: Interplay of space radiation and microgravity in DNA damage and DNA damage response.
Keywords: interplay space radiation and microgravity DNA
Resumen: The text addresses how space radiation and microgravity, environmental factors unique to space, pose a constant threat to DNA integrity in living organisms, potentially increasing the risk of adverse health effects such as cancer. Space radiation can damage DNA directly and indirectly, and microgravity can impact organisms' ability to repair DNA. While ground-based studies using simulated microgravity have yielded often conflicting results regarding its synergy with radiation in DNA damage and repair, real-space experiments, although limited, suggest an increase in DNA damage and mutations, correlated with flight duration. Therefore, it is concluded that further experiments in the true space environment are needed to address this critical issue.

Title: Synergistic Effects of Weightlessness, Isoproterenol, and Radiation on DNA Damage Response and Cytokine Production in Immune Cells
Keywords: Synergistic weightlessness isoproterenol and radiation DNA
Resumen: The study investigates the synergistic effects of simulated microgravity, radiation, and adrenergic activation on immune cells, specifically peripheral blood monocytes. Using rotating-wall vessels to simulate microgravity, the researchers observed that microgravity increased DNA strand breaks and, in combination with radiation, induced cytokine production. A key finding was that pretreatment with isoproterenol, a sympathomimetic drug, prevented most microgravity-mediated adverse effects. This research underscores the importance of the adrenergic system in regulating the immune response under stress and suggests that these findings could benefit astronauts and patients with immune disorders or undergoing radiation therapy.

Title: Transcriptome and proteome responses in RNAlater preserved tissue of Arabidopsis thaliana.
Keywords: transcriptome and proteome responses, rnalater, preserved
Resumen: This study evaluated the effectiveness of RNAlater as a preservative for omics analyses in *Arabidopsis thaliana* tissues, comparing it with rapid freezing in liquid nitrogen. Although RNAlater preserved RNA and protein integrity, a significant transcriptomic and proteomic response was observed. Differential expression of 5,770 gene transcripts was detected, with a response to osmotic stress, and alterations in the expression levels of 84 soluble and 120 membrane-bound proteins. Furthermore, the abundance of post-translational modifications, especially phosphorylation, was affected. The results suggest that RNAlater induces a cellular response before complete fixation, so caution is advised when using it in plant omics experiments.

Title: Spaceflight induces novel regulatory responses in Arabidopsis seedling as revealed by combined proteomic and transcriptomic analyses.
Keywords: spaceflight, induces, novel, regulatory, responses, arabidopsis
Resumen: study analyzed the effects of microgravity on *Arabidopsis thaliana* seedlings using simultaneous proteomic and transcriptomic analyses. Differential expression of 968 RNAs, 107 soluble proteins, and 103 membrane proteins, as well as 16 phosphorylation events, was identified. The findings revealed significant impacts on post-transcriptional mechanisms, cell wall adaptations, redox/microtubule dynamics, and dysregulation of plastid gene transcription. The low correlation between mRNA and protein changes highlights the need for combined omics approaches, offering new insights for optimizing plant growth in microgravity and on Earth.

Title: Mitigation and use of biofilms in space for the benefit of human space exploration
Keywords: mitigation and use biofilms space for
Resumen: The text highlights the crucial importance of microbiology for the success and sustainability of future long-duration human space missions to the Moon and Mars. It explains that while microbes can pose risks such as biofilm formation and increased pathogenicity that affect astronaut health and the integrity of spacecraft, they also offer vital solutions. These include their application in bioregenerative life support systems for plant cultivation, water treatment, and atmospheric revitalization, as well as in situ resource utilization (bISRU) to improve soil fertility, act as radiation shields, generate electricity, and create plant habitats. The ability of microbes to adapt and genetically modify themselves is critical to human self-sufficiency in deep space, making it imperative to understand and manage both their benefits and limitations.

Title: Toward sustainable space exploration: A roadmap for harnessing the power of microorganisms.
Keywords: toward, sustainable, space, exploration, roadmap, for
Resumen: Sustainable space exploration requires independence from terrestrial resources, considering the ethics of waste generation and the preservation of extraterrestrial environments. Microbial biotechnologies are crucial for in-situ resource utilization and closing loops in space, enabling recycling and reuse for a circular economy. These technologies can be applied on Earth to address environmental problems and support the UN Sustainable Development Goals. Solutions include CO2 removal, oxygen production, human waste management to generate food and fertilizer, and microbial-assisted food cultivation. Drug manufacturing in space using microorganisms is also essential for long-duration missions.

Title: Longitudinal characterization of multispecies microbial populations recovered from spaceflight drinking water
Keywords: longitudinal, characterization, multispecies, microbial, populations, recovered
Resumen: This study extensively characterizes the microbial phenotypes of drinking water on the International Space Station (ISS), analyzing isolates archived by NASA between 2009 and 2015. Antibiotic resistance, metabolism, hemolysis, and biofilm formation were assessed in single and multispecies communities. The results revealed that most isolates are multidrug-resistant to antibiotics and strong biofilm formers, with Burkholderiales (especially *Ralstonia pickettii*) as the predominant order. A temporal dependence in microbial interactions was observed, suggesting adaptation. Furthermore, some subpopulations of *Burkholderia* displayed hemolytic activity, posing a health risk to astronauts. The research underscores the importance of functional phenotypic assessments for understanding microbial risk in built environments, both in space and on Earth, given that sequencing technologies alone do not fully predict dynamic phenotypes.

Title: Designing a Novel Monitoring Approach for the Effects of Space Travel on Astronautsâ€šÃ„Ã´ Health
Keywords: designing, novel, monitoring, approach, for, space
Resumen: study analyzed the gene expression patterns of ten astronauts (eight men and two women) before, during, and after spaceflight, with the goal of developing a rapid method for monitoring their health. Space travel exposes astronauts to significant risks of disease due to radiation and microgravity. The study identified 218 genes with differential expression during flight compared to before flight, observing an overall decrease in genomic regulation and gene correlations. This loss of genetic coordination is suggested as a contributing factor to the risk of cancer and other conditions. As a result, a list of 32 key genes was proposed for a potential rapid astronaut health monitoring trial, although further studies are required for validation.

Title: Draft genome sequence of Sphingomonas paucimobilis strain Sph5, isolated from tap water filtration membrane
Keywords: draft, genome, sequence, sphingomonas, paucimobilis, strain
Resumen: This article reports the draft whole-genome sequence of *Sphingomonas Sph5* strain, isolated from a drinking water filtration membrane, in the context of studies on long-term genetic changes in drinking water biofilm species and biofouling. Using whole-genome sequencing (WGS) and de novo assembly, the strain was determined to be *Sphingomonas paucimobilis*. The research was led by Sara Koroli, Kristina Buss, and Jiseon Yang, and funded by NASA, with genomic data deposited at NCBI.

Title: Overexpression of CupB5 activates alginate overproduction in Pseudomonas aeruginosa by a novel AlgW-dependent mechanism
Keywords: overexpression, cupb5, activates, alginate, overproduction, pseudomonas
Resumen: Alginate overproduction, or mucoidy, in *Pseudomonas aeruginosa*, a key factor in chronic infections, is regulated by the MucA/AlgU pathway, where MucA degradation by the protease AlgW releases AlgU for alginate biosynthesis. This degradation normally requires signals from unassembled outer membrane proteins and lipopolysaccharides that release MucA from MucB, an inhibitor of AlgW. This study identifies CupB5, a chaperone-usher pathway protein, as a novel activator of alginate production. CupB5 overexpression induces mucoidy via the AlgU pathway. In vitro experiments demonstrate that a CupB5-specific peptide stimulates MucA cleavage by AlgW, even in the presence of the inhibitor MucB, suggesting a novel mechanism in which CupB5 mediates the proteolytic activity of AlgW and its ability to compete with MucB, thereby boosting alginate production.

Title: Burn injury-associated MHCII(+) immune cell accumulation around lymphatic vessels of the mesentery and increased lymphatic endothelial permeability are blocked by doxycycline treatment.
Keywords: burn, injury associated, mhcii, immune, cell, accumulation
Resumen: This study investigates how lymph from a hyperpermeable gut in burn victims contributes to systemic damage and immune response. Using a rat burn model, researchers observed that burn injury significantly increases MHCII-positive immune cells along lymphatic vessels and alters their size and shape. Serum from burned animals also increased lymphatic endothelial permeability and caused disruptions in cell-cell junctions. Treatment with doxycycline, a microvascular permeability inhibitor, prevented the accumulation of these immune cells and blocked serum-induced lymphatic hyperpermeability. These findings suggest that factors produced during burns can damage the lymphatic endothelial barrier, and lymph resulting from traumatic injuries influences the attraction and morphology of immune cell populations around vessels.

Title: CubeSats for microbiology and astrobiology research
Keywords: cubesats for microbiology and astrobiology research
Resumen: Space experiments are crucial for research in astrobiology and astrochemistry, complementing the work of the International Space Station and utilizing future platforms such as CubeSats and the Lunar Orbital Gateway. The European Space Agency has identified key topics such as the origin of life, habitability, and signs of life, highlighting that the complex space environment (radiation, vacuum, microgravity) cannot be fully simulated on Earth. These studies are essential for understanding the survival and adaptation of organisms and biomolecules, supporting space exploration, ensuring planetary protection, and searching for life and biosignatures beyond our planet.

Title: In situ resource utilization: The potential for space biomining
Keywords: situ, resource, utilization, potential, for, space
Resumen: Space biomining is a promising strategy for in situ resource utilization (ISRU), key to human expansion into space by reducing dependence on Earth. It uses microorganisms to extract metals, minerals, water, oxygen, and other volatiles from extraterrestrial rocks and regolith, and can also be applied in bioremediation, waste recycling, and life support systems. Although the science in this field is incipient, successful experiments have been conducted on the International Space Station. Its development requires extensive research, as the space conditions (gravity, radiation) and rock types available on celestial bodies such as the Moon, Mars, and asteroids differ significantly from those on Earth, preventing the direct application of current terrestrial techniques. It is essential to investigate new bioleaching mechanisms and use synthetic biology to overcome the environmental limitations of space.

Title: The smallest space miners: Principles of space biomining
Keywords: smallest, space, miners, principles, biomining
Resumen: Space biomining is presented as a key strategy for in situ resource utilization (ISRU) in human expansion into space, seeking independence from terrestrial resources. This technique proposes the use of microbial biotechnologies to extract structural metals, minerals, water, oxygen, and other volatiles from extraterrestrial regoliths and rocks, with additional applications in bioremediation and recycling for regenerative life support systems. Although experiments such as BioRock have already demonstrated its viability in space, the science is still in its infancy. Significant differences exist between terrestrial and extraterrestrial conditions, including rock types and gravity, which preclude the direct application of current biomining techniques. Therefore, it is essential to investigate space-specific methods, expanding knowledge of organotrophic, community-based, and anaerobic bioleaching mechanisms, and investigating the use of synthetic biology to overcome the limitations of the space environment.

Title: Simulated micro-, lunar, and Martian gravities on Earthâ€šÃ„Ã®effects on Escherichia coli growth, phenotype, and sensitivity to antibiotics.
Keywords: simulated micro lunar and martian gravities
Resumen: study investigated the behavior of three Escherichia coli strains, including uropathogenic strains, under simulated microgravity, lunar, and Martian conditions on Earth using tilted clinostats. The research evaluated growth dynamics, phenotypic changes, and antibiotic sensitivity. The results indicated increased growth for some strains in simulated microgravity and lunar gravity, and the need for higher antibiotic concentrations under simulated lunar gravity compared to microgravity and Martian conditions. Although the environments created by clinostats are suggestive and not identical to actual space conditions, this approach lays a foundation for understanding microbial processes relevant to human health and exploration on lunar and Martian surfaces.

Title: Biofilm formation of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in spaceflight is minimized on lubricant impregnated surfaces.
Keywords: biofilm formation, pseudomonas aeruginosa, spaceflight, minimized
Resumen: The Space Biofilms project investigated the formation of *Pseudomonas aeruginosa* bacterial biofilms in microgravity, given the risk they pose to spacecraft systems and astronaut health. Biofilm growth was compared on stainless steel (SS) surfaces and lubricant-impregnated surfaces (LIS). The results showed that biofilms in microgravity are less robust than on Earth. Furthermore, LIS significantly inhibit biofilm formation compared to SS, and this effect is even more pronounced in space, making them a promising strategy for biofilm control in the space environment.

Title: Competitive Growth Assay of Mutagenized Chlamydomonas reinhardtii Compatible With the International Space Station Veggie Plant Growth Chamber.
Keywords: competitive, growth, assay, mutagenized, chlamydomonas, reinhardtii
Resumen: This article investigates the use of microalgae, specifically *Chlamydomonas reinhardtii*, in biological life support systems for spaceflight, with the goal of recycling carbon dioxide and generating useful organic compounds. To this end, a method was developed to cultivate these algae in breathable plastic tissue culture bags within the Veggie growth chamber of the International Space Station (ISS), overcoming the challenge of liquid handling in microgravity. Using ultraviolet C (UVC) mutagenesis, competitive growth assays, and genome sequencing, genes with mutations indicative of positive selection were identified, enriched in information processing functions related to DNA repair, RNA processing, translation, cytoskeletal motors, kinases, and ABC transporters. These data suggest that modifying DNA repair, signal transduction, and metabolite transport may be necessary to improve growth rates in this spatial production system.

Title: Spatial Characterization of Microbial Communities on Multi-Species Leafy Greens Grown Simultaneously in the Vegetable Production Systems on the International Space Station
Keywords: spatial, characterization, microbial, communities, multi species, leafy
Resumen: This study focuses on establishing continuous crop production for deep space missions, vital for crew nutritional and psychological benefits. Three technology demonstrations (VEG-03D, E, and F) were completed on the International Space Station (ISS) using two Veggie Units, achieving simultaneous growth of multiple leafy green plant species, such as lettuce and mizuna, and concurrent use of the units. Microbiological characterization of leaves, roots, growth pad components, and Veggie Chamber surfaces confirmed that the plants were safe for consumption and revealed low counts of bacteria and fungi on the surfaces, commonly isolated on the ISS. Microbial community analysis showed greater diversity in the roots and substrate than in the leaves and wick. This work provides crucial information for research into food production on the ISS and the impact of the plant microbiome in this unique, closed environment, highlighting the importance of controlling conditions to avoid microbial risks, as observed in previous incidents with opportunistic fungi. The experiments demonstrated a mixed-crop approach with continuous harvests to maximize crew production.

Title: Response of Arabidopsis thaliana and Mizuna mustard seeds to simulated space radiation exposures.
Keywords: response arabidopsis thaliana and mizuna mustard
Resumen: This study investigates the impact of space radiation from solar particle events (SPE) and galactic cosmic rays (GCR) on plant seeds, a critical factor for long-duration crewed missions to the Moon and Mars. Fresh food production in space could provide nutritional and psychological benefits, but the effects of radiation on plants have not been sufficiently investigated. The study evaluated dried and hydrated seeds of the model plant *Arabidopsis thaliana* and the mustard crop plant Mizuna, exposing them to GCR and SPE simulations with various particles and doses at NASA's Space Radiation Laboratory. The results showed that hydrated Arabidopsis seeds exhibited dose- and quality-dependent responses to radiation, with heavier ions causing more severe damage. The observed damage varied by seed type, highlighting the need for specific research for space crops and the importance of understanding the viability of fresh food production in deep radiation environments.

Title: Editorial: Revisiting the limits of plant life - plant adaptations to extreme terrestrial environments relating to astrobiology and space biology.
Keywords: editorial, revisiting, limits, plant, life, adaptations
Resumen: The text summarizes research exploring the adaptations of terrestrial plants to extreme environments for application in space exploration and the search for extraterrestrial life. The studies presented cover the potential of plants to mitigate cosmic radiation in manned missions, the improvement of crop yields in simulated space conditions through co-cultivation with desert endophytic fungi, and the factors influencing seed germination in extraterrestrial regolith, highlighting the importance of porosity and low compaction. Furthermore, it is demonstrated that cyanobacteria can perform oxygenic photosynthesis under the light spectrum of M dwarf stars, which is crucial for the search for oxygen biosignatures on exoplanets. Together, these investigations seek to advance the selection and genetic improvement of plants for critical functions in space missions and guide the detection of life beyond Earth.

Title: Metagenomic interrogation of urban Superfund site reveals antimicrobial resistance reservoir and bioremediation potential.
Keywords: metagenomic, interrogation, urban, superfund, site, reveals
Resumen: metagenomic study of the microbiome of the Gowanus Canal, a highly contaminated Superfund site in Brooklyn, reveals its potential for bioremediation. Sediment analyses identified 455 microbial species, including extremophiles, that collectively encode 64 metabolic pathways for organic pollutant degradation and 1,171 genes related to heavy metal utilization and detoxification. The study also uncovered an environmental reservoir of eight classes of antimicrobial resistance markers and 2,319 novel biosynthetic gene clusters with biomining potential. This suggests that the Gowanus Canal microbiome is a valuable biotechnological resource for bioremediation, antimicrobial resistance mapping, and heavy metal mitigation.

Title: In situ monitoring of barrier function on-chip via automated, non-invasive luminescence sensing.
Keywords: situ, monitoring, barrier, function, on chip, via
Resumen: This text presents a novel fiber-optic sensing platform that enables automated, temporal, and noninvasive luminescence monitoring in organs-on-a-chip (OOCs). This technology addresses the limitations of current OOC characterization methods, which often require human intervention and offer only point-in-time data or are costly. The platform was validated for real-time readout of epithelial and endothelial barrier function under cytokine-induced inflammation, showing the capability for continuous spatiotemporal monitoring of paracellular transport in an intestinal chip over several days. This approach offers an alternative for on-chip microenvironment characterization, improving the reliability and robustness of OOC systems by providing continuous, noninvasive monitoring.

Title: 37-day microgravity exposure in 16-week female C57BL/6J mice is associated with bone loss specific to weight-bearing skeletal sites.
Keywords: 37 day, microgravity, exposure, 16 week, female, c57bl
Resumen: This study investigated bone loss in mice exposed to the microgravity of the International Space Station, hypothesizing that it is primarily associated with mechanical unloading of weight-bearing skeletal sites. Analyses showed significant bone loss in the femur, a weight-bearing bone, but not in the L2 vertebrae, suggesting that microgravity is the primary cause and not space radiation or other systemic stresses. Furthermore, accelerated progression of endochondral ossification was observed in the femoral head. The results conclude that mechanical unloading at load-bearing sites is the primary cause of bone loss in microgravity in female mice, whereas sites predominantly loaded by muscle activity remain unaltered, and premature ossification of the femoral head is a novel effect.

Title: Effects of Space Flight on Inflammasome Activation in the Brain of Mice.
Keywords: space, flight, inflammasome, activation, brain, mice
Resumen: This study investigated the impact of spaceflight on inflammasome activation in the brains of mice, given the vulnerability of astronauts to infections due to immune compromise. C57BL/6 mice were housed on the International Space Station (ISS) for 37 days. Postflight analyses of their brains indicated a significant decrease in inflammasome activation (measured by proteins such as caspase-1, ASC, and IL-1Î²) compared to ground-based and basal control groups (sacrificed at the start of the mission). However, no significant changes were detected in the levels of various proinflammatory cytokines. These findings suggest that spaceflight reduces innate immune signaling molecules that regulate the inflammasome in the brains of mice.

Title: Immunization induces inflammation in the mouse heart during spaceflight.
Keywords: immunization induces inflammation of mouse heart during
Resumen: This study investigated the cardiovascular response to immunization in mice housed on the International Space Station (ISS). The mice were vaccinated with tetanus toxoid and an adjuvant, and transcriptomics was used to analyze the effects on the heart. The results showed that immunization in space stimulates increased cardiac inflammation, activating the NF-? signaling pathway and promoting the release of proinflammatory cytokines such as IFN?, IL-17, and IL-6. These findings suggest that immunization in space can induce inflammation in the heart, similar to terrestrial myocarditis, and highlight the need for future research into cardiac events during spaceflight.

Title: Analyzing the relationship between gene expression and phenotype in space-flown mice using a causal inference machine learning ensemble.
Keywords: analyzing relationship between gene expression and
Resumen: study investigates the detrimental effects of spaceflight on the liver health of rodents, focusing on liver dysfunction and lipid dysregulation. To identify genes and molecular targets more accurately than traditional methods, which often detect spurious correlations, the researchers employed CRISP (Causal Research and Inference Search Platform), a suite of machine learning methods based on causal inference. Using transcriptomic and histological data from the livers of space and control mice from the NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR), CRISP identified a unique set of high-density lipid-predictive genes implicated in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) that were missed by previous analyses. This work represents the first machine learning analysis predictive of a liver disease-related response in spaceflight, paving the way for the development of countermeasures for future long-duration space missions.

Title: Sex-specific cardiovascular adaptations to simulated microgravity in Sprague-Dawley rats
Keywords: sex specific, cardiovascular, adaptations, simulated, microgravity, sprague dawley
Resumen: This study investigated sex-specific cardiovascular responses to simulated microgravity (hindlimb unloading, HLU) in rats. Female rats exposed to HLU were found to develop increased aortic stiffness, lower levels of G protein-coupled estrogen receptor (GPER) and PPAR?, increased oxidative stress, and diastolic dysfunction. Males, however, showed no changes in aortic stiffness or other parameters following HLU. Administration of a GPER agonist prevented arterial stiffness and oxidative stress in female rats exposed to HLU, highlighting sex-differentiated vascular adaptations to simulated microgravity and the potential role of GPER in female arterial stiffness.

Title: NASA open science data repository: Open science for life in space.
Keywords: nasa, open, science, data, repository, for
Resumen: The NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR), resulting from the 2021 integration of the Ames Life Sciences Data Archive and GeneLab, is a crucial platform for managing space biology and health data. Its goal is to make these data findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable (FAIR), promoting open science principles to support deep space missions. OSDR hosts a wide range of omics and non-omics data, including life sciences, biomedical-clinical, and mission telemetry, and features a new database architecture, a biological data management environment (BDME) for standardized upload, an improved API, and comprehensive visualization tools. It fosters global collaboration, transparency, and inclusiveness in research, with more than 500 studies and nearly 1,000 datasets, demonstrating a high return on investment in scientific publications. The data submission process is streamlined, enabling collaboration and controlled access to democratize spatial data.

Title: Artificial gravity attenuates the transcriptomic response to spaceflight in the optic nerve and retina
Keywords: artificial gravity attenuates transcriptomic response spaceflight
Resumen: Microgravity during spaceflight negatively affects astronaut ocular health by inducing transcriptomic changes in the optic nerve and retina associated with oxidative stress, inflammation, apoptosis, and lipid metabolic stress, which contribute to spaceflight-associated neuroocular syndrome (SANS). A study in mice on the International Space Station demonstrated that artificial gravity, generated by centrifugation at 0.33 G, 0.67 G, and 1 G, attenuates these damaging transcriptomic responses in a dose-dependent manner. Specifically, an artificial gravity of 1 G was the most effective in reverting genetic changes to control levels and mitigating oxidative stress in the retina. These findings suggest that artificial gravity is a promising countermeasure to protect eye tissue from the damaging effects of space.

Title: Effect of simulated cosmic radiation on cytomegalovirus reactivation and lytic replication.
Keywords: simulated, cosmic, radiation, cytomegalovirus, reactivation, and
Resumen: A study addressed reactivation of latent cytomegalovirus (CMV) due to galactic cosmic radiation (GCR), a risk to human space exploration. When CMV-infected Kasumi cells were irradiated with various radiations (including simulated GCR), a significant increase in viral copy number was observed, indicating reactivation. Although no notable genomic differences were found, transcriptomic analysis revealed upregulation of the UL49 ORF, implicating it in the switch from latency to lytic replication. These results support the hypothesis that GCR is an important factor in the CMV reactivation observed in space crew members.

Title: Protein kinase 2 of the giant sarcomeric protein UNC-89 regulates mitochondrial morphology and function.
Keywords: protein kinase giant sarcomeric unc 89 regulates
Resumen: This scientific article investigates the giant protein UNC-89 in *C. elegans*, essential for sarcomere organization and muscle function, which contains two protein kinase domains, PK1 and PK2. The study confirms that PK2 is a catalytically active kinase. By inactivating PK2 through a mutation, the researchers found that while the mutant worms maintained normal sarcomeres and muscle function, they exhibited fragmented mitochondria, elevated ATP levels, increased glycolysis, and altered mitochondrial respiration suggesting uncoupling. These results suggest a signaling pathway from sarcomeres to mitochondria to match energy needs to production, with UNC-89 PK2 playing a key role in this communication.

Title: To boldly go where no microRNAs have gone before: Spaceflight impact on risk for small-for-gestational-age infants.
Keywords: boldly, where, micrornas, have, gone, before
Resumen: This text is from an official U.S. government website (.gov with HTTPS) and describes details from a 2024 article on systems biology and reproductive disorders. The article is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives 4.0 International License, permitting noncommercial use and distribution with attribution, but without adaptations. A correction is reported to the original Communications Biology article, where a funding acknowledgment was omitted. The information is provided by Nature Publishing Group and the National Library of Medicine.

Title: Adaptation to space conditions of novel bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station revealed by functional gene annotations and comparative genome analysis.
Keywords: adaptation, space, conditions, novel, bacterial, species
Resumen: This study analyzed five new species of Gram-positive bacteria isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) using a deep learning tool for functional annotation. Genomic and proteomic adaptations to the extreme conditions of space were identified, such as handling of hypo-osmotic stress, enhanced DNA repair activity, and the presence of mobile genetic elements. The findings also suggest the evolution of genetic traits that indicate potential pathogenic capabilities and increased antibiotic resistance compared to their terrestrial relatives. The collective annotations and the presence of novel biosynthetic gene clusters suggest a convergent adaptation of these microorganisms to life in space, which could have implications for the bioproduction of biomolecules or serve as potential drug targets.

Title: Celebrating 30 years of access to NASA space life sciences data.
Keywords: celebrating, years, access, nasa, space, life
Resumen: NASA celebrates decades of space life science research, generating invaluable data for understanding life in space and mitigating the risks of space travel. This year, the Ames Life Sciences Data Archive (ALSDA) and GeneLab, an omics repository, are commemorated for 30 years. In 2021, the two merged to create the NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR), unifying these resources under a platform that promotes open access and the FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable) principles. OSDR, with more than 500 studies and the active participation of working groups, facilitates scientific collaboration, the reanalysis of historical data, and the development of new tools, including artificial intelligence applications, to advance space biology and human health in future missions.

Title: Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station.
Keywords: predicting, how, varying, moisture, conditions, impact
Resumen: Increased human activity in space requires predictive models for microbial growth in enclosed environments such as the International Space Station (ISS), where high humidity can lead to unwanted growth, affecting astronaut health and the integrity of spacecraft. This study demonstrated that even short exposures to high relative humidity can facilitate rapid growth and changes in the composition of microbial communities in spacecraft dust. Fungal growth in ISS dust was modeled using a "wetting time" framework, and a significant increase in fungal concentration and a reduction in their diversity was observed with increasing humidity and exposure time. Although the model was not applicable to bacteria, their communities also showed changes with increasing humidity. These results are crucial for developing strategies to protect astronaut health, strengthen spacecraft integrity, and promote planetary protection during future missions.

Title: Spaceflight alters host-gut microbiota interactions.
Keywords: spaceflight, alters, host gut, microbiota, interactions
Resumen: Spaceflight induces symptoms such as liver disease, insulin resistance, osteopenia, and myopathy in mammals. This study explored the gut microbiota and host gene expression in mice after 29 and 56 days in space using multi-omics. Changes were observed in 44 microbial species, with a reduction in bile acid and butyrate-metabolizing bacteria. Functional predictions and host gene expression showed alterations in fatty acid, bile acid, and energy metabolism, as well as immunosuppression. These findings suggest that host-microbiome interactions contribute to spaceflight pathology, an area where metabolic and immunological dysfunctions have previously been documented. In-flight mice also experienced weight gain and significant differences in their gut microbiome composition (beta diversity) compared to controls, although overall microbial diversity remained unchanged.

Title: Discoveries from human stem cell research in space that are relevant to advancing cellular therapies on Earth.
Keywords: discoveries from human stem cell research
Resumen: Stem cell research in space, particularly on the International Space Station, has revealed fundamental insights into how microgravity affects stem cell properties and behavior, including proliferation and differentiation. These studies suggest that the space environment may be advantageous for culturing stem cells in a more natural 3D format, which could lead to increased production of high-quality cells. The ultimate goal is to translate these discoveries to Earth-based clinical applications, improving cell therapies and regenerative medicine for the benefit of patients.

Title: Simulated microgravity impairs human NK [natural killer] cell cytotoxic activity against space radiation-relevant leukemic cells.
Keywords: simulated, microgravity, impairs, human, natural, killer
Resumen: This study investigates how simulated microgravity (sigma-Aldrich) affects the function of Natural Killer (NK) cells, critical for antitumor defense, during prolonged space missions. The results demonstrate that a 48-hour exposure to sigma-Aldrich significantly reduces the cytotoxicity of human NK cells, both cell lines and primary cells, against K-562 and MOLT-4 leukemia lines. This deleterious effect was even more pronounced when sigma-Aldrich conditions were maintained continuously throughout the cytotoxicity assessment, suggesting that previous studies may have underestimated the true impact. The marked reduction in MOLT-4 cell killing is particularly concerning given the potential link between space radiation and the induction of T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia. RNA-seq analyses of NK cells exposed to sÎ¼G revealed altered pathways, which could guide the development of countermeasures to mitigate the risk. The study concludes that microgravity could increase the risk of leukemogenesis in astronauts during extended missions beyond low-Earth orbit, warranting further research.

Title: Simulated microgravity alters gene regulation linked to immunity and cardiovascular disease.
Keywords: simulated, microgravity, alters, gene, regulation, linked
Resumen: This study investigated cardiac responses to prolonged exposure to simulated microgravity using the hindlimb unloading (HU) model in male and female Long-Evans rats of different ages. It was hypothesized that microgravity and subsequent recovery would increase oxidative damage and alter gene expression. The results showed sex-dependent changes in oxidative damage (8-OHdG marker) and antioxidant gene expression in the left ventricle. Young females (3 months old) exhibited elevated 8-OHdG levels after 14 days of HU, unlike age-matched males. In 9-month-old males, the analysis of RNAseq after 14 days of HU revealed upregulation of proinflammatory signaling pathways, immune cell activation, and differential expression of genes associated with cardiovascular disease progression. These findings highlight the need to consider sex differences and target antioxidant and immune pathways in the development of countermeasures to maintain cardiovascular health in space.

Title: Spaceflight increases sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ leak and this cannot be counteracted with BuOE treatment
Keywords: spaceflight, increases, sarcoplasmic, reticulum, ca2, leak
Resumen: This study investigated the effect of the antioxidant BuOE on muscle atrophy and SERCA pump dysfunction in the soleus muscle of mice exposed to 35 days of microgravity, an environment known to cause muscle weakness and atrophy due to Ca2+ dysregulation and oxidative stress. The results showed that spaceflight induced significant muscle atrophy in the soleus, increased Ca2+ leakage from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, and elevated levels of a marker of reactive oxygen/nitrogen species, with BuOE treatment unable to counteract any of these effects. It is concluded that BuOE does not attenuate microgravity-induced muscle atrophy or sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ leakage, suggesting the need to explore alternative treatments.
